div.l: Whan þᵗat Apryll wyth his shoures sote
Þᵉ drouȝt of Marche had percid þᵉ rote
And bathed eueri veyn in suche lycour
Of whyche vertue engendryd is the flour
Whanne zepherus also wyth his sote breth
Enspyred hath in euery holte and heth
The tendre croppys and the yonge sonne
Hath in the ram half his cours y ronne
And smale foules make melodye
That slepe all nyght wyth open eye
So prycketh them nature in ther corages
Then longeth folke to go on pylgrymages
And palmers to seke straunge strondis
To serue halowys couthe in sondry londes
And specyally fro euery shyres ende
Of englonde to caunterbury they wende
The holy blysfull martyr for to seke
That them hath holpe whan they were seke
Befyll that seson on a daye
In suthwerk atte taberde as I laye
Redy to goo on my pylgrymage
To caunterbury wyth deuowte corage
That nyght was come in to that hostelrye
Well nyne and twenty in a companye
Of sondry folke by auenture y falle
In felyshyp ⁊and pylgrymes were they alle
That towarde caunterbury wolde ryde
The chambres ⁊and the stables were wyde
And well were we esyd atte best
And shortly whan the sonne was at rest
So had I spoke wyth them euerychon
That I was of ther felyshyd anon
And made promyse erly for to ryse
To take our waye there as I you deuyse
But netheles whyle I haue tyme ⁊and space
Or that I ferder in this tale pace
Me thynketh it accordaunt to reson
To tell you all the condycyon
Of eche of them so as it semyd me
And whyche they were ⁊and of what degre
And in what araye also they were in
And at a knyght thenne I woll begyn
A Knyghte there was a worthy man
That fro the tyme þᵗat he fyrst began
To ryde out he louyd chyualrye
Trouthe ⁊and honour fredom ⁊and curtesye
Full worthy he was in his lordys werre
And therto had he ryden no man ferre
And as wel in cristendom as in hethenesse
And euer had honour for his worthynesse
At alisaundre he was whan it was wonne
Full oft tyme he had the bourde begonne
Abouen all nacyons in pruce
In lettow had he reysed ⁊and in ruse
No crysten man so often tymes as he
In garnade at the syge also had he be
At algezer and ryden in belmarye
At leyeys was he ⁊and also at satalye
Whan they were wonne ⁊and in the grete see
At many a noble arme had he be
At mortall bataylles had he be fyftene
And fought for our fayth at tramyssene
In lystis thryes and ay slayn his foo
This ylke worthy knyght had be also
Somtyme wyth the lorde of palathye
Agayn a nother hethen man in turkye
And euermore he had a souereyne prys
And though he was worthy he was wys
And of his port as meke as a mayde
Neuer yet noo vylanye he sayde
In all his lyf vnto no maner wyght
He was a very gentyll perfyght knyght
For to tell you of his aray
His hors were good but he was not gay
Of fustyan he ware a gyppion
All besmered wyth his hawbergeon
For he was late come fro his vyage
And sent for to do his pylgrymage
WYth hy ther was his sone a yonge squyre
A louer and a lusty bachelere
Wᵗith his lockys crulle as they wer layd in presse
Of twenty yere of aege he was I gesse
Of his stature he was of euen lengthe
And wonderly delyuer ⁊and of gret strengthe
And he had be somtyme in chyuauchye
In flaundres in artoys ⁊and in pycardye
And born hym well as of a lytyll space
In hope to stonde in his ladyes grace
Enbrowded was he as it were a mede
All full of fresshe floures whyte ⁊and rede
Syngyng he was or floytyng all the day
He was as fresshe as is the month of may
Short was his gowne wᵗith sleues long ⁊and wyde
Well cowde he sytte on hors ⁊and therto fayr ryde
He cowde songes make ⁊and well endyte
Ioust ⁊and daunce portraye ⁊and also wryte
So hote he loued that by nyghter tale
He slepte nomore than a nyghtyngale
Curteys he was lowly and seruysable
He keruid before his fader at the table
A Yeman had he ⁊and seruauntes nomo
At that tyme for he lyst to ryde so
And he was clad in cote ⁊and hode of grene
A sheef of pecok arowes bryght and shene
Vnder his gyrdyll he bare full thryftily
Well cowde he dresse his takyll yomanly
His arowes drowpid not wᵗith fethers lowe
And in his honde he bare a myghty bowe
A not hed he had wyth a browne vysage
Vpon his arme he bare a gay bracer
And by his syde a swerde ⁊and a bokeler
And on that other syde a gay daggare
Harneysid well ⁊and sharpe as poynt of spere
A cristofir on his brest of syluer shene
An horne he bare the bawdryk was of grene
A foster was he sothly as I gesse
THere was also a nonne a pryoresse
That of her smylyng was symple ⁊and koy
Her grettest othe was bi saynt loy
And she was callyd dame eglentyn
Ful well she songe tho seruyse dyuyne
Entoyned in her voys ful semely
And frensh she spake full fetously
After the scole of stratforde at the bowe
For frensh of parys was to her vnknowe
At mete well taught was she wyth all
She lete no morsell fro her lyppes fall
Ne wete her fyngres in her sauce depe
Well cowde she cary a morsell of mete
That no drope fyll vpon her brest
In curtesy was set full moche her lest
Her ouerlyppe whyped she so clene
That in her cuppe there was no ferthyng sene
Of grece whan she had dronke her draught
Full semely after her mete she raught
And sykerly she was of grete dysport
Of pleysaunce ⁊and amyable of port
And peyned her to counterfete chere
Of courte and to be stately of manere
And to be holde dygne of reuerence
But for to speke of her conscyence
She was so charytable and so pyetous
She wolde wepe yf that she sawe a mous
Caught in trappe yfit were ded or bledde
Of smale houndes had she that she fedde
Wyth rost flessh or mylke or wastell bred
But sore wept she yf ony of them were ded
Of yf men smote them wyth rodde smert
And all was conscyence ⁊and tender hert
Full semely her wympyll pynched was
Her nose tretyse her eyen grey as gras
Her mouth smale and therto soft ⁊and reed
But sykerly she had a fayr forheed
It was almost a span brode I trowe
For hardly she was not vnder growe
Flul fetyse was her cloke as I was waar
Of smal corall abowte her arme she baar
A peyre of bedys / gauded all wyth grene
And theron henge a broche full shene
On whyche fyrst was wryte a crowned . a .
And after that . amor vincit omnia .
A nother nonne wyth her hath she
That was her chapeleyn ⁊and preestis thre
A Monke ther was fayr for the maystry
An out ryder þᵗat loued well venory
A manly man to be an abbot able
Full many a deynte hors had he in stable
And whan he rode men myght his bridyl here
Gyngelyng ⁊and whystelyng in the wynde clere
And also as lowde as doth the chapell belle
There as this lorde was keper of the celle
The rule of saynt Maure ⁊and of saynt Benet
By cause he helde it som what olde ⁊and streyt
This sayd monke lete olde thynges pace
And helde after the newe worlde the space
He yaf not of the text a pulled henne
That sayth that hunters be not holy men
Ne that a monke whan he is rechelees
Is lyke to a fysshe whan it is waterlees
This is to say a monke out of a cloystre
But þᵗat text helde he not worth an oystre
And I saye þᵗat his opynyon was good
What sholde he study ⁊and make hym wood
Vpon a boke alway in cloystre to powre
Or besy wyth his hondes and labowre
As austin biddeth hou shold þᵉ world be serued
Let austin haue his trauell to hym reserued
Therfore he was a prycasour a ryght
Grehoıı̄undes he had as swyft as foule in flyght
Of pryckyng ⁊and of huntyng for the hare
Was all his lust for no coste wolde he spare
I sawe his sleuys purfelyd at the honde
Wyth grice ⁊and that the fynest of a londe
And to faste his hode vnder the chynne
He had of golde wrought a curious pynne
A loue knot in the gretter ende there was
His hed was ballyd whyche shone as glas
And also his face as he had be anoynte
He was a lorde fatte and in good poynt
His eyen stepe ⁊and rollyng in his heed
That stemyd as a furneys of a leed
His botes sowple his hors in grete astate
Now certenly he was a fayr prelate
He was not pale as a fourpyned ghost
A fatte swan loued he best of ony rost
His palfrey was as browne as a bery
A Frere ther was a wanton and a mery
A lymytour ⁊and a full solempne man
In all the ordres four is non that can
So moche of dalyaunce ⁊and fayr langage
He had made full many a fayr maryage
Of yong wymen at his owne cost
Vntyll his ordre he was a noble post
Full welbeloued ⁊and full famylyer was he
Wyth frankeleyns ouer all in his countre
And also wyth worthy yemen of the toun
For he had power of confessyon
As sayd hymself more than a curat
And of his ordre he was licenciat
Ful swetly herde he confessyon
And plesaunt was his absolucyon
And an esy man to geue penaunce
Ther he wyste to haue good pytaunce
For vnto a poore ordre for to geue
Is sygne that a man is well y shryue
For yf he yaue . he durst make auaunt
He wyste that a man was repentaunt
Many a man so harde is of herte
He may not wepe though he sore smerte
Therfore in stede of wepyng ⁊and prayres
Men must yeue syluer to the poore freres
His typet was yfarsed full of knyues
And wyth pynnes to geue fayre wyues
And certeyn he hadde a mery note
Merily cowde he synge ⁊and pleye at the rote
Of yeddynges he bare vtterly the prys
His necke was whyte as the flour delys
Therto stronge he was as a champyoun
And knewe the tauernes well in euery toun
And euery hosteler and tapstere
Better than a lazer or a beggestere
For vnto suche a worthy man as he
Acordyth not as by his faculte
To haue of suche lazers acqueyntaunce
It is not honest it may not auaunce
For to dele wyth suche poraylle
But wyth ryche ⁊and sellers of vytalle
And ouer all there as rychesse sholde aryse
Curteys he was ⁊and lowely of seruyse
Ther was no man nowher so vertuous
He was the best beggere in his hous
And yaf a certeyn ferme for the graunt
None of his brethern cam in his haunt
For though a wydowe had not a shoo
So plesaunt was his Inprincipio
Yet wolde he haue a ferthyng or he went
His purchace was better than his rent
And barke he cowde as it were a whelpe
In louedayes there cowde he moche helpe
For ther he nas lyke a cloysterer
Wyth a thredebare cope as a poore frere
But he was lyke a mayster or a pope
Of dowble worstede was his semy cope
That rounde was as a belle out of presse
Som what he lysped for his wantonnesse
To make his englysshe swete vpon his tonge
And in harpyng whan he had y songe
His eyen twynklyd in his heed aryght
As doon the sterris in the frosty nyght
This worthy frere was called hubberd
A Marchaunt ther was wᵗith a forkid berd
In motley on hygh on his hors he sat
Vpon his heed a flaundres beuer hat
His botys claspyd fayr ⁊and fetously
His resons he spake full solempnely
Shewyng alway the encresse of his wynnyng
He wolde the see were kept for ony thyng
Betwyxe myddelborough ⁊and orewelle
Well cowde he in his eschaunges selle
This worthy man his wytte full well besette
There wyst no wyght that he was in dette
So estatly he was of gouernaunce
With his bargeyns ⁊and wyth his cheuesaunce
Forsothe he was a worthy man wyth all
But soth to say I not how men hym call
A clerk ther was of oxenforde also
That vnto logyk had longe y go
As lene was his hors as a rake
And he was not ryght fat I vndertake
But lokyd holow ⁊and therto soberly
Full thredebare was his ouerest courtby
For he had gote hym yet no benefyce
Ne was not worldly to haue an offyce
For hy was leuer to haue at his beddes heed
Twenty bokes y clad in whyt ⁊and reed
Of aristotle and of his phylosophye
Than robes ryche or fydyll or sawtrye
But all be that he was a phylosophre
Yet had he but lytyll golde in cofre
But all þᵗat he myght of his frendes hent
On bokys ⁊and on lernynge he it spent
And besyly gan for the sowles praye
Of them that yaf hym wherwyth to scolaye
Of study toke he moost cure ⁊and hede
Nat a worde spake he more than nede
And that was sayd in fourme ⁊and reuerence
Short ⁊and quyck ⁊and full of hygh sentence
Sownyng morall vertu was his speche
And gladly wolde he lerne ⁊and gladly teche
A sergaunt of lawe ware ⁊and wyse
Was there that ofte had be at the peruyse
That was also full ryche of excellence
Dyscrete he was of grete reuerence
He semyd suche his wordes were so wyse
Iustyse he was full ofte in assyse
By patent ⁊and by playn commyssyon
For his scyence ⁊and his hygh renoun
Of fees ⁊and robes had he many on
So gret a purchasour was there nowher non
All was fee symple to hym in effecte
His purchace myght not be to hym suspecte
Nowhere so besy a man as he ther nas
And yet he semyd besyer than he was
In termes had he caas ⁊and domes alle
That fro þᵉ tyme of kyng wylliam were falle
Therto he cowde endyte ⁊and make a thyng
Ther coude no wyght pynche at his writyng
And euery statute cowde he playn by rote
He rode but homely in a medlyd cote
Y gyrt wyth a seynt of sylk wᵗith barrys smale
Of his aray telle I no lenger tale
A Frankeleyn was in his companye
Whyte was his berde as is the deysie
And of his complexyon was sanguyn
Well loued he by the morowe a cup wyn
To lyue in delyte was euer his wone
For he was epycuries owne sone
That helde opynyon that playn delyte
Was very felycyte perfyte
An housholder ⁊and that a grete was he
Saynt Iulian he was in his contre
His brede his ale was al way after one
A better vyned man was no where none
Wythout bake mete was he neuer in his hous
His fyssh his flessh and that so plenteuous
It snewed in his hous of mete and drynke
Of all deyntes that men cowde thynke
After the sondry seson of the yere
So changed he his mete ⁊and his suppere
Full many a fat partrych had he in mewe
And many a breme ⁊and luce in stewe
Wo was his coke but his sawce were
Poynant ⁊and sharpe ⁊and redy all his gere
His table dormaunt in his halle al way
Was redy couered all the longe day
At sessyons ther was he lorde ⁊and syre
Full ofte tyme he was knyght of the shyre
An anlace ⁊and a gypser all of sylk
Hyng at his gyrdyl as whyte as morow mylk
A shyreyf had he be and a coronour
Was nowher suche a worthy vauesour
AN haberdassher ther was ⁊and a carpenter
A webbe a dyer and a tapyser
And they were clothed all in o lyuere
Of a solempne and grete fraternyte
Full fressh ⁊and newe ther gere pyked was
Ther knyues chapyd were not wyth bras
But all wᵗith syluer wrought full clene ⁊and wele
Ther gyrdelys ⁊and ther powchys euerydele
Well semyd eche of them a fayr burgeys
To sytte in the yelde halle at the deys
Euerych for the wysdom that he can
Was haply for to be an aldyrman
For cateyll had they ynough ⁊and rent
And ther wyues wolde it well assent
And ellys certeyn they were to blame
It is full fayr to be callyd madame
And go to the vigyllis all before
And haue a mantell ryally ybore
A coke they had wᵗith them for the nonys
To boyle the chekyns ⁊and the mary bonys
And powder marchaunt tart ⁊and galyngale
Wel knewe he a draught of london ale
He cowde roste sethe broyle and frye
Make mortrewys and well bake a pye
But grete harm was it as it thoughte me
For on his shynne a mormall had he
And blanke manger made he wyth the best
A shypman was ther þᵗat woned fer by west
For ought I wote he was of derthemouthe
He rode vpon a rowncy as he couthe
In a gowne foldyng to the kne
A dagger on a lace hangyng had he
Abowte his necke vnder his arm a downe
The hote somer had made his hew al browne
Aod certaynly he was a good felawe
Full many a draughte wyn he had drawe
Fro burdeux ward whyle the chapman sleep
Of nyce conscyence toke he no keep
Yf þᵗat he faught and had the hygher honde
By water he sent them hom to euery londe
But of his craf to reken well his tydes
His stremys ⁊and his daungers hym besydes
His herberugh his mone ⁊and his lodemanage
Ther was none suche from hulle to cartage
Hardy he was ⁊and ware to vndertake
Wyth many a tempest his berde hath he shake
He knewe all the hauenes that there were
Fro gotelonde in to capfenestre
And euery creke in brytayne ⁊and in spayne
His barge was called the mawdeleyne
WYth vs there was a doctour in physyk
In the worlde was there none hym lyk
To speke of phisyk and surgerye
For he was groıı̄unded in astronomye
He kepte his pacyente a grete deel
In houres by magyk natureell
Well cowde he of fortune the assendent
Of his ymages for his pacyent
He knewe the cause of euery maladye
Were it of colde hete moyst or drye
And were engendred of what humour
He was a very perfyght practesour
The cause p know ⁊and of his harm the rote
Anon he yaf to the syk man his bote
For redy alway ben his apotecaryes
To sende hym drugges ⁊and his lectuaryes
For eche of them made other for to wynne
Her frendshyp was not newe to begynne
Full well knewe he the olde esculapius
And discorides and also rusus
Olde ypocras / haly ⁊and also galien
Serapyon rasis and also auicen
Aueroys damascene ⁊and constantyn
Bernarde gatisden and gylbertyn
Of his dyete mesurable was he
For it was of no superfluyte
But of grete nourysshynge ⁊and dygestyble
His stody was but lytyll on the byble
In sangwen ⁊and in perce y clad wyth all
Lyned wyth taffata ⁊and wyth sandall
And lytyll he was of his dyspence
He kepte that he wan in the pestylence
For golde in physyk is a cordyall
Therfore he louyd golde in especyall
A good wyf ther was of besyde bathe
And she was somdell def ⁊and that was scathe
Of cloth makyng had she suche an haunt
She passyd them of ypre ⁊and of gaunt
In all the parysshe wyf was ther non
That to the offrynge before her sholde goon
And yf ther dyde certeyn wroth was she
Then was she oute of all charyte
Her kercheuys full fyne were of grounde
I durste swere they weyed thre pounde
That on a sonday were on her hed
Her hosyn were of fyne scarlot reed
Full streyte y teyed ⁊and shoes full moyst ⁊and newe
Bolde was her face fayr ⁊and redde of hewe
She was a worthy woman all her lyue
Husbondes at the chyrche dore had she fyue
Wythout other company in youthe
But herof nedyth not to speke wyth mouthe
At acres had she ben and at Ierusaleme
She had passyd thorugh many a strange reme
At rome she had be and at boloyne
At saynt Iamys in galys and at coloyne
She cowde moche of wandryng in the waye
Gap tothed was she sothly to saye
Vpon an ambuler full easely she sat
Ywympled well ⁊and on herheed an hat
As brode as it were a bokeler or a targe
A foot mantyll abowte her hyppes large
And on her helys a payre of sporys sharpe
In felyshyp cowde she laugh ⁊and carpe
Of remedyes of loue she cowde per chaunce
For of þᵗat arte she cowde the olde daunce
A Good man there was of relygyon
And was a poore person of a toun
But ryche he was of holy thoughte ⁊and werk
He was also a lernyd man ⁊and a clerk
That cristis gospellis truely wolde preche
His paryshons deuowtly wolde he teche
Benygne he was ⁊and wonder dylygent

Or what ladyes fayrest ben or best daunsyuge
Or whyche of them can best daunce or synge
Ne who moost felyngly spekyth of loue
What hawkys sytte on the perkys aboue
What houndes lyen in the floor adoun
Of all this make I no mencyon
But of theffect that thynketh me best
Now comyth the poynt and herken yf ye lest
THe sonday at nyȝt or day began to spryg
Whan palamon herde the larke syng
All though it were not day by houres two
Yet songe the larke and palamon ryght tho
Wyth holy herte and wyth an hygh courage
Is rysen to wende on his pylgrymage
Vnto the blysfull sitherea benygne
I mene venus honourable and dygne
And in her houre he walked forth a pace
Vnto the lystes there her temple was
And downe he knelyd and wyth humble chere
And wyth hert sore he sayd as ye shall here
¶ Fayrest of fayre o lady my venus
Doughter to Iouis and spowse to vlcanus
That gladdest all the mount of sytherreon
For that loue that thou haddest to adon
Haue pyte on my bytter teris smert
And take myn humble prayer at thy hert
Alas I haue no langage for to telle
The effecte ne the torment of myn helle
Myn hert maye not myn harmes bewreye
I am so sorowfull that I can not seye
But mercy lady bright that knowest wele
My thought and seest the harmes that I fele
Consyder this and rewe vpon my sore
As wysly as I shall for euermore
Emforthe my myght thy true seruaunt to be
And holde werre lady alwaye wyth chastyte
That I make myn auowe so ye me helpe
I kepe not of armys for to yelpe
Ne I axe not to morowe for to haue vyctory
Ne renoun in this caas ne vaynglory
Of pryce of armys to blowe vp and doun
But I wolde fully haue possessyon
Of emelye and deye in thy seruyse
Fynd thou the manere how and in what wyse
I retche not but yf it may better be
To haue vyctory of them or they of me
So that I haue my lady in myn armys
For though so be that mars be god of armes
Your vertue is so grete in heuen aboue
That yf you lyst I shall haue my loue
Thy temple woll I worshyp euermo
And on an awter were I ryde or go
I woll do sacrifyce and fyres bete
And yf ye wyll not so my lady swete
Then praye I the to morow wyth a spere
That arcyte me thorugh the herte bere
Then recke I not whan I haue lost my lyf
Though that arcyte wedde her to his wyf
This is the effect and the ende of my prayere
Yeue me my loue my blessyd lady dere
¶ Whan that the orison was don of palamon
His sacrifyce he dyde and that anon
Full petously wyth alle cyrcumstaunces
Alle telle I not as now his obseruaunces
¶ And all the statue of venus shoke
And made a sygne wherby that he toke
That his prayer accepted was that daye
For though the fygure shewde delaye
Yet wyste he well that grauntyd was his bone
And wyth glad herte he went hym home sone
¶ The thyrde hour equall that palamon
Began to venus temple for to gon
UP rose the sonne andvp rose emelye
And to the temple of dyane gan hye
Hermaydens that she wyth her thether lad
Full redily wyth them the fyre they had
Thencence the clothes and the remenaunt all
That to the sacrifyce longen shall
The hornes full of methe as was the guyse
Ther lacked nought to don her sacrifyse
Smokynge the temple full of clothes fayr
This emely wyth herte debonayr
Her body wysshe wyth water in a welle
But how she dyde there dare I not telle
But it be ony thynge in generall
And yet it were a game to here it all
To hym that meneth well it were no charge
But it is good a man be at his large
Her bryght heer was kempt and vntressyd all
And a crowne of grene oke seryall
Vp on her hed was set full fayr and mete
Two fyres on the awter gan she bete
And dyde her thynges as men maye be holde
In state of thebes and in bokis olde
¶ Whan kyndled was þᵉ fyre wᵗith pyteous chere
Vnto dyane she spake as ye may here
O chast goddesse of the wode grene
To whom both heuene ⁊and erthe and see is seen
Quene of the regne of pluto derke and lowe
Goddesse of maydens þᵗat my hert hast knowe
Full many a yere and wotest what I desyre
And kepe me fro the vengaunce and thyn yre
That atheon aboughte truely
Chast goddesse well wotest thou that I
Desyre to be a mayden all my lyf
Ne neuer woll I be loue ne wyf
I am thou wotest yet of thy company
A mayden and loue huntynge and venery
And for to walken in the wodis wylde
And not to be a wyf and be wyth chylde
Nought woll I knowe companye of man
Now helpe me lady sythnes thou may and can
For the thre fourmes that thou hast in the
And palamon that suche loue hath to me
And eke arcyte that loueth me so sore
This grace I praye the wythouten more
As sende loue and peas bytwyx hem two
And fro me torne awaye her hertes so
That all her hote loue and all her desyre
And all her besy turment and all her fyre
Be queynt or torned in a nother place
And yf so be thou woll do me no grace
Or yf my desteny be shapen so
That I shall nedes haue one of hem two
As sende me hym that most desyreth me
Beholde goddesse of clene chastyte
The bytter teris that on my chekis falle
Sythnes thou art a mayde ⁊and keper of vs alle
My maydenhede thou kepe and well conserue
And whyles I lyue a mayden wyll I the serue
¶ Tyse fyres brenne vpon the awters clere
Whyle emely was thus in her prayere
But sodenly she sawe a syght queynt
For ryght anon one of the fyres queynt
And quechyd agayn and after that anon
That other fyre was queynt and all agon
And as it queynt it made a whystlynge
As don thyse wete brondes in her brennynge
And as the brondes endes out ran anon
As it were dropes blody many on
For why tho sosore agast was emelye
That she was almost mad and gan to crye
For she ne wyste what it sygnyfyed
But only for fere thus hath she cryed
And wepte that it was pyte to here
¶ And therwyth all dyane gan appere
Wyth bowe in honde ryght as an hunteresse
And sayd doughter stynt thyn heuynesse
Amonge the goddys an hyghe it is affermyd
And by eterne worde wryten and confermyd
Thou shall be wedded vntyll one of two
That haue for the so moche care and wo
But vnto whiche of hem may I not telle
Fare well for I may no lenger dwelle
The fyres whyche on myn awter brenne
Shall the declare or thou go henne
Thyn auenture of loue as in this caas
¶ And wyth that worde the arowes in þᵉ caas
Of the goddesse clateren faste and rynge
And forth she wente and made a vanysshyng
For whyche this emelye astonyed was
And sayd what amounteth this alas
I put me vnder thy proteccyon
Dyane and in thy dysposycyon
¶ And home she goth anon the nexte waye
This is the effect there is nomore to saye
In the nexte houre of mars after this
Arcyte vnto the temple walkyd is
Of fyers mars to do his sacryfyce
Wyth all the ryghtis of his paynem wyse
Wyth pytuous herte and hyghe deuocyon
Ryght thus to mars he sayd this oryson
¶ O stronge god that in the regnes colde
Of trace honoured art and lorde y holde
And hast in euery regne and euery londe
Of armys all the brydyll in thy honde
And hem fortunest as the lyst best deuyse
Accepte of me my pyteous sacryfyce
Yf so be that my thought may deserue
And that my myght be worthy to serue
Thy godhede that I maye be one of thyne
Then praye I the rewe on my pyne
For that payne and that hote fyre
In whyche thou whylom brendest for desyre
Whan that thou vsedyst the beaute
Of fayre yonge fresshe venus fre
And haddest her in thy armys at thy wyll
And though the ones a tyme mys fylle
Whan vlcanus had caught the in his laas
And fonde the lyenge be his wyf alas
For thylke sorowe that was in thy hert
Haue ruthe as well vp on my paynes smert
I am yonge and vncunnynge as thou wost
And as I trowe wyth loue offended most
Than euer was ony lyues creature
For she that doth me alle this wo endure
Ne retcheth neuer whether I synke or flete
And well I wote or sheme mercy hete
I muste wyth strengthe wynne her in þᵉ place
And well I wote wythout helpe and grace
Of the maye not my strengthe auayle
Then helpe me lord to morowe in my batayle
For that fyre that whylom brent the
As well as that fyre now brennyth me
And do that I to morowe haue the vyctory
Myn the trauayll and thyn be the glory
Thy souereyn temple woll I most honouren
Of ony place alwaye and most labouren
In thy plesaunce and in thy craftes stronge
And in thy temple I woll my baner honge
And all the armes of my companye
And euermore vntyll that daye I dye
Eterne fyre I woll beforn the fynde
And eke to this auowe I woll me bynde
My berde my heer that hangyth longe a doun
That neuer yet felt offensyoun
Of rasour ne of shere I woll the yeue
And be thy true seruaunt whyles I lyue
Now lorde haue ruthe vpon my sorowes sore
Yeue me the vyctory I axe nomore
¶ The prayer stynt of arcyte the stronge
The rynges that on the temple dore honge
And eke the dores clatteryd so faste
Of whyche arcyte somwhat hym agaste
¶ The fyres brent vpon the awters bryght
That it gan all the temple for to lyght
A sote smell anon the grounde vp yaf
And arcyte anon his honde vp gaf
And more encence in to the fyre caste
Wyth other rytes moo and at the laste
The statue of mars began his hawberk rynge
And with that sowne he herde a murmurynge
Full lowe and dym and sayd thus vyctory
For whiche he yaue to mars honour and glory
And thus wyth Ioye and hope well to fare
Arcyte anone to his Inne is fare
As fayn as foule is of the bryght sone
And ryght anon suche stryf is there begonne
For that grauntynge in heuene aboue
Betwyx venus goddesse of loue
And mars the sterne god armypotent
That Iupyter was besy it to stente
Tyll that the pale saturnus the colde
That knewe so many of auentures olde
Fonde in his olde experyence and art
That he full sone hath plesyd euery part
As soth is /sayd elde hath grete auauntage
In elde is both wysdom and vsage
Men may the olde out renne but not out rede
¶ Saturne anone to stynte stryf and drede
All be it that it is ayenst his kynde
Of all this stryf he gan remedyes fynde
My dere doughter venus quod saturne
My cours that hath so wyde for to turne
Hath more power than wote ony man
Myn is the drenchynge on the see so wan
Myn is the pryson in the derke cote
Myn is the stranglyng ⁊and hangyng by þᵉ throte
The murmur and the churles rebellynge
The groyninge and the pryue enpoysenynge
I do vengaunce and playn correccyon
Whyles I dwelle in the sygne of the lyon
Myn is the ruyn of the hyghe halles
The fallynge of the toures and the walles
Vp on the mynour or the carpenter
I slough sampson shakynge the pyler
And myne ben the maladyes colde
The derke treson and the castelles olde
My lokynge is the fader of pestylence
Now wepe nomore I shall don dylygence
That palamon that is thin owne knyghte
Shall haue his lady as thou hym behyghte
And mars shall kepe his knyghte yet netheles
Betwyx you ther must be somtyme pees
All be ye not of one complexyon
That causyth all daye suche dyuysion
I am thyn all redy at thy wyll
Wepe now nomore I woll thy lust fulfyll
¶ Now woll I stynte of the goddis aboue
Of mars and venus goddesse of loue
And telle you all playnly as I can
The grete effect for whyche I began
GRet was the feest in athenes that day
And eke the lusty seson of that may
Made euery wyght to be in such plesaunce
That all that monday Iuste they and daunce
And spenden it in venus hygh seruyse
But by cause that they sholden aryse
Erly for to se the grete syghte
Vnto her reste went they at nyghte
And on the morowe whan day gan sprynge
Of hors and noyse harneys and clatterynge
Ther was in hostelryes all abowte
And to the paleys rode there many a rowte
And lordes vp on stedys and palfreys
There mayst thou se deuysynge of harneys
So ancouthe ⁊and so ryche ⁊and wrought so wele
Of goldsmythrye of browderye and of stele
The sheldys bryght testeris and trappours
Gold hewēn helmes hauberkis ⁊and cote armours
Lordes in paramentis on her coursers
Knyghtes of retenue and eke squyers
Nayllyng the sperys and helmys bokelynge
Guydyng of sheldys wyth leyners lasynge
Ther as nede is they were nothyng ydyll
The fomy stedys on the golden brydyll
Gnawyng / and faste the armerers also
Wyth fyle and hamour prykynge to and fro
Yomen on fote and comyns many oon
Wyth short staues thycke as they may goon
Pypis trompis naconers and clarions
That in the bataylle blowen blody sowns
The palays full of pepyll vp and doun
Here thre there ten holdyng her questyoun
Demyng of the theban knyghtes two
Some sayd thus some sayd it shall be so
Some holde wyth hym wyth the blak berde
Some wyth þᵉ ballyd / some wyth þᵉ thyk herid
Some sayd he lokyd grym ⁊and he wolde fyghte
He hath a sparth of .xx. pounde of wyghte
Thus was the halle full of dyuynynge
¶ Longe after that the sonne gan to sprynge
The grete theseus that of his slepe awakyd
Wyth mynstralsy and noyse that was makyd
Helde yet the chambre of his palays ryche
Tyll that the theban knyghtes bothe ylyche
Honouryd were and in to the palays fet
¶ Duke theseus is at the wyndowe set
Arayd ryght as he were a god in trone
The pepyll precyd thytherwarde full soone
Hym for to seen and doon hygh reuerence
And eke to herken his hest and his sentence
¶ An herowde on a scaffolde made an O
Tyll all the noyse of the yepyll was do
And whan he sawe the peyll of noyse all styll
Thus shewd he the myghty dukes wyll
The lorde hath of his hygh dyscrecyon
Consydred that it were dystruccyon
To gentyll blood to fyghte in this wyse
Of mortall bataylle now in this empryse
Wherfore to shapen that they shold not dye
He wyll his fyrst purpos modyfye
¶No man therfore on payne of losse of lyf
No maner shot / ne pollax / ne short knyf
In the lystes sende or thyther brynge
Ne shorte swerd for to styke with poynt biting
Ne noman ne drawe ne bere it by his syde
Ne noman shall vnto his felow ryde
But one cours wyth a sharp y grounded spere
Foynynge yf hym lyst on fote hym self to were
And he that is at myschyef shall be take
And not slayn but be brought to the stake
That shall be ordeyned on eyther syde
But thyder he shall by force and there abyde
And yf so falle the cheefteyn be take
On eyther syde or elles sleeth his make
No lenger shall the turneyeng laste
God spede you goth forth and laye on fast
Wyth longe swerdes ⁊and maces fyght your fyll
Goth now your way this is the lordes wyll
¶The voys of pepyll towchyd the heuen
So lowde cryed they wyth mery steuen
God saue suche a lorde that is so good
He wylneth no destruccyon of blood
¶Vp goth the trumpis and the melodye
And to the lystis rydeth this companye
By ordynaunce thorugh out the cyte large
Hangyd wyth cloth of golde ⁊and not wyth sarge
¶ Full lyke a lorde this noble duke gan ryde
Thyse two thebans vp on eyther syde
And after rode the quene and emelye
And after that a nother companye
Of one and other after her degre
And thus they passe thorugh the cyte
And to the lystes come they betyme
Hyt nas not of the daye yet fully pryme
Whan set was theseus ryche on hyghe
Ipolyta the quene and emelye
And other ladyes in degrees abowte
Vnto the cetes preceth all the rowte
And westwarde thrugh the yates vnder marte
Arcyte and eke the hundryd of his parte
Wyth baner reede is entred ryght anon
And in that self moment palamon
Is vnder venus estwarde in that place
Wyth baner whyte and hardy chere of face
In all the worlde to seke vp and doun
So euyn wythoute ony varyacyoun
Ther nere suche companyes tweye
For ther was non so wyse that cowde seye
That ony hadde of other auauntage
Of worthynesse ne estate ne of aege
So euen were they chosen forto gesse
And in two renges fayre they hem dresse
And whan that her names rad were euerychon
That in her nombre gyle were ther non
Tho were the yates shyt and cryed was lowde
Do now your deuer yonge knyghtes prowde
¶The herowdes left her pryckyng vp ⁊and doun
Now ryngen trompes lowde and claryoun
Ther is no more to say but est and west
In gooth the speris full sadly in the rest
In goth the sharpe spore in to the syde
Ther seen men who can Iust ⁊and who can ryde
Ther shyueryn shaftes vp on sheldes thycke
He felyth thorough the herte sponne the pryk
Vp spryngeth sperys twenty fote on heyghte
Out gon the swerdes as the syluer bryghte
The helmes they to heuen and to shrede
Out breste the blood wyth sterne stremes rede
Wyth myghty maces the bones they to brest
He thrugh þᵉ thyckest of the thronge gan threst
There stombelyn stedys strong ⁊and doun goth al
He rollyth vnder fote as doth a bal
He foyneth on his fete with his trunchon
And he hurtelyth wyth his hors adoun
He thorugh the body is hurt and sythnes take
Magre his heed and brought so the stake
As forward was ryght there he must abyde
A nother led is on that other syde
And somtyme doth hem theseus to reste
Hem for to refresshe and drynke yf theym leste
Ful ofte aday haue the thebans two
To gyder y met and wrought eyther wo
Vnhorsyd hath eche other of hem tweye
Ther is no tygre in the vale of galegopheye
Whan that her whelpe is stole whan it is lyte
So cruell on the hunte as is arcyte
For Ielous herte vpon this palamon
Ne in belmarie ther nys so fell lyon
That huntyd is or for angre wood
Ne of his pray desyreth so the blood
As palamon to sle his foo arcyte
The Ielous strokes on her helmes byte
Out renneth blood on bothe her sydes reede
Somtyme an ende ther is of euery deede
For or the sonne vnto reste went
The strong kynge emetrius gan hente
This palamon as he fought wyth arcyte
And made his swerde depe in his flesshe byte
And by the force of twenty was he take
Vnyolden and drawe to the stake
And in the rescous of this palamon
The stronge kynge ligurge is born a doun
And kynge emetrius for all his strengthe
Is born out of his sadyll a swerdes lengthe
So hytte hym palamon or he were take
But all for nought he was brought to þᵉ stake
His hardy hert ne myght hym helpe nought
He muste abyde whan he was caught
By force and eke by composycyon
¶ Who soroweth now but wofull palamon
That muste nomore go ayen to fyght
¶ And whan that theseus hadde seye þᵗat syght
Vnto the folke that foughten thus echone
He cryed than ho / nomore for it is done
I woll be true Iuge and not party
Arcyte of thebes shall haue emely
That by his fortuue hath her fayr y wonne
Anon ther is a noyse of pepyll begonne
For Ioye of this so lowde ⁊and hyghe wyth all
That it semyd that the lystes sholde fall
WHat can now fayre venus done aboue
What sayth she what doth þᵉ quene of loue
But wepyth so for wantyng of her wyll
Tyll that her teres in the lystes fyll
She sayd I am ashamed doutlees
¶ Saturne sayd doughter holde thy pees
Mars hath his wyll the knyght hath his bone
And by my hed thou shalt be esyd sone
¶The trompettis wyth the loude mynstralsie
The herowdes that full lowde yelle and crye
Bene in her Ioye for the wele of dane arcyte
But herkenyth me and stynt noyse alyte
Whyche a myracle there befell anone
¶ This fyres arcyte hath his helme of done
And on a courser forto shewe his face
He prycked endlonge the large place
Lokyng vpwarde vnto this emelye
And she agayn hym cast a frendly eye
And was all in his chere as in his hert
Out of the grounde a fyre Infernall stert
Fro pluto sent atte request of saturne
For wyhyche his hors for fere gan to torne
And lepte asyde and foundryd as he lepe
And or that arcyte may take kepe
He hyghte hym on the pomell of his hed
That in the place he laye as he were ded
His brest to brosten wyth his sadyll bowe
As blak he laye as ony cole or crowe
So was the blood ronne in his face
Anon he was born out of the place
Wyth herte sore to theseus palayes
Tho was he coruen out of his harneyes
And in a bed brought full fayre and blyue
For he was yet in memorye and alyue
And alwaye cryenge after emelye
¶ Duke theseus wyth all his companye
Is come home to athenes his cyte
Wyth all blys and grete solempnyte
All be it that this auenture was falle
He nolde not discomforte hem all
Men sayd eke that arcyte sholde not dye
He sholde be heelyd of his maladye
And of a nother thynge they were feyne
That of hem al ther was none sleyne
All were they sore hurte and namely one
That wyth a spere was thyrled the brestbone
The other woundes and the broke armes
Some hadde salues ⁊and some hadden charmes
Fermacyes of herbes and eke sane
They dronken for they wolde her lyues hane
For whyche this noble duke as he well can
Comforteth and honoureth euery man
And made reuell all the longe nyght
Vnto the strange lordes as was ryght
Ne there was holden no discomfytynge
But as a Iustes or a tourneyenge
For ther was holden no discomfyture
For faylynge nys but auenture
Ne to be lad by force vnto the stake
Vn yelden and wyth .xx. knyghtes take
One persone alone wythoute mo
And haryed forth by harme fote and to
And eke his stede dryuen forth wyth staues
With fotemen both yoman and eke knanes
It nas y rettyd hym no vylonye
Ther may no man clepe it cowardrye
For whyche anon duke theseus lete crye
To stynten all rancour and enuye
The degre as well in o syde as in other
And eyther syde lyke as other brother
And yaf hem gyftes after her degre
And fully helde a feest dayes thre
And conueyed the kynges worthyly
Out of his towne a Iourney largely
And home went euery man the ryght way
Ther was nomore but farwel haue gode day
AFter this batayll I woll nomore endyte
But speke of palamon and of arcyte
Swelleth the brest of arcyte and the sore
Encrecyth at his hert ay more and more
The cluteryd blood for ony lechecraft
Corruptyth and in his bowke is laft
That neyther veyne bloode ne ventusynge
Ne drynke of herbes may be his helpynge
The vertu expulsyf or animall
Fro that vertue y clepyd naturall
Ne may the venym voyde ne expelle
The pypes of his longes gan to swelle
And euery lacert in his brest a doun
Is shent wyth venym and corrupcyoun
Hym gayneth nothyng for to gete his lyf
Vomyte vpwarde and dounwarde laxatyf
All is to brosten thylke regyon
Nature hath in hym no domynacyon
And certaynly there nature woll not werche
Fare well physik go bere the man to chyrche
This is all and som arcyte must dye
For whyche he sendeth after emelye
And palamon that was his cosyn dere
Then sayd he thus as ye shall after here
¶ Not may the wofull spyryte in my herte
Declare a poynt of all my sorowe smerte
To you my lady that I loue most
But bequethe the seruyce of my gost
To you aboue euery creature
Sythnes that my lyf may no lenger dure
Alas the woo alas the paynes stronge
That I for you haue suffred and so longe
Alas the deth / alas my emelye
Alas the departynge of our companye
Alas my hertes quene / alas my wyf
My hertes lady ender of my lyf
What is this worlde what axeth men to haue
Now wyth his loue now colde in his graue
Alon wythouten ony company
Fare well my swete foo my emely
And softe take me in your armes tweye
For the loue of god and herkenith what I seye
¶ I haue here wyth my cosyn palamon
Had stryf and rancour many a daye agoon
For loue of you and of my Ielousye
And Iupyter so wysly my soule gye
To speken of a seruaunt properly
Wyth circumstannces all truely
That is to sayn trouth honour ⁊and knygthode
Wysdom humblesse estate and hye kynrede
Fredom and all that longeth to that arte
So Iupyter haue of my soule parte
As in this worlde ryght now knowe I non
So worthy to be loued as palamon
That serueth you and woll do all his lyf
And yf that euer ye shul be a wyf
Foryeteth not palamon the gentyll man
¶ And wyth that worde his speche faylle gan
For fro his fete vnto his breste was come
The colde of deth that hath him ouercome
And yet more ouer for in his armes two
The vytall strengthe is lost and all ago
Only the Intellectes wythouten more
That dwelleth in his herte syke and sore
Gan fayle whan the herte felyth deth
Dusshyd his eyen two and faylleth his breth
But on his lady yet caste he his eye
His laste worde was mercy emelye
His spiryte chaunged the hous and wente there
As I cam neuer I can not telle where
There I stynte I am not dyuynyster
Of soules fynde I not in this register
Ne me lyst the opynyons to tell
Of thēm though þᵗat they wryten where they dwell
¶ Arcyte is colde there mars his soule guye
Now woll I speke forth of emelye
¶ Shrgyhte emelye and howleth palamon
And theseus his syster toke anon
Swownyng and bare her fro the cours away
What helpyth it to tary forth the daye
To telle how she wepte bothe eue and morow
For in suche caas wymmen haue suche sorow
Whan that her husbondes be fro hem ago
That for the more parte they sorowen so
Or elles fallen in suche a maladye
That at the laste certaynly they dye
Infynyt ben the sorowes and the teris
Of olde folke and folke of tendre yeris
In all the towne for deth of this theban
For hym there wepyth bothe the chylde and man
So grete wepynge was ther non certayn
Whan ector was brought all fressh y slayn
To troy alas the pyte that was there
Cratchynge of chekys rentynge eke of here
Why woldest thou be ded thus wymmen crye
And haddest golde ynough and emelye
¶ No man myght glade theseus
Sauynge his olde fader egeus
That knewe this worldes transmutacyon
And he hadde seen it channge vp and doun
Ioye after woo and woo after gladnesse
And shewed hym ensample and lyknesse
Ryght as ther deyed neuer man quod he
That he ne lyued in erth in some degre
Ryght so ther lyued neuer man he seyde
In all this worlde that somtyme he ne deyde
This worlde is but a thrugh fare full of wo
And we be pylgryms passynge to and fro
Deth is an ende of euery worldes sore
¶ And ouer all this yet sayd he moche more
To this effect full wysely to enhorte
The pepyll that they sholde hem recomforte
¶ Duke theseus wyth all his besy cure
Caste now where that the sepulture
Of good arcyte may best y maked be
And eke most honourable in his degre
And at the last he toke conclusyon
That there as fyrst arcyte and palamon
Hadden for loue the bataylle them betwene
That in that selfe groue swete and grene
There as he hadde his amerous desyres
His complaynt and for loue his hote fyres
He wolde make a fyre in whyche the offyce
Funerall he myght fully accomplyce
And comaundyd anon to hacke and to hewe
The okys olde and laye hem on a rewe
In culpyns well arayed for to brenne
¶ His offycers wyth swyft fete they renne
And ryden anon at his cōmmaundement
And after this theseus hath sent
After a bere and he it ouer sprad
Wyth clothes of gold the richest that he had
And of the same sute he clothed arcyte
Vp on his hondes his gloues whyte
And on his hed a crowne of lawrer grene
And in his honde a swerde full bryght ⁊and kene
He layed hym bare the vysage on the bere
Ther with he wept that pyte was to here
And for the pepyll shold se hym alle
Whan it was day / he brought hym in the halle
That roreth of the cryenge and the soun
Tho cam this wofull theban palamoun
Wyth floteryd berde / and rugged asshy heris
In clothe blak droppyd all wyth teris
And passynge other of wepynge emelye
The rewfullest of all the companye
¶ And in as moche as the seruyse sholde be
The more noble and ryche in his degre
Duke theseus lete thre stedys forth brynge
That trappyd were in stele all glytterynge
And coueryd wyth the armys of arcyte
And eke vpon the stedys grete and whyte
Ther saten folke of whiche one bare his sheld
A nother a spere vpon his sholders held
The thyrde bare wyth hym his bowe turkeys
Of brend golde was the caas and the harneys
And ryden forth a paas wyth sorowfull chere
Toward the groue as ye shall after here
¶ The noblest of the grekys that there were
Vpon theyr backes cariden the bere
Wyth slak paas and eyen rede and wete
Thorugh out the cyte by the mayster strete
That sprad was all wyth blak and wond9 hye
Ryght of the same is the strete y wrye
Vp on the ryght honde went olde egeus
And on that other syde duke theseus
Wyth vessellis of golde in her hondefull fyne
And full of hony mylke / blood and wyne
Eke palamon wyth full grete companye
And after that came wofull emelye
Wyth fyre in hond as was that tyme the gyse
To do the offyce of the funerall seruyce
¶ High labour and full grete apparelynge
Was at the seruyce of that fyre makynge
That wyth his grene top the heuen raughte
And .xx. fadom of brede the armys straughte
This is to saye the bowes were so brode
Of strawe fyrst was layd many a lode
¶ But how the fyre was made vp an heyghte
Ne eke the names how the trees hyghte
As ook fyrr / byrche assh / alder holm populer
Mapyl thorn bech aspe box chesteyn lynd laurer
Wylow / elme / plane / hasyl ⁊and whypultre
How they were fellyd shall not be tolde for me
Ne how the goddis rennen vp and doun
Disheryted of theyr habitacyoun
In whyche they woned in rest and pees
Nymphes faunes and a madrides
Ne how the bestis and the bryddes all
Fledden for fere whan the wode gan fall
Ne how the grounde agast was of the lyhgte
That was not wont to se the sonne bryghte
Ne how the fyre was cowchyd fyrst wyth stre
And then wyth drye styckes clouen on thre
Andthan wyth grene wode and spycery
And then wyth cloth of golde ⁊and wyth perry
And garlondes hangynge wyth many a flour
The myrre the encence wyth swete odour
Ne how arcyte laye amonge all this
Ne what rychesse abowte his body ther is
Ne how that emelye as was the gyse
Put in the fyre of funerall seruyse
Ne how she swouned whan made was the fyre
Ne what she spake ne what was her desyre
Ne what Iewellis men in to the fyre caste
Whan that the fyre was grete and brente faste
Ne how some caste her shelde ⁊and some her spere
And of her vestimentes whyche that they were
And cuppis full of mylke wyne and blood
In to the fyre that brent as it were wood
Ne how the grekys wyth an huge rowte
Thryes ryden all the fyre aboute
Vp on the lyft hond wyth an hyghe showtyng
And thryes wyth here speres claterynge
And thryes how the ladyes gan crye
Ne how that led was hom warde emelye
Ne how arcyte is brent to asshen colde
Ne how the lyche wakys were y holde
That ylke nyghte ne how the grekys playe
The wake playes ne kepe I not to saye
Whyche wrasteleth best nakyd wᵗith oyle anoynt
Ne how that bare hym best at the poynt
I woll not telle all how they goon
Home to athenes when the playe is doon
But shortly to the poynt then wol I wende
And make of my longe tale an ende
BY processe and by lengthe of certen yeres
All stynt is the mornynge and the cheres
Of grekys by one generall assent
Than semyth me ther was a parlement
At athenes vpon a certeyn poynt and caas
And among the whyche poyntes spoken was
To haue wyth certen countrees alyaunce
And haue fully of thebans obeysaunce
For whyche this noble theseus anon
Lete sende after gentyll palamon
Vnwyst of hym what was the cause and why
But in his blacke clothes sorowfully
He cam at his comaundement an hye
¶ Tho sent theseus for emelye
Whan they were set ⁊and hust was all the place
And theseus abyden hath a space
Or ony worde cam fro his wyse brest
His eyen set he there as hym lyst
And wyth a sad vysage he syghed stylle
And after that ryght thus he sayd his wyll
¶ The fyrst mouer of the cause aboue
Whan he fyrste made the fayre cheyne of loue
Grete was the effect ⁊and highe was his entent
Well wyst he why and what ther of he ment
For wyth that fayr cheyne of loue he bonde
The fyre the ayer the water and the londe
In certen bondes that men maye not flee
That same prynce and that mouer quod he
Hath stablished in this wretchyd world adoun
Certen dayes and duracyoun
To all that is engendryd in this place
Ouer the whyche daye they mow not pace
All mowe they yet tho dayes abrydge
Ther nedyth non auctoryte to ledge
For it is proued by experyence
But that me lyst to declare my sentence
Then may wel men by this order dyscerne
That thylke mouer stable is and eterne
Well maye men knowe but it be a fole
That euery party is deryued fro his hole
For nature hath not take his begynnynge
Of one parte or of a cantell of a thynge
But of a thynge that parfyght is and stable
Descendynge so tyll it be corrumpable
And therfore for his wyse purueaunce
He hath so well be set his ordynaunce
That speces of thynge and progressyons
Sholden endure by successyons
And nought eterne wythout ony lye
Thus mayst thou vnderstonde and se at eye
Lo the oke that hath so longe a nourysshyng
Fro the tyme that it fyrst gynneth to sprynge
And hath so longe lyf as ye maye see
Yet at the last wasted is the tree
Consydereth eke how that the harde stoon
Vnder our fete / on whyche we trede and goon
Yet wastyth it as it lyeth by the waye
The brode ryuer somtyme wexeth drey
The grete townes se we wane and wende
Then ye se that all thynge hath an ende
Of man of woman se we also
That nedys in one of thyse termes two
This is to saye in yongthe or ellis in aege
He mot be ded the kynge as shall a page
Some in his bed some in the depe see
Some in the large felde as men maye see
Ther helpyth noght / all gon that ylke weye
Then may I saye all thynges mot nedes deye
What makyth this but Iupyter the kynge
That is prynce and cause of all thynge
Conuertynge alle vnto his propre wyll
For whyche it is deryued soth to tell
And here agaynst no creature a lyue
Of no degre auaylleth for to stryue
Then is it wysdom as thynketh me
To make vertue of necessyte
And take it well that we maye not eschewe
And namely that to vs all is dewe
And who so grutcheth ought he doth folye
And rebell is to hym that maye all gye
And certeynly a man hath most honour
To dyen in his most excellent flour
Whan he is syker of his good name
Then hath he do his frende ne hym no shame
And gladder ought his frende be of his deth
Whan wyth honour so vp yolden is his breth
Than whan his name appallyd is for age
For all foryten is then his vassellage
Then it is best as for a worthy fame
To dyen whan a man is best of name
The contrary of all this is wylfulnesse
Why grutche we why haue we heuynesse
That good arcyte of chyualrye the flour
Departyd is wyth duete and honour
Out of the fowle pryson of this lyf
Why grutchyd his cosyn and his wyf
Of his welfare that loueth hym so wele
Can he hem thanke nay god wote neuer a dele
That bothe his soule and eke hem offende
And yet they mow her lustes not amende
¶ What may I conclude of this longe sery
But after wo I rede vs to be mery
And thanke Iupyter of all his grace
And er we departen from this place
I rede that we make of sorowes two
O perfyt Ioye lastyng euer mo
And lokyth now where most sorow is inne
There wyll I fyrst amende and begynne
¶ Syster quod he this is my full assent
Wyth all the auyse of my parlement
That gentyll palamon your owne knyght
That serueth you wyth hert and myght
And euer hath do syn ye fyrst hym knewe
That ye shal of your grace on hym rewe
And take hym for husbonde and for lorde
Lene me your honde for this is our acorde
¶ Lete se now of your womanly pyte
He is a kyngis brother sone perde
And though he were a poore bacheler
Syn he hath serued you so many a yeer
And hadde for you so gret aduersyte
It mot be consydered leuyth me
For gentyll mercy ought to passe ryght
¶ Then sayd he thus to palamon the knyght
I trow ther nedyth lytyll sermonynge
To make you assent to this thynge
Comyth ner ⁊and takyth your lady by the honde
And thus of hem bothe was made the bonde
That hyght matrymony or maryage
By all the counsell of the baronage
And thus wyth all blys and melodye
Hath palamon wedded emelye
¶ And god that all this worlde hath wrought
Sente hym his loue that he dere had bought
For now is palamon in alle wele
Lyuynge in blis in ryches and in hele
And emelye hym louyth so tenderly
And he here seruyth agayue so gentylly
That ther was no worde hem betwene
Of Ielowsye or of ony other tene
Thus endyth palamon and emelye
And god saue alle this companye
Here endyth the knyghtes tale

l.hi:
And here begynneth the myl
lars prologue

div.l: WHan þᵗat the knyȝt had th9 his tale told
In all þᵗat cōmpanye nas ther yong ne old
That he ne sayd it was a noble story
And worthy to be drawe in memory
And namely the gentylis euerychon
¶ Our hoste lough and swore so mot I gon
This goth aryght vnbokelyd is the male
Lete se now who shall telle a nother tale
For truely the game is well begonne
Now telle ye syr monke yf that ye conne
Som what to quyte the knyght his tale
¶ The myllarre that fordronkyn was all pale
To that vnethes vp on his hors he sate
He nolde auale nother hode ne hate
Ne abyde no man for his curteysye
But in pylatis voys he gan crye
And swore by armys blood and bones
I can a noble tale for the nones
With whiche I wol now quyte þᵉ knyghtes tale
¶ Our hoste sawe that he was dronke of ale
And sayd abyde robyn leue brother
Som better man shal telle fyrst a nother
Abyde and let vs werke thryftely
¶ By cockys soule quod he that nyll not I
For I woll speke or elles go my waye
¶ Our hoste answeede tell on a deuyll waye
Thou art a fole thy wytte is ouercome
¶ Now herkeneth quod the myllar alle ⁊and some
But fyrst I make a protestacyoun
That I am dronke I knowe by my soun
And therfore yf I ought mys speke or saye
Wyte it the ale of suthwerke I you praye
For I woll telle a legende and a lyf
Bothe of a carpenter and of hys wyf
How that a clerke hath set the wryghtes cappe
¶ The reue answerde ⁊and sayd stynt thy clappe
Let be thy lewde dronken harlottry
It is a synne and eke grete folye
To appeyre ony man or hym defame
And eke brynge wyues in suche a name
Thou mayst ynough of other thynges sayn
¶ This dronkēn myllare spake ful sone agayn
And sayd o leue brother oswolde
Who hath no wyf he is no cokeold
But I saye not therfor that thou art one
Ther ben good wyues many one
Why art thou angry wyth my tale now
I haue a wyf parde as well as thou
Yet nolde I not for the oxen in my plow
Take vp on me more than ynow
As deme of myself that I were one
I woll byleue well that I am none
An husbonde sholde not be Inquisytif
Of goddis preuyte ne of his wyf
So he may fynde goddys fuson there
Of the remenaunt nedyth not to enquere
¶ What sholde I more saye but this myllere
He nolde his worde for no man forbere
But tolde his curles tale in his manere
Me forthynketh that I shall reherce it here
And therfore euery gentyll wyght I praye
Demyth not for goddys loue that I saye
Of euyll entent but that I must reherce
Here tales all be they better or worce
Or elles falsen some of my matere
¶ And therfore who so lysteth not to here
Torne ouer the leyf and chese a nother tale
For he shall fynde ynowe both grete ⁊and smale
Of historyall thynge þᵗat towchyth gentylnesse
And eke moralyte and holynesse
Blamyth not me yf that ye chose amys
The myllar is a churle ye knowe well this
So is the reue and eke other mo
And harlottrye they tolde bothe two
Auyseth you and put me out of blame
And eke men sholde not make ernest of game
WHylom ther was dwellyg in oxenford
A ryche gnuf that gestys had to bord
And of his craft was he a carpenter
Wyth hym ther was dwellynge a poore scoler
Hadde lernyd art but all his fantasye
Was torned to lerne astrologye
And cowde a certayn of conclusyons
To demyn by Interogacyons
Yf that men axed hym certayn houres
Whether they sholde haue droughte or shoures
Or yf that men axed hym what sholde befalle
Of euery thynge I maye not reken alle
¶ This clerke was clepyd hynde nycholas
Of dern loue he cowde and of solas
And therto he was sly and full preuy
And lyke a mayden meke for to se
A chambre hadde he in that hostelerye
Alone without ony companye
Full fetously ydyght wyth herbes sote
And he hym self was swete as is the rote
Of lycoryce or of ony cetewale
His almegeste hts bokes grete and smale
His astrologye longynge for his art
His awgrym stones laye fayr a part
On sheluys cowchid at his beddys heed
His presse ycoueryd wyth a foldyuge reed
And all aboue ther laye a gaye sawtrye
Of whyche he made a nyghtes melodye
So swetely that all the chambre ronge
And angelus ad virginem he songe
And after that he songe the kynges note
Ful often blessyd was his mery throte
And this swete clerke his tyme spent
After his frendys fyndynge and his rent
¶ This carpenter hadde weddyd newe a wyf
Whyche that he louyd more than his lyf
Of . xviij . yere she was of aege
Ielous he was and helde her narow in cage
For she was wylde ⁊and yong and he was olde
And demyd hym self lyke to be a cokewolde
He knewe not caton for his wyt was rude
That bad a man shold wedde his symylitude
Men sholde wedde after her astate
For yougthe and olde ben often at debate
But sythen he was fallen in the snare
He muste endure as other folke his care
¶ Fayr was this yong wyf ⁊and there wyth all
As ony wesyll her body gent and small
A seynt she weryd barryd alle of sylke
A barmecloth as whyte as morowe mylke
Vp on her lendys wyth full many a gore
Whyte was her smocke and broyden all before
And eke behynde on her coler abowte
Of coleblak sylke wythinne and eke wythout
The tapettis of her whyte voluper
Were of the same sute of the coler
Her fylet brode of sylke and set full hye
And sykerly she had a lykerous eye
Full smale y pulled were her browes two
And they were bent and blak as ony slo
She was moche more blysfull on to see
Than is the newe pere genet tree
And softer than is the wulle of a weder
And by her gyrdyll hangyth a purs of leder
Tarselyd wyth sylke and perlyd wyth laton
In all this worlde to seke vp and doun
Ther is no man so wyse that cowde thenche
So gaye a pupelot or so praty a wenche
For bryghter was she shynynge of her hewe
Than in the tour the nobyll forgyd newe
But of her songe it was as lowde and yern
As ony swalowe syttynge on the bern
Therto she cowde skyppe and make game
As ony kyd or calf folowyng his dame
Her mouth was swete as braket or methe
Or hord of appyls layd on hey or hethe
Wynsynge she was as is a Ioly colt
Long as a mast and vpryght as a bolt
A broche she bare vp on her lowe coler
As brode as is the boos of a bokeler
Her shoon were lacyd on her legges hye
She was a prymerolle a pyggys nye
For ony lorde to lyggen in his bed
Or yet for ony good yoman to wed
¶ Now syre and eft syre so befyll the caas
That on a day this hende nicholas
Fell wyth thys yonge wyf to rage and to playe
Whyles that her husbonde was at oseneye
As clerkis be full subtyll and full queynt
And pryuely he caughte her by the queynt
And sayd ywys but yf I haue my wylle
For dern loue of the lemman I spylle
And helde her harde by the shanke bones
And sayd lemman loue me all a tones
Or I wolde dye al so god me saue
And she spronge as a colt doth in the traue
And wyth her hed she wryeth faste awaye
She sayd I woll not kysse you by my faye
Why lete be quod she let be nycholas
Or I woll crye out harowe and alas
Do way your hondes for your curtesye
¶ This nycholas gan mercy for to crye
And spake so fayre and proferyd her so fast
That she her loue graunted hym at the last
And swore her oth by saynt thomas of kent
That she wolde be at his cōmmaundement
Whan that she maye her leyser well espye
Myn husbonde is so full of Ielowsye
That but ye wayte well and be preuy
I wot ryght well I nam but deed quod she
Ye must be full dern as in this caas
¶ Nay therof care ye not quod nycholas
Lytherly a clerke had be set his whyle
But yf he cowde a carpenter begyle
And thus they ben accorded and y sworn
To wayte a tyme as I haue tolde beforn
¶ Whan nycholas had do thus euery dele
And thacked her abowte the lendys wele
He kyst her swete and toke his sawtrye
And played faste and made melodye
¶ Then fell it thus þᵗat to the parysshe chyrche
Crystis owne werkes for to werche
This good wyfe went on an holy daye
Her forehed shoon as bryght as ony daye
So was it wasshe whan she lete her werke
¶ Now was ther of þᵗat chyrche a paryssh clerke
The whyche that was y callyd absolon
Crullid was his heere ⁊and as the golde it shoon
And strowtyd as a fan large and brode
Full streyght and euyn laye his Ioly shode
His rode was red his eyen graye as goos
Wyth poulis wyndowes coruen in his shoos
In hoses red he went full fetously
Alle in a kyrtyll of a lyght waget
Ful fayr and thycke ben the poyntes set
And ther vpon he hadde a gaye surplys
As whyte as is the blossom of the rys
A mery chylde he was so god me saue
Well cowde he leten blood and clyppe ⁊and shaue
And make a chartre of londe and aquytaunce
And twenty maners coude he tryppe ⁊and daunce
After the scole of oxenforde tho
And wyth his legges caste to and fro
And playe songes on a smale ribyble
Therto he songe somtyme a lowde quynyble
And as well cowde he playe on his geterne
In all the towne nas brewe hous ne tauerne
That he ne visyted wyth his solace
There as ony gaylarde tapster was
But soth to saye he was somdel sqweymous
Of fartynge and of speche daungerous
¶ This absolon that Ioly was and gay
Goth wyth a senser on the holy day
Sensynge wyues of the parysshe fast
And many a louely loke on hem he cast
And namely on this carpenters wyf
To loke on her hym thoughte a mery lyf
She was so propre swete and eke lykerous
I dar well say yf she had be a mous
And he a cate he wolde her hente anon
¶ This parysshe clerke this Ioly absolon
Hath in his hert suche a loue longynge
That of no wyf toke he non offrynge
For curtesye he sayd he wolde non
The mone whan it was nyght bryght shoon
And absolon his gyterne hadde y take
For paramours he thoughte for to wake
And forth he goth Ioly and amerous
Tyll he cam to the carpenters hous
A lytyll after cockes hadde y crowe
And dressyd hym vp by the shot wyndowe
That was vpon the carpenters walle
He syngeth in his voys gentyll and smalle
Now dere lady yf thy wyll be
I praye you that ye wyll thynke on me
Full well acordynge to his gytternynge
¶ This carpenter a woke ⁊and herde hym synge
And spake vnto his wyf and sayd anon
What alyson herest thou not absolon
That chauntyth thus vnder our bowres wall
And she answerde her husbonde ther wyth all
Yes god wote Iohn I here it euerydele

¶ Thus passyth forth what wyll ye bet than
wele
From day to day this Ioly absolon
So woweth her that he is wo begon
He wakyth all the nyghte and all the day
He kempte his lockes brode ⁊and made hym gaye
He woweth her by menes and brocage
And swore he wolde be her owne page
He syngeth brockyng as a nyghtyngale
He sent after pyment methe and spyced ale
And wafres pypynge hote out of the glede
And for she was of towne he proferyd mede
For some folke woll be wonnen for rychesse
And some for strokys and some for Iolynesse

¶ Somtyme he shewyth his lustynesse ⁊and ma
ystri
He playeth herodes vpon a scaffold hye
But what auayleth him as in this cas
She loued so this hynde nycholas
That absolon maye blowe in the buckis horn
He ne had for his labour but a scorn
And thus she makyth absolon her ape
And all his ernest torneth to a Iape
Full soth is this prouerbe it is no lye
Men saye ryght thus alwaye the nyghe slye
Makyth the ferre leyf for to be loth
For though that absolon be wood or wroth
By cause that he ferre was from her syghte
This nyghe nycholas stode in his lyghte
¶ Now bere the well thou hende nycholas
For absolon maye wayle and synge alas
And so befell it that on a saterday
This carpenter was gon tyll osnay
And eke hynde nycholas and alyson
Acorded be fully to thys conclusyon
That nycholas shall shapen hym a wyle
This sely Ielous husbonde to begyle
And yf so be the game wente a ryght
She sholde slepe in his armys all nyght
For this was her desyre and his also
And ryght anon wythout wordys mo
This nycholas no lenger wolde tary
But doth full softe in to his chambre cary
Bothe mete and drynke for a daye or tweye
And to her husbonde bad her for to seye
Yf that he axed after nycholas
She sholde saye she nyst where he was
Of all that day she sawe hym not wyth eye
She troweth that he is in some maladye
For that no crye her mayde cowde hym calle
He nolde answer for no thynge myghte falle
¶ This passyth forth all that saterday
That nycholas styll in his chambre laye
And ete or slepe or dyde what hym leste
Tyll sonday that the sonne goth to reste
¶ This sely carpenter hath gret meruayle
Of nycholas or what myght hym ayll
And sayd I am a drad by saynt thomas
It stondyth not aryght wyth nycholas
God shelde it that he deyed sodenly
This worlde is now full tykell sikerly
I sawe a corps to daye bore to chyrche
That now a monday last I saw him werche
¶ Go vp quod he vnto his knaue anon
Clepe at the dore or knocke wyth a ston
Loke how it is and telle me boldly
¶ This knaue goth hym vp full sturdely
And at the chambre dore whyle that he stode
He cryed and knocked as he were wood
What how what do ye mayster nychola
How may ye slepen all the longe day
But all for nought he herde not a worde
An hole full lowe he founde vpon a borde
Ther as the cat was wont in for to crepe
And at the hole he lokyd in full depe
Tyll at the laste he hadde of hym a syght
¶ This nycholas sate gapynge euer vpryght
As he had kyked on the newe mone
¶ Adowne he goth and tolde his mayster sone
In what araye he sawe this ylke man
¶ This carpenter to blesse hym began
And sayd helpe vs saynt frydeswyde
A man wote lytyll what hym shall betyde
This man is fallen wyth his astronomye
In some wodnesse or in some agonye
I thoughte aye well how it sholde be
Men sholde not knowe of goddys preuyte
Y blessyd be alwaye a lewde man
That nought but only his byleue can
So ferd a nother clerke wyth astronomye
He walked in the feldes for to prye
Vpon the sterres what ther shold befalle
Tyll he was in a marlepyt y falle
He sawe not that but yet by saynt thomas
Me reweth sore of hynde nycholas
He shall be ratyd of his studyenge
Yf that I maye by Ihesu heuen kynge
¶ Gete me astaffe that I man vnderspore
Whyle that thou robyn heuest of the dore
He shall out of this studyenge as I gesse
And to the chambre dore he gan hym dresse
His knaue was a stronge churle for the nones
And by the haspe he haf it vp at ones
In to the floor the dore fell anone
¶ This nycholas sat ay as styll as stone
And euer gapyd vp warde in the ayre
¶ This carpenter wende þᵗat he were in dispeyr
And hente hym by the sholders myghtely
And shoke hym harde and cryed spytously
What nycholay what how loke a downe
Awake and thynke on cristys passyon
I crouche the fro eluys and fro wyghtis
Therwᵗith the nyghtspel sayd he anon ryghtis
On four halues on the hous abowte
And on the thressholde of the dore wythout
Ihesu crist and saynt benedyght
Blesse this hous from euery wyckyd wyghte
For nyghtes verry the wyght (pater noster)
Where wonnest thou saynt peters syster
¶ And at the last this hynde nycholas
Gan for to syghe sore and sayd alas
Shall all the worlde be loste eftsones now
¶ This carpenter answerde what sayst thou
What thynkon god as we do men that swynk
¶ This nycholas answerd fette me drynk
And after woll I speke to the in preuyte
Of certen thynges that towchen me and the
I woll tell it non other man certayn
¶ This carpenter goth doun ⁊and comyth again
And broughte of myghty ale a large quarte
And whan eche of hem hadde dronke his part
This nycholas his dore faste shette
And downe the carpenter by hym he sette
¶ He sayd Iohn myn hoste leue and dere
Thou shalt vpon thy trouth swere me here
That to no wyght þᵘ shalt this counsell wrey
For it is cristys counsell that I sey
And yf thou telle it man thou art forlore
For this vengaunce thou shalt haue therfore
That yf thou wreye it man shalt be wood
¶ Nay crist forbede it for his very blood
Quod tho this sely man I am no blabbe
Ne though I saye I am not leue to gabbe
Saye what thou wolt I shall it neuer telle
To chylde ne wyf by hym that harowed helle
¶ Now Iohn quod nycholas I woll not lye
I haue founde it in myn astrologye
As I haue lokyd in the mone bryght
That now a monday at quarter nyght
Shall falle a reyne and that so wylde ⁊and wood
That half so grete was neuer noes flood
Thus worlde he sayd in lesse than in an hour
Shall all be dreynt so hydous is the shour
This shall mankynde drenche and lese his lyf
¶ This carpenter answerde alas my wyf
And shall she drenche alas my alysoun
For sorowe of this he fell almost a doun
And sayd is ther no remedy in this caas
¶ Why yes for god quod hynde nycholas
Yf thou wolt werke after lore and rede
Thou mayst not werke after thyn owne hede
For thus sayth salamon that was full true
Werke all by counsell and thou shalt not rewe
And yf thou werke wylt by good counsayll
I vndertake wythouten mast or sayll
Yet shall I saue her and the and me
Hast thou not herde how saued was noe
Whan that our lorde had warned hym beforn
That all the worlde wyth water shold be lorn
¶ Yes quod this carpenter full yore ago
¶ Hast thou not herde quod nycholas also
The sorowe of noe wyth his felyshyp
Or that he myght gete his wyf to shyp
Hym had be leuer I dare well vndertake
At that tyme than all his wetheris blake
That she hadde had a shyp herself alone
And therfore wotest thou what is best to done
This askyth haste and of an hasty thynge
Maye men not preche ne make taryenge
Anon go gete vs faste in to this in
A knedynge trough or ellis a kemelyn
For eche of vs but loke that they be large
In whyche we mow swymmen as in a barge
And haue therin vytayll suffysaunt
But for o daye fye on the remenaunt
The water shall a slake and go awaye
Abowte pryme vpon the nexte daye
But robyn maye not wyte of this thy knaue
Ne eke thy mayden gylle I maye not saue
Axe not why for though thou aske me
I woll not telle goddys preuyte
It suffyseth the but yf thy wyt be mad
To haue as grete a grace as noe had
Thy wyf shall I well saue out of doute
Go now thy waye and spede the here abowte
¶ But whan thou hast for the ⁊and her and me
Y goten vs thyse knedynge tubbes thre
Then shalt thou heng hem in the roof full hye
That no man of our purueaunce espye
And whan thou thus hast don as I haue sayd
And hast our vytayll fayr in hem y layd
And eke an axe to smyte the corde a two
Whan that the water comyth that we may go
And breke an hole an hyghe vpon the gabyll
In to the gardyn warde ouer the stable
That we maye frely passe forth our waye
Whan that the grete shour is passyd awaye
¶ Then shal we swyme as merily I vndtake
As doth the whyte ducke after the drake
Then woll I clepe how alyson how Iohn
Be mery for the flodde wyll passe anon
And thou woll say hayll mayster nycholay
Good morow I se the well for it is daye
And thenne shall we be lordys all our lyf
Of all the worlde as noe and his wyf
But of o thynge I warne the full ryght
Be well auysed on that ylke nyght
Whan we be entryd in to the shyppe borde
That none of vs ne speke not a worde
Ne clepe ne crye but be in his prayere
For it is goddys owne hest dere
¶ Thy wyf and thou must hange fer a twyn
For that betwyx you shall be no synne
Nomore in lokynge than ther shall in dede
This ordenaunce is sayd goo god the spede
To morow at nyght whan folke be al a slepe
In to our knedynge tubbis woll we crepe
And sytten there abydynge goddys grace
Go now thy way I haue no lenger space
To make of this no lenger sermonynge
Men say thus sende the wyse ⁊and saye no thynge
Thou art so wyse it nedyth the not to teche
Goo saue our lyf and that I the beseche
¶ This sely carpenter goth forth his waye
Full oft he sayd alas and weleaway
But to his wyf he tolde this preuyte
And she was war and knewe it bet than he
What all this queynte cast was for to saye
But netheles she ferde as she woll deye
And sayd alas go forth thy way anon
Helpe vs to scape or we be ded echeon
I am thy true very weddyd wyf
Go dere spouse and helpe to saue our lyf
¶ Lo whyche a grete thynge is affeccyon
Men maye deye all daye of ymagynacyon
So depe may Impressyon be take
This sely carpenter begynneth quake
Hym thynketh veryly that he maye se
Noes flode come walowynge as the see
To drenchon alyson his hony dere
He wepyth waylleth and maketh sory chere
He syghed wyth many a sory swough
He goth and getyth hym a knedynge trough
And after that a tub and a kemelyn
And pyuely he sent hem to his In
And henge hem in the roof in preuyte
His owne honde he made ladders thre
To clymben by the rengys and the stalkes
Into the tubbes hangynge in the balkys
And hem vitaylleth both trough and tub
Wyth brede and chese and gode ale in a Iub
Suffysynge ryght ynough as for o daye
But or that he had made all that araye
He sent his knaue and eke his wenche also
Vp on his eronde to london for to go
And on the mondaye whan it drewe to nyght
He shytte his dore wythout candyll lyght
And dressyd all thyng as it sholde be
And shortly vp they clomben alle thre
They sytten stylle well a forlonge waye
Now (pater noster) clum sayd nycholay
And clum sayd Iohn and clum sayd alyson
This carpenter sayd his deuocyon
And styll he sytteth and byddeth his prayer
Awaytynge on the rayne yf he it her
¶ The deed slepe for wery besynesse
Fell on this carpenter ryght as I gesse
Abowte curfu tyme or lytyll more
For traueyll of the ghost he gronyth sore
And eft he rowtyth for his hed mys lay
¶ Downe of the ladder stalketh nycholay
And alyson full softe downe she spedde
Wythout wordes mo they go to bedde
Ther as the carpenter was wont to lye
There was the reuell and the melodye
And thus lyeth alyson and nycholas
In besynesse of myrthe and in solas
Tyll that the belle of laudes gan to rynge
And freres in the chauncell gan to synge
¶ This parysshe clerke this amerous absolon
That is for loue alwaye so wo begon
Vp on the monday was at oseney
Wyth companye hym to dysport and pley
And askyd vp on a caas a cloysterer
Full preuely after Iohn the carpenter
And he drewe hym a part out of the chyrche
And sayd I note I sawe hym not werche
Syth saterday I trowe that he be went
For tymbre ther our abbot hath hym sent
For he is wont for tymbre for to go
And dwelle at the graunge a daye or two
Or ellis he is at his hous certayn
Where that he be I can not sothly sayn
¶ This absolon full Ioly was and lyght
And thought now tyme is to walke all nyght
For sykerly I sawe hym not sterynge
Abowte his dore syn day gan to sprynge
¶ So mote I thryue I shall or cockys crowe
Pryuely knocken at his wyndowe
That stont ful lowe vp on his bowrys wall
To alyson now woll I tellen all
My loue longynge for yet I shall not mys
That at the leest waye I shall her kysse
Som maner comfort shall I haue parfay
My mouth hath ytched all this longe daye
That is a sygne of kyssynge at the leest
All nyghte me mette eke I was at a feest
Therfor I woll go slepe an hour or tweye
And all the nyght then woll I walke or pleye
¶ Whan that the fyrst cok hath crowe anon
Vp ryseth this Ioly louer absolon
And hym arayeth gaye at poynt deuyse
But fyrst he chewyth grayn and lycoryse
To smelle swete or he had kempte his heere
Vnder his tonge a true loue he beere
For therby wende he to haue be gracyous
He rometh to the carpentars hous
And stylle he stont vnder the shot wyndow
Vnto his brest it raught it was so lowe
And softe he cowchyth wyth a semy sowne
What do ye honycombe swete alysowne
My fayr byrde my swete synamome
Awakyth lemman myn and speke to me
Full lytyll thynke ye vp on my woo
That for your loue I swete there I goo
No wonder is though I swelte and swete
I morne as doth a lamb after the tete
Iwys lemman I haue suche loue longynge
That lyke a turtyll true is my mornynge
I maye not ete nomore than a mayde
¶ Go fro the wyndow Iacke fole she sayd
As helpe me god it woll not be combame
I loue a nother and elles I were to blame
Well bet than the by Ihesu absolon
Go forth thy waye or I woll throwe a ston
And let me slepe a twenty deuyll waye
¶ Alas quod absolon and well awaye
That true loue was euer so euyll be set
Then skys me syn it may be no bet
For Ihesus loue and for the loue of me
¶ Wylt þᵘ then go thy way therwyth quod she
¶ Ye certys lemman quod this absolon
¶ Then make the redy quod she I come anon
And vnto nycholas she sayd stylle
Now peas and thou shalt laugh all thy fylle
This absolon downe set hym on his knees
And sayd I am a lorde at all degrees
For after this I hope ther comyth more
Lemman thy grace and swete byrde thyn ore
¶ The wyndowes she vndoth ⁊and that in haste
Haue do quod she come of and spede the faste
Lest that our neyghbours the aspye
¶ This absolon gan wipe his mouth full drye
Derke was the nyght as pytche or cole
And at the wyndowe she put out her hole
And absolon hym felte ne bet ne wars
But wyth his mouth he kyst her ars
Full sauerly or he were ware of this
¶ Abak he stert and thought it was amys
Full well wyste he a woman had no berde
He felt a thynge all rough and long heryd
And sayde fye alas what haue I do
¶ Tehe quod she and clappid the wyndow to
And absolon goth forth a sory pas
¶ A berde a berde sayd hynde nycholas
By goddis corpus this goth fayr and wele
¶ This sely absolon herde euery dele
And on his lyppe he gan for angre byte
And to hym self he sayd I shall the quyte

¶ Who rubbyth now who frotith now his lyp
pis
Wyth dust wᵗith cloth wyth sond wᵗith chippis
But absolon that sayth full ofte alas
My soule betake I sayd he to sathanas
But me were leuer than all this towne quod he
On this dispyte awroken for to be
¶ Alas quod he alas ne that I had blent
His hote loue was colde and all queynt
For fro that tyme that he had kyst her ars
Of paramours set he not a cars
For he was helyd of his maladye
Full ofte paramours gan he dyffye
And wepte as doth a chylde that is bete
A softe paas he went hym ouer the strete
Vnto a smyth men callyd dane gerueys
That in his forge smyteth plow harneys
He sharpith the share and the cultre besily
This absolon knocketh all esely
And sayd vndo geruays and that anon
¶ What who art thou / it am I absolon
What absolon / what cristys swete tree
Why ryse ye so rathe / ey benedicitee
What eyleth you some gaye gyrle god it wote
Hath broughte you thus vpon the verytote
By saynt note / ye wote what I mene
¶ This absolon ne rought not a bene
Of all this playe agayn no worde he yaf
He had well more towe on his dystaf
Then geruays knewe and sayd frende so dere
That hote cultre in thy chymney here
As lene it me I haue therwyth to doon
I woll brynge it the agayn full soon
¶ Geruays answerde / certes were it golde
Or in a poke nobyls all vntolde
Thou sholdest it haue as I am true smyth
Ey cristys fote what woll ye do therwyth
¶ Therfore quod absolon be as be may
I shall well telle it the to morowe or daye
And caughte the cultre by the colde stele
And softe out of the dore he gan stele
And wente vnto the carpenteris walle
He coughed fyrst and knocked therwyth alle
Vp on the wyndowe ryght as he dyde ere
¶ This alyson answerde who is there
That knockyth so I warant it a thef
¶ Why nay quod he god wote my swete lef
I am absolon thyn owne derlynge
Of gold quod he I haue the broughte a rynge
My moder yaue it me so god me saue
Full fyne it is and therto well y graue
