This woll I geue the yf thou me kysse
¶ This nycholas was rysen for to pysse
And thoughte he wolde amende all the Iape
Hesholde kysse his ars or that he scape
And vp the wyndowe dyde he hastely
And out his ars he puttyth preuely
Ouer the buttok to the shank boon
And therwyth spak this clerke absolon
Spek swete bryd I note where thou art
¶ This nycholas anon let fle a fart
As gret as it had be a thonder dent
That wyth the stroke he was almost y blent
And he was redy wyth his yren hote
And nycholas amyd the ars he smote
¶ Of goth the skyn an honde brode abowte
The hote cultre brent so his towte
And for the smert he went for to dye
As he were wood for wo he gan crye
Help water water helpe for goddys hert
This carpenter out of his slombre stert
And herde one crye water as he were wood
And thoughte alas now comyth the flood
He set hym vp wythout wordes mo
And wyth his axe he smote the corde atwo
And downe goth all he fonde neyther to selle
Ne brede ne ale tyll he come to the selle
Vp on the flour and there aswoun he lay
¶ Vp stert her alyson and nycholay
And cryed out and harow in the strete
The neyghbours bothe smale and grete
In ronnen for to gawryn on this man
That yet a swonn laye bothe pale and wan
For wyth the falle broste hath he his arme
But stonde he must vnto his owne harme
For whan he spake he was anon bore downe
Wyth hynde nycholas and alysowne
They tolde eueri man that he was wood
So was he agast of noes flood
Thorugh fantasye that of his vanyte
He hadde boughte hym knedynge-tubbes thre
And hadde hem hanged in the roof aboue
And that he prayde hem for goddis loue
To sytten in the roof per companye
¶ The folke gan laughen at his fantasye
In to the roof they kyken and they gape
And torned all his harme in to a Iape
For what so euer this carpenter answerde
It was for nought no man his reson herde
Wyth othes grete he wasswore a doun
That he was holde wood in all the toun
For euery clerke ryght anon helde wyth other
They said þᵉ man was wood my leue brother
And euery wyght gan laugh at this stryf
¶ Thus swyued was the carpentars wyf
For all his kepynge and all his Ielowsye
And absolon hath kyssed her nether eye
And nycholas is scalded in the towte
This tale is done and god saue all the rowte

And here begynneth the reues
prologue
Whan folke had laughe at this nyce caas
Of absolon and of hynde nycholas
Dyuerse folke dyuersly they sayden
But for the more part thei lough and playden
Ne at this tale I sawe no man hym greue
But yf it were only oswolde the reue
By cause he was of carpentaris craft
A lytyll yre is in his herte there laft
He gan to grutche and blame it a lyte
¶ Sy the quod he full well I cowde the quyte
Wyth bleryng of a prowde myllars eye
Yf that me lyst to speke of rybawdrye
But I am olde me lyst not playe for aege
Gras tyme is doon my foder is now forage
This whyte top wryteth myn olde yeres
Myn hert also moulyd as myn heere is
But yet I fare as doth an open ers
For that ylke fruyt is euer lenger the wers
Tyll it be rotyn in mullok or in stre
¶ We olde men I drede so faren we
Tyll we be rotyn can we not be rype
We hoppyn alway whyle the world wold pype
For in our wyll ther stycketh euer a nayll
To haue an hoore heed and a grene tayll
As hath a leke for though our myght be gon
Our wyll desyreth foly euer in on
For whān we may nouȝt do then wol we speken
Yet in our asshen olde fyre is reken
¶ Four gledys haue we whyche I shall deuyse
Auauntynge lyenge angre and couetyse
Thyse four sparcles longeth vnto elde
Our olde lymmes mow we not be welde
But wyll ne shall not faylle that is soth
Aud yet haue I alwaye a coltys toth
As many a yere as it is passyd henne
Sen that my tappe of lyf began to renne
For sykerly whan I was born anone
Deth drewe the tappe of lyf and lete it gone
And euer syth hath so the tappe ronne
Tyll that almost all empty is the tonne
The streme of lyf now droppyth on þᵉ chymbe
The sely tonge maye well rynge and chymbe
Of wretchydnesse that past is full yore
Wyth olde folke saue dotage ther is nomore
¶ Whan þᵗat our hoste had herd this sermonyng
He gan to speken as lordly as a kynge
And sayd what amountyth all this wyt
What sholl we speke all daye of holy wryt
The deuyll made a reue for to preche
Or of a sowter a shypman or a leche
¶ Say forth thy tale and tary not the tyme
Lo depford and it is half way to pryme
Lo grenewych that many a shrewe is inne
It were all tyme thy tale to begynne
¶ Now syres quod this oswolde the reue
I praye you all that ye you not greue
Though þᵗat I answere ⁊and somdele set hishouue
For lefull is wyth force / force of shoue
¶ This dronken myllar hath tolde vs heer
How that begyled was a carpentere
Perauenture in scorn for that I am one
And by your leue I shall hym quyte anone
Ryght in his churlys termes woll I speke
I praye to god his necke mow to breke
He can well in myn eye se a stalke
But in his owe he can not se a balke
Here endyth the reues prologue
And here begynneth his tale
AT trompynton not fer fro cambryge
Ther goth a broke ⁊and ouer that a bryge
Vpōn þᵉ whiche broke ther stont a mylle
And this is very soth that I you telle
A myllar was there dwellynge many a daye
As ony pecok he was proude and gaye
Pype he cowde and fysshe and nettes bete
And torne cuppes and well wrastyll and shete
Ay by his belt he bare a longe pauade
And of a swerde full trenchant was the blade
A Ioly popper bare he in his powche
Ther was noman for peryll durste hȳm towche
A sheffelde thwytell bare he in his hose
Round was his face ⁊and camoysed was his nose
Also pylled as an ape was his skulle
He was a market beter at the full
Ther durste no wyght honde vp on hym ledge
That he ne swore anon he sholde abedge
A thef he was forsothe of corn and mele
And that a slygh and vsant for to stele
His name was y hote deynus symkyn
A wyf he hadde y comen of noble ky
The person of the towne her fader was
Wyth her he yaue many a panne of bras
For that synkyn sholde in his blood alye
She was y frostryd in a nonnerye
For synkyn wolde no wyfe as he sayde
But yf she were well y nourysshed and a mayde
To saue his astate of yemanrye
And she was proude and pert as a pye
A full fayr syght was vpon hem two
On holy daye beforn her wold he go
Wyth his typet ybounde abowte his hed
And she came after in a gyte of red
And symkyn hadde hosen of the same
Ther durst no wyght clepe her but dame
Was non so hardy that went by the waye
That wyth her durst ones rage or playe
But yf he wolde be slayn of symkyn
Wyth spauade or wyth knyf or bodekyn
For Ielous folke ben parlous euermo
Algates they wolde her wyues wenden so
And eke also for she was somdele smotterlych
She was as dygne as water in a dych
And full of hocour and of bysmare
Her thoughte a lady sholde her spare
What for her kynrede and her nortylrye
That she had lerned in the nonerye
¶ A doughter had they betwyx hem two
Of twenty yere wythoute ony mo
Sauynge a chylde þᵗat was of half yere aege
In cradyll it lay and was a propre page
This wenche thycke and well y growe was
Wyth camoys nose and eyen greye as glas
Buttockes brode and brestis rounde and hye
But ryght fayr was her heere I woll not lye
¶ The person of the towne for she was feyr
In purpos was to make her his heyr
Bothe of his catell and of his mesuage
And straunge he made it of her maryage
His purpos was for to bestowe her hye
Vnto some worthy bloode of auncetry
For holy chyrche goodes muste be spended
On holy chyrche blode that is descended
Therfore he wolde his holy blode honoure
Though that he holy chyrche sholde deuoure
¶ Gret sokyn hath this myllar out of doute
Wyih whete ⁊and malte of all the londe abowte
And namely ther was a gret college
Men clepyth it the soler halle at Cambrege
Ther was her whete ⁊and eke her malt y groıı̄unde
On a daye it happed in a stounde
Syke laye the mancyple on a malady
Men wende wysly that he sholde dy
Fro whom this myllar stale bothe mele ⁊and corn
An hundryd tyme more than he dyde beforn
For there before he stale but curtesly
But now he was a theyf outrageously
For whyche the wardeyn chydde ⁊and made fare
But therof set this myllar not a tare
He craked boste and swore it was not so
¶ Then were there yonge scolers two
That dweldyn in this halle of whyche I say
Testyf they were and lusty forto play
And only for her myrthe and reuelrye
Vp on the warden besyly they crye
To yeue hem leue but a lytyll stounde
To go to the mylle and se her corn y grounde
And hardily they durste laye her necke
The myllar shold not stele half a pecke
Of corne by sleyghte ne bi force hem reue
And at the laste the wardeyn yaf hem leue
Iohn hyght that one ⁊and aleyn hyȝt that other
Of a towne were they born that hyghte stroder
Fer in the north I can not telle where
¶ This aleyn makyth redy alle his gere
And on an hors the sackys he cast anon
Forth goth aleyn the clerke and eke Iohn
Wyth good swerde and bokeler by his syde
Iohn knewe the waye hym neded no to gyde
And at the mylle the sak a downe he leyth
¶ Aleyn spake fyrst al hayl symonde in feyth
How farys thy fayr doughter and thy wyf
¶ Aleyn welcome quod symkyn by my lyf
And Iohn also how now what do ye here
¶ Symōnd quod Iohn by god nede has no pere
Hym bus serue hym self that has no swayn
Or elles he is a fuole as clerkes sayn
Our mauncyple hope I he woll be ded
Swa workis ay there wangis in his hed
And therfor I is come and this aleyn
To grynde our corn and cary it heme agay
I praye you spede vs heme in that ye maye
¶ It shall be do quod symkyn by my fay
What wyll ye do whyles it is in honde
By god ryght by the holper woll I stonde
Quod Iohn and se how the corn goos in
Yet sawe I neuer by my fader kyn
How the hopper waggys to and fro
¶ Aleyn answerd Iohn wylt thou so
Then woll I be byneth by my crowne
And se how the mele fallys downe
In to the trough that shall be my disport
For Iohn in fayth I may be of your sort
I is as ylle a myllare as is ye
¶ The myllar smyled of her nycete
And thought all this is don but for a wyle
They wene that no man maye hem begyle
But by my thryfte yet shall I blere her eye
For al her sleyghte and her phylosophye
The more queynte crekys that they make
The more shall I stele whan I take
In stede of flouur yet woll I yeue hem bren
The grettest clerkes be not the wysest men
As whylom to the wulf thus spak the mare
Of alle her art ne counte I not a tare
¶ Out at the dore he goth full preuely
Whan that he sawe his tyme softly
He lokyth vp and downe tyll he hath founde
Thyse clerkes hors where it stode y bounde
Behynde the mylle vnder a leefsell
And to the hors he goth fayr and well
He strypeth of the brydyll ryght anon
¶ And whan the hors was loos he gan to gon
Toward the fenne where wylde marys renne
Forth wyth wehy thrugh thycke and thynne
This myllar goth ayen no worde he sayde
But doth his note ⁊and wyth the clerkes playde
Tyll that her corn was fayr and wel grounde
And whan the mele is sackyd and bounde
This Iohn goth forth ⁊and fynt her hors awaye
And gan to crye harrow and well awaye
Our hors is lost aleyn by cockys banys
Stepe on thy fete come of man alle at anys
Alas our wardeyn hath his palfraye lorn
¶ This aleyn all forgate both mele and corn
All was out of mynde his husbondrye
What whylke waye is he gon he gan crye
¶ The wyf came rennyng Inward at a renne
She sayd allas your hors gooth to fenue
Wyth wylde marys / as faste as he may go
Vnthanke come on his honde þᵗat bond hym so
And he that better sholde haue knyt the reyne
¶ Alas quod Iohn alas for crystis peyne
Ley downe thy swerde and I woll myn alswa
I is full swyfte / god wote as is a raa
By goddys sale he shall not escape vs bathe
Why ne had thou put the capyll in the lathe
Ille hayll by god aleyn thou is a fonne
¶ Thyse sely clerkes haue well fast y ronne
Toward the fenne hothe aleyn and eke Iohn
And whan the myllar sawe they were goon
He half a busshell of her flowur hath take
And bad his wyf go knede it in a cake
He sayd I trowe the clerkes were a ferde
Yet can a myllar make a clerkes berde
For all her art yet lete hem goo her waye
Lo where he gon so lete the chyldren playe
They get hym nought so lyȝtly by my crowne
Thyse sely clerkes rennen vp and downe
Wyth kepe kepe stonde stond Iossa ware derere
Gea whystle þᵘou thare and I shall kepe hȳm here
But shortly tyll it was veryly nyght
They cowde not thouȝ they dyde all her myȝt
Her capyll catche he ranne alwaye so faste
Tyll in a dyche they caughte hym at the laste
¶ Wery and wete as best is in the rayn
Comyth Iohn þᵉ clerke ⁊and wyth hȳm came aleyn
Alas quod Iohn the daye that I was born
Now are we dryuen to hethynge and to scorn
Our corn is stole men wyll vs foles calle
Bothe the wardeyn and our felowes alle
And namely the myllar wel a waye
Thus playneth Iohn as he goth by the waye
Towarde the mylle and bayarde in his honde
¶ The myllar syttynge by the fyre he fonde
For it was nyght ⁊and ferther myght they nought
But for the loue of god they hym besought
Of herborugh and of ese as for her peny
The myllar sayd agayn yf ther be ony
Suche as it is yet shall ye haue your part
Myn hous is streyght but ye haue lernyd ar
Ye can by argumentes maken a place
A myle brode of tWenty fote of space
Let se now yf this place woll suffyse
Or make it romer with speche as is your gyse
¶ Now symond sayd this Iohn by saynt cuthberd
Ay is þᵘou mery and that is well answerd
I haue herd say men shal take of twa thȳnges
Swylk as he fyndes or swylk as he brynges
But specyally I pray the hoste so dere
Gete vs som mete ⁊and drynke ⁊and make vs chere
And we woll paye truely at the full
With empti hondes men may not hawkis tull
Lo here my syluer redy for to spende
¶ This myllar to þᵉ towne his doughter sende
For ale and brede and rostyd hem a goos
And bonde her hors he sholde nomore go loos
And in his owne chambre he made a bed
Wyth shetes and wyth chalons fayre y spred
Not from his owne bed ten fote or twelue
His doughter had a bed all by her selue
Ryght in the same chambre by and by
It myght be no bet and cause why
Ther was no romer herberow in the place
They suppen and speken hem of solace
And dronken ener stronge atte beste
Abowte mydnyghte went they to reste
¶ Wel hath this myllar vernysshed his hed
Full pale he was for dronke and not red
He yexith and he spekyth thorugh the nose
As he were in the quacke or in the pose
To bedde he goth ⁊and wyth hym goth his wyf
As ony Iay was she lyght and Iolyf
So was her Ioly whystyll well y wet
The cradyll at her beddys fete was fet
To rockyn and to geue the chylde sucke
And whan that dawkyn was in the crucke
To bedde wente the doughter ryght anone
To bedde goth aleyn and also Iohn
Ther nas nomore ther nedeth hem no dwale
This myllar hath so wysely bybbed ale
That as an hors he fnortyth and slepe
Ne of his tayll behynde he toke no kepe
His wyf bare hym a burden a full stronge
Men myghte her rowtynge here a furlonge
The wenche rowtyd eke per company
¶ Aleyn the clerke that herde this melody
He powkyd Iohn and sayd slepest thou
Herdest thou euer syke a songe or now
Lo whylke a cowplynge is a twene hem alle
A wylde fyre vpon her bodyes falle
Who herde euer syke a ferly thynge
Ye they shall haue the floure of yll endynge
This longe nyght ther tyd me ne reste
But yet ne force all shall be for the beste
For Iohn sayd aleyn also mot I thryue
Yf that I may yon wenche woll I swyue
Som esement hath lawe shapen vs
For Iohn ther is a lawe that sayth thus
That yf a man in o thynge be agreued
That in a nother he shall be releuyd
Our corn is stole sothly it is no naye
And we haue had an euyll fytte to daye
And syn I shall haue non amendement
Agayns my losse I woll haue esement
By goddys sale it shall non other be
¶ This Iohn answerde aleyn auyse the
The myllar is a perlous man he sayd
And yf that he out of his slepe brayd
He myght do vs bethe a vilonye
¶ Aleyn answerde I counte hym not a flye
And vp he rose and by the wenche he crept
This wenche laye vpryght and fast slept
Tyll he so ny was or she myght aspye
That it had be to late for to crye
And shortly for to telle they were attone
Now play aleyn for I woll speke of Iohn
¶ This Iohn lyeth styll a forlongway or two
And to hym self he made ruthe and wo
Alas qnod he this is a wycked Iape
Now maye I saye that I is but an ape
Yet hath my felowe somwhat for his harme
He hath the myllars doughter in his arme
He auntred hym and hath his nedes spedde
And I lye as a draf sak in my bedde
And whan this Iape is tolde a nother day
I shall be hold a daffe a cokenay
I woll aryse and auntre it by my fayth
Vnhardy is vnsely thus men sayth
¶ And vp he roos and softly he went
Vnto the cradyll and in his arm it hen
And bare it softe vnto his beddys fete
Sone after the wyf her rowtynge lete
And gan a wake and wente her out to pysse
And cam ayen and gan her cradyll mysse
And gropyd here and there but she fonde non
Alas quod she I hadde almost mysgon
I hadde almost goon to the clerkys bed
Ey benedicite than hadde I fowle sped
And forth she goth tyll she the cradyll fonde
She gropyth alwaye ferther wyth her honde
And fond the bed and thought not but good
By cause that the cradyll by it stood
And nyst where she was for it was derke
But fayr and well she crepte vnto the clerke
And lyth full styll ⁊and wold haue caught a slepe
Wythin a whyle this Iohn vp lepe
And on this good wyf he layeth on sore
So mery a fytte ne hadde not she ful yore
He prickyd harde and sore as he were mad
This Ioly lyf haue thyse two clerkes lad
Tyll that the thyrde cok began to synge
¶ Aleyn wext wery in the dawnynge
For he had swonken all the longe nyght
And sayd fare well malyn swete wyght
The daye is come I may no lenger byde
Yet euermore where so I go or ryde
I am thyn owne clerke so haue I hele
¶ Now dere lemman quod she go fare well
But or thou go o thynge I woll the telle
Whan that þᵘou wendest homwarde by the melle
Ryght at entre of the dore behynde
Thou shalt a cake of half a busshell fynde
That was made of thyn owne mele
Whyche that I halpe my syre for to stele
And good lemman god the saue and kepe
And wyth that worde almost she gan to wepe
¶ Aleyn vp ryst and thought or that it dawe
I woll go crepe in by my felowe
And fonde the cradyll wyth his honde anon
By god thoughte he all wronge haue I gon
My hed is toty of my swynk to nyght
That maketh me that I go not a ryght
I wote well by the cradyll I haue mys go
Here lyeth the myllar and his wyf also
And forth he goth a twenty deuyll waye
In to the bed there the myllare laye
He wende haue cropen in by his felowe Iohn
And by the myllar in he crept anon
And caught hym by the necke and softe spake
He sayd thou Iohn thou swyneshede awake
For cristys soule and here a noble game
For by that lorde that callyd is saynt Iame
As I haue thries in this short nyght
Swyuyd the myllars doughter bolt vpryght
Whyles thou hast as a cowarde be agast
¶ Ye false harlot quod the myllar hast
A fals traytour fals clerke quod he
Thou shalt be ded by goddys dygnyte
Who durst be so bolde to dysperage
My doughter that is of suche lygnage
And by the throte bolle he caughte aleyn
And he hente hym dispytously agayn
And on the nose he smot hym wyth his fyst
Downe ran the blody streme vpon his brest
And in the floor wᵗith the nose ⁊and mouth to kroke
They walowed as pygges don in a poke
And vp they goon and downe ayen anon
Tyll that the myllar sporued at a stoon
And downe he fell bakward on his wyf
That wyst no thyng of this nyce stryf
For she was falle a slepe a lytyll wyght
Wyth Iohn the clerke þᵗat wakyd had all nyght
And wyth the fall out of her slepe she brayd
Help holy crosse of bromehom she sayd
In manus tuas to the lord I calle
Awake symond the fende is on me falle
Myn herte is broken helpe I am but ded
There lyeth one on my wombe and on my hed
Help symkyn for the fals clerkes fyghte
This Iohn stert vp as faste as he myghte
And graspyd by the walles to and fro
To fynde a staf and she stert vp also
And knewe the efters bet than dyde this Iohn
And by the wall a staf she toke anon
And sawe a lytyll shymerynge of a lyghte
For at an hole in shone the mone brighte
And by that lyght she sawe hem bothe two
But sykerly she nyst who was who
And as she sawe a whyte thynge in her eye
And whan she gan this whyte thynge aspy
She wende the clerke hadde weryd a volupere
And wyth the staf she drewe aye nere and nere
And haue hyt this aleyn at the full
And smote the myllar on the pylled skull
And downe he goth and cryed harow I dye
The clerkes bete hym well and lete hym lye
And greyden hem and toke her hors anon
And eke her mele and on her way they gon
And at mylle dore yet they toke her cake
Of half a busshell flowur well y bake
Thus is the prowde myllar well y bete
And hath lost the gryndynge of the whete
And payd for the supper euerydell
Of aleyn and of Iohn that bete hym well
His wyf is swyued and his doughter als
Lo suche it is a myllar to be fals
And therto this prouerbe is sayd full soth
Hym dare not wene well that euyll doth
A gylour shall hym self begyled be
And god that syt hyghe in mageste
Saue all this companye grete and smale
Thus haue I quyt the myllar in my tale
Here endyth the reues tale
And begynneth the cokys prologe
THe coke of london whyle the reue spak
For Ioy he thouȝt he clawed hȳm on þᵉ bak
A ha quod he for cristys owne passyon
This myllar hath a sharpe conclusyon
Vpon his argument of herbegage
Well soth sayd salamon in his langage
Ne brynge not euery man in thy hous
For herberowyng by nyght is perlous
Well ought a man auysed for to be
Whom that he brynge in to his pryuyte
I pray to god so yeue me sorowe and care
Yf euer syth that I hyght hodge of ware
Herd I myllar bet y set a werke
He hadde a Iape of malyce in the derke
But god forbede that we stynten here
And therfore yf ye wouchesauf to here
A tale of me that am a poore man
I woll you tell as well as I can
A lytyll Iape that fell in our cyte
¶Our hoste answerde ⁊and sayd I graunt it the
Now telle on roger loke that it be good
For many a pasty hast thou lete blode
And many a Iacke of douer hast thou solde
That had be twyes hote and twyes colde
Of many a pylgrym hast thou cristys curs
For of thy persely yet fare they the wors
That they haue eten wyth the stubbed goos
For in thy shop is many a flye loos
Now tell on gentyll roger by thy name
But I praye the be not wroth for game
A man may say full soth in game and play
¶Thou sayst soth sayd roger by my faye
But soth play quade play as þᵉ flemyng sayth
And therfore harry bally by thy fayth
Be thou not wroth ar we departen here
Though that my tale be of an hostyllere
But netheles I woll not telle it yet
But or we depart ywis thou shalt be quyt
And therwyth all he lough and made chere
And sayd his tale as ye shall after here
Here endyth the cokys prologe
And here begynneth his tale
A Prentis whylom dwelt in our cyte
Of crafte of vytayllers was he

As gaylard he was as goldfynche in þᵉ
shawe
Broun as a bery a propre short felawe
Wyth lockes y kembyd full fetously
Daunce he cowde well and Iolyly
Then he was clepyd perkyn reuelour
He was as full of loue and paramour
As is the hyue full of hony swete
Wel was the wenche þᵗat wyth hym myght slepe
And at euery brydale wolde he synge ⁊and hoppe
He louid better the nether ende than the shoppe
For whan there ony rydynge was in chepe
Out of the shoppe thyder wolde he lepe
Tyll that he hadde all the syght y seen
And daunsed wel he wolde not come ayen
And gadryd hym a meyne of his sorte
To hoppe and synge and make suche disporte
And there they sette steuene for to mete
To playn at the dyse in suche a strete
For in the towne was there no prentyse
That fayrer cowde caste a payre of dyse
Than perkyn cowde and therto he was free
Of his dispence in place of preuytee
That fonde his mayster well in his chaffare
For oftyme he fonde his boxe full bare
For shortly a prentis that is a reuelour
That hauntyth dyse ryot and paramour
His mayster shall it in his shoppe abye
All haue he no part of the mynstralsye
For thefte and ryot they be conuertyble
All can he playe on gytterne or rybyble
Reuell and trouthe as in a lowe degre
They be full wroth aldaye as men maye se
¶This Ioly prenstis wyth his mayster stode
Tyll he was nere out of his prentishode
All were he snybbed bothe erly and late
And somtyme lad wyth reuell to newgate
But at laste his mayster hym bethoughte
On a daye whan he his paper soughte
Vpon a prouerbe that sayth this same worde
Well bet is rotyn apple oute of horde
Than that he roteth all the remenaunt
So faryth it by a ryotous seruaunt
It is full lasse harme to late hym pace
Than he sholde all the seruauntis in the plac
Therfore his mayster yaf hym a quytaunce
And bad him go wyth sorowe and myschaıı̄unce
And thus this Ioly prentis had his leue
Now let hym ryot all the nyghte or leue
¶And for ther is no theyf wythout a lowke
That helpyth hym to waste and to sowke
Of that he brybe can or borow may
Anon he sent his bed and his aray
Vnto a compyere of his owne sorte
That loueth dyse ryot and dysporte
And hadde a wyf that helde for countenannce
A shop and swyued for her sustenaunce

OVr host sawe well þᵗat by the bryght sonne
The ark of his artifyciall day had rōnne
The fourth part and half an houre and more
And though he were not deppest stert in lore
He wyste well it was the xviij day
Of aprill that is messenger to may
And sawe well that the shadow of euery tre
Was as in lengthe of the same quantyte
That was the body erect that causyd it
And therfore by the shadowe he toke his wyt
That phebus whyche þᵗat shon so clere ⁊and bryght
Degrees was xlv clomben on heyght
And for that daye as in latitude
It was ten of the clocke he gan conclude
And sodenly he plyght his hors abowte
¶ Lordynges quod he I warne you all þˢ rowte
The fourth part of this daye is goon
Now for the loue of god and saynt Iohn
Lese no tyme as ferforth as ye maye
Lordynges the tyme wastith both nyght ⁊and day
And stelyth fro vs what preuely slepyng
And what thrugh neclygence in our wakynge
As doth the streme that turneth neuer agayn
Descendyng fro the mountayn in to the playn
Well can senek and many a phylosopher
Bewayles tyme more than golde in cofer
For losse of catell maye recoueryd be
But losse of tyme shendyth vs quod he
It wyll not come ayen wythouten drede
Nomore than woll malkynes maydenhede
Whan that she hath lost it in her wantonnesse
Let vs not mollen thus in ydylnesse
Syre yre man of lawe quod he so haue ye blys
Tell vs a tale anon as forward is
Ye be submytted thrugh your fre assent
To stonde in this caas at my Iugement
Acquyte you now of your beheste
Than haue ye do your deuoyr at leest
¶ Hoost quod he depardieux Ic assent
To breke forwarde is not myn entent
Beheste is dette and I wolde hold fayn
Alle my behest I can no better sayn
For suche lawe as man geuyth a nother wyght
He sholde hym self vse it by ryght
Thus woll our text but netheles certeyn
I can ryght now no thryfty tale sayn
That chaucer though he can but lewdly
On metris and on rymynge craftely
Hath sayd hem in suche englyssh as he can
Of olde tyme as knoweth many a man
And yf he ne hath sayd hem leue brother
In o boke he hath sayd hem in a nother
For he hath tode of louers vp and doun
Mo than ouyde made of mencyoun
In his epistles that ben full olde
What shold I telle hem syth they be tolde
In yongth he made of ceys and alcyon
And syth he hath spoken of euerychon
Thyse noble wyues ⁊and thyse noble louers eke
Who so that woll his large volume seke
Clepyd the sayntis lyues of cupyde
Ther may he se the large woundis wyde
Of lucrece and of babylone tysbe
The swerd of dydo for the fals enee
The tree of phylles for her demophon
The playnte of dyanere and of hermyon
Of adryane and eke of ysiphyle
The bareyn yle stondynge in the see
The dreyent lyandre for his erro
The terys of eleyne and eke the wo
Of Briseyde and of ladomea
The cruelte of the quene medea
The lytyll chyldren hangyng by the hals
For thy Iason that was of loue so fals
Empyrmysta penelope and alceste
Your wyfhode cōmmendynge wyth the beste
¶ But certenly no worde ne wryteth he
Of that wycked ensample of canace
That loued her owne brother synfully
Of whyche cursyd storyes I saye fy
Or elles of tyrus appolonyus
How that the cursyd kynge anthiochus
Beraft his doughter of her maydenhede
That is so horryble a tale for to rede
Whan he her threwe vpon the pament
And therfore he full of auysement
Wlode neuer wryte in none of his sermons
Of suche vnkynde abhomynacyons
Ne I wyll none reherce yf that I maye
But of my tale what sholde do this daye
Me were full loth be lykned doutles
To myses that men clepe pyerides
Methamorphoseos wote what I mene
But netheles I recke not a bene
They I come after hym wyth hawe y bake
I speke in prose and lete hym rymes make
And wyth that worde he wyth a sobre chere
Began his tale as ye shull after here

l.hi:
Here endyth the man of lawe prologue
And here begynneth his tale

fw.hi:
Here endyth the man of lawe prologue
And here begynneth his tale

div.l: O Hatefull harm condicyon of pouert
With thryst / cold ⁊and hungre so cofounded
To asken help the shamyth in thyn hert
Yf thou none aske with nede art þᵘ so wounded

That very nede vnwrappyth al thy woundes
byd
Magre thyn hed þᵘ must for Indigence
Or stele or begge or borow thyn dispence
Thou blamyst crist and sayst full bytterly
He mys departyth ryches temporall
Thyn neyghbour thou wyttest synfully
And sayst thou hast to lyte and he hath all
Parfay sayst thou somtyme he reken shall
Whan that his tayll shall brenne in the glede
For he not helpyth the nedfull in her nede
Herke what is the sentence of the wyse
Bet is to deye than to haue Indygence
Thy self neyghbour woll the dispyse
Yf thou be poore farewell thy reuerence
Yet of the wyseman take this sentence
That al the dayes of poore men ben wycke
Beware therfore or thou come to the prycke
Yf thou be poore thy brother hatyth the
And all thy frendes fle fro the alas
O ryche marchauntes full of wele ye be
O noble o prudent folke as in this caas
Your bagges be not fylled wyth ambes aas
But sys synk that rennyth in your chaunce
At crystmasse mery mowe ye daunce
Ye seken londe and see for your wynnynges
And as wyse folke ye knowe all the state
Of regnys ye ben faders of tydynges
And talys bothe of peas and of debate
I were ryght now of a tale desolate
Nere that a marchaunt gon is many a yere
Me taught a tale the whyche that ye shal here
IN surry whylom dwellyd a companye
Of chapmen riche and therto sad ⁊and treue
That wyde where senten theyr spycery
Clothes of golde and saten riche of hewe
Her chaffare was so trusty and so newe
That euery wyght hath deynte to chaffare
Wyth hem and eke to sellen hem her ware
Now fyll it that the maysters of the sort
Haue shapen hem to rome for to wende
Were it for chapmanhode or for disport
None other message wolde they thyder sende
But cam hemself to rome this is the ende
And in suche place as thoughte hem auantage
For her entent they taken her herbygage
Soiorned haue thyse marchantes in that toun
A certen tyme as fell for her plesaunce
But so befell that the excellent renoun
Of the emperours doughter dame custaunce
Reportyd was wyth euery cyrcumstaunce
Vnto thyse surryens marchaıı̄untis in suche wise
Fro daye to daye as I shall you deuyse
This was the comyn voys of euery man
Our emperour of rome god hym se
A doughter hath that syth the worlde began
To reken as well her goodnes as her bewte
Was neuer suche a nother as was she
I praye to god in honour her susteyne
And wolde she were of all europe the quene
In her is hyghe bewte wythoute pryde
Yongthe wythout greyf or folye
To all her werkes vertue is her gyde
Humbles hath slayn in her all tyrannye
She is a myrrour of alle curtesye
Her herte is very chambre of holynesse
Her honde mynystre of fredom for almesse
And all this voys is soth as god is trewe
But now to purpos lete vs torne agayn

Thise marchaıı̄unts haue do freyght her shippes
newe
And whān thei haue þˢ blisful mayde seen
Home to surry ben they wente ageyn
And don her nedys as they haue do yore
And lyuen in wele I can saye nomore
Now fyll it þᵗat thyse marchaıı̄untes stode in grace
Of hym that was the sowdan of surrye
For whan they came from ony straunge place
He wolde hym self of his benygne curtesye
Make hem good chere and besely aspye
Tydynges of sundry regnes for to lere
The wondres that they myght se or here
Among other thynges specyally
Thyse marchaıı̄unts haue told of dame custaıı̄unce
So grete noblesse in ernest ceriously

That this sowdan hath caught so grete pleysa
ıı̄unce
That all his lust and all his besy cure
Was for to loue her whyle his lyf may dure
Parauenture in that large boke
Whyche men clepe the heuen y wryte was
Wyth sterrys or that he his byrthe toke
That he for loue sholde haue his deth alas
For in the sterrys clere than is the glas
Is wreten god wote who so cowde it rede
The deth of euery man wythouten drede
In sterrys many a wynter there beforn
Was wryte the deth of hector and achilles
Of pompey Iulius or they were born
The stryf of thebes and of hercules
Of sampson turnus and socrates
The deth but mennys wyttes be so dull
That no wyght can rede it atte full
This sowdan for his preuy counsell sent
And shortly on this matere for to passe
He hath to hem declared his entent
And sayd hem certen but he might haue grace
To haue custaunce wythin a lytyll space
He nas but ded and chargyd hem on hye
To shapen for hym som remedye
Dyuers men dyuers thynges sayden
They argumentes casten vp and doun
Many a subtyll reson forth they laden
They spak of magyk and abusyon
But fynally as in this conclusyon
They can not se in that none auauntage
Ne in none other waye saue in maryage
Thenne sawe they ther inne suche dyffyculte
By way of reson to speke all playn
By cause that ther was suche dyuersyte
Betwyx her bothe lawes that they sayen
They trowe that no crysten prynce wold fayn
Wedden his chylde vnder our lawes swete
That vs was tauȝt by mahoıı̄unde our prophete
And he answerde hem rather than I lese
Custaunce I woll be crystned doutlees
I muste be heris I maye none other chese
I praye you holde your argumentes in pees
Sauyth my lyf and be not recheles
To geten her that hath my lyf in cure
For in this woo I may not longe endure
What nedyth gretter dylatacyon
I saye by tretyse and embassetrye
And by the popis mediacyoun
And all the chyrche and all the chyualrye
That in destruccyon of mawmettrye
And in encrees of cristys lawe dere
They be accorded so as ye shall here
How that the sowdan and his baronage
And all his lycges shall crystened be
And he shall haue custaunce in maryage
And certeyn golde I not what quantyte
And therto founde they suffycyent surete
The same accorde was sworne in eyther syde
Now fayre custaunce almyghty god the gyde
¶ Now wold som men wene as I gesse
That I sholde telle all the purueaunce
That the emperour of his grete noblesse
Hath shape for his doughter dame custaunce
Wel may men knowe that so grete ordenaunce
Maye noman telle in a lytyll clause
As was arayed for so hyghe a cause
Bysshoppis ben shapen wyth her for to wende
Lordis ladyes knyghtes of gret renoun
And other folke ynough this is the ende
And notifyed is thrugh out the toun
That euery wyght wyth grete deuocyoun
Sholde praye crist that he this maryage
Resceyue in gre and spede this vyage
The daye is come of her departynge
I say the wofull day fatall is come
That there maye be no lenger taryenge
But forwarde they dresse hem alle and som
Custaunce that was wyth sorowe all ouercom
Full pale aryseth and dressyth her to wende
For well she wote ther is none other ende
Allas what wonder it is though she wepte
That shall be sent to straunge nacyon
Fro frendys that her so tenderly kepte
And to be bounde vnder subieccyon
Of one she knoweth not the condycyon
Husbondes ben all good and haue be yore
That knowe wyues I dare saye nomore
Fader she sayd thy wretchyd chyde Custaunce
Thy yonge doughter fostryd vp so softe
And ye my moder my souereyn plesaunce
Ouer all thynge out take criste on lofte
Custaunce your chylde her recomaundeth ofte
Vnto your grace for I shall to surrye
Ne shall I neuer se you more wyth eye
Alas vnto the barbaryk nacyon
I must anon syth that is your wyll
But crist that deyed for our redempcyon
So yeue me grace his hestis to fulfylle
I wretchyd woman no force though I spylle
Wymmen are born to thraldom and penaunce
And to be vnder mannys gouernaunce
I trowe at troye whan turnus brake the wall
Of Ilyon ne not brent was thebes the cyte
Ne at rome for the harme thrugh hanyball
That romayns had vaynquysshed tymes thre
Nas herde suche tender wepynge for pyte
As was in the chambre for her departynge
But forth she must whether she wepe or synge
¶ O fyrst moeuynge cruell fyrmament
Wyth thy dyurnall sweygh that crodest ay
And hurtelyst all fro este to occident
That naturelly wolde holde a nother waye
Thy crowdynge set the heuen in suche araye
At the begynnynge of this fyrers vyage
That cruell mars hath slayn this maryage
O infortunat accendant tortuos
Of whyche the lorde is helples falle alas
Out of his angle in to the thyrde hous
O mars o occitaler as in this caas
O feble mone vnhappy be thy paas
Thou knyttest the there thou art not receyued
There thou were well fro thens art þᵘ weyued
Imprudent emperour of rome alas
Was there no phylosophre in thy toun
Is no tyme better than a nother in this caas
Of vyages is ther none eleccyon
Namely to folke of hyghe condycyon
Not whan a rote is of a byrthe y knowe
Allas we ben to lewde or elles to slowe
To shyppe is bronȝt this wofull fayre mayde
Solempnly wyth euery cyrcumstaunce
Now Ihesu crist be wyth you all she sayd
Ther is nomore but fare well fayre custaunce
She payneth herself to make good contenaıı̄unce
And forth I lete her saylle in this manere
And torne ayen I woll to my matere

Explicit prima pars
Sequitur pars secunda
THe moder of the sowdan welle of vyces
Aspyed hath her sonys playn entent
How he wolde lete his olde sacryfyces
And ryght anon she for her counsell sent
And they came to knowe what she ment
And whan assembled was this folke in fere
She sette her downe and sayd as ye shall here
¶ Lordyges quod she ye knowe wel euerychon
How that my sone is in poynt for to lete
The holy lawes of our alcaron
Yeuen by goddis messenger machomete
But on auowe to the grete god I hete
The lyf shall rather out of my body stert
Or machometis lawe go out of my hert
What shold vs tyden of this newe lawe
But thraldom to our body and penaunce
And afterwarde in helle to be drawe
For we renyed mahounde our creaunce
But lordis woll ye make assuraunce
As I shall say assentynge to my lore
And I shall make vs sauf for euer more
They sworen and assentyd euery man
To lyue wyth her and deye ⁊and by her stonde
And eueryche in the beste wyse that he can
To strengthe her shall his frendes fonde
As she that hath this empryse take on honde
Whyche ye shall here as I shall deuyse
And to hem all she spake in this wyse
We shull vs fyrst fayne crystendom to take
Colde water ne shall vs greue but a lyte
And I shall suche a feste and a reuell make
That as I trowe I shall the sowdan quyte
For though his wyf be crystnyd neuer so whyte
She shall haue nede to wasshe awaye the rede
Thouh she afonte full of water wyth her lede
¶ O sowdonnes rote of Inyquyte
Virago thou samarian the seconde
O serpent vnder femynyte
Y lyke vnto the serpent depe in helle y bounde
O feyned woman all that may confounde
Vertu and Innocence thrugh thy malyce
Y bred is in the a nest of euery vyce
O sathan enuyous syn that daye
That thou were chacyd from our herytage
Well knowest thou to wymen the olde way
Thou madest eua to brynge vs in seruage
Thou wolt fordon this cristen mariage
Thin Instrument so well a way the whyle
Makyst thou of wymen whan þᵘ wolt begyle
This sowdōnnesse whom I thus blame ⁊and wery
Let pryuely her counsell go her way
What sholde I lenger in this tale tary
She rydeth to the sowdan on a daye
And sayd to hym that she wolde renye her lay
And cristendome of prestis honde fonge
Repentynge her that she hethen was so longe
Besechynge hym to do her that honour
That she myght haue the cristen folke to feste
To plesen hem I woll do my labour
The sowdan sayth I woll do at your heste
And knelynge thanked her of that requeste
So glad he was he nyst what to sey
She kyssed her sone ⁊and home she goth her wey
Aryued be this cristen folke to londe
In surry wyth a grete solempne rowte
And hastely this sowdan sente his sonde
Fyrste to his moder and to al the regne aboute
And sayd his wyf was come wythout doubte
And prayed her to ryde ayenst the quene
The honour of his regne to sustene
Grete was the prees and ryche was the aray
Of surryens and of romayns met in fere
The moder of the sowdan ryche and gay
Receyueth her wyth all glad chere
As ony moder myght he doughter dere
And to the next cyte there besyde
A softe paas solempnly they ryde
Nought trow I the triumphe of Iulius
Of whyche that lucan makyth suche a boost
Was ryaller ne more curyous
Than was the assemble of this blysfull hoost
But this scorpyon this wycked goost
The sowdonnesse for all her flaterynge
Cast vnder this full mortally to stynge
The sodan comyth hymself sone after this
So ryally that wonder was to telle
He welcomyth her wyth Ioye aud blys
And thus in Ioye and blys I lete hem dwelle
The fruyt of euery tale is for to telle
Men thoughte it whan tyme came for the best
That reuell to stynt and men to go to rest
The tyme came this olde sowdonnesse
Ordeyned hath this feste of whyche I tolde
And to the feste cristen men dresse
In generall bothe yonge and olde
There may men ryalte and feste beholde
And deyntees mo than I can dyuyse
But all to dere they boughte it at they ryse
¶ O soden woo that euer art successour
To worldly blys spreynt wyth bytternes
The ende of the Ioye ⁊and of our worldly labour
Wo occupyeth the fyne of our gladnesse
Herken this counsell for thy sykernesse
Vpon thy glad day haue in thy mynde
The vnwaar wo that comyth the behynde
For shortly to telle at o worde
The sowdan and the cristen euerychone
Been all to hewen and stycked at the borde
But it were only dame custaunce allone
This olde sowdonnes cursyd crone
Hath wᵗith her frendes there don this cursyd dede
For she hel self wolde all the countre lede
Ne there was surreyn non that was conuertyd
That of the counsell of the sowdan wote
That he nas all to hewen or he astertyd
And custaunce haue taken anon fote hote
And in a shyp steerles god it wote
They haue her set and byd her lerne to saylle
Out of surrye agaynwarde in to ytayllye
A certeyn tresour that she thyther ladde
And soth to sayn vytayll grete plente
They haue her yeue and clothes eke she had
And forth she saylled in to the salt see
O my custaunce full of benygnytee
O emperours yonge doughter dere
He that is lorde ouer fortune be thy stere
She blessyd her and wyth full pytous voys
Vnto the cros of crist thus sayd she
O clere o welefull awter holy croys
Redde of the lambes blood ful of pyte
That wysshist the worlde fro olde Inyquyte
Me fro the fende and fro his clawes kepe
That daye that I shall drenche in the depe
Victoryous tree of proteccyon trewe
That only were worthy for to bere
The kyng of heuen wyth his woundes newe
The whyte lamb that hurt was wyth a spere
Flemer of fendys out of hym and of here
Of whyche thy lynes faythfully extende
Me kepe and yeue me my lyf tamende
Yeres and dayes fleet this creature
Thorugh out the see of greke in to the strayte
Of marok as it was her auenture
O many a sory mele may she bayte
After her deth full ofte may she wayte
Or that the wylde wawes wolde her dryue
Vnto the place where that she shall aryue
Men myghte aske Why she was not slayn
Eke at the feste who myghte her body saue
And I answere to that demaunde agayn
Who sauyd danyel in the horryble caue
There euery wyght were he mayster or knaue
Was wyth the lyon fret or he a stert
No wyght but god that she bare in her hert
God lyst to shewe his wonderfull myracle
In her for we sholde see his myghty werkes
Crist that is of euery harme tryacle
By certayn menys as knowen clerkes
Doth thynges that for certeyn ende ful derk is
To mannys wyt that for our Ignoraunce
Ne can not knowe his prudent purueaunce
Now syth that she was at the feest y slawe
Who kepte her fro drenchynge in the see
Who kept Ionas in the fysshes mawe
Tyll he was spowtyd out at nynyue
Wel may men knowe it was no wyght but he
That kept the pepyll hebrayke fro drenchyng
Wyth drye fote thorugh out the see passyng
Who hath the four spirytes of tempeste
That power haue to anoyen londe and see
Bothe north and south west and est
Annoyeth nother londe hous ne tree
Sothly the cōmmaunder of that was he
That fro the tempest ay this woman kepte
As well whan she woke as whan she slepte
Where myȝt this woman mete ⁊and drynke haue
Thre yere ⁊and more lasteth her vitayll
Who fedde the egypcian mary in the caue
Or in deserte not but crist sauns faylle
Fyue thousand folk it was a grete merueylle
Wyth louys fyue and fysshes two to fede
God sente his foyson at her grete nede
She dryueth forth in to our occean
Thorough out our wylde see tyll at the laste
Vnder an holde that nempne I ne can
Fer in northumbyrlonde the wawes her caste
And in the sonde the shyppe stycked so faste
That thens wolde it not all that tyde
The wyll of crist was there she sholde abyde
The constable of the castell downe is fare
To se this wracke all the shype he soughte
And fonde this wery man full of care
He fonde also the tresour that she brought
In her langage mercy she besought
The lyf out of her body for to twynne
Her to delyuer out of the wo that she was ynne
Amaner latyn corrupt was her speche
But algatys ther by was she vnderstonde
The constable whan him lyst no lenger seche
This wofull woman brought he to londe
She knelyth downe ⁊and thankyth cristys sonde
But what she was she wolde to no man saye
For foul ne fayr though she sholde deye
She sayd she was so masyd in the see
That she forgat her mynde by her trouth
The constable hath of her so grete pyte
And eke his wyf that wepen sore for rowth
She was so dilygent wythout slouthe
To serue and pleyse eueryche in that place
That all her loue that loken in her face
The constable and dame hermegyld his wyf
Were payneinys and that countre euery where
But hermegyld loued her ryght as her lyf
And custaıı̄unce hath so longe y soiournyd there
In oryson wyth many a bytter tere
Tyll Ihesus hath conuertyd thrugh his grace
Dame hermegyld þᵉ constablesse of that place
In all that londe no crysten durste route
All crysten men be fled fro that countre
Thrugh paynemes that conquered all aboute
The realme as well by londe as by see
To walys thenne fledde the crystianytee
Of olde brytons dwellynge in that yle
Ther was no refute for the mene whyle
But yet nere crysten brytons so exyled
That there nare some in her preuyte
Honouryd crist and hethen folke begyled
And nyghe the castell suche there dwelled thre
That one of hem was blynde ⁊and myght not se
But it were wyth thycke eyen of his mynde
Wyth whyche they seen after men be blynde
Bryght was the sonne as in somers daye
For whyche the constable and his wyf also
And custaunce hath take the ryght waye
Towarde the see a forlong waye or two
To playen and to romen to and fro
And in this walke the blynde man they mette
Crokyd and olde wyth eyen faste y shette
In the name of criste cryed this briton
Dame hermegyld yeue me my syghte ageyn
This lady wexyd afrayd of that soun
Lest that her husbonde shortly for to sayn
Wolde her for Ihesus cristys lore haue sleyn
Tyll custaıı̄unce made her bold ⁊and bad her werche
The wyll of crist as doughter of holy chyrche
The constable wexte abasshyd of that syghte
And sayd what amounteth all this fare

But I lete all thyse storyes passe by
Of custaunce is my tale specyally
In olde romaynes gestis men maye well fynde
Mauricius lyf I bere it not in mynde
Then kynge alla whan he his tyme say
Wyth custaunce his holy wyf so swete
To englonde ben they come the ryght way
Where as they lyuen in Ioye and in quyete
But lytyll whyle it lasted I you behete
Ioye of this worlde but tyme woll not abyde
Fro day to nyght it chaungeth as the tyde
Who lyueth euer in suche delyte a daye
That ne meued eyther in conscyence
Or yre or talent or some kynnys affraye
Enuye or pryde or passyon or offence
I ne saye but for the ende of this sentence

Lastyth þᵉ lyf of alla wᵗith custaıı̄unce

Now pray we to god his soule blesse
And dame custaunce fynally to say
Towarde the towne of rome goth her way
To rome is come this holy creature
And fyndeth hir frendis ther hole and sounde
Now is she scapyd all her auenture
And whan she her fader hath y founde

They lyuen alle and neuer a sonder wende
Tyll deth departed hem this lyf they lede
And faryth now well my tale is at an ende
Now Iesus crist that of his myght may sende
Ioye after woo gouerne vs in his grace
And kepe vs all that ben in this place
Here endith the man of lawes tale
And here begynneth the prologe of the wyf of bathes tale
EXperyence though none auctoryte
Were in this worlde is ryght ynow for me

But lordis syn I twelue yere was of age
Thankyd be god that is eternall a lyue
Husbondys at the chyrch dore haue I had fyue
Yf I so often myghte haue weddyd be
And alle were worthy men in her degre
But me was tolde not longe a go ywys
That syth crist wente neuer but onys

¶ Lo her whyche a sharp worde for the nonys
Besyde a welle Ihesus god and man

Thou hast had fyue husbondis sayd he
And that ylke man that now hath the

How many myght he haue in maryage
Yet herde I neuer tellen in myn age
Of this noumbre very diffynicyoun
Men mow deme and glose vp and doun
But well I wote expresse wythouten lye
That god bad vs wexe and multiplye

Eke well I wote he sayde that myn husbonde

¶ Lo here the wyse kynge dame salomon

For the appostle sayth that I am fre

¶ I wote abraham was a full holy man

Ye knowe what this ensample maye resemble

¶ Freelte clepe I but yf that he or she

Of myn estate I woll make no boost

God clepyth to hym folke in syndry wyse
And eche hath of god a proper yefte
Som this som that as hym lyste to shyfte
Virgynyte is a grete perfeccyon

¶ Tell me also to what conclusyon

I woll perseuere I am not precyous

Ryght thus the appostle tolde it me

All this sentence me lyketh euery dell
¶ Vp stert the pardoner and that anon

¶ Abyde quod she my tale is not begonne

¶ Now syris then wol I tell you forth my tale

Ye wote wele what I mene parde

I gouerned hem so well after my lawe

For god it wot I chydde hem spytously
Now herke how I bare me properly
Ye wyse wyues that can vnderstonde
Thus shold ye speken and bere hem on honde
For half so boldly can there no man

But yf be whan they hem mys auyse

¶ Syre olde kaynarde is this thyn araye
Why is myn neyghbours wyf so gay
She is honouryd where euer she gooth
I sytte at home and haue no thryfty cloth
What dost thou at my neyghbours hous
Is she so fayr art thou so amerous
What rownest thou wyth a mayde benedicite
Syre olde lechour lete thy Iapys be
And yf that I haue a gossyb or a frende

¶ Thou sayst some folke desyre vs for ryches

¶ Thou sayst men may not kepe a castell wal

¶ Thou sayst a droppynge hous and eke smoke

¶ Thou sayst we wyues woll our vyces hyde
Tyll we be fast ⁊and then we woll hem shewe

¶ Thou sayst that oxen assis hors ⁊and houndys
They ben assayde of dyuers stoundys

¶ And also for that our prentyce Iankyn

¶ Of all maner men blessyd mote he be

¶ Thou sayst also yf that we make vs gay

yet cowde I make his berde so mote I thee

yet prechest thou and sayst an hatefull wyf

¶ Thou rekenest eke a womans loue to helle

¶ Thou rekenest eke also to wylde fyre

¶ Thou sayst ryght as wormys shenden a tre

This knowen they that be to wyues bonde
¶ Lordynges right thus as ye haue vndstonde
Bare I styfly myn olde husbondes on honde

Of Iankyn and of myn nece also
O lorde the pyne I dyde hem and the wo
Full gyltlees by goddys swete pyne
For as an hors I cowde byte and whyne

Or elles I hadde ofte tymes be spylt
Who so comyth fyrst to þᵉ mylle fyrst he grynt

Yet tyklid I his herte for that he
Wende that I of hym had so grete cheerte
I swore that all my walkyng out by nyght

Vnder that colour hadde I many a myrthe

To wymen kyndly whyle that they lyue
And thus of o thynge maye I auaunte me
Atte ende I haue the better in eche degre

Namely a bedde hadde they myschaunce
There wolde I chyde and do hem no plesaıı̄unce

Then wolde I suffre hym do his nycete
And therfore euery man this tale I telle
Wyn who so may for all is for to selle
Wyth empty hondes men may no hawkes lure

And make me than a feyned appetyt
And yet in bacon hadde I neuer delyt

For by my trouthe I quytte hem euery worde
As so helpe me god omnypotent
Though right now shold make my testament

For though he lokyd as wylde as a lyon

¶ Then wolde I say good leyf take kepe
How mekely lokyth wylkyn our shepe
Come ner my spouse let me ba thy cheke
Ye sholde be all pacyent and meke

Suffryth alway syn ye can so well preche

It is fayr a man to haue his wyf in pees

And syth a man is euer more resonable
Than a woman is ye must be sufferable
What ayleth you to grutche and grone
It is for ye wolde haue my queynte alone
Why take it lo haue it euerydeel
Petyr I shrewe you but ye loue it well
For yf I wolde selle my bele chose
I cowde walke as fresshe as a rose
But I woll kepe it for your owne toth

¶ Suche maner wordes hadde we on honde
Now wol I speke of my fourth husbonde
MY fourth husbonde was a reuelour
This is to say he hadde a paramour
And I was yonge and full of ragery
Styborn ⁊and stronge and plyaunt as a pye

Metullis the fowle churle the swyne
That with a staf beraft his wyf her lyf
For she dranke wyne ⁊and I had be his wyf
He sholde not haue dauntyd me fro drynke
And after wyne on venus must I thynke
And also syker as colde engendryth hayll
A lycorous mouth must haue a lycorous tayll
In woman vynolent is no defence
This knowen lechours by experyence
¶ But lorde crist whan it remembreth me
Vpon my yongthe and on my Iolyte
It tykleth me abowt my herte rote
Vnto this daye it doth my herte bote
That I haue had my worlde as in my tyme
But age alas that woll enuenyme
Hath me byraft my bewte and my pyth
Let go fare well the deuyll go therwyth
The floure is go ther nys nomore to telle

Now to be ryght mery woll I fonde
Now woll I telle of my fourth husbonde
I Saye he had in herte a grete dispyte
That I in ony other hadde delyte
But he was quyt by god and by saynt Ioys
I made hym of the same wode a troys
Not of my body in no fowle manere
But certenly I made folke suche chere
That in his owne greys I made hym frye
For angre and for very Ielousye
By god in erthe I was his purgatorye
For whyche I hope his soule be in glorye
For god it wote he sat ful oft and songe
Whan that his sho full bytterly hym wronge
Ther was no wyght saue god and he þᵗat wyste
He deyed whan I came fro Iherusalem
And lyth y graue vnder the rode beem
All is his tombe not so curyus
As was the sepulcre of hym darius
Whyche that appelles wrought so subtylly
It is but wast to burye him precyously
Let hym fare well god yeue his soule good rest
He is now in his graue and layd in his chest
NOw of my fyfth husbonde woll I telle
God lete his soule neuer come in helle
And yet was he to me the moste shrewe
That fele I on my rybbes all by rewe
And euer shall vnto myn endynge daye
But in our bed he was full fresshe and gaye
And therwyth all he cowde so well me glose
Whan that he wolde haue my bele chose
That though he hadde bete me on euery boon
He cowde wynne my loue agayn anoon
I trowe I louyd hym best for that he
Was of his loue so daungerous vnto me
We wymmen haue yf that I shall not lye
In this mater a queynt fantasye
Wayte what thynge we may not lyghtly haue
Ther after woll we crye alday and craue
Forbede vs thynge and desyren we
Preese on vs faste and then woll we fle
Wyth daunger vtter we all our chaffare
Grete prees at market makyth dere ware
And to grete chepe is holden at lytyll pryce
This knoweth euery woman that is wyse
MY fyfthe husbonde god his soule blesse
Whyche I toke for loue and no rychesse
He somtyme was a clerke of oxenforde
And had left scole and went at home to borde
Wyth my gossyb tho dwellynge in our toun
God haue her soule her name was alysoun
She knewe my herte and eke my preuyte
Better than our paryssh prest so mot I the
To her bewreyed I my counsell alle
For had myn husbonde pyssed ageyns a walle
Or do a thynge that he sholde haue cost his lyf
To her and also to a nother worthy wyf
And to my nece whyche that I loued well
I wolde haue tolde his counsell euerydeell
And so I dyde full ofte god it wote
That made his face full oft redde and hote
For very shame and blamyd hymself that he
Hadde tolde to me so grete a preuyte
¶ And so befell that onys in a lente
So ofte tyme I to my gossyb went
For euer I loued to be gaye al waye
And for to walke in marche aprill and may
Fro hous to hous to here sundry talys
That Iankyn clerke and my gossyb dame alys
And I my self in to the feldis wente
My husbonde was at london all that lente
I hadde the better leyser for to playe
And for to se and eke for to be saye
Of lusty folke what wyst I where my grace
Was shapen for to be or in what place
Therfore I made my visytacyons
To vigylis and to processions
To prechynge eke and to pylgrymages
To playes of myracles and to maryages
And weryd vp on my gay scarlat gytes
This wormes ne thise mouthes ne thise mites
Vpon my parell frayed them neuer a deell
And wost thou why for they were vsyd well
¶ Now woll I tell forth what happyd me
I saye that in the feldes walkyd we
Tyll truly that we hadde suche dalyaunce
This clerke and I that of my purueaunce
I spake to hym and sayd how that he
If I were wydow sholde wedde me
For certeyn I saye you for no bobance
Yet was I neuer wythout purueaunce
Of maryage ne of other thynges eke
I holde a mous hert not worth a leke
That hath but one hole for to stert to
And yf that fayll then is all y do
¶ I bare hym on honde he had echauntyd me
My dame taughte me forsoth that suttylte
And eke I sayd I mette of hym all nyght
He wolde a slayn me as I laye vpryght
And all my bed was full of very blood
But yet I hope truly ye shul do me good
For blood betokenyth golde as I was taught
And all was fals I dremyd of him ryht nauȝt
But as I folowed aye my dames lore
As well of that as of other thynges more
¶ And now syre lete me se what sholde I sayn
A ha by god I haue my tale agayn
Whan that my fourth husbonde was on bere
I wepte algate and made a sory chere
As wyues moten for it is the vsage
And wyth my kerchyf I cleryd my visage
But for that I was purueyed of a make
I wepte full lytyll I dar vndertake
To chyrche was my husbond born on morow
With our neyghbours þᵗat for hym made sorowe
And Iankyn our clerke was one of tho
As helpe me god whan that I sawe hym go
After the beere me thought he had a peyre
Of leggis and fete so clene and so feyre
That all my hert I yaf vnto his holde
He was I trowe twenty wynter olde
But I was fourty yf I shall saye the soth
But yet I had alwaye a coltys toth
Gappe tothed I was but that becam me well
I had the prynt of saynt venus sell
As helpe me god I was a full lusty on
And fayr ⁊and ryche and yonge and well begon
And truly as my husbondis tolde me
I had the best queynte that myght be
For certes I am all fully venaryan
In felynge and my herte is marcyan
Venus me yaf my lust and my lycorousnesse
And mars yaf me my sturdy hardynesse
Myn ascendaıı̄unt was taure and mars therin
Alas alas that euer loue was synne
I folowed ay myn Inclynacyon
By vertue of my constyllacyon
That made me that I cowde not wythdrawe
My chambre of venus fro a good felawe
Yet haue I martis marke vpon my face
And also in a nother preuy place
For god so wysly be my sauacyon
I loued neuer by no dyscrecyon
But euer folowed myn appetyte
All were he longe short blacke or whyte
I toke no kepe so that he lyked me
How poore he was ne eke of what degre
¶ What shold I saye but at the monthes ende
This Ioly clerke Iankyn that was so hende
Hath weddyd me wyth grete solempnyte
And to hym yaf I all londe and fe
That euer was yeue me ther before
But afterwarde me repentyd it full sore
He nolde suffre no thynge of my lyst
By god he smote me onys on the lyst
On the cheke for I rente out of his boke a leyf
That of the stroke myn ere wax al deyf
Styborne I was as is a lyonesse
And of my tonge a very Iangylresse
And walke I wolde as I doon had beforn
Fro hous to hous all though he had it swon
For whyche he ofte tyme wolde preche
And me of olde romaunce gestis teche
¶ How he simplicius gallus lefte his wyf
And he forsoke for terme all of his lyf
Not but for onys open heded he her saye
Lokynge out at his dore vpon a daye
A nother romayn tolde he me by name
But for his wyf was at a someris game
Wythout his wytynge he forsoke her eke
And then wolde he vpon his byble seke
That ylke prouerbe of ecclesiast
There he cōmmaundyth and biddeth fast
Men shal not suffre her wyues to royle aboute
Then wolde he saye thus wythouten doute
Who so byldeth his hous all of salowes
And prycketh his blynd hors ouer the falowes
And suffryth his wyf to seke halowes
Is worthy to be hangyd on the galowes
But all for nought I set not an hawe
Of all his prouerbis ne of all his olde sawe
Ne I wolde not of hym correctyd be
I hate hem that tellen my vyces vnto
And so do mo god wote of vs than I
This made hym wood wyth me all vtterly
I wolde not forbere hym in no caas
¶ Now woll I saye you soth bi saynt thomas
Why that I rente out of his boke a leef
For whyche he smot me so that I was deef
He had a boke þᵗat gladly bothe nyghte ⁊and day
For his disport he wold rede alwaye
He clepyd it valery and theophraste
Atte whyche boke he lough alway full faste
And eke ther was a clerke somtyme in rome
And cardynall that hyght saynt Ierome
That made a boke agayn Ionynyan
In whyche boke ther was eke tortulan
Crisippus trotala and helowis
That was abbesse not fer fro paris
And eke the parables of wyse salomon
Onydes art and eke bokes many on
And all thyse were bounden in one volume
And euery daye and nyght was his custume
Whan he had leyser and ony vacacyon
Fro all other worldly occupacyon
To reden on this boke of wyckyd wyues
He knewe of hem mo legendis and lyues
Than be of good wyues in the byble
For trustyth well it is an impossyble
That ony clerke wolde speke good of wyues
But yf it be of holy sayntes lyues
Ne of none other wymen neuer the mo
Who paynted the lyon tell me who
By god yf wymen had wryten storyes
As clerkes haue wythin her oratoryes
They wold haue wrytēn of mēn mor wyckydnes
Than all the marke of adam maye redresse
The chyldren of mercury and venus
Ben in her werkynge full contraryous
Mercury louyth wysdom and scyence
And venus louyth ryot and dyspence
And for her dyuers dysposycyon
Eche faylleth in others exaltacyon
And thus god wote mercury is dyssolate
In pisces where venus is exaltate
And venus faylleth ther mercury is reysed
Therfor wymen of no clerke is praysed
The clerke whan he is olde ⁊and may nought do
Of venus werkys not worth his olde sho
Then sitteth he don ⁊and wryteth in his dotage
That wymen can not kepe her maryage
¶ But now to purpos why I tolde the
That I was beten for a boke parde
Vpon a nyght Iankyn that was our syre
Radde on his boke and he sate by the fyre
¶ Of eue fyrst that for her wyckydnes
Was all mankynde brought to wretchydnes
Fo whyche that Ihesu crist hym self was slayn
That boughte vs wyth his hert blood agayn
Lo here expresse of wymen may ye fynde
That woman was the los of all mankynde
Tho redde he me how sampson lost his herys
Slepyng his lemman kyt hem with her sheris
Thrugh whyche treson lost he both his eyen
¶ Tho radde he me yf that I shall not lyen
Of hercules and of his dyanyre
That causyd hym to sette hym self a fyre
No thynge forgate he the sorowe and the wo
That socrates had wyth his wyues two
How exantippa cast pysse vppon his heed
This sely man sat stylle as he were deed
He wyped his heed nomore durste he sayn
But or the thunder stynt ther comyth rayn
¶ Of pasipha that was the quene of crete
For shrewdnesse hym thought the tale swete
Fy speke nomore it is a grysly thynge
Of her horryble lust and of her lykynge
Of cletemystra for her hyghe lecherye
That falsly made her husbonde to dye
He redde it wyth full good deuocyon
He tolde me eke for what conclusyon
Amphioraxe at thebes loste his lyf
Myn husbonde had a legende of his wyf
¶ Eriphilem that for an ouche of golde
Hath pryuely vnto the grekys tolde
Wher that her husbonde hydde hym in a place
For whyche he had at thebes a sory grace
¶ Of lyma tolde he me and of lucy
They bothe made her husbondis for to dy
That one for loue that other was for hate
Lyma her husbonde vpon an euyn late
Enpoysond hym for that she was his fo
Lucia lykerous louyd her husbonde so
For he sholde algatys on her thynke
She yaf hym suche a loue drynke
That he was ded or it was at morowe
And thus algate husbondis had sorowe
¶ Then tolde he me how that latumeus
Compleyned how that fel man arrius
That in his gardyn growed suche a tre
On whyche he sayd that his wyues thre
Hanged hemself for her hertes dispytous
¶ O leue brother sayd then this arrius
Yef me a plante of that blessyd tre
And in my garden plantyd shall it be
¶ Of latter date of wyues hath he redde
That some haue slayn her husbondis a bedde
And let her lechour dyght hem all the nyght
Whyles that the corps laye in floor vpryght
And some haue dryue nayles in her brayn
Whiles þᵗat thei slept ⁊and thus they haue hem slain
Some haue yeue hem poyson in her drynke
He spake more harme than herte may thynke
And therwyth all he cowde mo prouerbes
Than in this worlde growe gras or herbes
Better is quod he thyn habitacyon
Be with a lyoun or a fowle dragon
Than wyth a woman vsynge for to chyde
Better is quod he hyghe in his roof abyde
Than wyth an angry wyf downe in the hous
They be so wycked and so contraryous
They haten that her husbondis loue ay
He sayd a woman cast her shame awaye
Whan she caste of her smok and ferder mo
A fayr woman but she be chaste also
Is lyke a golde rynge on a sowes nose
Who wolde leue or who wolde suppose
The wo that in myn herte was and pyne
And whan I sawe that he wolde neuer fyne
To reden on his cursyd boke all nyght
All sodenly thre leuys haue I plyght
Out of his boke ryght as he redde and eke
I wyth my fyst so toke hym on the cheke
That in our fyre he felle bakwarde a doun
And he vp stert as doth a wood lyoun
And wyth his fyst he smote me on the heed
That in the floor I lay as I were deed
And whan he sawe how stylle that I laye
He was agast and wolde haue fled a waye
Tyll at last I out of my swowne abreyed
O hast thou slayn me fals theyf I sayd
And for my londe thus hast thou murdred me
Or I be ded yet woll I ones kysse the
And nere he cam and knelyd fayre a doun
And sayd dere syster swete alysoun
As helpe me god I shall the neuer smyte
That I haue do it is thy self to wyte
Foryeue it me and that I the beseke
And yet eft sonys I hytte hym on the cheke
And sayd theyf thus moche am I bewreke
Now woll I deye I maye no lenger speke
¶ But atte laste wyth moche care and woo
We fell accorded by our selfen two
He yaf me the brydyll in my honde
To haue the gouernaunce of hous and londe
And after of his tonge and of his honde also
And made hym brenne his boke anone tho
And thenne whan I had goten vnto me
The maystry and eke the souereynte
And that he sayd myn owne true wyf
Doth as you lyst all the terme of thy lyf
Kepe thyn honour and eke myn astate
And after that daye we had neuer debate
God helpe me so I was to hym as kynde
As ony wyf fro denmark in to ynde
And also true and so was he to me
I pray to god that sytteth in mageste
So blysse his soule for his mercy dere
Now woll I saye my tale yf ye woll here
THe frere lough whan he had herde al this
Now dame quod he so haue I Ioy ⁊and blys
This is a longe preambyll of a tale
And whan the sompnour herde the frere gale
¶ Lo quod þᵉ sompnour for goddis armys two
A frere woll entremete hym euer mo
Lo good men a flye and eke a frere
Woll fall in euery mannys dysshe and matere
What spekyst thou of preambulacioun
What ambyll or trot go pysse or syt a doun
Thou lettyst our disporte in this matere
¶ Ye wolt þᵘ so syre sompnour quod the frere
Now by my fayth I shall or that I go
Telle of a sompnour suche a tale or two
That all folke shall laugh in this place
¶ Now ellys frere I beshrewe thy face
Quod this sompnour and I beshrewe me
But yf I telle talys two or thre
Of freres or that I come to sydyngbourne
That I shall make the sore for to morne
For well I wote thy pacyence is goon
¶ Our hooste cryed peas and that anon
And sayd lete the woman telle her tale
Ye faren as folke þᵗat dronken been of ale
Do dame tell forth your tale and that is best
¶ Al redy syre quod she ryght as you lyst
Yf I haue lycence of this worthy frere
¶ Yes dame quod he tell forth and I woll here

l.hi: Here endith the wyf of bathes prologe And begynneth her tale

div.l: And begynneth her tale
IN olde dayes of kynge artur
Of whyche brytons speke grete honour
All was this londe fulfylled of fayrie
The elf quene wyth her Ioly companye
Dauncyd full oft in many a grene mede
This was the olde opynyon as I rede
I speke of many an hundred yeres a go
But now can no man se none elphis mo
For now the grete charyte and prayers
Of lymytours and other holy freres
That serchen euery londe and euery streme
As thycke as motys in the sonne beme
Blessyng halles chambres kechyns ⁊and bowris
Cytees borowes castellis and hyghe towris
Thorpis bernes shepens and deyryes
This makyth that there be no feyries
For there as wont was to walke an elf
There walkyth now the lymytour hymself
In vndermelis and in mornynges
And sayth his matyns ⁊and his holy thynges
As he goth forth in his lymytacyonn
Wymen may now go saufly vp and doun
Vnder euery busshe and vnder euery tre
There is none other incubus but he
And he ne wolde do hem ony dishonour
¶ And so befell that this kynge artour
Had in his hous a lusty bacheler
That on a daye came rydynge fro the ryuere
And happyd that alone as he was born
He sawe a mayde walkynge hym beforn
Of whyche mayde anone magre her hed
By very force he byrefte her maydenhed
For whyche oppressyoun was suche clamour
And suche pursute vnto kynge artour
That dampned was this knyghte to be ded
By cours of lawe and shold haue lost his hed
Parauenture suche was the statute tho
But that the quene and other ladyes mo
So longe prayden the kyng of grace
Tyll he his lyf grauntyd in that place
And yaf hym to the quene all at her wylle
To chose whether she wold hym saue or spylle
The quene thankyd þᵉ kyng with all her myȝt
And after this thus spake she to the knyght
Whan she sawe her tyme vpon a daye
¶ Thou stondyst yet quod she in suche araye
That of thy lyf yet hast thou no surete
I graunt thy lyf yf thou canst telle me
What thynge is this that women most desiren
Beware and kepe thyn necke from yren
And yf thou canst not telle it anon
I shall ye yeue yet leue for to goon
A twelf monthe and a daye to seche and lere
An answere suffycient in this matere
And suerte woll I haue or that thou pace
Thy body forto yelden in this place
¶ Wo was this knyghte ⁊and sorowful he syȝheth
But he may not do all as hym lykyth
And at laste he chose hym for to wende
And come agayn ryght at the yeres ende
Wyth suche answer as god wolde hym puruey
And taketh his leue ⁊and wendyth forth his wey
He sekyth euery hous and euery place
Where as he hopyth for to fynde grace
To wyte what thynge wymen loued most
But he cowde aryuen in no cost
There as he myght fynde in this matere
Two creaturis accordyng in fere
¶ Some sayd wymen louyd best rychesse
Some sayd honour some sayd Iolynesse
Some sayd ryche araye some sayd lust a bed
And ofte tymes to be wydowe and to be wed
Some sayd that we be in hert most esyd
Whan we be yflateryd and y plesyd
He goth full nygh the soth I woll not lye
A man shall best wynne vs wyth flaterye
And wyth attendaunce and wyth besynesse
Ben we ylymed both more and lesse
¶ And some sayd that we louyd best
For to be fre and do ryght as vs lyst
And that no man repreue vs of our vyce
But saye that we be wyse ⁊and no thynge nyce
For truly there is none of vs all
Yf ony wyght woll clawe vs on the galle
That we nell kyke for that he sayth vs soth
Assay and he shall fynde it that it doth
For be we neuer so vycyous wyth Inne
We wolde be holden wyse ⁊and clene out of synne
¶ And some sayd grete delyte haue we
For to be holde stable and eke secre
And in one purpoos stedfastly to dwelle
And not to bewreye that men vs telle
But that tale is not worth a rake stele
Parde we wymen can no thynge hele
Wytnes on myda woll ye here the tale
¶ Ouide amonge other thynges smale
Sayd myda had vnder his longe herys
Growynge vpon his hed two assis eris
The whyche vyce he hydde as he best myght
Full subtylly from euery mannys syghte
That saue his wyf ther wyste of it nomo
He louyd her most and trustyd her also
He prayde her that to no maner creature
She wolde telle of hys fowle disfygure
¶ She swore him þᵗat for al the world to wynne
She nolde do that vylony ne synne
To make her husbonde to haue so fowle a name
She wolde not it for her owne shame
But netheles she thought that she deyen
That she so longe sholde a counsell hyde
She thoughte it was so sore abowte her herte
That nedys some worde her muste a sterte
And syth she durste telle it to no man
Doun to the maryce fast by she ranne
Tyll she cam there her herte was in fyre
And as a byttore blumbyth in the myre
She layed her mouth vnto the water downe
Bewrey me not thou water wyth thy sowne
Quod she to the I telle it and to no mo
Myn husbonde hath longe assys eres two
Now is myn herte all hole now it is oute
I myght no lenger kepe it out of doute
¶ Here mow ye se though we a tyme byde
Yet out it must we can no counsell hyde
The remenaunt of the tale yf ye woll here
Redyth ouyde and there ye maye it lere
¶ This knyght of whom my tale is specyally
Whan that he sawe he myght not come therby
This is to saye what wymen louen most
Wythin his brest so sorowfull was his ghost
But home he goth he myght not soiourne
The day was come þᵗat homward must he torne
And in hys waye as happyd him to ryde
In all his care vnder a forest syde
Where as he sawe vpon a daunce go
Of ladyes four and twenty and yet mo
Towarde whyche daunce he drowe full yerne
In hope that he sholde some wysdom lerne
But certenly or that he came fully there
Vanysshed was this daunce he nyste where
No creature sawe he that bare lyf
¶ Saue on the grene he sawe syttynge a wyf
A fowler wyght ther myght no man deuyse
¶ Agayn this knyght this olde wyf gan ryse
And sayd syre knyght herforth lyth no waye
But tell me what ye seke by your fay
Parauenture it maye the better be
Thyse olde folke can moche thynge quod she
¶ My leue moder quod this knyght certeyn
I nam but ded but yf that I can sayn
What thynge it is that wymen most desyre
Coude ye me wissh I wold wel quyte your hire
¶ Pliȝt me thy trouth her in my hond quod she
The nexte thynge that I requyre the
Thou shalt it do yf it lye in thy myght
And I woll telle it you or it be nyght
¶ Haue her my trouth quod þᵉ knyȝt I graunt
¶ Then quod she I dar well make auaunt
Thy lyf is sauf for I woll stonde therby
Vpon my lyf the quene woll saye as I
Lete se whyche is the prowdest of hem all
That weryth on other keuerchyf or calle
That dar say nay of that I woll the teche
Let vs go forth wythout more speche
¶ Tho rowned she a pystle in his ere
And bad hym be glad and haue no fere
¶ Whan they be comen to the court this knyȝt
Sayde he kepte his day as he had hyght
And redy was his answer as he sayd
Full many a noble wyf and many a mayde
And many a wydow for that they be wyse
¶ The quene her self syttynge as Iustyce
Assembled ben this answer for to here
And afterward this knyght was boden tapere
To euery wyghtwas cōmmaunded scylence
And that the knyght shold telle in audience
What thynge that worldly wymen loue best
This knyght stode not styll as doth a beest
But to his questyon anon answerde
Wyth manly voys that all the court it herde
¶ My lyege lady thenne generall quod he
Wymen desyren to haue souereynte
As well of her husbondis as of her loue
And for to ben in maystrye aboue
This is your most desyre though ye me kylle
Doth as ye lyst I am here at your wylle
¶ In all the court ne was ther wyf ne mayde
Ne wydow that contraryed that he sayd
But sayd he was worthy to haue his lyf
¶ And wyth þᵗat worde vp stert this olde wyf
Whyche þᵗat the knyght fond syttyng on þᵉ grene
Mercy quod she my souereyn lady quene
Er that your court departe as doth me ryght
I taught this answer vnto this knyght
For whyche he plyghte me his trouthe there
The fyrste thynge I wolde hym requyre
He wolde it do yf it laye in his myght
Befor this court then I praye the syr knyght
Quod she that thou me take vnto thy wyf
For wel thow wotest that I haue sauyd thy lyf
Yf I swere fals swere nay vpon thy fey
¶ The knyght answerde alas and wel awey
I wote ryght well that suche was my behest
For goddys loue chese a newe request
Take all my good and let my body go
¶ Nay then quod she I shrewe vs both two
For though that I be fowle old and poore
I woll not for all the metall and the oore
That vnder the grounde lyeth other aboue
But I thy wyf were and eke thy loue
¶ My loue quod he naye but my dampnacyon
Alas that euer ony of my nacyon
So fowle sholde euer disperaged be
But all for nought the ende is thus that he
Constreyned was nedis muste he her wedde

¶ Now wold some men sayn parauenture
For myn neclygence I do no cure
To telle you the Ioye and all the araye

¶ To whyche thynge shortly I answer shall
I say there was no fest ne Ioye at all
There nas but heuynesse and moche sorowe
For pryuely he weddyd her by the morowe
And all day after hydde hym as an owle
So wo was hym his wyf lokyd so fowle
Gret was the wo þᵗat the knight had in thought

¶ His olde wyf laye symylynge euermo
And sayd o dere husbonde benedicite
Farith euery knyght thus with his wif as ye
Is this the lawe of kynge artours hous
Is euery knyght of his loue so daungerous
I am your owne loue and eke your wyf
I am she whyche that saued hath your lyf
And certes yet I dyde you neuer vnryght
Why fare ye thus wyth me the fyrst nyght
Ye fare lyke a man hadde lost his wytt
What is my gylt for goddys loue telle me it

¶ Amendyd quod this knyght alas nay nay
It woll not be amended neuer the mo
Thou art so lothly and so olde also
And therto comyn of so lowe a kynde
That lytyl wond9 is though I walow ⁊and wynd
So wolde god quod he myn herte wolde breste
¶ Is this quod she the cause of your vnreste
¶ Ye certeyn quod he no wonder it is
¶ Now syre quod she I cowde amende all this

So well ye myght bere you vnto me
¶ But for ye speken of suche gentylnes
As is descendyd out of olde ryches
That therfore ye shull be gentylmen
Suche arrogaunce is not worth an henne
Loke who is mnst vertuous alwaye

¶ Criste wol we clayme of hym our gentylnes

¶ Lo in suche manere ryme is dauntis tale

¶ Eke euery wyght wote this as well as I

They myght do no vylony or vyce
¶ Take fyre and bere it in to the derkest hous
Betwyx this and the mounte of cancasus
And lete men shytte the dores and go thenne
Yet woll the fyre as fayre lye and brenne

Vp peryll of my lyf tyll that it dye
¶ Here maye ye se how that gentrye
Is not annexyd to possessyon
Suche folke ne doth her operacyon
Alway as doth the fyre lo in his kynde
For god it wote men may full ofte fynde
A lordis sone do shame and vylony
And he that woll haue pryce of his gentery
For he was born of a gentyll hous
And hadde his elders noble and vertuous
And nyll hem self do no gentyll dedys
Ne folowen his gentyll auncetres that deed is
He is not gentyll be he duke be he erle
Fy vileyns synfull dedys maken a cherle
For gentylnes nys but the renome
Of thyn auncetris for her hyghe bounte
Whyche is a straunge thynge to thy persone
Thy gentylnes comyth fro god alone
Thenne comyth our very gentylnes of grace
It was no thyng bequeden vs wyth our place
¶ Thynketh how noble as sayth valerius
Was that romayn tullius hostilius
That out of pouert rose to hygh noblesse
Redyth senek and redyth eke boece
There shull ye se expresse that no drede is
That he is gentyll that doth gentyll dedis
And therfore leue husbonde thus I conclude
Were it that myn auncetris were rude
Yet maye the hye god and so hope I
Graunte me grace to lyue vertuously
Than am I gentyll whan I begynne
