¶ And there as ye of pouerte me repreue
That hyghe god on whom hooly we byleue
In wylfull pouerte chose to lede his lyf
And certes euery man mayden or wyf
May vnderstonde that Ihesus heuen kynge
Ne wolde not chese a vicyous lyuynge
¶ Glad pouerte is a full honest thyng certein
This woll senek and other clerkis seyn
Who so that holdyth hym payd of his pouert
I holde hym ryche and he had not a shert
He that coueyteth he is a full poore wyght
For he wolde haue that is not in his myght
But he that nought hath ne coueyteth to haue
Is ryche al though he holde hym but a knaue
Very pouerte is synne properly
Iuuenall spekyth therof full merily
The poore man whan he gooth by the waye
Before the theuys he may synge and playe
Pouert is hatefull good and as I gesse
A full grete brynger out of besynesse
A grete amender eke of sapyence

Pouerte is this all though it semyth elenge
Possession þᵗat no man wolde gladly chalenge

Pouert a spectakyll is as thynketh me
Thrugh whyche he maye his very frendys se
And therfore syre syth therin ye be greued

¶ Now syre there as of elde ye repreue me
And certes syre though none auctoryte

Sayn that men shold an olde wyght fauour
And clepyd fader for theyr gentylnesse
And auctours shall I fynde as I gesse
¶ Now ther as ye saye I am fowle and olde
Then drede ye not to be made cokeolde
For fylthe elde and fowle so mot I the

¶ This knyght auyseth hym and syketh

¶ Kys me quod she we be no lenger wroth

Ye haue here towchyd also mot I the

And yf it lyke vnto this companye
I woll you of a sompnour telle a game
Parde ye mowen well knowe by the name

And is y bete at euery townes ende
¶ Our host then spake a syre ye shold be hende

¶ Nay quod the sompnour let hym say by m

WHylom there was dwellyng in my contre
An Archedekyn a man of high degre
That boldly dyd well execucyon
In punysshyng of fornycacyoun
Of wytchecraft and eke of bawdrye
Of dyffamacyon and auoutrye
Of chyrche reues and of testamentes
Of vsurye and eke of symonye also
But certes lechours dyde he grettest woo
They sholde syngen yf that they were hent
And smale tythers also were fowle shent
Yf ony persone wolde vpon hem playn
There myght astert no pecunyall payn
For smale tythes and smale offerynge
He made the peple full pytously to synge
For or þᵉ bysshop caught hem wyth his hoke
They were in the archedekens boke
And then had he thrugh his Iurisdyccyon

He had a sompnour redy to his honde
A slygher boye was none in engelonde
For subtylly he had his espiayll
That taught him where he myghte auayll
He cowde spare of lechours one or two
To teche hym to four and twenty mo
For though the sōmpnour wood were as an hare
To telle hys harlotrye I wol not spare
For we be out of his correccyon
They haue of vs no Iurisdiccyon

¶ Petyr so be wymmen of the stiwys
Quod the sompnour put out of our cure
¶ Pees wyth myschaıı̄unce ⁊and wyth mysauenture
Sayd our host and lete hym telle his tale
Now tell forth though the sompnour gale

¶ This fals theyf þᵉ sompnour quod the frere
Had alwaye redy bawdys to his honde
As any hawke is to the lure in engelonde
That tolde hym all the secre that they knewe
For ther acqueyntaunce was not comen of new
They were all hys approuers pryuely
He toke hym self a grete prouffyt therby
His mayster knewe not alway what he wan
Wythouten maundementis a lewd man
He cowde sompne on payn of cristis curse
And they were glad for to fyllen hys purse

And ryght as Iudas hadde pursis smal
And was a theyf ryght suche a theyf was he
His mayster hath but half his dute
He was yf I shall yeue hym his lawde
A theyf a sompnour and eke a bawde
He had eke wenchis at his retenue
That whether that syre robert or syre hue

Thus were the wenchys and he of one assent
And he wold fet a feyned maundement
And sompne hem to the chapytre bothe two
And pylle the man and lete the wenche go
Then wolde he say frende I shall for thy sake
Do stryke the out of our letters blake
The dar nomore as in this caas traueyle
I am thy frende there I the maye he auayle
Certen he knewe of brybours many mo
Than possyble is to telle in yeris two
For in this worlde nys dogge for the bowe
That can an hurt dere from an hole knowe
Beter than this sōmpnour knewe a slye lechour
Or auoutrer or elles ony paramour
And for that was the fruyt of al his rent
Therfore on it he sette alle his entent
¶ And so befyll that onys vp on a day
This sompnour was euer waytynge his pray
For to sompne an olde wyf a rybybe
Feynynge a cause for he wolde haue a brybe
It happed that he saw beforn hym ryde
A gay yeman vnder a forest syde

¶ Syre quod the sompnour heyl ⁊and well y take
¶ Welcome quod he and euery good felawe
Whyther rydest þᵘ vnder this grene wode shawe

¶ This sompnour answerde ⁊and sayd naye
Here faste by quod he is myn entent
To ryden for to reyse vp all the rent
That longyth now to my lordis duete
¶ Art thou then a baylyf ye quod he
He ne durste for vylonye and shame

¶ Deperdeux quod this yeman dere brother
Thou art a bayllyf and I am a nother
I am vnknowen now in thys contre
Of thyn acqueyntaunce then I praye the
And eke of bretherhed yf that thou lyst

¶ Gramercy quod the sompnour by my fayth
Eueryche in other honde his trouth he layeth
For to be sworn brethern tyll they deye
In dalyaunce they ryde forth and pleye
¶ This sōmpnour whiche was full of Iangelys
As full of venym ben thyse wery anglys
And euer enquyrynge vpon euery thynge
Brother quod he wher is now your dwellyng
A nother daye yf that I shall you seche
¶ This yeman him answerd with soft speche
Brother quod he fer in the north cuntre
Where as I hope somtyme I shall the se
Er we departe I shall the so well wys

¶ Now brod quod this sompnour I you praye
Teche me whyles we ryden by the waye
Syn that ye be a bayllyf and so am I
Some subtylte and telleth me feythfully
In myn offyce how I maye most wynne
And sparyth not for conscyence ne synne
But dere brother tell me how do ye
¶ Now by my trouthe dere brother sayd he
As I shall telle the a faythfull tale
My wagis be ful streyt and full smale
My lorde is harde to me and daungerous
And myn offyce is full labourous
And therfore by extorsyons I lyue
Forsoth I take all that men woll me yeue

From yere to yere I wynne all my dispence
I can no better tell the faythfully
¶ Now certes quod the sompnour so fare I
I spare not to take god it wote
But yf it be to heuy or to hote
That I may gete in counsell pryuely
Nomore conscyence of that haue I
Nere myn extorsyoun I myght not lyuen
Ne of suche Iapys woll I not be shryuen
Stomak ne conscyence knowe I none
I shrewe the shryftfaders euerychone
Well be we met by god and by saynt Iame
But leue brother telle me thy name
Quod this sompnour in this meane whyle
This yeman gan a lytyll forto smyle
¶ Brother quod he wolt thou that I the telle
I am a fende my dwellynge is in helle
And here I ryde abowte my purchacynge
To wyte yf men woll yeue me ony thynge
To purchace is the effecte of all my rent

¶ A quod þᵉ sompnour benedicite what ye say

But whan vs lyketh we can take vs one

Somtyme lyke a man ⁊and somtyme lyke an ape

¶ Why quod the sōmpnour ryde ye then or goon

¶ For we quod he woll vs in suche fourme make

¶ What makyth you to haue al this labour
¶ Well many a cause leue syre sompnour
Sayd this fende but all thynge hath tyme

And somtyme at our prayer haue we leue

But o thynge warne I the I woll not Iape

¶ Nay quod þᵉ sompnour that shall not betide

My trouthe woll I holde to the as in this caas

¶ I graunte quod the deuyll by my faye

¶ Lo brother quod the fende what tolde I the

¶ Whan þᵗat they comen somwhat out of þᵉ toun

LOrdynges ther is in york shyre as I gesse

This worthy man was lorde of þᵗat vylage
This frere came as he were in a rage
Where as this lorde sate etynge at his borde
Vnnethe myghte the frere speke o worde
Tyll at last he sayd god you se
¶ This lorde gan loke and sayd benedicite
What frere Iohn what mannere worlde is this
I se well some thynge there is amys
Ye loke as though þᵉ wode were full of theuys
Syt downe and tell me what your greyf is
And it shall be amended yf I maye
¶ I haue quod he haue a dispyte to daye
God yelde it you a doun in your vyllage
That in this worlde ther nys so poore a page
That he nolde haue abhomynacyon
Of that I haue receyued in the toun
And yet ne greuyth me no thynge so sore
As that the olde churle wyth lockis hore
Blasfemyd hath our holy couent eke
¶ Now mayster quod the lorde I you beseke
¶ No mayster syr quod he but seruytour
Though I haue had in scole that honour
God lyketh not that raby men vs calle
Nother in market ne in your large halle
¶ No fors quod he but tell me all your greyf
¶ Syre quod this frere an odyous myscheyf
This daye betyd is to myn ordre and me
And so per consequens in eche degre
Of holy chyrche god amende it sone
¶ Syre quod the lord ye wote what is to done
Distempere you not ye be my confessour
Ye be the salt of the erthe and the sauour
For goddis loue your pacyence now holde
Tell me your greyf and he anon hym tolde
As ye haue herde beforn ye wote well what
¶ The lady of the hous ay stylle sat
Tyll she had herde what the frere had sayd
Ey goddis moder quod she the blessyd mayde
Is ther ought ellys tell me faythfully
¶ Madame quod he how thynke ye ther by
¶ How that me thynketh so god me spede
I saye a churle hath do a churlys dede
What sholde I say god let hym neuer the
His syke hede is full of vanyte
I holde hym in a manere of a fransye
¶ Madame quod he by god I shall not lye
But I in ony wyse maye on hym a wreke
I shall dyffame hym ouer all where I speke
That fals blasfemer whiche that chargyd me
To parte it that woll not departyd be
To euery ylyke moche wyth myschaunce
¶ The lorde sate stylle as he were in a traunce
And in his herte he rollid vp and doun
How that this churle hath ymagynacyoun
To shewe suche a probleme to the frere
Neuer erst or now herde I of suche a matere
I trowe the deuyll put it in his mynde
In ars metryk shall there noman fynde
Beforn this daye of suche a questyoun
Who sholde make a demonstracioun
That euery man sholde haue lyke his part
As of a sowne or of sauour of a fart
O nyce prowde chorle I shrewe his face
¶ Lo syres quod the lord wyth harde grace
Who euer herde of suche a thynge or now
To euery man ylyke telle me how
It is an impossyble it maye not be
Ey nyce churle god lete hym neuer the
The romblyng of a fart and euery sowne
Nys but of ayre reuerberacyoun
And euer it wastyth lyte and lyte awaye
Ther is no man can deme by my faye
Yf that it were departyd equally
What lo my churle lo yet how shrewdly
Vnto my confessour to daye he spak
I holde hym certeyn a demonyak
Now ete your mete and lete the churle go play
Lete hym go hange hym self a deuyll way
¶ Now stode the lordis squyre at his borde
That carf hys mete and herde worde by worde
Of all this thynge of whiche I haue you sayd
My lorde quod he be ye not euyll apayd
For I cowde tell for a gowne cloth
To you syre frere so ye be not wroth
How that this fart sholde euyn delyd be
Amonge your couent yf it lyke sythe
¶ Tell quod the lorde ⁊and thou shalt haue anon
A gowne cloth by god and by saynt Iohn
¶ My lorde quod he whan þᵗat the weder is fayr
Wythout wynde or perturbynge of ayr
Let brynge a carte whele ryght in to this halle
But so that it haue his spokys alle
Twelf spokys hath a carte whele comynly
And bryng me then .xij. freres wote ye why
For thertene is a couent as I gesse
Your confessour here for his worthynesse
Shall perfourme vp the nombre of his couent
Then shull they knele downe by one assent
And to euery spokys ende in this manere
Full sadly lay his nose shall a frere
Your noble confessour ther god hym saue
Shall holde his nose vpryght vnder the naue
Then shal this churle wyth bely styf ⁊and strouȝt
As ony tabour hyder be y brought
And set hym on the whele ryght of this cart
Vpon the naue and make hym lete a fart
And ye shall se vp peryll of my lyfe
By preyf whiche that is demonstratyf
That equally the sowne of it wol wende
And eke the stynke out at the spokis ende
Saue that this worthy man your confessour
By cause he is a man of grete honour
Shall haue the fyrst fruyte as reson is
The noble vsage of freres yet is this
The worthiest man of theym shal first be serued
And certeynly he hath it well deseruyd
He hath to daye taughte vs so moche good
Wyth prechynge in the pulpet there he stode
That I may vouchesauf I saye for me
He had the fyrst smelle of fartis thre
And so wolde all his brethern hardely
He beryth hym so fayr and so holily
¶ The lorde þᵉ lady ⁊and eke man saue the frere
Sayd that Iankyn spake in this matere
As well as ouyde or ptholome
Towchynge the churlys they sayd subtylte
And hye wyt made hym speke as he spak
He nys no fole ne no demonyak
And Iankyn hath y wonne a newe gowne
My tale is done we be almost at towne
Here endyth the sompnours tale

And foloweth the prologe of the
clerke of oxenforde
xIr clerke of oxenford our host sayd
Ye ryde as quoy ⁊and stylle as doth a mayde
Were newe spowsyd syttynge at the borde
This daye ne herde I of your tonge a worde
I trowe ye study abowte some sophyme
But salamon sayd that all thynge hath tyme
For goddys sake as be of good chere
It is no tyme now to study here
Tell vs some mery tale by your faye
For what man as entryd in to a playe
He nedys moot in to the playe assente
But prechyth not as freres do in lente
To make vs for our olde synnes wepe
Ne that thy tale make vs not to slepe
¶ Tell vs some mery thynge of auenturis
Your termes your colours and your fyguris
Kepe hem in store tyll so be that ye endyte
Highe style is whan men to kyngis wryte
Speketh so playn at this tyme I you praye
That we maye vnderstonde you what ye saye
¶ This worthy clerke benygnely answerde
Host quod he I am vnder your yerde
Ye haue of vs as now the gouernaunce
And therfore I shall do you obeysaunce
As fer as reson askyth hardily
I woll you telle a tale whyche that I
Lernyd at padow of a worthy clerke
As preuyd is by his wordis and his werke
He is now ded and nayled in his cheste
I praye to god yeue his soule good reste
¶ Fraunceys petrark the laureat poete
Hyght this clerke whoos rethoryk swete
Enlumyned all ytayle of poetrye
As lynyan dyde of phylosophye
Or lawe or other art pertyculer
But deth that woll not suffre vs dwellen here
But as it were the twynkelynge of an eye
Hem both hath slayn and all shall we deye
¶ But forth to telle of this worthy man
That taught me this tale as I began
I say that fyrst wyth hygh style he endyteth
Er he the body of his tale wryteth
A prohemye in whyche discryueth he
Pemounte and of saluces the countree
And spekyth of arpentyn the hylles hye
That ben the boundes of west lumbardye
And of mount vesulus in specyall
Where that the poo out of the welle small
Takynge his fyrst spryngynge and his sours
That estwarde euer encresyth in his cours
To emek warde to ferrare and venyse
The whyche a longe thynge were to deuyse
And truely as to my Iugement
Me thynketh it a thynge inpertynent
Saue that hym lyst conueye his matere
But this is his tale as ye mowe here
Here endyth the prologue
Here begynneth the clerkis tale of oxenforde
THere is in the west syde of ytayle
Downe at the rote of vesulus the colde
A lusty playn habundaunt of vytaylle
Wher many a toun ⁊and toure thou mayst behold
That fouuded were in tyme of faders olde
And many a nother delectable syght
And saluces this noble countre hyght
A markys somtyme lorde was of that londe
As were his worthy eldres hym before
And obeysaunt ay redy to his honde
Were all his lyeges bothe lasse and more
Thus in delyte he lyued and hath do yore
Byleued and drad thrugh fauour of fortune
Both of his lordes and eke of his comune
Therwith he was to speke as of lygnage
The gentylest yborn of lumbardye
A fayr persone a stronge and yonge of aegea
And full of honour and of curtesye
Dyscrete ynough his contre for to gye
Saue in some thynges that he was to blame
And waltir was this yonge lordis name
I blame hym thus that he consydered not
I tyme comynge what myght hym betyde
But on his lyst present was all his thought
As for to hawke and hunte on euery syde
Well nygh all other curis let he slyde
And eke he nolde and that was worst of all
Wedde no wyf for ought that myght befall
Only that poynt his peple bare so sore
That flokmele on a day they to hym went
And one of hem that wysest was of lore
Or ellys that the lorde wolde best assent
That he sholde tell hym what his peple ment
Or ellys cowde he shewe well suche matere
He to the markis sayd as ye shull here
¶ O noble markis your humanyte
Assuryth vs and yeueth vs hardynes
As ofte as tyme is of necessyte
That we to you mow telle our heuynes
Acceptyth now lorde of your gentylnes
That we wyth pytous herte vnto you play ne
And lete your erys not my voys disdeyne
Al haue I not to doon in this matere
More than a nother man hath in this place
Yet for as moche as ye my lorde so dere
Haue alwaye shewed me fauour and grace
I dar the better axe of you a space
Of audyence to shewe our request
And ye my lorde to do ryght as you lyst
For certes lorde so well vs lyketh you
And all your werke ⁊and euer haue doon that we
Ne cowde not our self deuysen how
We myghte lyuen in more felycyte
Saue o thynge lorde yf your wyll be
That for to be a weddyd man you lest
Then were your peple in souereyn hertes rest
Bow ye your hed vnder the blessyd yok
Of souereynte and not of seruyse
Whyche that men clepyth spousayle or wedlok
And thynketh lord amonge your wyttes wyse
How that our dayes passen in sundry wyse
For though we slepe or wake renne or ryde
Ay fleeth the tyme it woll no man abyde
And though your grene youth floure as yet
In crepyth aege as stylle as ony stoon
And deth manasseth euery age and smyte
In eche astate for there ne ascapyth noon
And also certayn as we knowen echoon
That we shull dey and vncerteyn we all
Been of the daye whan deth shall on vs fall
Acceptyth then of vs the true entent
That yet neuer refuseden your heste
And we woll lorde yf ye woll assent
Chese you a wyf in short tyme at beste
Born of the gentyllest and of the meste
Of all ytalye so that it oughte seme
Honour to god and you as I can deme
Delyuer vs out of all this besy drede
And take a wyf for hyghe goddys sake
For yf so be it befalle as god forbede
That thrugh your deth your lyne shold slake
And that a straunge successour sholde take
Your herytage o wo were vs on lyue
Wherfore we praye you hastely to wyue
¶ Her meke prayer and her pyetous chere
Made the markis herte for to haue pyte
Ye woll quod he myn owne peple dere
To that I neuer erst thought constreyne me
I me reioysed in my lyberte
That selde tyme is founde in maryage
There I was fre I muste be in seruage
But netheles I se your true entente
And trust vpon your wyt and haue don ay
Wherfore of my fre wyll I woll assent
To wedde me as sone as euer I maye
But there as ye haue proferid me to daye
To chese me a wyf I you relece
That choys I pray you of that profer sece
For god it wote that chyldren ofte been
Vnlyke her worthy elders hem before
Bounte cometh all of god not of þᵉ streen
Of whyche they be gendred and y bore
I truste in goddys bounte and therfore
My maryage and myn astate and reste
I hym betake he may do as hym lest
Lete me alone in chesynge of my wyf
That charge vpon my bak I woll endure
But I you praye and charge vpon your lyf
That what wyf that I take ye ssure
To worshyp her whyles her lyf may dure
In worde and werk both here and eueriwhere
As she an emperours doughter were
And ferthermore this shall ye swere that ye
Ayenst my choys shall neuer grutche ne stryue
For syth I shall forgo my lyberte
At your request as euer mot I thryue
Ther as my herte is set there woll I wyue
And but ye woll assente in suche manere
I praye you spekyth uomore of this matere
¶ Wyth herty wyll they sworen and assenten
To al thisthyng ther sayd not one wygyt nay
Besechynge hym of grace or that they wenten
That he wold graunte hem a certen day
Of his spousayll as sone as euer he may
For yet alwaye many of the peple dredde
Lest the markis wolde no wyf wedde
¶ He grauntyd hem a daye suche as hym lest
On whyche he wolde be wedded sykerly
And sayd he dyde all this at her request
And they wyth humble entent buxomly
Knelynge vpon her knees full reuerently
Hym thankyd alle and thus they haue an ende
Of her entent and home ayen they wende
And here vpon he toke his offycers
Ann comaunded for the feste to purueye
And to his preuy knightes and squyers
Suche charge yaf as he lyst on hem leye
And they to his cōmmaundement obeye
And eche of hem doth all his dylygence
To do vnto that feste hyghe reuerence

NOught fer fro that palays honourable
Ther as this markis shope his mariage
Ther stode a thorpe of syght full dylectable
In whyche that pore folke of that vyllage
Hadden her bestys and her herbygage
And of her labour toke her sustynaunce
After that the erthe yaf hem habundaunce
Among thyse poore folke ther dwellyd a man
Whyche was y holde porest of hem alle
But hyghe god somtyme sende can
His grace in to a lytyll oxis stalle
Ianycola men of that throwpe hym calle
A doughter had he fayr ynough to syght
And grisildes this yonge mayden hyght
But for to speke of vertuous beaute
Then was she one the fayrest vnder sonne
And full pouerly yfostred vp was she
No lycorous lust was thrugh her herte y ronne
But ofter of the welle than of the wyne tonne
She dranke and for she wolde vertue plese
She knewe well labour but none ydle ese
But though this mayde so tendre were of age
Yet in the brest of her vyrginyte
There was enclosyd rype and sadde courage
And in grete reuerence and charyte
Her olde poore fader fostred she
A fewe shepe spynnynge on felde she kepte
She wolde not be ydle tyll she slepte
And whan she homward came she wold brynge
Wortys or other herbes tymes ofte
The which she shred ⁊and setheth for her lyuyng
And made her bed harde aud no thynge softe
And ay she kepte her faders lyf on lofte
Wyth eueriche obeysannce and dylygence
That childe myght do to the faders reuerence
¶ Vpon grisilde this pour creature
Full ofte sythes this markys sette his eyen
As he rode on huntynge perauenture
And whan it befell that he myght her aspye
He not wyth wanton lokynge of folye
His eyen cast on her but in sad wyse
Vpon her chere he wolde hym ofte auyse
Commendynge in his herte her womanhede
And eke her vertue passynge ony wyght
Of so yonge age as well in chere as dede
For though the peple had no grete insyght
In vertu he consydered full ryght
Her bounte and dysposed hym that he wolde
Wedde her only yf he euer wedde sholde
¶ The day of weddyng cam but no wyȝt can
Telle what manere woman it sholde be
For whiche merueyll wondred many a man
And sayd whan they were in preuyte
Woll not our lorde leue yet his vanyte
Woll he not wedde alas alas the whyle
Why woll he thus hymself and vs begyle
But netheles this markys had do make
Of gemmys sette in golde and in asure
Brochys and rynges for grisildes sake
And of her clothyng toke the mesure
Of a mayde lyke vnto her stature
And eke of her other ornamentis all
That vnto suche a weddynge sholde befall
The tyme of vndren on the same daye
Approchyd that the weddynge sholde be
And all the palays put was in aray
Both halle and chambres eche in his degre
Howses of offyce stuffed wyth grete plente
There mayst thou se of deynteous vitaylle
That may be founde as fer as lastyth ytaylle
This ryall markis rychely arayed
Lordis and ladyes in his companye
The whyche that to the feeste were prayed
And of his retenue the bachelrye
Wyth many a sowne of sundry melodye
Vnto the vyllage of whyche I tolde
In this araye the ryght waye haue holde
¶ Grisild of this god wote full Innocent
That for her shapen was all this araye
To fette water atte welle is went
And comyth home as sone as euer she may
For well she herde sayd that ylke day
That the markis shold wedde ⁊and yf she myght
She wolde fayne haue seen some of þᵗat syght
She thouȝt I wyll wyth other maydens stond
That been my felowes in our dore and se
The markys and therfore wolle I fonde
To doon at home as sone as it may be
The labour whyche that longeth to me
And then I may at leyser here beholde
Yf she this waye vnto the castell holde
And as she wolde ouer the thressholde goon
The markys cam and gan her for to calle
And she set downe her water pot anone
Besydes the thressholde in an oxes stalle
And downe vpon her knees she gan to falle
And wyth sad countenaunce kneled stylle
Tyll she had herde what was the lordys wyll
¶ This thoughtful markys spak vnto þᵉ mayde
Full soberly and sayd in this manere
Where is your fader o grisildis he sayde
And wyth reuerence and humble chere
Answerd lorde he is all redy here
And in she goth wythouten lenger let
And to the markys she her fader fet
He by the honde then toke this olde man
And sayd thus whan he had hym a syde
Ianycula I nother maye ne can
The plesaunce lenger of my herte hyde
Yf that thou vouchesauf that so betide
Thy doughter woll I take or that I wende
As to my wyf vnto her lyues ende
Thou louest me I wote it well certeyn
And art my faythfull lyege man bore
And all that lyketh me I dar well sayn
It lyketh the and specyally therfore
Tell me that poynt that I sayd before
And yf thou wolt vnto that purpoos drawe
To take me as for thy sone in lawe
¶ This soden caas thys man a stoned soo
That redde he wext abasshyd and al quakyng
He stode vnnethe sayde he wordis moo
But only thus lorde quod he my wyllynge
Is as ye wyll ne agaynst your lykynge
I woll no thynge ye be my lorde so dere
Ryght as you lyst gouernyth this matere
Yet woll I quod thys markys softely
That in your chambre I and you and she
Haue a collacyon and wotyst thou why
For I woll axe yf it her wyll be
To be my wyf and rule her after me
And all this shall be do in thy presence
I nyll not speke out of thyn audience
And in the chambre whyle they were aboute
Her tretees whyche as ye shall after here
The peple came in to the hous all wythoute
And wondryd hem in how honest manere
And so tentifly kept her fader dere
But vtterly grisilde wondre myghte
For neuer erst ne sawe she suche a syghte
No wonder it though she were stoned
To se so grete a gest come in that place
She neuer was to no suche gestys y wonyd
For whyche she loked wyth full pale face
But shortli forth this matere for to chace
Thyse ben the wordes that the markys sayde
To this very benygne feythfull mayde
¶Grisilde he sayd ye shull well vnd9stonde
It lyketh vnto your fader and vnto me
That I you wedde and eke it may so stonde
As I suppose that ye woll that it so be
But thise demaundis axe I fyrst quod he
That syth it shall be doon in hasty wyse
Woll ye assent or ellys you auyse
I saye thus be ye redy with good herte
To all my lust and that I frely may
As me best thynkith though ye laugh or smerte
And neuer ye to grutche nyghte ne day
Whan I say ye that ye say not ones naye
Nother bi worde ne by frownyng coıı̄untenaunce
Swere this and here I swere our alyance
¶Wondryng vpon thyse wordes quakyng for drede
She sayd lorde Indigne and vnworthy
I am to suche honour as ye me bede
But as ye woll yoursilf ryght so woll I
And here I swere that neuer wyllyngly
In werke ne thought I nyll you disobeye
For to be ded though me were loth to deye
¶This is ynough grisilde myn quod he
And forth he goth wyth a full sobre chere
Out at dore and after came she
And to the peple he sayd in this manere
This is my wyf quod he that stondeth here
Honoureth her and loueth her I you praye
Who so me loueth there is no more to saye
And for that no thyng of her olde gere
She sholde brynge in to his hous he bad
That wymen sholde dispoylle her there
Of whyche thyse ladyes were not full glad
To handle her clothes wherin she was clad
But netheles this mayde bryght of hewe
Fro fote to hede they clothed her all newe
Her herys they kempte that laye vntressyd
Full rudely and wyth her fyngres smale
A crowne on her hed they haue y dressyd
And set her full of owches grete and smale
Of her araye what sholde I make a tale
Vnethe the peple her knewe for her fayrnes
Whan she translated was in such ryches
¶This markis hath her spousid wyth a ryge
Brought for the same cause ⁊and thenne her set
Vpon an hors snowe whyte ful wel amblynge
And to his palays or he lenger let
Wyth Ioyfull peple that her ladde and met
Conueyed her and thus the daye they spende
In reuell tyl the sonne gan descende
And shortly forth this tale for to chace
I saye that to this newe markessesse
God hath suche fauour sent of his grace
That it ne semyd by no lyknes
That she was born and fedde in rudenes
As in a cote or in an oxys stalle
But nourysshed in an emperousr halle
To euery wyght she woxen is so dere
And worshipfull that folke there she was bore
And from her byrthe knewe her yere by yere
Vnethe trowed they but durst haue swore
That to Ianycul of whyche I spake before
She doughter was for as by coniecture
Hem thought she was a nother creature
For though that euer vertuous was she
She was encresyd in suche excellence
Of thewys good set in hyghe bounte
And so dyscrete and fayr of eloquence
So benygne and so dygne of reuerence
And cowde so the peples herte enbrace
That eche her louyd that lokyd in her face
Not only of saluces in the toun
Publysshed was the bounte of her name
But eke besyde in many a regyoun
Yf one sayd well a nother sayd the same
So spredde of her hyghe bounte the fame
That men ⁊and wymen both yonge and olde
Gon to saluces vpon her to beholde
¶Thus walter lowly nay but ryally
Weddyd hath wyth fortunat honeste
In goddys peas lyueth full honestly
At home and outwarde grace ynough had he
And for he sawe that vnder lowe degre
Was honest vertu hyd the peple hym helde
A prudent man and that is seen full selde
¶Not only this grisilde though her wyt
Cowde all the fete of wyfly humbylnes
But eke whan that the caas requyred it
The commune prouffyt cowde she redresse

This markys in his herte longeth so

That he ne myght out of his herte throwe
This meruaylous desyre his wyf to assaye
Nedelesse god wote he thought her taffraye

To assay a wyf whan that it is no nede
And put her in anguysshe and in drede
For which this markis wrouȝt in this maner
He came alone a nyght there as she lay

Ye haue not that forgoten as I gesse
I say grisilde the present dygnyte
In whyche I haue put you as I trowe
Maketh you not foryetfull for to be
That I you toke in poore astate full lowe
For ony wele ye must yourself knowe
Take hede of euery worde what I seye
There is no wyght that heryth but we twey
Ye wote yourself how that ye cam here
In to this hous it is not longe ago
And though to me ye be both leyf and dere
Vnto my gentyls ye be no thynge so

But I desyre as I haue doon before

Not as I wolde but as my peple lest
And yet god wote this is full loth to me
But netheles wythout your wytynge
I woll not do but thus I woll quod he

¶Suspecyous was the fame of this man

what cowde a sturdy husbonde more deuyse

Vnto the markys of saluces anon

¶ Certes grisilde I had ynough of plesaunce

To chaunge his wyf for it was for the best

Than is grisilde and more tender of aege
And fayrer fruyt betwene hem shall falle
And more plesaunt for her hyghe lygnage
Her brother eke so fayr was of vysage
That hem to se the peple hath cauȝt plesaıı̄unce
Cōmmendyng now the markys gouernaunce
¶ O stormy peple euer vnsad and vntrue
Ay vndiscrete and chaungynge as a vane
Delytyng euer in rombel that is newe
For lyke the mone ay waxe ye and wane
Ay full of clappyng dere ynow a Iane
Your dome is fals your constaıı̄unce euyl preueth
A full grete fole is he that on you leuyth
Thus sayden sad folke in that cyte
Whan that the peple garyd vp and doun
For they were glad ryght for the newelte
To haue a newe lady of her toun
Nomore of this now make I mencyon
But to grisilde agayn I woll me dresse
And telle her constaunce and her besynesse
¶ Full besy was grisilde in euery thynge
That to the fest was tho appertynent
Ryght nought was she abasshed of her clothyge
Though it were rude ⁊and somdele eke to rent
But wyth glad chere to the yate is went
With other folke to grete the markeses
And after that dooth forth her besynesse
Wyth ryght glad chere she his gestis receyued
And so cunnyngly eche in his degre
That no defawte no man perceyued
But ay they wondred what she myght be
That in so poore aray was for to se
And cowde suche honour and reuerence
And worthily they praysen her prudence
In all this mene whyle she ne stent
This mayde ⁊and eke her brother to cōmmede
Wyth all her herte in full benygne entent
So well that no man cowde her prys amende
But atte last whan that lordis wende
To sytten doun to mete he gan to calle
Grisilde as she was besy in the halle
Grisilde quod he as it were in his play
How lyketh the my wyf and her beaute
Ryght well my lorde quod she for in good fay
A fayrer sawe I neuer none than is she
I pray to god yeue her good prosperyte
And so hope I he woll to you sende
Plesaunce ynough vnto your lyues ende
¶ O thynge I beseche you and warne also
That ye not prycke wyth no tormentrye
This tender mayde as ye haue do mo
For she is fostred in her norisshynge
More tenderly and to my supposynge
She cowde not aduersyte well endure
As cowde a poore frostred creature
And whan this walter sawe her pacyence
Her glad chere and no malyce at all
And he so ofte had do to her offence
And she ay constaunt and sad as a wall
Contynuenge euer her Innocence ouer all
This sturdy markys gan his herte dresse
To rewe vpon her wyfly stedfastnesse
¶ This is ynough grisilde myn quod he
Be now nomore agast ne euyll apayd
I haue thy fayth and thy benygnyte
As well as euer woman was assayd
In gret astate or poorely arayd
Now knowe I dere wyf thy stedfastnesse
And in his armys toke and gan her kysse
And she for wonder toke of it no kepe
She herde not what thynge he to her sayd
She ferde as she had stert out of her slepe
Tyll she out of her masydnes abreyde
Grisilde quod he by god that for vs deyde
Thou art my wyf ne none other I haue
Ne neuer had as god my soule saue
This is thy doughter whyche þᵘ hast supposyd
To be my wyf that other faythfully
Shall be myn heyr as I haue purposyd
Thou bare hym in thy body truly
At boleyne haue I kept hem pryuely
Take hem ayen for now mayst thou not sey
That thou hast lorn none of thy chyld9n twey
And folke that otherwyse haue sayd by me
I warne hem well that I haue doon this dede
For no malyce ne for no cruelte
But for to assaye in the thy womanhede
And not to sle my children god forbede
But for to kepe hem pryuely and stylle
Tyll I thy purpos knewe and all thy wyll
¶ Whan she this herd in swownyng doun she fallyth
For pyteo9 Ioy ⁊and after her swownyng
She to bothe her yonge chyldren calleth
And in her armys full pyteously wepynge
Enbracyd hem and tenderly kyssynge
Full lyke a moder wyth her salt terys
She bathyth both her vysage and her heerys
¶ O whyche a pyteous thynge it was to se
Her swownynge and her pyteous voys to here
Graunt mercy lord / god thanke it you qd she
That ye haue saued me my chyldren dere
Now recke I neuer to be ded euyn here
Syth I stonde in your loue and in your grace
No doubte of deth ne whan my spyryt pace
¶ O tender o dere o yonge chyldren myn
Your wofull moder wende full stedfastly
That cruell houndys or some fowle vermyn
Had eten you but god of his mercy
And your benygne fader so tenderly
Hath done you kepe and in that same stounde
All sodenly she swapt doun to grounde
And in her swownyug so sadly holdyth she
Her chyld9n two whan she gan hem tembrace
That wyth grete sleyght ⁊and grete diffyculte
The chyldren from her arme gan they arace
O many a tere on many a piteous face
Doun ran of hem that stoden there besyde
Vnnethe abowte her myght they abyde
¶ Walter her gladyth and her sorow slakyth
She ryseth vp and abassheth from her traunce
And euery wyght her Ioye and feste makyth
Tyl she hath caught agayn her countenaunce
Walter doth her so faythfully plesaunce
That it was deynte for to se the chere
Betwene hem two now they be met in fere
¶ Thyse ladyes whan they her tyme sey
Haue taken her and in to chambre anon
And strypen her out of her rude aray
And in a cloth of golde that bryght shoon
Wyth a crowne of many a ryche stoon
Vpon her hed they in to the halle her brought
And there she was honouryd as her ought
¶ Thus hath this pytous daye a blysfull ende
For eueri man and woman doth his myght
This daye in myrthe and reuell to spende
Tyll on the welkyn shone the sterrys lyght
For more solempnyte in euery mannys syght
This fest was and of gretter costage
Than was the reuell of her maryage
¶ Full many a yere in hyghe prosperyte
Lyuen thyse two in concorde and in reste
And rychely his doughter maryed he
Vnto a lorde one of the worthyest
Of all ytayll and then in pees and rest
His wyues fader in his court he kepith
Tyll the soule out of the body crepith
His sone succedyth in his herytage
In reste and pees after his faders day
And fortunat was eke in maryage
All put he not his wyf in grete assaye
This worlde is not so stronge it is no nay
As it hath ben in olde tymes yore
And herkenyth what this auctor sayth therfor
This stori is sayd not for that wyues shold
Folow grisilde as in high humylyte
For it were Importable though they wolde
But for that euery wyght in his degre
Sholde be constant in all aduersyte
As was grisilde wherfore petrark wryteth
This story whiche wyth high style he endityth
For syth a woman was so pacyent
Vnto a mortall man well more we ought
Receyuen all in good that god vs sent
For grete skyll is / he preue that he wrought
But he ne tempteth no man that he bought
As sayth saynt Iame yf ye his pystle rede
He preuyth folke but a daye it is no drede
And suffryth vs as for our excercyse
Wyth sharpe scorgis and aduersyte
Full ofte to be bete in sondry wyse
Not for to knowe our wylle but certes he
Er we were born knewe all our freelte
And for our best is all his gouernaunce
Lete vs lyue than in vertuous suffraunce
But o word harkenyth lordys or I goo
It were full harde to fynde now a dayes
Grisildes in all a countre thre or two
For yf they were put to suche assayes
The golde of hem hath so bad alayes
Wyth bras for though it be fayr at eye
It wolde rather brast on two than plye
For whyche here for the wyues loue of bathe
Whoos lyf and sect myghty god mayntene
In hyghe maystry or elles were it scathe
I wyll wyth lusty herte fressh and grene
Saye you a songe to glad you I wene
And lete vs stynte of ernest matere

GRisilde is ded and eke her pacyence
And both at onys buryed in ytayle
For whyche I crye in open audyence
No weddyd man so hardy be to assayle
His wyues pacyence in truste to fynde
Grisildis / for in certeyn he shall fayle
¶ O noble wyues full of hyghe prudence
Lete non humylyte your tongis nayle
Ne lete no clerke haue cause or dilygence
To wryte of you a story of suche meruayle
As of grisilde pacyent and kynde
Lest cheuache you swalow in her entrayle
¶ Folowyth ecco that holdyth no scylence
But euer answerynge atte countertayl
Be not adaffyd for your Innocence
But sharply take on you the gouernayl
Enprynteth well that lesson in your mynde
For comyn profyt sayth it may auayle
¶ Ye archewyues stondyth at defence
Syn ye be stronge as is a grete camaylle
Ne suffre not that men do you offence
But sclender wyues as feble in bateyll
Beth egre as a tygre is / fer in ynde
Ay clappyng as a mylle I you counseyll
¶ Ne dredeth hem not doo hem no reuerence
For though thy husbond armyd be in mayll
Thy arowes of thy crabbyd eloquence

In Ielowsye I rede eke that thou hym bynde

¶ Yf thou be fayr there folke be in presence
Shew thou thy vysage and thyn appareyll
Yf thou be fowle be fre of thy dyspence
To gete the frendys ay doo thy trauaylle
Be ay of chere as lyghte as leyf on lynde

Wepyng ⁊and wayling care and other sorow

I haue a wyf the worste that may be
For though the fende cowpled to her were

¶ Ther is a longe and a large dyfference

That I say soth by saynt thomas of ynde
As for the more part I say not all

Whylom ther was dwellyng in lumbardie
A worthy knyȝt that born was of pauy
In whyche he lyued in gret prosperyte
And . lx . yere a wyflees man was he
And folowyd ay his bodily delyte
On wymen ther was his appetyt
As doon thyse folys that ben seculer
And whan that he was passyd . lx . yeer
Were it for holynesse or for dotage
I can not say but suche a grete courage
Hadde this knyght to been a weddyd man
That day and nyght he doth all that he can
To aspy wher he myght weddid be
Prayenge our lorde graunt hym that he
Myght ones knowe that blysfull lyf
That is betwyx an husbonde and his wyf
And for to lyue vnder that holy bonde
Wyth whiche god fyrst man ⁊and woman bonde
None other lyf sayd he is worth a bene
For wedlok is so esy and so clene
That in this worlde it is a paradys
Thus sayd this olde knyght þᵗat was so wyse
¶ And certeynly as soth as god is kyng
To take a wyf is a gloruyous thyng
And namely whan a man is olde and hoor
Then is a wyf the fruyt of his tresoor
Then sholde he take a yonge wyf and a feyr
On whyche he myghte engendre hym an heyr
And lede his lyf in Ioye and in solace
Where as thyse bachelers syngen alas
Whan that they fynde ony aduersyte
In loue whyche nys but childis vanyte
And truely it syt wel to be so
That bachelers haue ofte payne and wo
On brotyll ground they bylde ⁊and brotylnesse
They fynde freelte whan thei wene sykernesse
They lyue but as bryde or as a best
In lyberte and vnder noon arest
Ther as a weddid man in his astate
Lyueth his lyf blisfull and ordynat
Vnder this yocke of maryage ybounde
Well may his hert in Ioye ⁊and blysse habounde
For who can be so buxum as a wyf
Who is so true and eke so ententyf
To kepe hym seke and hole and is his make
For wele or wo she woll hym nat forsake
She is not wery hym to loue and serue
Though that he lye bredrede tyll he sterue
And yet som clerkis sayn it is not so
Of whyche he theofraste is one of tho
What force though theofraste lyst lye
¶ Ne tak no wyf quod he for husbondrye
As for to spare in housholde thyn expence
A true seruaunt doth more dilygence
Thy good to kepe than doth thy self wyf
For she woll clayme half part all her lyf
And yf that thou be syke so god me saue
Thy very frendys or a true knaue
Woll kepe the bet than she that weyteth ay
After thy deth and hath do many a day
This sentence ⁊and an hundred thynges worse
Wryteth this man there god his bonys curse
But take no kepe of suche vanyte
Do fye theofraste and herken me
¶ A wyf is goddys yefte verily
All other maner yeftes hardely
As londis rentis pasture or comune
Or moeblis all ben yeftes of fortune
That passen as a shadowe vpon a wall
But drede not yf I playnly speke shall
A wyf woll laste and in thy hondis endure
Well lenger than the lyste perauenture
¶ Maryage is a full grete sacrament
Who that hath no wyf is but shent
He lyueth helples and is all desolat
I speke of folke in seculer astat
And herken why I saye not this for nought
The woman is for mannys helpe y wrought.
The hyghe god whan he had adam makyd
And sawe hym allone bely nakyd
God of his gret goodnesse sayd then
Let vs now make an helpe to this man
Lyk to hymself and then he made eue
Here may ye se ⁊and here by may ye preue
That a wyf is mannys help ⁊and his comfort
His paradys terrestre and his disport
So buxom and so vertuous is she
They must nedys lyue in vnite
O flesshe they be and of o blood I gesse
Not but one herte in wyll and in distresse
¶ A wyf a saynte mary benedicite
How myght a man haue ony aduersyte
That hath a wyf certes I can not seye
The blysse that is betwyx hem tweye
Ther may no tonge telle it or herte thynke
Yf he be poore she helpeth hym to swynke
She kepyth it good and wastyth it neuer a del
And all that her husbonde lust her lyketh well
She sayth not onys nay whan he sayth ye
Do this sayth he all redy syre sayth she
¶ O blysfull order o wedlok precyous
Thou art so mery and eke so vertuous
And so cōmmendyd and approuyd eke
That euery man that holte hym worth a leke
Vpon his bare knees ought all his lyf
Thankyn his god that hym hath sent a wyf
Or ellis preye god hym for to sende
A wyf to laste vnto his lyues ende
For then his lyf is set in sykernesse
He may not be disceyued as I gesse
So that he werke after his wyues reed
Then may he boldly bere vp his heed
They be so true / and therto eke so wyse
For whyche yf thow wolt werke after the wyse
Do alway as woman woll the rede
¶ Lo how Iacob as thise clerkes rede
By good connsell of his moder rebecke
Bonde the kyddis skyn abowte his necke
For whyche his faders benyson he wan
¶ Lo Iudith as the story well telle can
By wyse counsell she goddys peple kept

Lo how abigayll by good counsell what she
Saued her husbonde naball whan that he
Sholde haue be slayne and loke hester also
By good counsell delyuerde out of wo
The peple of god and made mardoche
Of assuere enhaunsyd for to be
¶ Ther is no thyng in gre superlatyf
As sayth senec aboue an humble wyf
Suffre thy wyues tonge as caton byt
She shall cōmmaunde and thou shall suffre it

A wyf is keper of thyn husbondrye
Well may the syke man bewayll and wepe
There as no wyf the hous to kepe
I warne the yf wysely wyll werche
Loue wel thy wyf as crist loueth his chirche

No man hatyth his flessh but in his lyf
He frostrith it and therfore bydde I the
Cheryssh thy wyf or thou shalt neuer the
Husbonde and wyf what so men Iape or playe

And namely vpon the wyues syde
For whiche this Ianuary of whyche I tolde
Consydetyd hath in wyth his dayes olde
The lusty lyf the vertuous quyete
That is in maryage hony swete
And for his frendys on a day he sent
To them the effect of his entent
¶ Wᵗith face sad he hath his tale to hem tolde
He sayd frendis I am hoor and olde
And almost god wote at my pyttis brynke
Vpon my soule som what muste I thynke

Blessyd be god it shal be amended
For I wolde be certeyn a weddyd man
And that anon in all the hast I can
Vnto some mayde fayr and tendre of age
I pray yow shapyth for my maryage
All sodenly for I woll not abyde
And I woll fonde to aspye on my syde
To whom I may be weddid hastely
But for as moche as ye be mo than I
Ye shull rather suche a thyng espyen

¶ But o thyng warne I you my frendis dere
I wyll noon olde wyf haue in no manere
She shall not passe . xvi . yere certayn
Olde fysshe and yonge flesshe wyll I haue full fayn
Bet is layd he a pike than a pikerell
Better than olde beif is the tendre veel
I woll no woman of . xxx . yere of age
It is but bene strawe and grete forage
And eke thyse olde widowes god it wote
They cunne so moche crafte in wadis bote
So moche broken harme what hem lyst

For sundry scolys makyth subtyll clerkys
Woman of many a scole half a clerke is
But certenly a yonge thynge may men gye
Ryght as a man wyth hondis warm wex plye
Therfore I say you playnly in a clause
I wold none olde wyf haue for this cause
¶ For yf so were yf I had suche myschaunce
That I in her cowde haue no plesaunce
Then sholde I lede my lyf in auoutrye
And so streyght to the denyll whan I dey
Ne chyldren sholde I none on her getyn
Yet had I leuer houndes had me eten
Then that myn herytage sholde fall
In straunge honde and thus I telle you all
I dote not I wote the cause why
Men sholde wedde and ferthermore wote I
There spekyth many men of mariage
That wote nomore of it than doth my page
For whyche causis men sholde take a wyf
Yf he may not iyuen chast his lyf
Take hym a wyf wyth grete deuocyon
By cause of lefull procreacyon
Of chyldren to the honour of god aboue
And not only for paramour ne for loue
And for they shold lechery escheu
And yelde her dette whan that it is due
Or for that eche of hem shold helpe other
In myscheyf as a syster shall the brother
And lyue in chastyte full holyly
¶ But syres by your leue that am not I
For god bethankyd I dare make auaunt
I fele my lymes sterk and suffycyaunt
To do all that a man belongyth to
I wote myself best what I may do
And am stronge ynough to ryde or go
Though I be hoor I fare as doth a tre
That blosmed or that fruyt y woxen be

I fele me no where hoor but on my hed
My herte and all my lymes ben as grene

And sythnes ye haue herde all myn entent
I pray you that to my wyll ye assent
¶ Dyuerse men dyuersly hym tolde
Of maryage many ensamples olde
Some blamyd it some praysed it certeyn
But at the laste shortly for to sayn
As alday falleth altercacyon
Betwyx frendis in disputacyon

Full lytyll nede had ye my lorde so dere

To weyue fro the worde of Salomon

Werk all thynge by counsell thus sayd he
And then shalt not thou repent the

For brother myn of me take this motyf

That serueth a lorde of hyghe honour
That dare presume or onys thynke it

Ye haue yourself spoken here to day
So hyghe sentence so holy and so well
That I consent and conferme euerydell
Your wordis and all your opynyoun
By god there is no man in this toun
Ne in ytaylle cowde better haue sayd
Cryst holdyth hym of this full well payd
And truely it is an hyghe corage
Of ony man than that stept is in age
To take a yonge wyf for by my fader kyn
Your herte hongyth vpon a Ioly pyn
Doth now in this mater as you lest
For fynally I holde it for the best
¶ Iustinus that ay sat full stylle and herde
Ryght on this wyse he to placebo answerde
Now brother myn quod he be pacyent I praye
Syn ye haue sayd herken what I saye

To whome I yeue my good awaye fro me
Well moche more I ought for to auyse me
To whome I yeue my body for alwaye
I warne you well it is no childis play
To take a wyf wythout a vysement
Men must enquyren this is myn assent
Whether she be wyse sobre or dronklewe
An outgoer or other waye a shrewe
A chydester or waster of thy good

All be it so that no man fynde shall
