Ne man ne best suche as men can denyse
But neuertheles it ought ynough suffyse
With ony wyf yf so were that she hadde
Moo thewes good than her vices badde
And all this axeth leyser to enquyre
For god it wote I haue wept full many a tere
Full pryuely syn I had a wyf
Prayse who so woll a wedded mannys lyf
Certeyn I fynde it but coste and care
And obseruantis of all blysses bare
And yet god wote myn neyghbours abowte
And namely of wymen many a rowte
Sayn that I haue the moost stedfast wyf
And eke the mekest one that beryth lyf
But I wote best where wryngeth me my sho
Ye may for me ryght as ye lyke do
Auyseth you ye be a man of age
How that ye entren in to maryage
And namely wyth a yonge wyf and a feyre
By hym that made water erthe and eyre
The yongest man that in all this rowte
Is besy ynough to brynge it abowte
To haue a wyf alone but trustyth me
Ye shull not plesen her only yerys thre
This is to sey to do her full plesaunce
A wyf axeth full many an obseruance
I praye you that ye be not euyll apayd
¶ Well quod this Ianuary ⁊and hast thou sayd
Straw for thy senek and for thy prouerbes
I count not a panyer full of herbes
Of scole termes wyser men than thou
As thou hast herde hath sentyd ryght now
To my purpos . placebo what say ye
¶ I say it is a cursyd man quod he
That lettyth matrymony sykerly
And wyth that worde they rysen sodenly
And ben assentid anone that he sholde
Be weddid whan hym lyst ⁊and where he wolde
¶ Hyghe fantasye and the besy curyousnesse
Fro daye to daye gan in the soule impresse
Of Ianuary abowte his maryage
Many fayr shap and many fayr visage
Ther passyth thrugh his hert nyght by nyght
As who so toke a myrrour polysshid bryght
And let it in a comyn market place
Then sholde he se many a fygure pace
By this myrrour and in the same wyse
Gan Ianuary in wyth his thought deuyse
Of maydens whyche dwelled there besyde
He wyst not where he myght abyde
For yf that one haue bewte in her face
A nother stont so in the peples grace
For her sadnesse and her benygnyte
That of the peple grete voys had she
And some were ryche and had badde name
But netheles betwyx ernest and game
He atte laste appoyntid hym on one
And lete all other fro his herte gone
And chose her of his owne auctorite
For loue is blynde all daye and may not se
And whan he was in his bedde y broughte
He portreyed in his herte and in his thought
Her fresshe bewte and her age tender
Her myddyll smal her armys long and slender
Her wyse gouernaunce and her gentylnesse
Her womanly berynge and her sadnesse
And whan he was on her condescendid
Hym thought his choys myȝt not be amendyd
For whan he hymself concludyd hadde
Hym thought eche other mannys wyt so badd
That impossyble it were to replye
Ayens his choys this was his fantasye
¶ His frendys sent he to at his Instaunce
And prayed hem to do hym that plesaunce
That hastely they wolde to hem come
He wolde abredge her labour all and some
Nedyth nomore for hym to go ne ryde
He was apoyntid there he wolde abyde
¶ Placebo cam and eke his frendis sone
And alderfyrst he bad hem alle a bone
That non of hem non argument shold make
Ayens the purpoos whyche that he had y take
Whyche purpos was plesaunt to god sayd he
And very grounde of his prosperyte
¶ He sayd there was a mayden in the toun
Whyche that of bewte had grete renoun
Al were it so she was of small degre
Suffyseth hym her youth and her beaute
Whiche mayde he sayd he wold haue to his wyf
To lede in ese and holynesse his lyf
And thanke god that he myght haue her all
That no wyght wyth his blysse parten shall
And prayed hem to labour in this nede
And shapen that he faylleth not to spede
For then he sayd his spyryte was at ese
Than is quod he no thynge me may displese
Saue o thynge pryketh me my conscyence
The whyche I woll reherce in your presence
Ye haue herd sayd full long sythnis agoo
Ther may no man haue perfyt blysses two
This is to say in erthe and eke in heuen
For though he kepe hym fro the synnes seuen
And eke from eueryche braunche of that tre
Yet is there so perfyt prosperyte
And so grete ese and lust inmaryage
That euer I am agast now in myn age
That I shal lede now so mery a lyf
So delycate wythout wo and stryf
That I shall haue myn heuen in erthe here
For syth very heuen is bought so dere
Wyth trybulacyon and grete penaunce
How shold then that lyue in suche plesaunce
As all weddid men donn wyth her wyues
Com to the blys that crist etern on lyue is
This is my drede and ye my bretheen twey
Assoylieth me this questyon I you prey
¶ Iustinus whyche that hatyd his foly
Answerd anone ryght in his Iapery
And for he wolde his longe tale abredge
He wolde none auctoryte aledge
But sayd syre yf there be none obstacle
Other than this god of his hyghe myracle
And of his mercy may so for you werche
That er ye haue youe rightis of holy chyrche
Yo may repente of weddid mannys lyf
In whyche ye saye ther is no wo ne stryf
And ellys god forbede but yf he sent
A weddyd man grace hym to repente
Well ofter rather than a syngyll man
And therfore the beste rede that I can
Dispeyreth you not but haue in youre memorye
Parauenture she may be your purgatorye
She may be goddys mene ⁊and goddis whyppe
Then shall your soule vp to heuen skyppe
Swyfter than an arowe doth out of a bowe
I hope to god here after shall ye knowe
That ther nys non so grete felycyte
In maryage ne neuer none shall be
That you shall lette of your saluacyon
So that ye vse as skyll is and reson
The lustys of your wyf temperetly
And that ye plese her not to amerously
And that ye kepe you eke from other synne
My tale is doon for my wyt is thynne
Beth not agast here of my dere brother
But lete vs wade fro this matere to a nother
The wyf of bathe yf ye haue vnderstonde
Of maryage whyche I haue in honde
Declaryd hath full well in lytyll space
Fareth now well god haue you in his grace
¶ And wyth this worde he wyth his brother
Hath take her leue and ech of hem of other
For whan they sawe that it must nedys be
They wroughte so by slye and wyse trete
That this mayde whyche that mayus hyghte
As hastely as euer that she myghte
Shall weddyd be vnto Ianuary
I trowe it were you to longe to tary
Yf I you tolde of euery escrit and bonde
By whyche she was feffyd in his londe
Other for to herke of her ryche aray
But fynally comyn is the daye
That to the chyrche bothe ben they went
For to receyue the holy sacrament
¶ Forth comyth the preest wᵗith stole abowte his neck
And badd her be like sarra and rebeck
In wysdom and trouth of maryage
And sayd his oryson in his vsage
And crowchid hem ⁊and bad god shold hem bles
And made all syker ynough wyth holynes
¶ Thus ben they weddid wyth solempnyte
And at the feste sytteth he and she
Wyth other worthy folke vpon the deys
All full of Ioye and blysse is the paleys
And full of Instrumentes and vitayll
The most deynteous of all ytayll
Beforn hem stode Instrument of suche a soun
That orpheus ne of thebes amphioun
Ne made neuer suche a melodye
¶ At euery cours cam lowde mynstralsye
That neuer Ioab trompyd for to here
Neyther he theodomas half so clere
At thebes whan the cyte was in doute
Bachus the wyne hem shenkyth all abowte
And venus lough vpon euery wyght
For Ianuary was becomen her knyght
And wolde bothe assayen his corage
In liberte and eke in maryage
And wyth her fyerbronde in her hond abowte
Daunsyth beforn the pryde and all the rowte
And certeynly I dare well sayn ryght this
Emenyus that god of weddyng is
Sawe neuer in his lyf so mery a weddyd man
¶ Holde thou thy pees thou poete marcian
That wrytist vs that ylke weddynge mery
Of her philologye and of hym mercurye
And of songis that the musis songe
To small is bothe penne and eke tonge
For to discryuen of this maryage
Whan tend youth had weddyd stoupyng age
Ther is suche myrthe that it may not be wrytēn
Allay yourself and then may ye wyten
Yf that I lacke or none in this matere
¶ Mayus that syt wyth so benygne a chere
Here to eiholden it semyth fayrye
Quene hester lokyd neuer wyth suche an eye
On assuere so meke a loke as she
I may you not deuyse all her bewte
But thus moche of her bewte telle I may
That she was lyke the bryght morow of may
Fulfylled of all bewte and plesaunce
¶ This Ianuary is rauysshed in a traunce
At euery tyme he lokyd on her face
But in his hert he gan hero manace
That he that nyght in armys wolde her streyn
Harder than euer parys dyde eleyne
But netheles yet had he grete pyte
That that nyght offende her must he
And thought alas o tender creature
Now wolde god ye myght well endure
All my corage it is so sharpe and kene
I am agast ye maye it not sustene
But god forbede I dyde all my myght
Now wolde god it were woxe nyght
And that the nyghte wolde last euermo
I wolde that all this peple were ago
And fynally he doth all his labour
As he best myght sauynge his honour
To haue hem fro the mete in subtyll wyse
The tyme came that reson was to ryse
And after that men dauncyd and dranke faste
And spicys all abowte the hous they caste
And full of Ioye and blysse is euery man
Alle but a squyer hyght damyan
Whyche carf before the knyght many a day
Hr was so rauysshyd on his lady may
That for the very payne he was nyghe wood
Almost he sweltyd ⁊and swowned there he stode
So sore hath venus hurt hym wyth her bronde
As that she bare it daunsynge in her honde
And to his bed he went hym hastely
Nomore of hym at this tyme speke I
But there I lete hym wepe ynough and pleyne
Tyll fresshe may woll rewe on his payn
O perlous fyre that in the bedstraw bredyth
O famylyar foo that his seruyse bedyth
O seruaunt traytour fals homely hewe
Lyk to the adder Nygh in bosom vntrue
God shelde vs all from your acqueyntaunce
¶ O Ianuary dronken in plesaunce
Of maryage se how that thy damyan
Thyn owne squyre and thy born man
Entendyth for to do the a vylonye
God graunt the thyn homly fo for to espye
For in this worlde nys wors pestylence
Than an homly foo all day in thy presence
Parfourmyd hath the sonne his arke dyurne
No lenger may the body of hym soiourne
On the orysont as in that latitude
Nyght wyth his māntell that is so derke ⁊and rude
Gan for to sprede the emyspery abowte
For whyche departed is the lusty rowte
Fro Ianuary wyth thank on euery syde
Hoom to theyr houses lustyly they ryde
There as they do thynges as hem lest
And whan they se her tyme they go to rest
¶ Sone after this hastely this Ianuary
Wolde go to bedde he wolde no lenger tary
He drynketh ypocras clarrey and vernage
And spicys hote to encrece his corage
And many a lettuary had he full fyn
Suche as the cursyd monk dan constantyn
Hath wryten in his boke of coitu
To ete hem all he wolde no thyng escheu
And thus to his preuy frendys sayd he
For goddys loue as sone as it may be
Lete voyde all this hous in curteys wyse
And they haue doon right as he woll deuyse
¶ Men dronken and the trauers drewe anone
This bryde was brouȝt to bed as styll as stoone
And whan the bed was wyth the prest blessyd
Out of þᵉ chambre hath euery wight hy dressid
And Ianuary hah faste in armes take
His fresshe may his paradys his make
He lulleth her he kisseth her full ofte
Wyth the brystyls of his berde vnsofte
Lyke to þᵉ skyn of hound fyssh sharpe as brere
For he was shaue all newe in his manere
He rubbyth her vpon her tender face
And sayd thus alas I must trespace
To you my spouse and you gretly offende
Er tyme come that I woll downe descende
¶ But netheles consyderyth this quod he
Ther is no werkman what so euer he be
That may bothe werke well and hastely
This wolde be do at leyser perfytly
It is no force how longe that we pleye
In true wedlok cowplyd be we tweye
And blessyd be the yocke that we been ynne
For in our actes we mow do no synne
A man may do no synne wyth his wyf
Ne hurte hymself wyth his owne knyf
For we haue leue to playe vs by the lawe
Thus labouryth he tyll the day gan dawe
And then he takyth a sop in fyn clarre
And vpryght in his bedde sytteth he
And after that he song full lowde and clere
And kysseth his wyf and makith wanton cher`
He was all coltysshe and full of ragery
And full of Iergon as is a fleckyd pye
The slak skyn abowte his necke shakyth
Whyle that he songe so chauntyd he ⁊and crakyth
But god wote what may thoughte in her hert
Whan she hym sawe vp syttyng in his shert
In his nyght cappe and wyth his necke lene
She prayseth not his playenge worth a bene
Then sayd he thus my rest woll I take
Now day is come I may no lenger wake
And doun he layd his hede and slept tyll pryme
And after whan that he saw his tyme
Vp ryseth Ianuary but fresshe may
She holdyth her chambre vnto the fourth day
As vsage is of wyues for the best
For euery labour somtyme must haue rest
Or ellys longe maye he not endure
This is to saye no lyues creature
Be it fysshe or byrde or best or man
Now woll I speke of wofull damyan
That languryth for loue as ye shull here
¶ I say o sely damyan alas
Answere to this demaunde as in this caas
How shalt thou thy lady fresshe may
Telle thy wo she woll alway say nay
Eke yf thow speke she woll thy wo bewreye
God be thy helpe I can no better sayen
¶ This syk damyan in venus grete fyre
So brenneth that he dyeth for desyre
For whyche he puttyth his lyf in auenture
No lenger myght he in this wyse endure
But pryuely a penner gan he borowe
And in a lettre wroot he all his sorwe
In manere of a compleynt or a laye
Vnto his fresshe and fayr lady may
And in a purs of sylke hynge it on his shert
He hath it put and y layd it at his hert
That Ianuary hath weddyd fresshe may
¶ The mone that at none was that day
In two of taure was in to cankre slyden
So longe hath mayus in her chambre byden
As custome is vnto this nobles all
A bryde shall not eten in the halle
Tyll dayes foure or thre dayes atte lest
Passyd be then let her go to feste
¶ The fourth daye complet fro none to none
Whan that the hyghe masse was done
In halle sat this Ianuary and may
As fresshe as is the bryght someris daye
And so befell that this good man
Remembreth hym vpon this damyan
And sayd saynt mary how may this be
That damyan entendyth not to me
Is he ay syk or how may this betyde
¶ His squyre whiche that stoden hym besyde
Excused hym by cause of his siknesse
Whyche lettyth hym to do his besynesse
Noue other cause myght make hym to tary
¶ That me forthynketh quod this Ianuarye
He is a gentyll squyre by my trouthe
Yf that he deyde it were harm and rewthe
He is as wys discrete and secre
As ony man I wote of his degre
And therto manly and eke seruysa ble
And for to be a thryfti man ryght able
But after mete as sone as euer I may
I wyll myself vysyte hym and may
To do hym all the confort that I can
And for that worde hym blessyd euery man
That of his bonnte and his gentylnesse
He wolde so comforte in syknesse
His squyre for it was a gentyll dede
¶ Dame quod this Ianuary take good hede
That after mete ye wyth youre yomen all
Whan ye haue be in chambre out of this halle
That all ye go se this damyan
To do hym disporte he is a gentyll man
And tellyth that I wyll hym visyte
Haue I no thynge but restyd me a lyte
And spede you fast for I woll abyde
Tyll that ye slepe faste by my syde
And wyth this worde he gan hym to calle
A squyre that was marchall of his halle
And tolde hym certeyn thynges what he wold
¶ This fressh may hath streyt her wey hold
Wyth alle her wymen vnto this damyan
Downe by his syde anon sate she then
Comfortyng hym as goodly as she may
¶ This damyan whan he his tyme say
In preuy wyse his purs and eke his bylle
In whyche that he wryten had all his wyll
Hath put in to her honde wythouten more
Saue that he syghed ryght wonderly sore
And softly to her ryght thus sayd he
Mercy and that ye discouer not me
For I am ded yf that this thynge be kyd
¶ This byll hath she in her bosom hyd
And went her way ye gete nomore of me
Vnto Ianuary comen then is she
And on his beddys syde sat full softe
And taketh her and kysseth her full oft
And layd hym downe to slepe ⁊and that anone
She feyned her as that she must goone
There as ye wote euery wight must nede
And whan she of this bylle hath taken hede
She rente it all to clowtis at the laste
In the preuy softly hath she it caste
¶ Who studyeth now but fayr fresshe may
And downe bi olde Ianuary she lay
That sleppyd tyl the cough hath hym wakid
Anone he prayde her to strype her nakyd
He wolde of her he sayd haue some plesaunce
He sayd her clothis dyde hym encumbraunce
And she obeyth be she leyf or loth
But lest that precyous folke with me be wroth
How that he wrought I dare you not telle
Or whether her thought it paradys or helle
But here I lete hem werke in her wyse
Tyll euensonge and that they must aryse
Were it by destyne or by auenture
Were it by Influence or bi nature
Other constyllacyon that in in suche astate
The heuen stood that tyme fortunate
Was for to put a byll of venus werkis
For all thynge hath tyme as sayn clerkys
To ony woman for to gete her loue
I can not say but grete god aboue
That knoweth that none acte is causelees
He demyth all for I woll holde my pees
¶ But soth it is how that this fresshe may
Hath take suche Impressyon that daye
Of pyte on this syk man damyan
That fro her hert sle ne dryue she can
The remembraunce for to do hym ese
Certeyn thought she whom that this thing displese
I here recke not I hym assure
To loue hym best of ony creature
Though he nomore had than his shert
¶ Lo pyte rennyth sone in gentyll hert
Here may ye se how excellent fraunchyse
In wymen is whan they hem narow auyse
Some tyraunt ther is as there be many one
That hath an herte as harde as ony stone
Whyche wolde haue lete sterue in the place
Well rather than haue grauntyd hym grace
And hem reioysen in her cruell pryde
And recke not to be an homycide
¶ This gentyll may fulfylled of pyte
Ryght of her honde a letter maked she
In whyche she grauntyd hym her very grace
Ther lackyd not but only day and space
Where that she myght to his lust suffyse
For it shall be ryght as he woll deuyse
And whan she saw her tyme vpon a day
To visite this damyan goth this fresshe may
And subtylly a letter downe she thryst
Vnder his pylow red it yf hym lyst
She takyth hym by the hond ⁊and harde hy twyst
So secretly that no man it wyst
And bad hym be all hole ⁊and forth she went
To Ianuary whan that he for her sent
¶ Vp ryseth damyan the next morowe
All passyd was his syknes and his sorowe
He kembeth hym ⁊and proyneth hym ⁊and pyckyth
He doth all that his lady lust and lykyth
And eke to Ianuary he goth as lowe
As euer dide a dogge for the bowe
He is so plesaunt to euery man
For craft is all who so that it can
That euery wyȝt is fayne to speke hym good
And fully in his ladyes grace he stode
Thus lete I damyan abowte his nede
And in my tale forth I woll procede
¶ Some clerkyis holden that felycyte
Stont in delyt and therfore certeyn he
This noble Ianuary with all his myght
In honest wyse as longeth to a knyght
Shope hym to lyue full delycyously
His housyng his aray as honestly
To his degre was made as a kynges
Amonge other of his honest thynges
He had a gardeyn wallyd all wyth stone
So fayr a gardyn wot I nowher none
For out of dowte I verily suppose
That he that wrote the romans of the rose
Ne cowde of it the bewte well deuyse
Ne priapus ne myght not suffyse
Though he be god of gardyns for to telle
The bewte of the gardyn and the welle
That stode vnder a lawrer alwaye grene
Full ofte tyme kyng pluto and his quene
Proserpina and alle her feyrye
Disporten hem and make melodye
Abowte that welle and dauncyd an men tolde
¶ This noble knyght this Ianuary the olde
Suche deynte hath in it to walke and pleye
That he woll suffre no wyght suffre bere the key
Saue he hymself for of the smale wycket
He bar alwey of syluer a clyket
Wyth the whyche whan he lyst vnshet
And whan he wolde pay his wyf his dette
In somer seson thyther wolde he go
And may his wyf ⁊and no wyght but they two
And thynges that were not do a bedde
He in the gardyn parfourmyd hem and spedde
And in this wyse many a mery day
Lyuen this Ianuary and fresshe may
But worldly ioye may not alwey dure
To Ianuary ne to no worldly creature
¶ O sodeyn hap o thou fortune vnstable
Lyk vnto the scorpyon so dysceyuable
That flatrest wᵗith thy hede whan þᵘ wylt stynge
Thy tayll is deth thrugh thyn euenymyng
O brytyll Ioy o thou swete poysoun queynt
O thou monstre that subtylly canst peynt
Thy gyftes vnder hewe of stedfastnesse
That thou disceyuest bothe more and lesse
Why hast thou Ianuary thus disceyued
That haddest hym for thy frende receyued
And now thou hast beraft both his eyen
For sorowe of whyche desyreth to deyen
Alas this Ianuary that is so free
Amyd his lust and his prosperyte
Is now woxen blynde and that all sodenly
He wepith and he waylleth pytously
And therwyth all the fyre of Ielosye
Lest that his wyf sholde falle in som folye
So brent his hert that he wolde fayn
That some man bothe hym ⁊and her had slayn
For neuer after his deth ne his lyf
Ne wolde he that she were loue ne wyf
But euer lyue as wydow in clothes blake
Sool as the turtyll that hath lost her make
But atte laste after a monthe or tweye
His sorow gan to swage soth to seye
For he wyst it may none other be
He pacyently toke his aduersyte
Saue out of dowte he may not forgon
That he ne was Ielous euermore in one
Whyche Ielousye it was so outrageous
That neyther in halle ne in other hous
Ne in none other place neuer the mo
He nolde suffre her for to ryde ne go
But yf that he had honde on her alwaye
For whyche full ofte wepyth fresshe may
That louyth damyan so tenderly
That she must other dyen sodenly
Or ellys she must haue hym as her lest
She wayteth whan her hert wolde to breste
¶ Vpon that other syde this damyan
Becomyn is the sorowfullyst man
That euer was for neyther nyght ne day
Ne myght he speke a worde wyth fresshe may
As of his purpose of none suche matere
But yf that Ianuary muste it here
That had an honde vpon her euer mo
But nethelees by wrytynge to and fro
And preuy signes wyste he what she ment
And she knew eke the same of his entent
¶ O Ianuary what myght the auaylle
Though þᵘ myghtist se as fer as ship doth sayl
For as good blynde is disceyued to be
As to be disceyued whan a man may se
¶ Lo argus whyche that had an hundred eyen
For all that euer he cowde poor or pryen
Yet was he blent and god wote so be mo
That wenen well that it is no thynge so
Passe ouer is an ese I saye no more
¶ This fressh may of whyche I spake of yore
In warm wex hath prynted this clyket
That Ianuary bare of the smale wycket
By whyche vnto his gardyn ofte he went
And damyan that kneweher entent
The clyket counterfetyd pryuely
Ther is no more to say but hastely
Some wonder by this clyket shall be tyde
Whyche ye shall here yf ye woll abyde
¶ O noble ouyde soth sayst thou god wote
What sleyght it is though it be longe and hote
That he nyll fynde it out in some manere
By pyramus and tysbe men may here
Though they were kept streyt longe ouer all
They ben acorded rownyng thrugh a wall
Ther no wight coude haue foıı̄unde suche a sleyghte
But now to purpoos or þᵗat dayes eyghte
Were passyd or the monthe of Iuyll be fyll
That Ianuary hath caught so grete a wyll
Thrugh eggyng of his wyf hym for to pley
In his gardyn and no wyght but they twey
That in a morow vnto this may sayd he
Ryse vp my wyf my loue my lady fre
The turtelys voys I herde my spowse swete
The wynter is goon wyth his raynes wete
Come forth wyth thyn eyen columbyne
Now fayrer ben thyn eyen than is wyn
The gardyn is closyd all abowte
Come forth my swete spowse out of dowte
Thou hast me wounded in my hert o wyf
No spot of the ne knew I all my lyf
Come forth and lete vs taken our disporte
I chees the for my wyf ⁊and my comfort
Suche olde lewde wordes vsyd he
On damyan a sygne made she
That he sholde go before wyth his clyket
This damyan hath openy the wycket
And in he stert and that in suche manere
That no wyght myght it se ne here
And stylle he sat vnder a busshe anone
¶ This Ianuary as blynde as is a stone
Wyth may in his honde and no wyght mo
In to this f resshe gardyn is he go
And clappyd to the wycket sodenly
¶ Now wyf quod he here nys but thou and I
That art the creature that I best loue
For by that lorde that syt vs all aboue
I had leuer ryght now dey on a knyf
Than the offenden myn owne dere wyf
For goddys sake thynke how I the chees
Not for couetyse ne other good doutlees
But only for the loue I had to the
And though that I be olde and may not se
Be to me true and I woll telle the why
Certis thre thynges sholde ye wynne therby
Fyrst loue of crist and to yourself honour
And all myn heritage both towne and tour
I yeue it you makyth chartres as ye lyst
This sall be do to morow or sonne ryst
So wysly god my soule brynge in blysse
And I praye you of couenaunt ye me kysse
And though I be Ielous wyte me nought
Ye be so depe pryntid in my thought
That whan I consydre your bewte
And therwyth all the vnlyklyelde of me
I may not certis though I sholde dye
Forbere to ben out of your companye
For very loue this is wythouten dowte
Now kys me wyf and lete vs rome abowte
¶ This fresshe may whan she þᵉ wordis herde
Benygnely to Ianuary answerde
But fyrst and forwarde she began to wepe
I haue quod she a soule for to kepe
As well as ye and also my honour
And of wyfhode that tender flour
Whyche that I haue assuryd in your honde
Whan that the preest to you my body bonde
Wherfore I woll answere in this manere
Wyth the leue of you my lorde so dere
¶ I pray to god that neuer dawe that day
That I ne sterue as fowle as woman may
Yf euer I do to my kynne that shame
Or ellys that I empeyre so my name
That I be fals and yf I do that lacke
Do stripe me and put me in a sak
And in the next ryuer do me drenche
I am a gentyll woman and no wenche
Why speke ye thus but men be euer vntrue
And wymen haue repreef of you ay newe
Ye can none other cōmmunycacyon I leue
But speke to vs of vntrust and vs repreue
And wyth that worde she saw where damyan
Sat in the busshe and knele he began
And wyth her fyngres sygnes made she
That damyan sholde clymbe vpon a tre
That chargyd was wyth fruyt ⁊and vp he went
For verily he knewe all her entent
And euery sygne that she cowde make
Well bet than Ianuary her owne make
For in a letter she hadde tolde hym all
Of this matere how he werke shall
And thus I lete hym sytte in the pery
And Ianuary wyth may romynge mery
Bryȝt was the sonne ⁊and blew the firmament
Phebus of gold doun his bemes hath sent
To gladen euery floure wyth his warmnesse
He was that tyme in geminis as I gesse
But lytyll fro his declynacyon
Of cancer Iouis exaltacyon
And so it fell that in a bryght morow tyde
That in that gardyn on the ferther syde
Pluto that is kynge of feyrie
And many a lady in his companye
Folwynge his wyf the quene proserpyne
Eche after other ryght as ony lyne
Whyles that she gadrid flouris in a mede
In claudyan ye may the storyes rede
How in his grysly cart he her sette
This kyng of feyri adowne hym sette
Vpon a benche of turues fayr and grene
And ryght anone sayd he to his quene
¶ My wyf qd he ther may no wyght say nay
The experyence so prouyth it euery day
The treson whiche that wyman do to men
Ten hundrid thowsande tellen I can
Ensamples and of your vntrouth ⁊and britylnesse
O salomon wyse and rychest of ryches
Fulfyllid of sapyence and of worldly glorye
Well worthy be thy wordes in memory
To euery wyght that wyt and reson can
Thus prayseth he yet the bounte of man
¶ Among a thousand men yet fonde I one
But of alle wymen fond he neuer none
Th9 sayd the kyng þᵗat knoweth your wickidnes
And Iesus filius sirack as I gesse
Ne spekyth of you but seldom reuerence
A wylde fyre and a corupt pestylence
So falle on your bodyes yet to nyght
Ne se ye not this honourable knyght
By cause alas he is blynde and olde
His owne man shall make hym cokeolde
Lo where he syt the lechour in the tre
Now woll I graunte of my mageste
Vnto this olde blynde worthy knyght
That he shall haue ayen his eyen syght
Whan that his wyf wolde do hym vylonye
Ther shall he knowe all her harlotrye
Bothe in repreyf of her and other mo
¶ Ye shall quod proserpyne and woll ye so
Now by my moders soule syre I swere
That I shall yeue her suffycient answere
And all wymen after for her sake
Though they be in ony gylt y take
Wyth face bolde they shall hemself excuse
And bere hym downe that wolde hem accuse
For lak of answer none of hem shall dyen
All had he seen a thyng wyth bothe his eyen
Yet shull we wymen vysage it hardely
And wepe and swere and chyde subtylly
So that ye men sholde be as lewde as gees
What recketh me of your auctorytees
¶ I wote well this Iewe this salomon
Fond of vs wymen mo folis than one
But though ne he fond no good woman
Yet haue ther founden many a nother man
Wymen full true full good and vertuous
Wytnes of hem that dwelle in crystis hous
Wyth martyrdom they preuyd theyr constance
The romayn gestys eke make remembraunce
Of many a very true wyf also
But syr ne be not wroth also
All though he sayd he foud no good woman
I pray you take the sentence of the man
He ment thus that in souereyn bounte
Nys none but god that sytteth in trinyte
¶ Ey for very god that is but on
What make ye so moche of salomon
What though he made a temple goddis hous
What though he were ryche and gloryous
So made he eke a temple of false goddys
How myght he do a thyng þᵗat more forbode is
Parde as fayre as ye his name enplastre
He was a lechour and eke an ydolaster
And in his elde he very god forsoke
And yf god ne had as sayth the boke
Y spared hym for his fader sake he sholde
Haue lost his regne rather than he wolde
I yeue ryght nought of all the vylonye
That he of wymen wryteth a butter flye
I am a woman nedys must I speke
Or ellys swelle tyll myn herte breke
For sythen ye say that we be Iangeleressis
As euer I myght broke hole my tressis
I shall not spare now for no curtesye
To speke hym harm that wolde vs vylonye
¶ Dame quod this pluto be no lenger wroth
I yeue it vp but syth I swere myn othe
That I woll graunt hym his syght ayen
My worde shall stonde I saye you certeyn
I am a kynge it syt me not to lye
¶ And I a quene quod she of the fayrie
Her answere shall she haue I vndertake
Lete vs no mo wordis herof make
Forsoth I woll you no lenger contrarye
¶ Now lete vs turne ayen to Ianuary
That in the gardyn wyth his fresshe may
Syngeth full meryer than the popyngeay
Yow loue I best and shall and other none
So longe abowte the aleys is he goone
Tyll he was come ayenst the ylke pery
Where as this damyan sytteth full mery
And hyghe amonge the fresshe leuys grene
¶ This fresshe may that is so bryght ⁊and shene
Gan for to syghe and sayd alas my syde
Now syre quod she for ought that may betyde
I muste haue of the perys that I se
Or I must dye so sore longyth me
To ete of the smale perys grene
Help for her loue that is of heuen quene
I telle you well a woman in my plyt
May haue in fruyt so gret an appetyt
That she may deye but she of it haue
¶ Alas quod he that I ne had here a knaue
That cowde clymbe alas alas quod he
For I am blynde ye syr no force quod she
But wolde ye vouchesauf for goddis sake
¶ The pery wythin your harmys for to take
For well I wote that ye mystrust me
Then sholde I clymbe well ynough quod she
So I my fete myght set vpon youre bak
¶ Certis quod he therof shall be no lack
Myght I you helpen wyth myn herte blood
He stoupeth a downe and on his bak she stood
And caught her by a twyste ⁊and vp she gooth
Ladyes I praye you be not wrooth
I can no glose I am a rude man
And sodenly anone this damyan
Gan pulle vp the smok and in he thronge
¶ And whan that pluto sawe this that wronge
To Ianuary yaf ayen his syght
And made hym se as well as euer he myght
And whan þᵗat he had caught his syght agayn
Ne was there no man of thynge so fayn
But on his wyf his thought was euer mo
¶ Vp to the tre he cast his eyen two
And saw how damyan his wyf had dressyd
In suche manere it may not be expressyd
But yf I wolde speke vncurteysly
Out helpe alas harow he gan cry
O stronge lady hore what dost thou
¶ And she answerde syre what eyleth you
Haue pacyence and reson in your mynde
I haue you holpen on both youre eyen blynde
Vp peryll of my soule I shall not lyen
As me was taught to hele wyth youre eyen
Was no thyng bet to make you to se
Than for to strogyll wyth a man in a tre
God wote I dyde it in full good entent
¶ Strogyll quod he ye algate in it went
God yeue you both on shamys deth to deyen
He dyde the so I sawe it wyth myn eyen
And ellys I be hangyd by the hals
¶ Then is quod she my medycyne fals
For certenly yf ye myght se
Ye wolde not say thyse wordes to me
Ye haue some glymsyng and not perfyt syghte
¶ I se quod he as well as euer I myght
Thankyd be god wyth both myn eyen two
And by my trough me thought he dyde so
¶ Ye maas good syre quod she
This thanke haue I for I made you se
Alas quod she that euer I was so kynde
¶ Now dame quod he let all passe out of myde
Come downe my leyf and yf I haue myssayd
God help me so I am euyll apayd
But by my fader soule I went haue seyn
How that this damyan had by the leyn
And that thy smok he layd vpon his brest
¶ Ye syre quod she ye may wene as ye lest
But syre qd she a man þᵗat wakyth of his slepe
He may not so sodenly take keep
Vpon a thynge ne se it so perfytly
Tyll that he be well adawed verely
Ne may not sodenly so sone well se
Fyrst whan his syght is newe comen ageyn
As he that hath a day or tweyne y seen
Tyll that your syght y satelyd be a whyle
Ther may full many a syght you begyle
Beware I pray you for by heuen kyng
Full many a man weneth to see a thyng
And yet it is all a nother than it semyth
He that mysconceyueth ofte mys demyth
And wyth that worde she lept fro the tre
¶ This Ianuary who is glad but he
He kysseth her and clyppeth her full oft
And on her wombe he striketh her full softe
And to his paleys home he hath her lad
Now good men I pray you be mery ⁊and glad
Thus endyth here my tale of Ianuary
God blesse vs all and his moder mary

l.hi:
Here endyth the marchauntis
tale And begynneth the squy
res prologue

div.l: And begynneth the squy res prologue
OVr hoste in his stiroppis stondyth anon
And sayd godemen herkenyth euerichon
This was a sharpe tale for the nonys
Syre paryssh preest quod he for goddys bonys
Tell vs a tale as was thy forwarde yore
Knowe moche thynge by goddis dignyte
¶ The person hym answerde benedicite
What eyleth the man so synfully to swere
¶ Oure host answerde o Iankyn be ye there
I smelle a lollere in the wynde quod he
¶ Now good men quod our hoost herkenyth me
Abydeth for goddis dygne passyon
For we shull haue now a predicacion
This lollere woll preche vs here somwhat
¶ Nay by my faders soule that shall he not
Sayde the squyer he shall not here preche
He shall no gospell gloce here ne teche
We leue all in the grete god quod he
He wolde sowe some diffyculte
Or spryngen cokyll in our clene corn
And therfore hoost I warne the beforn
My Ioly body shall a tale telle
And I shall clynke you so mery a belle
That it shall wakyn all this company
But it shall not be of phylosophy
Ne of phislias ne termes queynte of lawe
There is but lytyll latyn in my mawe
Here endyth the prologue
Here begynneth the squyres tale
AT surrey in the londe of tartarye
There dwellyd a kyng þᵗat warryd russy
Thrugh whyche ther dyed many a douȝtymān
This noble kyng was clepid cambuscan
Whyche in hys tyme was of so grete renoun
That ther was nowhere in no regyoun
So excellent a lorde in all thyng
He lackid nought that longed to a kynge
As of the secte of whyche he was born
He kept hys lay to whyche he was sworn
And therto he was hardy wyse and ryche
Pytous Iuste and alway ylyche
Soth of hys worde benygne and honourable
Of his courage as ony center stable
As ony bacheler dwellynge in his hous
A fayr persone he was and fortunate
And kept alway so well ryall astate
That there was nowhere suche a man
This noble kyng this tartyr cambuscan
He had two sones on alphete hys wyf
Of whyche the eldyst hyghte algarsyf
That other sone was clepyd camballo
¶ A doughter had this worthy kynge also
That yongest was and hyghte canace
But for to telle you of her bewte
It lyth not in my tonge nyn my connyng
I dare not take on me so hyghe a thyng
And also myn englysshe eke is insuffycyent
It muste be a clerke and rethour excellent
That knewe the colours longynge to that art
Yf he sholde discrye her in euery part
I am no suche I must speke as I can
¶ And so befell this cambuscan
Hath twenty wynter bore hys dyademe
As he went fro yeer to yere I deme
He lete the feste of hys natyuyte
Done crye thorugh out saray the cyte
The laste ydus of marche after the yere
¶ Phebus the sonne ful Ioly was and clere
For he was nyghe hys exaltacyon
In martis face and in his mansyon
In aries the hote coleryk sygne
Full lusty was the whether and benygne
For whyche the foulys ayens the sonne shene
What for the seson andthe yonge grene
Full lowde songen her affeccyons
Hem semyd to getyn them proteccyons
Agayn the swerde of wynter kene and colde
¶ This cambuscan of whyche I you tolde
In ryall vestymentis sat on his deys
Wyth dyademe full hyghe in hys paleys
And holte his feste so solempne and ryche
That in this worlde was there none it lyke
Of whyche yf I sholde telle all the aray
Then wolde it occupye a someris day
And eke it nedeth not to deuyse
At euery cours the ordre of her seruyse
I woll not telle of her strange sewis
Ne of her swannys ne of her heronsewis
Eke in that londe as tellen knyghtes olde
Is some mete that is full deynte holde
That in this londe men recke of it but small
Ther is noman that may reporten all
¶ I woll not tarye you for it is pryme
And for it is no fruyt but losse of tyme
Vnto my fyrst tale I wyll haue my recours
¶ And so befelle that after the thryde cours
Whyle this kynge sat thus in hys nobleye
Herkenyng his mynstrallys her thynges pley
Beforn hym at hys borde delycyously
In at the halle dore all sodenly
There came a knyght vpon a stede of bras
And in his honde a brode myrrour of glas
Vpon his thombe he had of golde a ryng
And by his syde a nakid swerde hangyng
And vp he rydeth to the hyghe borde
In all the halle ne was there spoke a worde
For merueyll of this knyght hym to beholde
And besely they wayten yonge and olde
¶ The straunge knyght that cam so sodenly
All armyd saue hys hed full rychely
Saluyth kynge quene and lordis alle
By ordre as they sytten in the halle
Wyth so hyghe reuerence and obeysaunce
As well in speche as in countenaunce
That gawyn wyth his olde curtesye
Though he were come agayn out of feyrie
Ne cowde hym amende wyth a worde
And after this before the hyghe borde
He wyth manly voys sayd his message
After the fourme vsyd in hys langage
Wythout vyce of syllable or letter
And for hys tale sholde seme the better
Accordant to his wordis was his chere
As techith art of speche hem that it lere
All be it that I can not sowne his style
Ne I can not clymbe on so hygh a style
Then say I thus to the comyn entent
Thus moche amounteth all that he ment
Yf it so be that I haue it in mynde
¶ He sayd the kyng of arabye and of ynde
My lyege lorde on this solempne day
Saleweth yow as he best can and may
And sendyth you honour at your feste
By me that am all redy at your heste
This stede of bras that esely and well
Can in the space of a day naturell
This is to say in four and twenty houres
Where you lyst in droughte or in showres
Bere your body in to euery place
To whyche your herte wylneth for to pace
Wythout wem of you thorugh fowle or fayr
Or yf ye lyst to fle as hyghe in the ayer
As doth an egle whan hym lyst to sore
This same stede shall bere you euermore
Wythout harme tyll ye be there ye leste
Though that ye slepe on hys back or reste
And torne agayn wyth wrythynge of a pyn
He that it wrought cowthe many a gyn
He waytid many a constellacyon
Or he had wrought this operacyon
And knewe many a seal and many a bonde
¶ This myrrour eke that I haue in myn hond
Hath suche a myght that men may in it se
Whan ther shall falle ony aduersyte
Vnto your regne or vnto yourself also
And openly who is your frendor fo
¶ And ouer all this yf ony lady bryght
Had set her hert on ony maner wyght
Yf he be fals she shall his treson se
His newe loue and all his subtylyte
So openly that ther shall no thynge hyde
Wherfore agayns this lusty someris tyde
This myrrour and this rynge as ye may se
He sent hath to my lady canace
Your excellent doughter that is here
¶ The vertue of this rynge yf ye woll here
Is this yf that her lyst it for to were
Vpon her thombe or in her purs it bere
There is no foule that fleeth vnder heuen
That she ne shall vnderstonde his steuyn
And knowe hys menynge openly and playn
And answere hym in hys langage agayn
And euery gras that growyth vpon the rote
She shall knowe and whom it woll do bote
All be his wounde neuer so depe or wyde
¶ This nakyd swerde þᵗat hangyth by my syde
Suche vertu hath what man ye smyte
Thorugh out his armour it woll kerue ⁊and byte
Were it as thycke as a braunchyd oke
And what man is wounded wyth the stroke
He shall neuer be hole tyll ye lyst of grace
To stroke hym with the plat in the same place
Ther he is hurt that is as moche to sayn
Ye moot wyth the plat swerde agayn
Stroke hym in the wounde and it woll close
This is a very sothe wythouten glose
It fayleth not whiles it is in your holde
And whan the knyght had thus his tale tolde
He rode out of the halle and downe he lyght
His stede whyche that shone as the sōnne bright
Stont in the court stylle as ony stoon
This knyght in to the chambre is led anon
And is vnarmyd and to mete I sette
The presentes be ryght rychely fette
This is to say the swerde and the myrrour
Been born anon in to the hyghe tour
Wyth certeyn offycers ordeyned therfore
And vnto canace this rynge is bore
Solempnely there she sate at the table
But sykerly wythouten ony fable
The hors of bras that may not be remeuyd
It stont as it were in the grounde y cleuyd
They maye it not out of the place dryue
For none engynes wyndas ne polyue
And cause why for they can not the craft
And therfore in the place they haue it laft
Tyll þᵗat the knyght haue taught hem þᵉ manere
To voyden hym as ye shall after here
¶ Gret was þᵉ prees þᵗat swermed to ⁊and fro
To gawryn on the hors that stode so
For it so hyghe was so brode and so longe
So well proporcyoned to be stronge
Ryght as it were a stede of lumbardye
Therwyth so horsly and so quyk at eye
As it a gentyll poleyn courser were
For certis from his tayll vnto hys ere
Nature ne art cowde hym not amende
In no degre as all the peple wende
But euermore her moost wonder was
How that it cowde go andwas of bras
It was a fayre as all the peple semyd
Dyuerse folke dyuersly they demyd
As meny hedis / as many wyttes ther been
They murmeden as doth a swarme of been
And maken skylles aftyr her fantasye
Rehersynge of the olde potrye
And sayd it was lyke the pegase
The hors that had wynges for to fle
Or ellys it was the grekys hors synon
That brought troye vnto distruccyon
As men in thyse olde gestis rede
¶ Myn hert quod one is euermore in drede
I trowe some man of armys be therin
That shape hem this cyte for to wyn
It wer ryȝt good þᵗat al suche thyng were knowe
¶ A nother rowned to his felowe
And sayd he lyed for it was rather lyke
An apparence made by some magyke
As Iogelours pleyn at the festis grete
Of sundry doubtes thus they Iangle and trete
As lewde peple demyn all day comynly
Of thynges that been made more subtylly
Than they conne in her lewdnes comprehend
They demen gladly to the badder ende
¶ And some of theym wondred on þᵉ myrrour
That born was vp in to the mayster tour
How men myghte in it suche thynges se
¶ An other answerde ⁊and sayd it may well be
Naturelly made by composycyons
Of aungelis and of sly refeccyons
And sayd that in rome was suche one
They spake of alocen andof vytelone
And of aristotle that wryten in her lyues
Of queynte myrrours and of prospectatiuys
As knowe they that haue her bokis herde
¶ And other folke haue wondred on þᵉ swerde
That woll perece thorugh euery thynge
And fylle in speche of thelephus the kynge
And of achylles wyth hys queynte spere
For he cowde wyth it bothe hele and dere
Ryȝt in suche wyse as men may wyth þᵉ swerd
Of whyche ryght now ye haue yourself herde
¶ They speken of sondry hardyng of metall
And speken of medycynes therwyth all
And how and whan it sholde hardyd be
Whyche vnknowe is algate to me
¶ Tho speke they than of canaces rynge
And sayd that all suche wonder thynge
Of crafte of rynges herde they neuer non
Saue that he moyses and kynge salamon
Had a manere cunnynge of suche an art
Thus sayn the peple and drawen hem a part
¶ But netheles some sayd that it was
Wonder to make of fern asshes glas
And yet is glas not lyke asshen of fern
But for they haue knowe it so fern
Therfore sesseeth her Iangelyng ⁊and her wonder
¶ As sore wondre som on cause of the thonder
On ebbe on flood on gossomer and on myste
And on all thynge tyll the cause is wyst
¶ Thus Iangelyn they ⁊and demen and deuyse
Tyll that the kyng gan fro his borde aryse
¶ Phebus hath lost the angle merydyonall
And yet ascendyng was the best ryall
The gentyll lyon wyth his aldryan
Whan that this tartyr kyng cambuscan
Roos from hys borde there he sat full hye
Beforn hym goth the lowde mynstralcye
Tyll þᵗat he came to his chambre of parementys
There as they sownen dyuers Instrumentys
That is lyke an heuen for to here
Now dauncen lusty venus chyldren dere
For in the fysshe her lady sat full hye
And lokyth on hem wyth a frendly eye
¶ This noble kynge is set vpon his trone
This straunge knyght is fet to hym full sone
And on the daunce he goth wyth canace
Here is the reuell and the Iolyte
That is not able a dull man to deuyse
He must haue know loue and his seruyse
And he a festlyche man as fressh as may
That shull you denysen suche aray
¶ How coude you telle the fourme of daunses
So vncouth and so fressh contenaunses
Suche subtyll lokyng and dissimyllyngis
For drede of Ielowsye mennys peeceyuynges
No man but launcelot and he is ded
Therfore I passe ouer of all this lustyhed
I say nomore but in this Iolynesse
I lete hem tyll men to sopper hem dresse
¶ The stywarde byddeth spyces for to hye
And eke the wyne in alle this melodye
The vsshers and the squyerye ben gon
The spyces and the wyne is comen anon
They ete ⁊and drynke ⁊and whan this was at ende
Vnto the temple as reson was they wende
The seruyse don they suppen al by day
What nedyth me to rehersen her aray
Eche man wote well that a kynges feste
Hath plente to the moost and to the leest
And deyntees mo than be in my knowynge
¶ And after soupper goth this noble kynge
To se this hors of bras wyth all the rowte
Of lordis andof ladyes hym abowte
Suche wodryng was ther of this hors of bras
That sethen the grete sege of troye was
There as men sawe suche an hors also
Ne was there suche wondrynge as was tho
But fynally the kynge askyd the knyght
The vertue of this courser and the myght
And prayed to telle hym his gouernaunce
¶ The hors anone gan to tryppe and daunce
Whan þᵗat this knyght layed honde on his reyne
And sayd syre there is nomore to sayne
But whan you lyst to riden ony where
¶ Ye muste trylle a pyn that stont in his ere
Whyche I shall you tell betwyx vs two
Ye moot nempne hym to what place also
Or to what countre that ye lyst to ryde
And whan ye come there as ye lyste abyde
Byd hym descende and trylle a nother pyn
For therein lyth the effect of all the gyn
And he wolde downe descende ⁊and do your wyll
And in that place he wolle abyde styll
Though all the world hath the contrary swore
He shall not thens be drawe ne bore
And or yf you lyst bydde hym thens goon
Trylle this pynne ⁊and he woll vanysshe anon
Out of the syght of euery manere wyght
And come ayen be it day or nyght
Whan that you lyst clepyn hym ageyn
In suche a gyse as I shall to you sayn
Betwene me and you and that ryght sone
Ryde whan you lyst ther is nomore to done
¶ Enfourmed whan þᵉ kyng was of þᵉ knight
And hath conceyued in hys wyt a ryght
The maner and the fourme of all this thyng
Full glad and blythe was this noble kyng
Repeyrynge vnto his reuell as beforn
The bridyll is to the tour y born
And kept amonge his Iewels leyf and dere
The hors vanysshed I not in what manere
Out of her syghte ye gete nomore of me
But thus I lete in luste and in Iolyte
This cambuscan hys lordis festeynge
Tyll well nygh the day began to sprynge
Explicit prima pars Et sequi- tur secunda pars
THe nouryce of dygestyon the slepe
Gan on hēm wynke ⁊and bad hem take kepe
That moche mete and labour woll haue reste
And wyth a gapyng mouth he hem alle kest
And sayd it was tyme to lye a doun
For blood was in his domynacyon
Cherysshe blood natures frend quod he
They thanken hym galpyng by two by thre
And euery wyght gan drawe hym to his rest
As slepe hem bad and toke it for the best
¶ Her dremys shall not be tolde for me
Full were her hedys of fumosytee
That causyth drem of whyche ther is no charge
They slepen tyll it was pryme large
The most part but yf it were canace
She was full mesurable as wymen be
For of her fader hath she take her leue
To go to reste sone after it was eue
Her lyst not appallyd for to be
Ne on the morowe vnfestlyche for to se
And slept her fyrst slepe and awoke
For suche a Ioye she in her myrrour toke
Bothe of her rynge and of her myrrour
That twenty tyme she chaungyd colour
And in her sleep ryght for the impressyon
Of her myrrour she had a visyon
Wherfore or the sonne gan vp glyde
She clepyd vp her maystresse her besyde
And sayd that her luste for to aryse
¶ Thyse olde wymen that ben gladly wyse
As her maystresse answerde her anon
And sayd madame whether woll ye goon
Thus erly for folke ben all in reste
¶ I woll quod she aryse for me leste
No lenger slepe but walken abowte
¶ Her maystresse clepyth wymen a grete rowte
And vp they rysen well ten or twelue
Vp ryseth fressh canase herselue
As rody and bryghte as the yonge sonne
That in the ram is four degrees y ronne
No hygher was he whan she redy was
And forth she walkyth esely a paas
Arayed after the lusti seson sote
Lyghtly for to play and walken on fote
Not but wyth fyue or syxe of her meyne
And in a trenche forth in the parke goth she
The vapour whyche fro the erthe glode
Makyth the sonne to seme rody and brode
But neuerthelesse it was fayr of syghte
That it made all her hertis for to lyghte
What for the seson and the mornynge
And for the foulis that she herde synge
For ryght anone she wyst what they ment
Ryght by her songe and knewe all her entent
¶ The knot why that euery tale is tolde
Yf it be taryed tyll the lust be colde
Of hem that haue it harkenyd after yore
The sauour passyth and euer lenger the more
For fulsomnes of hys prolyxyte
And by the same reson thynketh me
I sholde vnto the knotte condescende
And make of her walkynge sone an ende
¶ Amydde a treford reyde as whyte as chalk
As canace was playenge in her walk
Ther sat a fawcon ouer her hed full hye
That wyth a pytous voys so gan to crye
That all the wood resowned of her crye
And beten hadde herself full pytouslye
Wyth bothe her wynges tyll the reede blood
Ran endlonge the tree ther as she stode
And euer in one she cryed alwaye and shryght
And wyth her bek herself to twyght
That ther nas tygre nor so cruell beste
That dwelleth other in wood or in foreste
That nolde haue wepte yf he wepe cowde
For sorowe of her shryche alwaye so lowde
For ther was neuer yet man on lyue
Yf that he cowde a fawcon well discryue
That herde of suche a nother of fayrnes
As well of plumage as of gentylnes
Of shap and alle that myght rekenyd be
A fawcon peregryn than semyd she
Of fremd londe and euermore as she stode
She swowned now ⁊and now for lak of blode
Tyll wel nygh is she fallen fro the tre
¶ This fayr kyngis doughter canace
That on her fyngre bare the queynte rynge
Thrugh whyche she vndstode wel euery thyng
That ony foule may on hys leden sayen
And cowde answere in his leden agayn
Hath vnderstond what this fawcon sayde
And wel nygh for the rowthe almost she deyde
And to the tre she goth full hastely
And on this fawcon lokyth full pytously
And helde her lappe abrode for well she wyste
The fawcon muste falle fro the twyste
Whan that it swowned next for lak of blode
A longe whyle to wayte there she stode
Tyll at the last she spake in this manere
Vnto the hawke as ye shull after here
¶ What is the cause yf it be for to telle
That ye be in this furiall payne of helle
Quod canace vnto this hawke aboue
Is this sorowe of deth or losse of loue
For as I trowe thyse ben the causes two
That causen most a gentyll herte wo
Of other harme it reckyth not to speke
For ye yourself vpon yourself ye wreke
Whyche preuyth well that other loue or drede
Mot be enchesen of your cruell dede
Syn that I se none other wyghte you chace
For loue of god so do yourself grace
Or what may be your helpe for west ne eest
Sawe I neuer or now bryde nor beest
That ferde wyth hym so pytously
Ye sle me wyth your sorow verely
I haue of you so gret compassyon
For goddys loue come fro the tre a doun
And as I am a kynges doughter true
Yf that I verely the causes knewe
Of your disese yf it laye in my myght
I wolde amende it or it were nyght
As wys helpe me grete god of kynde
And herbes shall I ryght ynow fynde
To hele wyth your hurtis hastely
¶ Tho shryght this fawcon yet more pitously
Than euer she dyd and fyll to grounde anone
And lyth a swowne as ded as ony stone
Tyll canace hath in her lappe her take
Vnto tyme she gan out of her swowne awake
And after þᵗat she out of swowne gan brayde
Ryght in her hawkis leden thus she sayde
That pyte rennyth sone in gentyll herte
Felyng hys symylytude in paynes smerte
Is prouyd alday as men may se
As well by werke as by auctoryte
For gentyll herte kydeth gentylnesse
I se well that ye haue of my dystresse
Compassyoun my fayre canace
Of very womanly benygnyte
That nature in your pryncyplis hath set
But for no hope for to fare the bet
But for to obeye to your herte fre
And for to make other beware by me
As by the the whelpe chastysed is the lyon
Ryght for that cause andthat conclusyon
Whyle that I haue leyser and space
Myn harm I woll confesse er I pace
And euer whyle that one her sorowe tolde
That other wepte as she to water wolde
Tyll that the fawcon bad her be styll
And wyth a syghe thus she sayd her wylle
¶ There I was bred alas that harde day
And frostrid in a roche of marbyll gray
So tenderly that no thynge ayled me
I ne wyst what was aduersyte
Tyll I cowde fle full hye vnder the skye
Tho dwellyd a tarcelet me fast by
That semyd welle of all gentylnes
All were he full of treson and falsnes
It was so wrappyd vnder humble chere
And vnder hue of trouthe in suche manere
Vnder plesaunce and vnder besy payne
That I ne cowde haue wend he cowde feyne
So depe in greyn he dyed his colours
Ryght as a serpent hydeth hym vnder flouris
Tyll he may se his tyme for to byte
Ryght so this god of louys ypocryte
Doth so hys serymonyes ⁊and his obeysaunces
And kepyth in semblauuce all his obeysounces
That sowneth vnto gentylnesse of loue
As in a tombe is all the fayr aboue
And vnder is the corps suche as ye wote
Suche was this ypocryte both colde ⁊and hote
And in this wyse he serued his entent
That saue the fende none wyst what he ment
Tyll he so longe had wepte and compleyned
And many a yer his seruyse vnto me feyned
Tyll that my herte to pytous and to nyce
All Innocent of his crowned malyce
For fere of his deth as thoughte me
Vpon his othis and his suerte
Grauntyd hym loue vpon this condycyon
That euermo myn honour and my renon
Were saued bothe preuy and apert
This is to sayn that after his desert
I gaf hym all my herte and all my thought
God wote ⁊and he and other wyse nought
And toke his hert in chaunge of myn for ay
But soth is sayd goon seth is many a day
A true wyght ⁊and a theyf thynketh not one
And whan he sawe the thynge so fer agone
That I had grauntyd hym my loue
In suche a gyse as I haue sayd aboue
As yeue hym my true herte as fre
As he swore he yaue his herte to me
Anone this tygre full of dowblynesse
Fyll on his knees wyth so grete humblynesse
Wyth hygh reuerence and as by his chere
So lyke a gentyll louer of manere
So rauysshed as it semed for the Ioye
That neuer troylus ne paris of troye
Iason certis ne none other man
Syn lameth was that alderfyrst began
To louen two as wryten folk beforn
Ne neuer syth that fyrst man was born
Ne cowthe man by twenty thousande part
Counterfet the sophyms of his art
Ne worthy to vnbokelen his galoche
There dowblenes or feynyng sholde aproche
Ne so couthe thonke a wight as he dyde me
His manere was an heuen for to se
To ony woman were she neuer so wyse
So payntid he his chere at poynt deuyce
As well his wordes as his countenaunce
And so I loued hym for his obeysaunce
And for the trouth I demyd in his hert
That yf so were that ony thynge hym smert
All were it neuer so lyte and I it wyste
Me thoughte I felte deth at my herte twyste
And shortly so ferforth this thynge is went
That my wyll was his wylles Instrument
This is to say my wyll obeyed to his wyll
In all thynge as fer as reson fyll
Kepynge the boundis of my worship euer
Ne neuer had I thynge so leyf ne leuer
As him god wote ne neuer shall nomo
This lasted lenger than a yere or two
That I supposyd of hym no thynge but good
¶ But fynally thus at the laste it stood
That fortune wolde that he must twynne
Out of that place whyche I was in
Where me was wo it is no question
I can not make of it discripcyon
For o thynge dar I telle boldly
I knowe what the payn of deth is therby
Suche harm I felte that he ne myght bleue
¶ So on a day of me he toke his leue
So sorowfully eke that he wende verely
That he had felt as moche sorowe as I
Whan that I herde him speke ⁊and sawe his hewe
But neuertheles I thoughte he was so true
And eke that he repayre sholde agayn
Wythin a lytyll whyle soth to sayn
And reson wolde eke that he must go
For his honour and ofte it falleth so
That I made vertue of necessyte
And toke it well syn it nedys must be
As I best myght I hyd fro hym my sorowe
And toke hy by the hond saynt Iohn to borow
And I sayd thus lo I am youris all
Be ye suche as I haue be to you and shall
¶ What he answerd nedyth not to reherce
Who can say bet than he that can do wors
Whan he hath all sayd then hath he doon
Therfore behoueth him to haue a longe spoon
That shall ete wyth a fend thus herde I say
So at laste he muste forth his way
And forth fleeth tyll he came there hym leste
Whan it cam hym to purpos for to reste
I trowe he had the texte in mynde
That all thynge repayryng to his kynde
Gladyth hymself thus say men as I gesse
Men loue of propre kynde newfangylnesse
As brydes doon that men in cagis fede
For thouh thou nyght ⁊and day take of hem hede
And strewe her cage fayre and soft as sylke
And yeue hem suger hony bred and mylke
Yet ryght anon as that his dore is vp
He wyth his fete spurneth downe his cup
And to the wode he woll and wormes ete
So newfangyll ben they of her mete
And loue noueltees of proper kynde
No gentymesse of blood may hym bynde
¶ So ferde this tarcelet alas the day
Though he were gentyll born fresshe and gay
And goodly for to se humble and fre
He sawe vpon a tyme a kyte fle
And sodenly he loued this kyte so
That all his loue is clene fro me go
And hath his trouthe falsyd in this wyse
Thus hath the kyte my loue in her seruyse
And I am lorn wythout remedy
¶ And with that word this fawcon gan to cry
And swowed eft in canaces barm
Greet was the sorow for the hawkis harm
That canace and all her wymmen made
They nyst how they myght the fawcon glade
But canace home beryth her in her lappe
And softly in plasters gan her wrappe
There as she wyth her bek had hurt herselue
¶ Now can not canace but herbes delue
Out of the grounde and make salues newe
Of herbes precyous and fyne of hewe
To hele wyth the hawke fro day to nygte
She doth her besynes and all her myght
And by her beddis hede she made a mewe
And coueryd it wyth veluetis blewe
In sygne of trouthe that is in wymen seen
And all without the mewe is paynted green
In whiche were paynted all thyse false fowlis
As been thyse tydyffis tarcellis and owlys
Ryght for dispyt were peynted her besyde
Pyes on theym for to crye and to chyde
¶ Thus lete I canace her hawke kepyng
I woll as now nomore speke of her rynge
Tyll it come eft to purpoos for to sayn
How that this fawcon gat her loue agayn
Repentyng as the story telleth vs
By medyacyon of cambalus
The kyngis sone of whyche I you tolde
But hens forth I wol my processe holde
To speken of auenturis and of bataylles
That yet was neuer herde so grete merueylles
¶ Fyrst I woll you telle of cambuscan
That in his tyme many a cyte wan
¶ And after woll I speke of algarsyf
How that he wan theodora to his wyf
For whom full ofte in grete peryll he was
Ne had he be holpen by the hors of bras
¶ And after woll I speke of camballo
That faught in lystis wyth bretheren two
For canace or that he myghte her wynne
And there I lefte I woll ayen begynne

to the squyre And the wordes
of the hoste to the frankeleyn
In fayth squyer thou hast þᵉ well y quyt
And gentylly I prayse well thy wyt
Quod the frankeleyn consyderyng thy youth
So felyngly thou spekest / syr I allowe the
As to my dome ther nys none that is here
Of eloquence that shall be thy pere
Yf þᵗat thou lyue god gyue þᵉ ryght good chaıı̄unce
And in vertue sende the contynuaunce
For of thy speche I haue ryght grete deynte
I haue a sone / and by the trinyte
I had leuer than twenty pounde worth londe
Though it ryght now were fallen in my hond
He were a man of suche discrecyon
As that ye ben / fy on possessyon
But yf a man be vertuous wyth all
I haue my sone snybbed / and yet shall
For he to vertu lyst not tentende
But for to play at dyse and dyspende
And lese all that he hath / is his vsage
And he had leuer talken wyth a page
Than to comyne wyth ony gentyll wyght
Where he myght lerne gentylnes a ryght
¶ Straw for your gentylnesse qduod tho our hoost
What frankelyn parde / syr well thou woost
That eche of you mote tellen at the lest
A tale or two / or breken hys beheste
¶ That know I wel syr quod this frankeleyn
I pray you haue ye not me in disdeyn
Though to this man I speke a worde or two
¶ Telle on thy tale wythout wordis mo
¶ Gladly quod he syr hoste I woll obeye
Vnto your wyll / now herken what I say
I woll you not contraryen in no wyse
As fer as my wytte wyll suffyse
I pray to god that it may plesen you
Then wote I well that it is good ynow

THyse olde gentyll brytons in her dayes
Of dyuers auetours maden her layes
Rymed fyrst in her owne bryton tonge
Suche layes wyth her Instrumentes they sung
Or ellys reden hem for her plesaunce
And one of hem haue I in remembraunc
Whiche I shall say wyth a good wyll as I can
¶ But syres by cause I am a borell man
At my begynnyng fyrst I you beseche
Haue me excusyd of my rude speche
I lernyd neuer rethoryh in certayn
Thynge that I speke must be bare and playn
I slepte neuer in the mount of pernaso
Ne lernyd marcus tullius ne sithero
Colouris knowe I none wythouten drede
But suche colouris as growen in the mede
Or ellys as men dyen or peynt
Colours of rethoryk be to me queynt
My spyrite felyth in no suche matere
But and ye lyst my tale shall ye here

Ther was a kniȝt þᵗat loued ⁊and dide hys pay
(ne
To serue ladyes in his best wyse
And many a labour and many a grete emprise
He for his lady wrought or she were wonne
For she was one the fayrest vnder sonne
And eke therto comyn of so hyghe kynrede
That well vnneth durste the knyght for drede
Telle her his wo his payne and his dystres
But atte last she for his worthynes
And namely for his meke obeysaunce
Hath suche appetyt caught of his penaunce
That she preuely fyll of his accorde
To take hym for her husbond and her lorde
Of suche lordship as men haue ouer her wiues
And for to lede in the more blysse her lyues
Of his fre wyll he swore her as a knyght
That neuer in all his lyf he day ne nyght
Ne sholde vpon hym take no maystry
Ageyns her wyll ne kythe her Ielousy
But her obeye and folowe her wyll in all
As ony louer to his lady shall
Saue that the name of souereynte
That wolde he haue for shame of his degre
¶ She thanketh hym of his humblynesse
She sayd syre syth of your gentylnesse
Ye profre me to haue so large a reyne
Ne wolde god neuer betwyx vs tweyne
As in my gylt were other werre or stryf
Syre I woll be your humble true wyf
Haue here my trouth tyll my herte breste
Thus ben they bothe in quyete and in reste
¶ For one thynge syres sauely dar I say
That frendes eueryche other muste obey
Yf they woll lyue in pees and holde companye
Loue woll not be constreyned by maystrye
Whan maystry is come the god of loue anon
Betyth his wynges and fare well it is goon
Loue is a thynge as ony thought fre
For wymen of kynde desyren lyberte
And not to be constreyned as a thrall
And so doth men yf I the soth tell shall
Loke who is most pacyent in loue
He is at his auauntage all aboue
Pacyence is an hyghe vertue certeyn
For it vaynquyssheth as clerkis seyn
Thynges that rygour shall neuer atteyne
For euery worde men may not chyde or pleyne
Lernyth to suffre or ellys so mot I goon
Ye shall it lerne whether so ye wyll or noon
For in this worlde certeyn no wyght is
That he ne doth or sayth somtyme amys
Ire syknes or constylacyoun
Wyne wo or chaungynge of complexyoun
Causyth full ofte to do amys or speken
On euery wronge a man maye not be wreken
After the tyme must be temperaunce
To euery wyght that can of gouernaunce
And therfore hath this wyse worthi knyght
To lyuen in ese suffraunce her behyght
And she to hym full wysly gan swere
That neuer sholde there be defawte in here
¶ Here men maye se in humble wyse acorde
Thus hath she take her seruaunt and her lord
Seruaunt in loue and lorde in maryage
Then was he bothe in lordshyp ⁊and in seruage
