And after that she sayd as ye mow here
¶ Lo ryght so as the loue of crist quod she
Made me thy brothers wyf ryght in this wyse
Anon for myn alye here take I the
Syn that thou wolt thyn ydols dispyse
Go wyth thy brother now and the baptyse
And make the clene so that thou may beholde
That aıı̄ungels face whyche thy brother of tolde
¶ Tiburce answerde ⁊and sayd brother dere
Fyrst tel me whether I shall ⁊and to what man
To whom quod he come forth wᵗith ryȝt good cher
I woll the lede vnto the pope vrban
To vrban brother myn valerian
Quod tho tiburce wolt thou me thyder lede
Me thynketh that it were a wonder drede
¶ Ne mene ye not vrban quod he tho
That is so ofte dampued to be deed
And wonyth in hawkys alway to and fro
And dar not onys put forth his heed
Men sholde hym brenne in a fyre so reed
Yf he were founde yf men myght hym aspy
And we also to bere hym compauy
And whyle we seken that dyuynyte
That is hyd in heuen pryuely
Algate brent in this worlde shall we be
To whom cecily answerde boldly
Men myght drede well and skylfully
This lyf to lese myn owne dere brother
Yf this were lyuynge only and none other
But there is better lyf in other place
That neuer shall be loste ne drede thenonght
Whyche goddys sone vs told thrugh his grace
That faders sone hath all thyng wrought
And all þᵗat wrought is wyth a skylfull thouȝt
The ghost that from the fader gan procede
Hath soulyd hym wythout ony drede
By worde and by myracle lo goddys sone
Whan he was in this worlde declared here
That there is other lyf there men may wonne
To whom answerde tiburce o syster dere
Ne saydest thou ryght now in this manere
Ther nas but o god lord in sothfastnes
And now of thre how maye thou bere wytnes
¶ That shall I telle quod she or that I go
Ryght as a man hath sapyences thre
Memorye engyne and Intellect also
So in suche beynge of dyuynyte
Thre persones may there ryght well be
Tho gan she there full besyly hym preche
Of cristis sone and of his peynes teche
And many poyntes of his passyon
Hou goddys sone in this worlde was wythholde
To do mankynde playn remyssyon
That ben bounde in synnes and carys colde
All thyse thynges she vnto tiburce tolde
And after this tiburce in good entent
Wyth valerian to pope vrban went
That thankyd god ⁊and wyth glad hert ⁊and lyght
He cristnyd hym and made him in that place
Perfyght in his lernynge goddys knyght
And after this tiburce gate suche grace
That euery day he sawe in tyme and space
The aungell of god and euery maner bone
That he god axyd it was sped full sone
¶ It were full harde by order for to sayn
How many wondres Ihesus for hym wrought
But at laste to telle short and playn
The sergauntes of the towne hem sought
And hem before almache the prefect brought
Whyche hem apposid and knewe all her entent
And to the ymage of Iubiter hem sent
And sayd who so woll do no sacrifyce
Swap of his hed this is my sentence here
Anone thyse martyrs that I you deuyse
One maximus that was an offycere
Of the prefectis and his councelere
Hem hent and the sayntes forth ladde
Hymself he wepte for pyte that he had
Whan maximus had herde the seyntis lore
He gat hym of the tormentours leue
And had hem to his hous wythoten more
And wyth her prechynge or it were eue
They gonne fro the turmentours for to reue
And fro maxime and fro his folke echone
The fals fayth to trowe in god alone
¶ Cecily cam whan it was woxe nyght
Wyth preestys that hem cristenyd all in fere
And afterward whan daye was woxen lyght
Cecily sayd hem wyth a full stedfast chere
Now cristys owne knyghtes leef and dere
Cast away the werkys of derknesse
And arme you wyth armys of bryghtnesse
Ye haue forsoth y don a grete batayle
Your cours is don your fayth hath you conserued
Goth to the crowne of lyf þᵗat may not fayl
The ryghtfull Iuge whyche ye haue serued
Shall yeue it you as ye haue it deseruyd
And whan this thynge was sayd as I deuyse
Men ledde hem forth to do sacrifyce
But whan they were to the place ybrought
To tellen shortly the conclusyon
They nolde encence ne sacrice ryght nought
But on her knees setten hem a doun
Wyth humble herte and sad deuocyoun
And losten bothe her hedys in the place
Her soulys wente to the kynge of grace
¶ This maxymus that saw this thyng betide
Wyth pytous terys tolde it anon ryght
That he her soulys sawe to heuen glyde
Wyth aungelys full of clerenes and lyght
And wyth his wordes cōnuertid many a wyght
For whyche almachius dyde hym so to bete
Wyth whyppes of led tyll he his lyf gan lete
Cecily hym toke and beryed hym anon
By tyburce and valeryan sothly
Wythin her buryenge place vnder the stoon
And after this almachius hastely
Bad his mynysters fetchen openly
Cecily so that she myght in his presence
Do sacrifyse and Iubyter encence
But they conuertyd at her wyse lore
Wepten full sore and yaf full credence
Vnto her worde and cryden more and more
Crist goddys sone whyche wythoute dyfference
Is very god this is our sentence
That hath a seruannt so good hym to serue
This wyth o voys we trowen thouh we sterue
¶ Almachius that herde of this doyng
Bad fetche cecily that he myght her se
And alderfyrst this was his axyng
What maner woman art thou quod he
I am a gentylwoman born quod she
I axe the quod he though it the greue
Of thy relygion and of thy byleue
¶ Why then begyn ye your questyon folyly
Quod she that wolde two answers conclude
In one demaunde ye axed lewdly
Almache answerde to that symylytude
Of whens comyth thyn answer so rude
Of whens quod she whan þᵗat she was freyned
Of conscyence and of good fayth vnfeyned
¶ Almachius sayd ne takest thou no hede
Of my power / and she answerd hym thys
Your myght quod she is full lytyll to drede
For euery mortall mannys power nys
But lyke a blader full of wynde ywys
For wyth a nedelys poynt when it is blowe
May all the boste of it be layde full lowe
Full wrongfnlly began thou quod he
And in wrong is yet all thy perseueraunce
Wost thou not how our prynces myghty ⁊and fre
Haue thus cōmmaunded ⁊and made ordenaunce
That euery crysten wyght shall haue penaıı̄unce
But yf that he his crystendom wythsey
And gon all quyt yf he woll it reney
¶ Your prynces erren as your nobley doth
Quod tho cecily in a wood sentence
Ye make vs gylty and it is not soth
For ye that knowen well our Innocence
For as moche as we do ay reuerence
To crist and for we bere a crysten name
Ye put on vs a cryme and eke a blame
But we that knowen that name so
For vertuous we may it not wythseye
¶ Almache answerde chese one of thyse two
Do sacrifyce or crystendom reneye
That thou mowe ascape by that weye
At whyche worde this holy blysfull mayde
Gan for to laugh and to the Iuge sayde
¶ O Iuge confusid in thy nycete
Wolt thou that I renye Innocence
To make me a wyckid wyght quod she
Lo he dissymuleth here in audyence
He staryth and wodyth in his aduertence
To whom almache sayd o sely wretche
Ne wost þᵘ not how fer my myght may stretche
Haue not our myghty prynces yeuen
To me both power and auctoryte
To make folke bothe deyen and lyuen
Why spekest thou then so proudly to me
I speke not but stedfastly quod she
Not proudly for I say as for my syde
We hatten dedly that vyce of pryde
And yf thou drede not a soth for to here
Then woll I shewe all openly by ryght
Thou that hast made a full grete lesynge here
Thou sayst thy prynces haue yeue the myght
Bothe for to sle ⁊and for to quycken a wyght
That thou mayst but only lyf bereue
Thou hast non other power ne none leue
¶ But þᵘ mayst say thy pryncis hath þᵉ makid
Mynystre of deth for yf thou speke of mo
Thou lyest for thy power is full nakyd
Do way thy boldnes sayd almache tho
And do sacrifyce to our goddis or thou go
I retche not what wrong thou me profre
For I can suffre as can a phylosophre
But that wronges may I not endure
That thou spekyst of our goddis here quod he
Cecily answer o nyce creature
Thou saydest no word sith thou spakest to me
That I ne knewe therwyth thy nycete
And that thou were in euery maner wyse
A lewde offycer and a veyn Iustyse
There lackyth no thyng of thyn vtter eyen
But thou art blynde for thynge that we se all
That is a stoon that mowe men well aspyen
That ylke stoon a god thou wolt it call
I rede the lete thyn honde vpon it falle
And taste it well ⁊and stoon thou shalt it fynde
Syn that thou seest not wyth thyn eyen blyde
It is a shame that the peple shall
So scorne the and laughe at thy folye
For comynly men wote it well ouer all
That myghty god is in heuens hye
And thyse ymages well thou mayst aspye
To the ne to hemself may do no profyte
For in effect they be not worth a myce
¶ This and suche other wordes sayde she
And he wax wrothe ⁊and bad men shold her lede
Home vntyll her hous ⁊and in her hous quod he
Brenne her in a bath of flames rede
And as he bad ryght so it was do in dede
For in a bath they gonne her fast shytten
And nyght ⁊and daye fyre they vnder betten
¶ The longe nyght and eke the day also
For all the fyre and eke the grete hete
She sate all colde and felte uo manere wo
It made her not a drope for to swete
But in that bath her lyf she moot lete
For almachius wyth a full wycked entent
To sle her in the bath his sonde to her sent
Thre strokys in the necke he smote her tho
The turmentour but for no maner chaunce
He myght not smyte her necke a two
And for there was that tyme an ordenaunce
That no man sholde do to no persone suche penaıı̄unce
The fourth stroke to smyten softe or sore
This tormentour ne durst do no more
But half ded wyth her necke coruen there
He left her lye and on his way is went
The cristen folke whyche that abonte her wer
Wyth shetys haue the blood vp hent
Thre dayes lyued she in this torment
And neuer sessyd hem the fayth to teche
That she had frostred hem she gan to preche
And hem she yaf her meuables ⁊and her thynge
And to pope vrban betoke hem tho
And sayd I askyd this of heuen kynge
To haue respyte thre dayes and no mo
To recomende to you or that I go
Thyse soules lo and that I may do wyrche
Here of my hous perpetuelly a chyrche
¶ Saynt vrban wyth his dekenys pryuely
The body fet and buryed it by nyght
Amonge his other sayntes honestly
Her hous the chyrche of saynt cecily hyght
Saynt vrban halowed it as he well myght
In whyche in to this day in noble wyse
Men do to crist and his sayntis seruyse
Here endith the seconde non- nys tale

And begynneth the
prologe of the chanons yoman
WHan tolde was the lyf of saynt cecily
Or we had ryden fully fyue myle
At boughton vnder ble thus gan a take
A man that clothed was in clothes blake
And vndernethe he ware a whyte surplice
His hakney whyche was of pomell grice
So swette he that wonder was to see
It semyd that he had pryckyd myles thre
Abowte the peytrell stode the fome full hye
He was of fome as fleckyd as a pye
The hakney eke that his yoman rode vpon
So swette that vnethis myght it gon
A male twyfolde vpon his cropyn lay
It semyd that he caryed lytyll aray
All lyght for somer rode this worthy man
And in myn herte to wonder I began
What that he was tyll that I vnderstonde
How that his cloke was sewyd to his hode
For whyche whan I had longe auysed me
I demed hym some chanon for to be
His hat hynge at his bak doun by a lace
For he had ryden more than trot or pace
He rode ay pryckynge as he were wood
A clote leyf he had layd vnder his hood
For swete and for to kepe his hede fro hete
But it was Ioye for to se hym swete
His forhed droppyd as a styllatory
Were ful of planteyn or of peritory
And whan he was come he gan crye
God saue quod he this Ioly companye
Fast haue I pryckyd quod he for your sake
By cause that I wolde you ouertake
To ryden in this mery companye
¶ His yoman was eke full of curtesye
And sayd syres now in the morow tyde
Out of your hostery I sawe you ryde
And warned here my lorde and souereyn
Whyche that to ryden wyth you is full fayn
For his dysporte he louyth dalyaunce
¶ Frēnde for thy warnyg god yeue þᵉ good chaıı̄unce
Then sayd our hoste certeyn it wold seme
Thy lorde were wyse ⁊and so I may well deme
He is full Iocnde also dar I ley
Can he ought telle a meri tale or twey
Wyth whyche he glad may this companye
¶ Who syr my lord / ye syr wythouten lye
He can of myrthe and eke of Iolyte
Not but ynow also syre trustyth me
And ye hym knewe as well as do I
Ye wolde wonder how well and craftely
He cowde werke and that in sundry wyse
He hath taken on hym many a grete emprye
Whyche were full harde for ony that is here
To brynge abowte but they of hym lere
As homly as he rydeth amonges you
Yf ye hym knew it wold be for your prow
Ye wolde not forgon his acqueyntaunce
For moche good I dare laye in balaunce
All that I haue in my possessyon
He is a man of hye dyscretyon
I warne you he is a passynge wyse man
¶ Well quod our hoste I pray the telle me than
Is he a clerke or none telle me what he is
A clerk nay nay he is greter thān a clerk y wis
Sayd this yoman and in wordes fewe
Hoost ⁊and of his craft somwhat woll I shewe
¶ Syr my lorde can suche a subtylte
But all his crafte ye maye not wyte of me
For all the grounde to caunterbury toun
He cowde all clene torne vp so doun
And paue it all wyth syluer and wyth golde
¶ And whan this yoman hath thus tolde
Vnto our hoste / he sayd benedicite
This thynge is wonder meruelous to me
Syn that thy lorde is of so hyghe prudence
By cause of whyche shold men hym reuerence
That of his worshyp reckyth he so lyte
His oueryst sloppe is not worth a myte
As in effect to hym so mot I go
It is all bawdy and to tore also
Why is thy lorde so sluttyssh I the pray
And of power is better clothe to bey
Yf that his dede accorde wyth his speche
Tell me that and that I the beseche
¶ Why quod this yoman wherto axe ye of me
God helpe me so for he shall neuer the
But I woll not auowe that I say
And therfore kepe it secrete I you pray
He is to wyse in fayth as I byleue
That is ouer doiit woll neuer preue
And ryght as clerkys sayn it is a vyce
Wherfore in that I holde hym lewde and nyce
For whan a man hath oner gtete a wytte
Full oft it happyth hym to mysuse it
So doth my lorde and that me greuyth sore
God it amende I can say nomore
¶ Therof no force good yeman quod our hoyst
Syn of the cunnynge of thy lorde thou bost
Tell how he doth tel on now hardelye
Syn that he is so crafty and so slye
Where dwelle ye yf it to telle be
¶ In the subbarbes of a towne quod he
Lurkynge in hernes and in lanes blynde
Where as thise robbers ⁊and thyse theuys by kyde
Holden her ferdfull preuy resydence
As they that dare not shewe her presence
So fare we yf we shall say the sothe
¶ Now quod our hoste lete me talke to the
Why art thou so discolouryd in thy face
¶ Peter quod he god geue it harde grace
I am so vsyd the hote fyre to blowe
That it hath chaungyd my colour I trowe
I am not wont in no myrrour to prye
But swynke sore and lerne multyplye
We bloundryn euer and powryn in the fyre
And for all that we faylen of our desyre
For euer we lacke our conclusyon
To moche folke we do illusyon
And borow golde be it a pounde or two
Or ten or twelue or many sōmmys mo
And make hem wene atte leste weye
That of a pounde we cowde make twey
It is fals and ay we haue good hope
It for to do and after it we grope
But that scyence is so fer vs beforn
We mowen not all though we had it sworn
It ouer take it flyt away so faste
It woll vs make beggars atte laste
¶ Whyle this yeman was thus in his talkyug
This chanon drew hy nere and herd al thyng
Whyche this yeman spake / for suspecyon
Of mennys speche euer had this chanon
For caton sayth he that gylty is
Demyth all thynge to be spoke of hym ywys
That was the cause he gan so nyghe drawe
div.fw: The tale of the chanons yeman
div.l: To this yeman to herken all his sawe
And thus he sayd to his yeman tho
Holde thou thy pees and speke no wordes mo
For yf thou do thou shalt it dere abye
Thou sklaundrest me here in this companye
And eke dyscuuerest that thou sholdest hyde
¶ Ye quod our hoste tell on what so betyde
Of all his thretynge recke thou not a myte
¶ In fayth quod he nomore I do but a lyte
And whan this chanon sawe it wolde not be
But that his yeman wolde telle his preuite
He fled away for verry sorowe and shame
¶ A ha quod the yeman here shall ryse a game
All that I can anon I wol you telle
Syn he is goon the fowle fende hym qwelle
For neuer here after woll I wyth hym mete
For peny ne for pounde I you behete
He that me fyrst brought to that game
Or that he deye sorowe haue he and shame
For it is ernest to me by my fayth
That fele I well what that ony man sayth
And yet for all my smert and all my greef
For all my sorowe labour and myscheef
I cowde neuer leue it in no wyse
Now wolde to god my wytte myght suffyse
To tellen all that longyth to that art
But netheles you wol I telle a part
Syn that my lorde is goon I woll not spare
Suche thynges as I knowe I woll declare
Here endyth the prologe of the chanons yeman
Here begynneth his tale
WYth this chanon I dwelled seuen yere
And of his scyence am I neuer the nere
All that I had I haue lost ther by
And god wote so haue mo than I
There as I was wont to be ryght fressh ⁊and gay
Of clothyng and of other good aray
div.fw: The tale of the chanons yeman
div.l: Now may I were an hose vpon myn hed
And where my colour was both fressh ⁊and rede
Now it is wan and of a ledyn hewe
Who so it vsyth sore shall he rewe
And of my swynke yblent is myn eye
Lo suche auauntage it is to multiplye
That slydynge scyence hath made me so bare
That I haue no good where that euer I fare
And yet I am endettyd so therby
Of golde that I borowed truely
That whyle I lyue I shall it quyte neuer
Lete euery man bewaar by me for euer
What maner man that castyth hym therto
Yf he contynewe I holde his thryft y do
So helpe me god ther by shall he not wynne
But enpeyre his purs ⁊and make his wytte thyne
And whan he thorugh his madnes and folye
Hath lost his owne good thrugh Iepardy
Then he excyteth other folke therto
To lese her good as he hymself hath do
For vnto wretches Ioye it is and ese
To haue her felowes in peyne and dysese
For thus was I onys lerned of a clerke
Of that no charge I woll speke of our werke
¶ Whan we be there as we shall excersice
Our eluys craft we semen wonder wyse
Our termys ben so clergyall and so queynt
I blowe the fyre tyll myn herte feynt
¶ What sholde I telle eche proporcyon
Of thynges whyche we werken vpon
As on .v. or .vj. vncis maye well be
Of sylner or some other quantyte
And besy me to telle you the namys
Of orpement brent bonys yren squamys
That in to powder grounde be full small
And in an erthen pot how put is all
And salt petir and also papyr
Beforn thyse powders that I speke of here
And well y coueryd wyth a lampe of glas
And of moche other thyng whych þᵗat ther was
And of the pottis and glassis enlutynge
That of the ayer myght passe out no thynge
And of the fyre esy and smerte also
Whyche þᵗat was made and of the care ⁊and wo
That we had in our mater sublymynge
And in a malgamynge and calcenynge
Of qnyksyluer is clepyd mercury crude
For all our syghtes we can not conclude
Our orpement and sublymis mercury
Our grounden litargee ke on the perfury
Of eche of theym of vncis a certeyn
Not helpyth vs our labour is in veyn
And eke our spyrytes assencyoun
Ne our materes that lyen all fyx a doun
Mow in our werkynge nothynge vs auaylle
For lost is all our labour and traueylle
And all the cost a twenty deuyll wey
Is lost also whyche we on it lay
¶ There is also full many a nother thynge
That is to our craft apperteyninge
Though I bi ordr hem reherce ne can
By cause that I am alewde man
Yet woll I telle hem as they come to mynde
Though I ne can not sette them in her kynde
As bool armonyak veerdegrece boras
And sondry vessellys made of erthe and glas
Our vrinalis aud our discensories
Violes crossolectis and sublumatorijs
Concurbitees and alembikes eke
And other suche dere ynough a leke
Not nedyth it to reherce hem alle
Waters rubifienge and bulles galle
Arsenyk sal armonyak and brymstone
And herbes eke cowde I telle many one
As egremoigne valerian and lunarye
And other suche yf that me lyst to tarye
Our lampes brennynge nyght and day
To brynge abowte our crafte yf we may
Our furneys eke of calcynacyon
And of waters albifitacion
Vnsleckyd lyme chalke gleyr of an eye
Powders dyuers asshes dong pysse ⁊and cleye
Seryd pottes salt petyr vitriole
And dyuers fyres made of wode and cole
Sal tartir alcoly and sal preparat
And combust maters and coagulat
Cley made wyth hors dunge māmnys here or oyle
Of tartir alym glas berme worte ⁊and argule
Rosealger aud other maters enbibyng
And eke of our maters encorporyng
And of our syluer cytrynacyon
Our sementynge ⁊and also fermentacyon
Our Ingottis testis and many mo
¶ I woll you telle as me was taught also
The . iiij . spirytes and the bodyes . vij .
By order as I herde my lorde neueyn
¶ The fyrst spiryte quyksyluer clepyd is
¶ The seconde orpement the thyrde ywys
Sal armonyak and the fourth brymstone
¶ The bodyes seuen loke hem here anon
Sol golde is / and luna syluer we threpe
Mars yren / mercury quyksyluer we clepe
Saturnus led / and Iubiter is tyn
And venus copre by my fader kyn
¶ This cursyd craft who woll excersyce
He shall no good haue that hym may suffyse
For all the good he spendyth ther abowte
He lese shall therof haue I no dowte
Who so that lysteth vtter his folye
Lete hym come forth and lerne to mulplye
And euery man that hath ought in his cofre
Let hym apere and wexe a philosophre
Preest or chanon or ony other wyght
Though he sytte at his boke day and nyght
In lernynge of this eluyssh nyce lore
Alle is in veyn and parde moche more
Is to lerne a lewde man this subtylte
Fy speke not therof it woll not be
And can he lettrure or can he none
As in effecte he shall fynde it alone
For bothe two by my sauacyon
Concluden in multiplycacyon
All lyche well whan they haue all y do
This is to sayen they fayllen bothe two
¶ Yet forgat I to make rehersayll
Of waters corosyf and of lymayll
And of bodyes mollifycacyon
And also of her enduracyon
Oyles ablacyons metall fusyble
To telle you all it wolde passe ony byble
That owhere is therfore as for the best
Of thyse namys now I woll me rest
For as I trowe I haue tolde ynowe
To reyse a fende all loke he neuer so rowe
¶ A nay let be the phylosophers stoon
Elixer we clepen we seken fast echoon
For had we hym then were we syker ynowe
But vnto god of heuen I make auowe
For all our craft whan we haue all y do
And all our sleyghte he wyll not come vs to
He hath made vs spende muche good
For sorowe therof almost we wexen wood
But that good hope crepyth in our herte
Supposyng euer though we sore smerte
To be releuyd by hym afterwarde
Suche supposyng ⁊and hope is sharpe and harde
I warne you well it is to seken euer
That future temps hath made men disseuer
In trust therof all that euer they had
Yet of that art they conne not wexe sad
For vnto hem it is a bytter swete
So semyth it for ne had they but a shete
Whiche that myght wrappen hem inne a nyȝt
And a brate to walken in by day lyght
They wolde it selle ⁊and spende it in this craft
They can not stynt tyll no thynge be laft
And euermore where euer that they goon
Men may hem ken by smell of brymstoon
For all the worlde they styuken as a goot
Her sauour is so rammyssh and so hoot
That though a man a myle from hem be
The sauour woll enfect hym trustyth me
Lo thus by smellyng and thredebare araye
Yf that men lyst thyse folkes know they maye
And yf a man woll axe hem pryuely
Why they be clothed so vnthryftely
Ryght anone they woll roune in his ere
And sayen yf that they aspyed were
Men wolde hem sle by cause of her scyence
Lo thus thyse folke betrayen Innocence
Pas ouer this I go my tale vnto
¶ Er that the pot be on the fyre y do
And metalles a certeyn quantyte
My lorde hem tempreth and no man but he
Now is he goon I dare say boldely
For as men say he can do craftely
Algate I wote well he hath suche a name
And yet full ofte he renneth in the blame
¶ And wyte ye how full ofte it fareth so
The pot to brekyth and fare well alle is do
The metallys ben of so grete vyolence
Our walles mow not make hem resistence
But yf they were wrought of lyme ⁊and stoon
They persen so ⁊and thorugh the wall they goon
And som of hem synke doun in to the grounde
Thus haue we lost by tyme many a pounde
And some are scateryd all the floor abowte
Some lepen in to the roof withouten dowte
Though þᵗat the fende in our syght hy not shewe
I trowe that he wyth vs be that ylke shrewe
In helle where he is lorde and syre
Ne is there more wo ne rancour ne yre
Whan that our pot is broken as I haue sayd
Euery man chyt and holdith him euyll apayd
¶ Some sayd it was of the fyre makynge
Some sayde nay it was of the blowynge
Then was I ferde for that was myn offyce
¶ Strawe quod the thyrde ye be lewde ⁊and nyce
It was not tempryd as it ought to be
Nay quod the fourth stynte and herkenyth me
By cause our fyre was not made of beche
What is the cause and other none suche
I can not telle where on it was a longe
But well I wote grete stryf is vs amonge
¶ What quod my lorde there is no more to doon
Of thyse peryllys I woll beware eftsone
I am ryght syker that the pot was crasyd
Be as be maye be ye not amasyd
As vsage is lete swepe the floor swythe
Pluk vp your hertis and be glad and blythe
¶ The mullok on an hepe sweped was
And on the floor cast a canuas
And all the mullok in a side y throwe
And syfted and pykid many a throwe
¶ Parde quod one som what of our metall
Yet is ther here though we haue not all
And though this thynge myshapped hath an now
A nother tyme it may be well ynow
We must put our good in auenture
A marchaunt parde may not ay endure
Trustyth me well in his prosperyte
Somtyme his goodes be drenchyd in the see
And somtyme it comyth sauf vnto londe
¶ Pes quod my lorde the nexte tyme I woll fond
To brynge our craft all in a nother plyte
And but I do syres lete me haue the wyte
Ther was a defawte in somwhat well I wote
¶ Another sayd the fyre was ouer hote
But be it hote or colde I dar say this
That we concluden euermore amys
We faylen alway of that we wolden haue
And in our madnes euermore we raue
And whan we be togyder euerychon
Euery man semyth as wyse as salamon
But all thynge whyche that shyneth as golde
It is no golde as I haue herde tolde
Ne euery appyll that is fayr at eye
Nys not good what so we clappe or crye
¶ Ryght so it faryth it amonge vs
He that semyth wysest by swete Ihesus
Is most fole whan it comyth to the preef
And he that semeth truest is a theyf
That shal ye knowe or that I from you wende
Be that my tale be tolde vnto an ende
¶ There was a chanon of relygion
Amonge vs wolde enfect all a towne
Though it were as grete as was nynyue
Rome alisaunder troye or other thre
His sleyghtes and his infinyte falsnes
Ne cowde no man wryten as I ges
Though that he might lyue a thousande yere
In all the worlde of falsnes nis his pere
For in his termys he woll hym so wynde
And speke his wordes in so slyly kynde
Whan he comyn shall wyth ony wyght
That he woll make hym dote anon ryght
But it a fende be as hymself is
Full many a man hath he begyled or this
And woll yf that he lyue maye a whyle
And yet men ryde and goon many a myle
Hym for to seke ⁊and haue his acqueyntaunce
Not knowynge of his fals gouernaunce
And yf ye lyst to yeue me audience
I wole it telle here in your presence
¶ But worshypfull chanons relygious
Ne demyth not that I sclaunder your hous
All though my tale of a chanon be
Of euery order some shrewe is parde
As god forbede that all a companye
Sholde rewe a synguler manys folye
div.fw: The tale of the chanons yeman
div.l: To sklaundre you it is no thynge myn entent
But to correct that is myswent
This tale was not only tolde for you
But eke for other mo ye wote well how
That amonge cristys appostles twelue
Ther was no traytour but Iudas hymself
Then whi shold þᵉ remenaunt haue a blame
That gyltles were by you I say the same
Saue only this yf ye woll herken me
Yf ony Iudas in your couent be
Remeuyth hym by tymes I you rede
Yf shame or los may cause ony drede
And be no thynge displesid I you pray
But in this caas herken what I saye
IN london was a preest annueler
That therin had dwelt many a yeer
Whyche was so plesaunt ⁊and so seruysable
Vnto the wyf where as he was at table
That she wolde suffre hym no thyng to pay
For borde ne clothyng went he neuer so gay
And spendyng syluer had he ryght ynow
Therof no force in plesaunce went his plow
But for to telle you forth of this chanon
That brought this preest to confusion
¶ This fals chanon came vpon a day
Vnto the preestis chambre where he lay
Besechynge hym to lene hym a certeyn
Of golde and he wolde quyte hym ageyn
Lene me a marke quod he but dayes thre
At my day I wyll sauns fayle quyte it there
And yf so be thou fynde me then fals
Another day hange me by the hals
¶ This prest hy toke a mark ⁊and that as swyth
And this chanon hym thankyd ofte syth
And toke his leue and went forth his wey
And atte thyrde day brought his money
And toke this preest this golde agayn
Wherof this preest was wonder glad ⁊and feyn
¶ Certes quod he no thynge anoyeth me
To lene a man a noble or two or thre
Or what thynge were in my possessyon
Whan he is so true of condycyon
That in no wyse he breke woll his daye
To suche a man I can not say naye
¶ What quod this chanon sholde I be vntrue
Nay that were a thyng fallen of newe
Trouth is a thyng that I woll euer kepe
In to that day in whyche I shall crepe
In to my graue or ellys crist forbede
Byleuyth this as syker as the crede
God I thanke ⁊and in good tyme be it sayd
That ther nas neuer man yet euyll payd
For golde ne syluer that he me lent
Yet neuer fashede in my herte I ment
¶ And syr quod he now of my pryuete
Syn ye so goodlyche haue be to me
And sheweth to me so grete gentylnes
Somwhat to quyte wyth your kyndenes
I woll you shewe yf that ye lyst here
I woll you teche plener the matere
How I can werken in philosophye
Take good hede ye shull well seen at eye
That I woll a maystri do or I go
¶ Ye syr quod the preest and woll ye so
Mary therof I pray you hertely
¶ At your cōmmaundement syr truely
Quod the chanon and ellys cryst forbede
Lo how this theef cowde his seruyse bede
Full soth it is that suche profred seruyse
Stynketh as wytnessyth the olde wyse
And that ryght sone I woll it verifye
In this chanon rote of all trecherye
That euer more delyte hath and gladnes
Suche fendly thoughtes in his herte empresse
How cristys peple he may to myschyef brynge
God kepe vs from his fals dissymulynge
¶ Nouȝt wyst this preest wyth whom þᵗat he delt
Ne of his harme comynge no thyng he felt
O sely preest o sely Innocent
Wyth couetyse anon thou shalt be blent
O graceles full blynde is thy conceyt
No thynge art thou ware of his disceyt
Whyche that this foxe shapen hath to the
His whyles his wrenches thou mayst not fle
Wherfore go to the conclusyon
That referryth to thy confusyon
Vnhappy man anon I woll me hye
To tellen thyn wyt and thy folye
And eke the falsnes of that other wretche
As ferforth as my cnnynge woll stretche
div.fw: The tale of the chanons yeman
div.l: This chanon was my lorde ye wolde wene
Syre hoste in fayth and by heueus quene
It was a nother chanon and not he
That can an hundred folde more subtylte
He hath betrayed folke many a tyme
Of his falsnes it dulleth me to ryme
Euer whan I speke of his falshede
For shame of hym my chekes wexe rede
Algatis they begynnen for to glowe
For rednes haue I none ryght wel I knowe
In my vysage for fumes dyuerce
Of metall whyche ye haue herde me reherce
Consumyd and wastyd hath my reednes
Now taketh hede of this chanons cursidnes
¶ Syr qd he to the preest lete your man goon
For quyksyluer that we had it anoon
And lete hym brynge vncys two or thre
And whan he comyth as fast ye shull se
A wonder thyng whyche ye sawe nener or this
Syr quod the preest it shall be do ywys
He bad his seruaunt fet hym this thynge
And he all redy was at his byddynge
And went hym forth and came anone agayn
Wyth this quyksyluer shortly for to sayn
And toke the vncis thre to the chanon
And he hem layd well and fayr a doun
And bad the seruaunt colys for to brynge
That he anon myght goo to his werkynge
¶ The colys ryght anon were y fet
And this chanon toke out a crosselet
Of his bosom and shewyd it to the preest
This instrument qd he whyche that thou seest
Take in thy honde and put thyself therin
Of this quyksyluer an vnce and begyn
In the name of cryst to wexe a philosopher
Ther be full fewe whyche I wolde it profre
To shewe hem thus moche of my scyence
For here shull ye se by experyen ce
That this quyksyluer I woll mortifye
Ryght in your syght anon wythouten lye
And make it as good syluer and as fyne
As there is ony in your purs or myn
Or ellys where and make it malliable
And elles hold me fals and vnstable
Amonges folk for euer to apere
I haue a powdre that coste me dere
Sholl make all good for it is cause of alle
My cunnynge whyche I shewe you shall
Voydeth your man and lete hym be wythoute
And shyt the dore whyles we be there aboute
Our preuyte that no man vs aspye
Whyles that we werke in this phylosophye
¶ All as he bad fulfylled was in dede
This ylke seruaunt anon out yede
And his mayster shytte the dore anon
And to her labour spedely they gon
¶ This prest at this cursyd chanous byddyng
Vpon the fyre ryght anon set this thyng
And blewe the fyre and besyed hym full faste
And this chanon in to the crosselet caste
A powder not I neuer wherof it was
Y made of chalke or of erth or of glas
Or somwhat ellys was not worth a flye
To blynde wyth this preest and bad hym hye
The colys for to cowchen all aboue
For in tokenynge that I the loue
Quod this chanon thy hondys two
Shall werke all thynge that here shall be do
¶ Graıı̄unt mercy qd þᵉ preest ⁊and was ryght glad
And cowchyd the colys as the chanon bad
And whyle he besy was this fendly wretche
This fals chanon the fowle fende hym fetche
Out of his bosom toke a bechen cole
In whyche full subtylly was made an hole
And therin was put of syluer lymayll
An vnse and stoppyd was wythouten fayll
The hole wyth wex to kepe the lymayll in
¶ And understondyth that this fals gyn
Was not made there but it was made before
And other thynges that I you telle shall more
Here after whyche that he wyth hym brought
Er he cam there hym to begyle he thought
And so he dyde or that they yede a twynne
Tyll he had termyd him he coude not twynne
It dullyth me whan that I of hym speke
Of his falshede fayn wolde I me wreke
Yf I wyst how but he is here and there
He is so varyaunt he abydeth no where
¶ But takyth hede syres for goddys loue
He toke his cole of whiche I spake aboue
div.fw: The tale of the chanons yeman
div.l: And in his honde he bare it prynely
And whyles this preest couchyd besily
The colys as I you tolde or this
This chanon sayd frende ye do amys
This is not cowchyd as it oughte to be
But sone I shall amenden it quod he
Now lete me medle therwyth but a whyle
For of you I haue pyte by sayut gyle
Ye be ryght hote I se how ye swete
Haue here a clothe and wype away the wete
And whiles the preest wyped his face
This chanon toke his cole wyth sory grace
And layed it aboue vpon the mydwarde
Of the croslet and blewe well afterwarde
Tyll that the colys gan fast to brenne
¶ Now yeue vs drynke quod the chanon thene
As swythe al shall be well I vndertake
Syt we downe and lete vs mery make
And when that this chanon his bechin cole
Had broughte and the lymayll out of the hole
In to the croslet it fell anon doun
And so it must nedys by reson
Syn it so euyn aboue cowchyd was
But therof wyst the preest no thynge alas
He demyd all the colys lyke good
For of the slyght he no thynge vnderstood
¶ And whan this alkamystre sawe his tyme
Ryse vp syr preest he sayd anon ⁊and stonde bi me
And for I wote well yngot haue ye non
Goth walkyth forth ⁊and brynge a chalkston
For I woll make of it the same shappe
That an yngot is yf it may happe
And brynge eke wyth you a bolle or a panne
Full of water and ye shull well se thanne
How that our besynes shall thryue and preue
And yet for ye shall haue no mysbyleue
Ne wronge conceyt of me in your absence
I woll not be out of your presence
But go wyth you ⁊and come wyth you agayn
The chambre dore shortly for to sayn
They openyd and shyt ⁊and went her weye
And forth wyth hem they toke the keye
And comen ayen wythout ony delay
What sholde I tary all the longe day
He toke the chalk and shope it in wyse
Of an yngot as I shall you deuyse
¶ I sey he toke out of his owne sleue
A teyne of syluer euyll mot he cheue
Whiche that ne was but an vnce of weyȝt
And takyth hede now of his cursyd sleyght
He shope his yngot in lengthe and in brede
Of this teyn wythout ony drede
So slyghly that the preest it not aspyed
And in his sleue agayn he gan it hyde
And from the fyre he toke vp the matere
And in the yngot he put it wyth mery chere
And in to the water vessell he it caste
Whan that hym lyst ⁊and bad the preest as faste
Loke what there is / put in thy honde and grope
Thou shalt fynde there syluer as I hope
What deuyll of hell sholde it ellys be
Shauynge of syluer syluer is syr parde
¶ He put his honde in and toke vp a teyne
Of syluer fyne and glad in euery veyne
Blythe was this prest whan he sawe it was so
Goddys blessynge and his moders also
And all halowes haue ye syr chanon
Sayd this preest and I her malyson
But and ye vouchesauf to teche it me
This noble crafte and this subtylte
I woll be your man in all that euer I maye
¶ Quod this chanon yet woll I make assay
The second tyme that ye mow take hede
And be expert in this at your nede
A nother day assaye in myn absence
This discyplyne and this crafty scyence
Lete take a nother vnce quod he tho
Of quyksyluer wythout wordes mo
And do therwyth as ye haue do or this
Wyth þᵗat other whyche that now syluer is
¶ The preest hym besyeth all that euer he can
To do as this chanon this cursyd man
Cōmmaundyd hym and fast blewe the fyre
For to come to the effect of his desyre
And this chanon ryght in this mene whyle
All redy was this preest for to begyle
And for countenaunce in his honde bare
An holowe stycke take kepe and beware
In the ende of whyche an vnce and more
Of syluer lymayll put as sayd it before
div.fw: The tale of the chanons yeman
div.l: Was his cole and stoppyd wyth wexe wele
For to kepe in his lymayll euery dele
And whyle the preest was in his besynes
This chanon wyth his stycke gan it dres
To hym anon and his powder cast in
As he dyde erst / the deuyll out of his skin
Hym torne I pray to god for his falshede
For he was euer fals in thoughte and dede
And wyth his stycke aboue his crosselet
That was ordeyned wyth that fals get
He styred the colys tyll alle relente began
The wex ayenst the fyre as euery man
But it a fole be wote well it must nede
And all that in the stycke was out yede
And in the crosselet hastely fell
¶ Now gode syres what woll ye bet than well
Whan þᵗat this preest was thus begyled agayn
Supposynge noughte but tronthe soth to sayn
He was so glad I can not expres
In no maner his myrthe and his gladnes
And to the chanonn he profryd eftsone
Body ⁊and good ye quod the chanon anone
Though I be poore crafty you shall me fynde
I warne the well yet is there more behynde
Is ther ony copre here inne quod he
¶ Ye quod the preest syr I trowe ther be
¶ Ellys go by vs sum and that as swythe
Now good syr go forth thy way ⁊and hye the
¶ He went his way and wyth his copre cam
And the chanon in his honde it nam
And of that copre he weyed out an vnce
All to symple is my tonge to pronounce
As to mynystre of my wyt the dowblenes
Of this chanon rote of all cursydnes
He semyd frendly to hem þᵗat knew hym nought
But he was fendly bothe in herte and thought
It weryeth me to telle of his falsnes
And netheles yet woll I it expres
To that entent that men mow beware therby
And for none other cause truely
¶ He put this vnce of copre in his crosselet
And on the fyre as swythe he it set
And cast in powder ⁊and made the preest to blowe
And in his workynge for to stowpe lowe
As he dyde er and all was but a Iape
Ryght as hym lyst the preest he made his ape
And after in the ingot he it cast
And in the panne put it atte last
Of water and in he put his owne honde
Aud in his sleue as ye beforn honde
Herde me telle he had of syluer a teyne
He slyghly toke it out this cursyd heyne
Vnwetynge of the preest of this fals crafte
And in the pannes botom he it lafte
And in the water rombelyth to and fro
And wonder pryuely he toke vp also
The copyr teyn not knowynge the preest
And hyd it and hym hent by the breest
And to hym spake and thus he sayd in game
Stowpyth a downe by god ye be to blame
Helpe me now as I dyde you whyle eer
Put in your honde ⁊and lokyth what is there
¶ This preest toke vp this syluer teyn anon
And then sayd the chanon lete vs gon
Wᵗith thyse thre teynes whych þᵗat we haue wrouȝt
To som goldsmyth to loke yf they be ought
For by my fayth I nolde for myn hood
But yf they were syluer fyne and good
And that as swythe preuyd it shall be
¶ Vnto the goldsmyth wyth thyse teynes thre
They went and put thyse teynes in assay
To fyre and hamyr might no man say nay
But that they were as them ought to be
¶ This sotted preest who was gladd9 than he
Was neuer byrde gladder ayenst the daye
Ne nyghtyngale in the seson of may
Was neuer none that best lyst to synge
Ne lady lustyer in carolynge
Or for to speke of loue or womanhede
Ne knyght in armys done a hardy dede
To stonden in grace of his lady dere
Than had this preest this sory craft to lere
And to the chanon thus he spake and sayd
That for the loue of god that for vs all deyd
And as I may deserue it vnto you
What shall this receyt coste telle me now
¶ By our lady quod this chanon it is dere
I warne you well saue I and a frere
In englonde can no man it make
¶ No force quod he now syr for goddys sake
div.fw: The tale of the chanons yeman
div.l: What shall I paye tell me I you pray
Syr at o worde yf that it lyst you haue
Ye shull pay . xl . pounde so god me saue
And nere the frendshyp that ye dyde or this
To me sholde ye paye more ywys
¶ This preest the some of . xl . pound anone
Of nobles fetche and toke hem euerychone
To this chanon for this ylke receyt
All his werkynge was but frawde and disceyt
¶ Syr preest he sayd I kepe to haue no loos
Of my crafte for I woll kepe it cloos
And as ye loue me kepe ye it secre
For yf men knowe all my subtylte
By god they woll haue so grete enuye
To me by cause of my phylosophye
I sholde be ded ther were none other wey
¶ God it forbede quod the preest what ye sey
Yet had I leuer spende all the good
Whyche that I haue or ellys were I wood
Than that ye sholde falle in suche a myscheef
¶ For your good wylll syr haue ye ryȝt gode preef
Quod this chanon ⁊and fare well graunt mercy
And went his wey ⁊and nener the preest hym sy
After that daye / ⁊and whan þᵗat this preest sholde
Maken assay at suche tyme as he wolde
Of this receyt farewell it wolde not be
Lo thus beiapyd and begyled was he
Thus makyth he his Introduccyon
¶ Consydereth syres how that in eche astat
Betwyx men and golde there is a debat
So ferforth that vnethes is there noon
This multyplyeng blyndeth so many oon
That in good fayth I trowe that it be
The cause grettest of suche scarsyte
Thyse phylosophers speken so mystyly
In this crafte that men can not rome therby
For ony wit that men mow haue now a dayes
They mow wel chytteryn as doon Iayes
And in her termys setten her lust and peyn
But to her purpoos shall they neuer atteyne
A man may lyghtly lerne yf he haue ought
To multiplye ⁊and brynge his good to uought
¶ Lo whyche a lucre is in this lusty game
A mannys myrthe it wol torne vnto grame
And empte also grete and heuy pursis
And maken folke for to purchace cursis
Of hem that haue her good to hem lente
O fy for shame tho that haue be brente
Alas can they not fle the fyris hete
Ye that it vse I rede that ye it lete
Lest þᵗat ye lese all for bet than neuer is late
Neuer to thryue were to longe a date
Though ye prolle euer neuer shull ye it fynde
Ye be as bolde as is bayarde the blynde
That blundreth forth ⁊and peryll castyth none
He is as bolde to renne ayenst a stoon
As for to goo besydes in the waye
So faren ye that multiplye I saye
Yf that your eyen can not se a ryght
Loke that your mynde lacke not his syght
For though that ye loke ryght brode and stare
Ye shull wynne neuer of that chaffare
But waste all that ye mow rappe ⁊and rende
Wythdrawe the fyre lest it to faste brenne
Medleth no more wyth that art I mene
For yf ye do your thryft is goon full clene
And ryght as swythe I woll you telle here
What philosophers dyde in this matere
¶ Lo thus sayth arnolde of the newe toun
As his rosary makyth mensyoun
He sayth ryght thus wythoten ony lye
Ther may no man mercury mortifye
But yf it be wyth his brothers knowlechynge
Lo how þᵗat he whyche fyrste sayd this thynge
Of philosophers fader was armes
¶ He sayth how that the dragon doutles
Ne deyeth not but yf that he be slayn
Wyth his brother and that is for to sayen
By the dragon mercury and none other
He vnd9stondyth and brymstoon be his brother
That out of sol and luna were y drawe
And therfore sayd he take hede to my sawe
¶ Let no man besy hym this art for to seche
But he the entencyon ⁊and the speche
Of philosophers vnderstonde can
And yf he do he is a lewde man
For this scyence and this cunnynge sayd he
Is of the secrete of secretis parde
div.fw: The tale of the doctour of phisyk
div.l: ¶ Also there was a discyple of plato
That on a tyme sayde his mayster to
As his boke semor woll bere wytues
And this was his demaunde in sothfastnes
Tell me the name of that preuy stoon
¶ And plato answerde vnto hym anoon
Take the stoon that thitanes men name
¶ Whyche is þᵗat quod he magnacia is the same
Sayde plato ye syr is it thus
This is ignotum per ignocius
What is magnacia good syr I you preye
¶ It is a water that is made you I seye
Of elementis foure quod plato
¶ Tell me the rote good syr quod he tho
Of that water yf it be your wylle
¶ Nay nay quod plato certeyn that I nylle
The phylosophers were sworn euerychone
That they sholde discouere it to none
Ne in no boke it wryten in no manere
For vnto god it is so leef and dere
For he wolde not that it discoueryd be
But where it lyketh to his deyte
Man to enspyre and eke vnto defende
Whan that hym lyketh lo this is the ende
¶ Than conclude I thus syth þᵗat god of heuen
Ne woll not that the phylosophers neuyn
How that a man shall come vnto this stoon
I rede as for the best let it goon
For who so makyth god his aduersary
As for to werken ony thynge in contrary
Of his wyll neuer shall he neuer thryue
Though that he multiplye terme of his lyue
And there a poynt for eudyd is my tale
God sende euery good man bote of his bale
Here endyth the tale of the chanons yoman of multiplycacion
Here begynneth the tale of the doctour of phisyk
THer was as tellyth titus liuius
A knyght that clepyd was virginius
Fulfylled of honour and of worthynes
And stronge of frendes and of ryches
¶ Adoughter had this knyght by his wyf
No chyldren had he mo in all his lyf
Fayr was this mayde in excelleut beaute
Abouen euery wyghte that men myght se
For nature hath wyth souereyn dilygence
Fourmyd her in so grete excellence
As though she wolde say lo I nature
Thus can I fourme and peynte a creature
Whan that me lyst who can me counterfete
Pigmaleon not though he forge and bete
Or graue or peynte for I dar well seyn
Appellis ȝanȝis sholde werke in veyn
To graue or peynte or forge or bete
Yf they presumyd me to counterfete
For he that is the fourmer pryncypall
Hath made me his vicayr generall
To fourme and peynt erthly creatures
Ryght as me lyst for all thynge in my cure is
Vnder the mone that may wane and wexe
And for my werke no thyng woll I axe
My lorde and I be fully of accorde
I made her to the worshyp of my lorde
So do I all myn other creatures
Of what colours they be or what fygures
Thus semyth me that nature wolde seye
¶ This mayde was of twelue yere age and tweye
In whyche that uature had suche delyt
For ryght as he can peynte a lely whyt
And rody as a rose wyth suche peynture
She peynted hath this noble creature
Er she was born vpon her lymes fre
Where as by ryght suche colours sholde be
And phebus dyed hath her tresses grete
Lyke to the stremys of his burnyd hete
And yf that excellent was her bewte
A thousand folde more vertuous was she
In her ne lackyth no condycyon
That is to prayse as by dyscrecyon
As well in body as ghost chast was she
For whyche she floured in virgynyte
Wyth all humylyte and abstynence
Wyth all attemperaunce and pacyence
Wyth mesure eke and berynge of aray
Discrete she was in answerynge alway
She was as wyse as pallas dare I seyn
Her facunde eke full womanly and playn
None countrefetyd termys had she
To seme wyse but after her degre
She spake and all her wordes more and les
Sownynge in vertue and in gentylnes
Shamfast she was in maydens shamfastnes
Constant in herte and euer in besynes
To dryue her out of ydyll slogardrye
Bachus had of her mouth no maystry
For wyne and yougthe doth venus encrece
As men in fyre woll cast oyle or grece
And of her owne vertue vnconstreyned
She hath full oft tymes her syke feyned
For that she wolde fle the companye
Where lykly was to treten of foly
As is at festis reuellis and dauncis
That ben occasyons of dalyauncis
Suche thynges make chyldren for to be
To sone rype and bolde as men may se
Whyche is full peryllous and hath be yore
For all to sone may she lerne lore
Of boldnes whan she is woxen a wyf
¶ And ye mastresses in your olde lyf
That lordis doughters hauen in gouernaunce
Ne taketh of my wordis no displesaunce
Thynke that ye be set in gouernynges
Of lordys doughters only for two thynges
Eyther for ye haue kept your honeste
Or ellys ye haue fallen in freelte
And knowe well ynough the olde daunce
And han forsake fully myschaunce
For euer more / therfore for cristys sake
To teche hem vertu loke that ye not slake
¶ A theyf of venyson that hath forlafte
His lycorousnesse ⁊and al his olde crafte
Can kepe a forest best of ony man
Now kepe hem well for and ye woll ye can
Lokyth well to no vyce that ye assente
Lest ye dampned be for your euyl entent
For who so doth a traytour is certeyn
And taketh hede of that I shall seyn
Of all treson souereyn pestylence
Is whan a wyght betrayeth Innocence
¶ Ye faders and ye moders eke also
Though ye haue chyldren be it one or mo
Your is the charge of all her surueyaunce
Whyle they ben vnder your gouernaunce
Beware yf by ensamples of your lyuynge
Or by your neclygence in chastisynge
That they ne peryssh for I dare well seye
Yf that they do ye shull it dere abeye
Vnder a shepherde softe ⁊and neclygent
The wulf hath many a shepe ⁊and lambe to rent
Suffyseth ensamples ynow as here
For I must torne ayen to my matere
¶ This mayde of whyche I telle expres
She kepte herself she nedyd no maystres
For in her lyuynge maydens myght rede
As in a boke euery good worde in dede
That longyth to a mayde vertuous
She was so prudent ⁊and so bounteous
For whiche the fame out sprong on euery syde
Bothe of her bounte ⁊and of her beaute wyde
That thrugh the londe they praysen her echon
That loued vertue saue enuye alon
That sory is of other mennys wele
And glad is of his sorowe and vnhele
This doctour makyth this discrypsyon
This mayde on a day went in to the toun
Towarde the temple wyth her moder dere
As is of yonge maydens the manere
¶ Now was ther a Iustyce in the towne
That gouernour was of that regyowne
And so befell this Iuge his eyen caste
Vpon this mayde auysynge her full fast
As she came forth by there the Iuge stode
Anone his herte chaungyd ⁊and his mode
So was he caughte wyth bewte of this mayde
And to hymself full pryuely he sayd
This mayde shall be myn for ony man
Anone the fende in to his herte ran
And taught hym sodenly by what sleyghte
The mayden to his purpos wynne he myght
For certis by no force ne by no mede
Hym thoughte he was not able for to spede
For she was stronge of frendis and eke she
Confermyd was in suche souereyn beaute
That well he wyst he myght her not wynne
As for to make her wyth her body to syne
For whyche wyth grete delyberacyon
He sent after a churle was in the toun
The whiche he knewe full subtyll ⁊and ful bolde
This Iuge vnto this churle the tale hath told
In secrete wyse and made hym to assure
He sholde telle it to no creature
And yf he dyde he sholde lese his hede
Whan assentyd was this cursyd dede
Glad was the Iuge and made glad chere
And yaf hym yeftes precyous and dere
¶ Whan shapen was all this conspyracye
From poynt to poynt how that his lecherye
Perfourmyd sholde be full subtylly
As ye shullen here it after openly
Hoomgoon this churle that hyghte claudius
This fals Iuge that hight appius
So was his name for it is no fable
But knowen for an historyall thynge notable
The sentence of it soth is out of dowte
This fals Iuge goth now faste abowte
To hasten his delyte all that he may
And so befyll sone after on a day
This fals Iuge as tellyth vs the storye
As he was wont sat in in his consistorie
And yaue his domes vpon sondry caas
This fals churle came forth a full grete paas
And sayde lord yf it be your wyll
As doth me ryght vpon my pytous byll
In whyche I playn vpon virginius
And yf he woll seye it is not thus
I woll preue it and fynde good wytnes
That soth is that my byll woll expres
¶ The Iuge answered of this in his absence
I may not yeue diffynyte sentence
Lete do calle hym and I woll gladly here
Thou shalt haue right and no wronge here
¶ Virginius came to here the Iustices wyll
And ryght anon was red this cursyd byll
The sentence was therof as ye shull here
¶ To you my lorde appius so dere
Shewyth your poore seruaunt claudius
How that a knyght callyd virginius
Ayenst the lawe and ayenst all equyte
Holdyth expres ayenst the wyll of me
My seruaunt whyche that is my thrall by ryȝt
Whiche from my hous was stollyn on a nyght
Whyles she was full yonge I woll it preue
By wytnes lorde so that ye not greue
She nys not his doughter what so he say
Therfore my lorde Iustyse I you pray
Yelde me my thrall yf it be your wylle
Lo this was all the sentence of his bylle
¶Virginius gan vpon the churle beholde
But hastely or he his tale tolde
He wolde a defended it as sholde a knyght
And by wytnes of many a true wyght
That all was fals that sayd his aduersary
This cursyd Iuge wolde no lenger tary
Ne here a worde more of virginius
But yaf his Iugement ⁊and sayd thus
¶ I deme anone this churle his seruannt haue
Thou shalt no lenger in thy hous her saue
Go set her forth ⁊and put her in our warde
This churle shal haue his thrall th9 I award
¶ And whan this worthy knyght virginius
Thorough sentence of the Iuge appius
Must by force his dere doughter yeuen
Vnto the Iuge in lechery to lyuen
He goth hym hoom and set hym in his halle
And lete anon his dere doughter calle
And wyth a face ded as asshes colde
Vpon her humble face he gan beholde
wyth faders pyte styckynge thorugh his herte
All woll he not from his purpos conuerte
¶ Doughter quod he virginea by thy name
Ther ben two weyes other deth or shame
That thon must suffre allas that I was bore
For neuer thou deseruest wherfore
To deye wyth a swerde or wyth a knyf
O dere doughter whyche that all my lyf
I haue frustred vp wyth suche plesaunce
That thou ne were out of my remembraunce
O doughter whyche that art my last wo
And in my lyf my laste Ioye also
O gemme of chastyte in pacyence
Take thou thy deth for this is my sentence
For loue ⁊and not for hate thou must be ded
My pytous honde must smyte of thy hed
Alas that euer appius the say
Thus hath he Iuged the to day
And tolde her all the caas as ye before
Haue herd it nedyth to telle nomore
¶ O mercy dere fader quod the mayde
And wyth þᵗat worde she bothe her armys leyde
Abowte his necke as she was wont to do
The terys brast out of her eyen two
And sayd good fader shall I dye
Is ther no grace is ther no remedye
¶ No certes dere doughter myn quod he
¶ Then yeue me leyser fader myn quod she
My deth to compleyne a lytyll space
For parde Iept yaf his doughter grace
For to compleyne or he her slow alas
And god it wote no thynge was her trespas
But that she ran her fader for to se
To welcome hym wyth grete solempnyte
And wyth that worde she fell a swowne anon
And after whan her swownynge was agon
She ryseth vp and to her fader sayd
Blessyd be god that I shall deye a mayde
Gyf me my deth or that I haue a shame
Doth wᵗith your childe your wyll a goddis nam
And wyth that worde she prayeth full ofte
That wyth his swerde he sholde smyte softe
And wyth that worde a swowne doun she fyll
Her fader wyth soroufull herte and wyll
Her hed of smote and by the toppe it hent
And to the Iuge he yaf it in present
As he sat yet in dome in consistory
Whan that the Iuge it sawe as sayth the story
He bad take hym ⁊and hange hym al so faste
But ryght anone all the peple in thraste
To saue the knyght for routhe and for pyte
For knowen was the fals Inyquyte
The peple anone had suspect in this thynge
By maner of this churlys chalengynge
That it was by assent of appius
They wyst well that he was lecherous
Forthwyth vnto this appius they gon
And cast hym in pryson and that anon
Where as he slow hymself and claudius
That seruaunt was vnto this appius
Was demyd for to be hangyd vpon a tre
But virginius of his grete pyte
So prayde for hym that he was exyled
And ellys certys had he be begyled
The remenaunt were hangyd both more ⁊and les
That consentyd were to this cursydnes
¶ Here may men se how syne hath his meryte
Beware for no man wote how god wol smyte
In no degre ne in no maner wyse
The worme of conscyence may ynough agrise
Of wyckid lyf though it so preuy be
That no man wote of but god and he
Whether that he be lewde man or leryd
He note how sone he may be a feryd
Therfore I rede you this counceyll take
Forsake synne or synnne you forsake
Here endyth the phisyciens tale

Here begynneth the wordys
of the hoste
OVr hoste gan swere as he were wood
Harow quod he by nayles and by blood
This was a fals thef a cursyd Iustise
As shamefull deth as herte can deuyse
Come to thyse fals Iuges and her aduocats
Alas this sely mayde is slayn alas
Alas to dere aboughte she her bewte
Wherfore I say that all men mow se
That yeftes of fortnne and of nature
Ben cause of deth of many a creature
Her bewte was her deth I dar well sayn
Alas so pitously as she was slayn
But herof woll I not procede as now
Men haue full oft more harme than prow
¶ But truely myn owne mayster dere
This is a pytous tale for to here
But netheles passe ouer is no force
I pray to god so haue thy gentyll corps
And thyn vrynals and thy Iourdens
Thyn ypocras and thy galiens
And euery boyst full of letuary
God blysse hem and our lady saynt mary
So mote I the thou art a propre man
And lyke a prelat by saynt damyan
Thou hast spoke ynough I can not say in term
But well I wote thou makest my herte to ern
That I almoste haue caught a cardiakyl
By corpus dominus but yf I haue triakyl
Or elles a draughte of corny moysty ale
Or but I here a nother a mery tale
My herte is lost for pyte of this mayde
Thou belamy thou Iohn pardoner he sayde
Tell vs sum myrthes or Iapys ryght anon
¶ It shall be doo he sayd by saynt Runion
But fyrst quod he here at this ale stake
I woll bothe drynke and ete of a cake
But ryght anone thyse gentyls began to crye
Nay lete hym telle vs of no rybaudrye
Tell vs sum morall thynge that we mow lere
Som wyt ⁊and then woll we gladly here
I graunt ywys quod he but I must thynke
Vpon sum honest thyng whyles that I drynke

Here endyth the wordes of
the hoste
The prologue of the pardoner
LOrdyges qd he in chirches whan I preche
I payn me to haue an haunten speche
And rynge it out as rounde as goth a belle
For I can by rote all that I telle
My teme is euer one and alway was
Radix malorıı̄un est cupiditas
¶ Fyrst I pronounce whens that I come
And then my byllys shewe I all and some
Our lyege lordis seale on my patent
That shewe I fyrst my body to warent
That no man be so bolde ne preest ne clerke
Me to distourbe of cristys holy werke
And after that telle I forth my talys
Bullys of popis and of cardynalis
Of patriarkis and bysshops I shewe
And in laten I speke wordes a fewe
To saffron wyth my predicacyon
And for to styre men to deuocyon
Thenne shewe I forth my long cristall stonys
Y crammyd in clowtys full of bonys
Relykes they ben as wenen they echon
Then haue I in laton a sholder boon
Whyche that was of an holy Iewes shepe
Good men say I take of my wordes kepe
Yf that this boon be wasshe in ony welle
Yf cowe or calf shepe or oxe swelle
That ony worme hath ete or hym stonge
Take water of this welle ⁊and wasshe his tonge
And it is hole anon / and ferthermore
Of pockis and of scabbis and euery sore
Shall euery shepe be hole that of this welle
Drynketh a draughte take kepe of that I telle
¶ Yf that the good man that the beestys oweth
Woll euery weke or that the cok croweth
Fastynge drynke of this welle a draughte
As that holy Iewe our elders taughte
His bestis and his store shall multiplye
And syres also it helyth Ielousye
And though a man be falle in Ielous rage
Let make wyth this water his potage
And neuer shall he more his wyf mystryst
Though he in soth the defawte by her wyst
All had she take preestys two or thre
¶ Here is a metayn eke that ye may se
He that his honde woll put in that meteyn
He shall haue multiplyenge of his greyn
Whan he hath sowen be it whete or otys
So that he offre pens or ellys grotys
¶ Good men ⁊and wymen o thyng warne I you
Yf ony wyght be in this chyrche now
That hath do synne so horryble that he
Dar not for shame shryuen be
Or ony woman be so yonge or olde
That hath y made her husbonde cokeolde
Suche folke shall haue no power ne grace
To offre to my relykis in this place
And who so fyndeth hym out of suche blame
Comyth vp and offre in goddys name
And I assoylle hem by the anctoryte
Suche as by bull was grauntyd to me
¶ By this gaude haue I wonne many a yeer
An hundred mark syn I was pardoner
I stonde lyke a clerke in my pulpet
And whan lewde peple be downe y set
I preche so as ye haue herde before
And tell an hundryd fals Iapys more
Then peyne I me to stretche forth myn necke
And est and west vpon the pepyll I becke
As doth a douue syttynge vpon a berne
Myn hondys and my tunge goon so yerne
That it is Ioye to se my besynes
Of auaryce and of suche cursydnes
Is all my prechynge to make hem fre
To yeue her peus and namely vnto me
For myn entent is not but for to wynne
And no thynge for correccyon of synne
I recke not whan that they be buryed
Though her soulis goon a blakberyed
For certys full many a predycacion
Sownyth ofte tyme of euyll entencyon
¶ Some for plesaunce of folke ⁊and for flaterye
To ben auaunsyd by ypocrysie
And some for veynglory and som for hate
For whan I dar not other wayes debate
Then woll I stynge hem wyth my tong smert
In prechynge so that they shall not asterte
To ben dyffamyd falsly yf that he
Hath trespassyd other to my brethern or me
For though I telle not his propre name
Men shall well knowe that it is the same
By sygnes or by other cyrcumstauncis
Thus quyte I folke that doth vs displesaıı̄uncis
Thus spyt I out my venym vnder hewe
Of holynes to seme holy and trewe
But shortly myn entent woll I deuyse
I preche of no thynge but of couetyse
Therfore my teme is yet and euer was
Radix omnium malorum est cupiditas
¶ Thus gan I preche the same vyce
To suche as be vsyng the synne of auaryce
But though myself be gylty in that synne
Yet can I make other folke to twynne
From auarice / and sore hem to repent
But that is not my pryncypall entent
I preche no thynge but for couetyse
Of this mater it ought y nough snffyse
¶ Then telle I hem ensamplys many one
Of olde storyes longe tyme agone
For lewde peple louen talys olde
Whyche thynges can they well reporte ⁊and holde
What trowe ye whyles that I may preche
And for to wynne golde and siluer for to teche
That I woll lyue in pouert wylfully
Nay nay I thought it neuer truly
For I woll preche and begge in sondry londis
I woll not do no labour wyth my hondys
Ne maken baskettis and lyue therby
By cause I woll not begge ydelly
I woll none of the appostlys counterfete
I woll haue money / wulle chese and whete
All were it yeuen of the poorest page
Or of the poorest wydow in a vyllage
All sholde her chyldren sterue for famyn
Nay I woll drynke the lycour of the vyn
And haue a Ioly wenche in euery toun
But herkeneth lordynges in conclusyoun
¶ Your lykyng is that I shall telle a tale
Now I haue dronke a draughte of corny ale
By god I hope I shall telle you a thynge
That shall by reson be at your lykynge
For though myself be a full vycyous man
A moralle tale yet I you telle can
Whyche I am wont for to preche ⁊and also wyne
Now holde your pes my tale I woll begynne
Here endyth the prologe of the pardoner Here begynneth the tale of the pardoner
IN flaundris somtyme was a company
Of yonge folke that hauntedyn folye
As ryot hazarde stewys and tauernys
Where as wyth harpys lutys and gyternys
They daıı̄unce ⁊and pley at the dyce both day ⁊and nyȝt
And eten also and drynken aboue her myght
Thrugh whyche they don the deuyll sacrifyce
Wythin the deuyls temple in cursyd wyse
The superfluytees abhomynable
Her othes be so grete and soo dampnable
That it is grisly for to here hem swere
Our blessyd lordys body they to tere
Hem thought the Iewys rent hym not ynough
And eche of hem at other synne lough
¶ And ryght anon came in the tomblesteris
Fetys and smale and yonge frutestris
Syngars wyth harpys bawdys wafrerys
Suche as ben very the deuyllis offyceris
To kyndle and blowe the fyres of lecherye
That is annexyd vnto glotenye
The holy wrytte take I to wytnes
That lechery is in wyne and in dronkenes
¶ Lo how that dronken loth vnkyndely
Lay by his doughters two vnwetyngly
So dronke he was he nyste what he wroughte
And therfore sore repente hym oughte
Herodis who so woll the storyes seche
There maye ye lerne ⁊and by ensample teche
Whan he of wyne was replete at his feste
Ryght at his owne table yaue his heste
To slee the baptist Iohn full gyltlees
Senek sayth eke good wordes doutles
¶ He sayth he can no dyfference fynde
Betwyx a man that is out of his mynde
And a man whyche that is dronkelew
But that woodnes fallen is in a shrew
Perseueryth lenger than doth dronkenes
Out glotenye full of cursydnes
O cause fyrst of our confusyon
O origynall synne of our dampnacyon
Tyll cryst had bought vs wᵗith his blood ageyn
Lo how dere shortly for to seyn
A bought was this cursyd vylonye
Corupt was all this worlde thrugh glotonye
Adam our forn fader and his wyf also
Fro paradys to labour and to wo
Were dryuen for that vyce it is no drede
For whyles that adam fastyd as I rede
He was in paradyse ⁊and whan that he
Ete of the fruyt defended on the tre
Anon he was out cast to woo and payne
O glotonye on the ought vs well to playne
¶ O wyste a man how many maladyes
Folowen of excesse and of glotonyes
He sholde be the more mesurable
Of his dyete syttynge at his table
Alas the shorte throte the tender mouth
Makyth that este and west north and south
In erthe in ayer in water men to swynke
To gete a gloton deynte mete and drynke
O poule of this matere well canst thou entrete
Mete vnto wombe ⁊and wombe eke vnto mete
Shal god distroyen bothe as poule sayth
Alas a fowle thynge it is by my fayth
To say this worde and fowler is the dede
Whan men so drynketh of the whyte ⁊and rede
That of his throte he makyth his preue
Thorugh that cursyd superfluyte
¶ The apostle wepyng sayth full pytously
Ther walke many of whyche you tolde haue I
I say it now wepynge wyth pytous voys
That they ben enmyes of cristes croys
Of whyche the ende is deth wombe is her god
O wombe o bely o stynkynge cod
Fulfylled of dunge and of corupcyon
At eyther ende of the foul is the sonn
How grete cost and labour is the to fynde
Thyse cokys how they stāmpe streyne ⁊and grynde

Out of the harde bonys knocken they
The mary for they caste nanght awey
That may go thrugh the golet soft and sote

Shall be his sauce y made by delyte
To make hym yet a newer appetyte
But certes he that haunteth suche delyces

¶ A lecherous thyng is wyne and dronkenesse

O dronken man disfyguryd in thy face
Sour is thy breth foul art thou to embrace
And thrugh thy dronkēn nose souneth thy soun
As though þᵘ saydest ay sampson sampsoun

For dronkenes is very sepulture

In whom that drynke hath domynacyon
He can no counsell kepe it is no drede
Now kepe you fro the white and fro the rede
Namely fro the whyte wyne of lepe
That is to selle in brydge strete or in chepe
This wyne of spayn crepyth subtylly
In other wynes growynge fast by
Of whyche ther ryseth suche fumosyte
That whan a man hath dronke draught thre
And wenyth that he be at home in chepe
He is in spayne ryght at the towne of lepe
Not at rochell ne at bordeux toun
And then woll he say sampsoun sampsoun
¶ But herkenyth lordyges o word I you pray
That all the souereyn actes dare I say
Of victories in the olde testament
Thorugh very god that is omnypotent
Were don in abstynence and in prayer
Lokyth the byble and there mow ye it leer
¶ Lokyth attilla the grete conquerour
Deyed in his slepe wyth shame and dishonour

¶ And ouer all this auyse you ryght well
What was cōmmaunded vnto lamuell
Not samuell but lamuell say I

Nomore of this for it may well suffyce
ANd now that I haue spoke of glotonye
Now woll I defende you hasardrye
Hasardrye is very moder of lesynges
And of disceyt and cursyd forswerynge is
Blasphemye of cryst manslauȝter ⁊and wast also

It is repreyf and contrary of honour
For to be holden a comyn hasardour
And euer the hygher that he is in astate
The more he is holden desolate
Yf that a prynce vse hasardrye
In all gouernaunce and all polecye
He is as by comune oppinyon
Y holde the lesse in reputacyon
¶ Stillebone þᵗat was hold a wyse embassedour
Was sent in to corinthe wyth grete honour
Fro calidone to make hem alyaunce
And whan he cam hym happed this chaunce
That all the grettest that were of that londe
Pleyenge at hasarde he hem fonde
For whyche as sone as that it myght be
He stale hym home ayen to his countre
And sayd there woll I not lese my name
I woll not take on me so grete defame
You for to alye to none hasardouris
Sendyth other wyse ambassiadouris
For b y my trouth me were leuer dye
Than I you to hasardours sholde alye
For ye that ben so gloryous in honouris
Shall not alye you to no hasardours
As by my wyll ne as by my trete
This wyse philosopher thus sayd he
¶ Loke eke how to þᵉ kynge demetrius
The kyng of parthes as the boke sayth vs
Sente hym a payr of dyse of golde in scorn
For he had vsyd hasardrye there beforn
For whyche he helde his glorye and his renoun
At no value or reputacyoun
Lordys myghten fynde other manere pleye
Honest ynough to dryue the day aweye
NOw woll I speke of othes fals ⁊and grete
A worde or two as many bokis trete
Grete swerynge is thynge abhomynable
And fals sweryng is a thyng more reprouable
The hyghe god forbad sweryng at all
Wytnes of mathew but in especyall
Of swerynge sayth holy Ieromye
Thou shalt swere soth thyn othes and not lye
And swere in dome and in ryghtwysnes
But ydyll swerynge is a cursydnes
¶ Beholde and se that in the fyrst table
Of hyghe goddys hestis honourable
How that the seconde hest of hym is this
Take not my name in ydylnes amys
Lo rather he forbedyth suche swerynge
Than homycide or ony other cursyd thynge
I say as by order thus it stondyth
This knowe they that his hestis vnderstōndith
How that the seconde hest of god is that
And ferdermore I woll the telle at plat
That vengaunce shall not part fro the hous

Ey by goddis precyous herte ⁊and by his nayles

Ey goddys armys yf thou falsly pleye
This daggar shall thorugh thyn herte goo
This fruyt comyth of the bytched bonys two
Forsweryng Ire falsnes and homycide
Now for the loue of cryst that for vs dyde
Leuyth your othes bothe grete and smale
For cristys sake and herkeuyth my tale
¶ Thyse ryotours thre of whyche I telle
Longe or to pryme were ronge ony belle
Were set hem in a tauerne to drynke
And as they sate they herde a belle clynke
Before a cors þᵗat was caryed to his graue

Go bet quod he and axe redily
What cors is this that passyth forth by
And loke that thou reporte his name wele
¶ Syr quod the boy it nedyth neuer a dele
It was me tolde or ye came here two houris
He was parde an olde felowe of youris
All sodenly was he slayn to nyght
For dronke as he sat on his benche vpryght
Ther cam a preuy theef men clepe deth
That in this countre all the peple sleeth
And wyth his spere he smote his herte in two
And went his way wythout wordis mo
He hath a thousande sleyn this pestilence
And mayster er ye come in his presence
Me thynketh it were necessary
For to be ware of suche an aduersary
Beth is redy for to mete him euermore
Thus taught me my dame I say nomore
¶ O saynt mary sayd this tauernere
The chylde sayth soth for he hath this yere
Hens ouer a myle slayn in a grete vylage
Bothe man ⁊and woman chylde hyne and page
I trowe his hahytacyon be there
To ben auysed grete wysdom it were
Er that he dyde a man dishonour
¶ Ye goddis armys sayd this ryotour
Is it suche peryll wyth hym for to mete
I shall hym seke by waye and eke by strete
I shall hym sle by goddys dygne bonys
Herken felowes we thre ben all onys
Let eche of vs becomen others brother
And eche of vs holde vp his honde to other
And we woll sle this traytour deth
He shal be slayn he that so many sleeth
By goddys dignyte or it be nyght
¶ Togyder haue thyse thre her trouthis plyȝt
To lyue and deye eche of theym wyth other
As though he were his owne born brother
And vp they sterte all dronke in this rage
And forth they goon towarde that vilage
Of whiche the tauernere hath spoke beforn
And many a grisly oth haue they sworn
And cristys blessyd body they to rent
Deth shall be ded yf that we may hym hent
¶Whan they haue goon not fully a myle
Ryght as they wolde haue goon ouer a style
An olde man ⁊and a poore wyth hem mette
This olde man full mekely hem grette
And sayd thus lordynges god you se
¶ The proudest of thyse ryotours thre
Answerde what churle wyth harde grace
Why art thou all forwrappyd saue thy face
Why lyuest thou so longe in so grete age
¶ This olde man gan loke in her vysage
And sayd thus for I can not fynde
A man though I walke in to ynde
Neyther in cyte ne in vyllage
That woll chaunge his youthe for myn age
And therfore must I haue myn age stylle
As longe tyme as it is goddys wylle
¶ Ne deth alas woll not haue my lyf
Thus walke I lyke a restles caytyf
And on the groıı̄unde whyche is my moders gate
I knocke with my staf erly and late
And saye to her leue moder lete me in
Lo how I vanysshe flessh blode and skyn
Alas whan shall my bonys be at reste
Moder wyth you wolde I chaunge my cheste
That in my chambre longe tyme hath be
Ye for an heyr cloute to wrappe in me
But yet to me she woll not do that grace
For whyche full pale ⁊and wretchid is my face
And syres to you it is no curtesye
To speke an olde man vylonye
But he trespasse other in worde or in dede
Ye may yourself in holy wryt rede
¶ Ayenst an olde man hore vpon his hed
Ye sholde aryse wherfore I you red
Ne doth to none olde man harme now
Nomore than ye wolde men dydz to you
In age yf ye sholde longe abyde
And god be wyth you where ye go or ryde
I must go thyder as I haue to do
¶ Nay olde churle by god thou shalt not so
Sayd this other hasardour anon
Thou partyst not so lyghtly by saynt Iohn
Thou spakest right now of that traytour deth
That in this countree all our frendes sleth
Haue here my trouth thou art his aspye
Tell where he is or thou shalt it abye
By god and by the holy sacrament
For shortly thou art one of his assent
To sle vs yonge folke thou fals theef
¶ Now syres quod he yf that it be to you leef
To fynde deth torne vp this crokyd wey
For in þᵗat groue I hym sawe last by my fey
Vnder a tre and there he woll abyde
For your boste he woll no thynge hym hyde
Se ye that oke ryght there ye shull hym fynde
God saue you þᵗat bought agayn all mankynde
And you amende thus sayd this olde man
¶ And euery of thyse ryotours ran
Tyll they cam to the tre and there they founde
Of floreyns fyn golde y coyned rounde
Wel nye an eyght busshellis as hem thoughte
No lenger then after deth they soughte
But eche of hem so glad was of that syghte
For that the floreyns so fayr were and bryghte
That downe they sat by the precyous horde
The worste of hem he spake the fyrst worde
¶ Brethern qd he take kepe what I saye
My wyt is grete though I bourde and playe
This tresour hath fortune vnto vs yeuen
In myrthe and Iolyte our lyf to lyuen
And lyghtly as it comyth so woll we spende
Ey goddis precyous dygnyte who wende
To day that we sholde haue so fayr a grace
But myght this golde be caryed fro this place
Home to my hous or ellys vnto youris
Then myght we say that it were all onris
Then were we in hyghe felycyte
But truely by day it may not be
Men wolde say that we were theuys stronge
And for our owne tresour don vs honge
This tresour must be caried by nyghte
As wysely and as slily as it myghte
Wherfore I rede let loke amonge vs alle
Drawe cut let se where that it woll falle
He þᵗat hath the shortest cut wyth herte blythe
Shall renne to towne and that full swythe
To brynge vs bred and wyne full pryuely
And two of vs shall kepe full subtylly
This tresour well ⁊and yf he woll not taryen
Whan it is nyght we woll this tresour caryen
By one assent where as vs lyst best
¶ That one of hem brought strawe in his fest
And bad hēm draw ⁊and loke on whōm it wold fall
And it fyll on the yongest of hem all
And forth towarde the towne he went anone
And also sone as he was gone
That one of hem spake thus vnto that other
Thou wotist well thou art my sworn brother
Thy profyt woll I telle the ryght anon
¶ Thou wost woll that our felowe is gon
And here is golde and that full grete plente
That shall be departyd amonge vs thre
But netheles yf I can shape it so
That it departyd were amonge vs two
Had I not doon a frendis torn to the
¶ That other ansuerde I note how it myȝt be
I wote well the golde shall be ouris two
What shull we say what shull we do
¶ Shal it be counsell sayd the fyrste shrewe
And I shall telle the in wordes fewe
What we shul do and brynge it well aboute
¶ I graunt quod that other out of doute
That by my trouth I woll the not bewreye
¶ Now qd he thou wotest well we be tweye
And tweyne of vs shall strenger be than one
Loke whan þᵗat he is set thou ryght anone
Aryse as though thou woldest wyth hy pleye

Whyles thou strogelyst wyth hym in game
And with thy dagger loke thou do the same
And then shall all this golde departyd be
My dere frende betwyxte me and the
Then maye we bothe our lustys fulfylle
And play at dyse ryght at our owne wylle
And accorded be thyse shrewes tweye
To sle the thyrde as ye haue herde me seye
¶ This yongest whyche that went to þᵉ toun
Full ofte in herte he rollyd vp and doun
The bewte of thyse floreyns newe and bryght
O lorde quod he yf so were that I myght
All this tresour wynne to myself alone
Ther nys no man that lyueth vnder trone
Of god that sholde lyue as mery as I
And at laste the fende our enemye
Put in his herte that he sholde poyson bey
Wyth whyche he myght sle his felowes twey
For why the fende fonde hym in suche lyuynge
That he had leue hym in sorowe to brynge
For this was vtterly his entent
To sle hem bothe and neuer to repent
¶ And forth he goth no lenger wolde he tary
In to the towne vnto a potecary
And prayed hym that he wolde hym selle
Som poyson that he myght his rattis quelle
And eke therwyth was a polcat in his hawe
That as he sayd his capons had slawe
And sayd he wolde wreke hem yf he myght

¶ The potecary answerde thou shalt haue
A thynge as wysly god my soule saue
In all this worlde there is no creature

Not but the mountenaıı̄unce of a corn of whete
That he ne shall anon his lyf forlete
Ye sterue he shall and in lesse whyle
Or thou wollt go passyng half a myle
This poyson is so stronge and ⁊and so vyolent
¶ This cursyd man hath in his honde it hent
This poyson in a boxe and syth he ran
In to the nexte strete vnto a man
And borowed hym large botellis thre
And in to the tweyne the poyson poured he
The thyrde he kepte clene for his drynke
For all nyghte he shope hym for to swynke
In caryenge of this golde / out of this place
And whan this ryotour wyth sory grace
Had fylled wyth wyne his grete botellys thre
