¶ What it to sermone of it more
For ryght as they had cast his deth afore
Ryght so they haue hym sleyn ryght anon
And whan this was don then spake that on
Now let vs syt ⁊and drynke and make vs mery
And afterwarde we woll his body bery
And afterwarde it happyd hem per caas

For whyche anon they steruen both two
¶ But certes I suppose that auicenne
Wrote neuer in no canoun ne in no fenne
More wondersorowes of enpoysonynge
Than had thyse wretches two in her endynge
Thus endyd ben thyse homycides two
And eke the fals empoysoner also
¶ O cursyd synne full of cursydnes
O traytours homicide o wyckidnes
O glotonye o luxury o hasardrye
Thou blasphemar of cryst wyth vylonye
And othes grete of vsage and of pryde
Alas mankynde how may it betyde
That to thy creatour whyche that the wrouȝt
And wyth his precyous blood the bought
Thou art so fals and so vnkynde alas
¶ Now gode men god foryeue you your trespas
And ware you from the synne of auaryce
My holy pardon may you alle waryce
So that ye offre nobillis or sterlyngis
Or elles syluer sponys brochis or ryngis
Bowyth your heed vnder thyse holy bullys
Cometh vp ye wyues offreth of your wullys
Your names I entre in my rolle anon
I you assoylle by my hyghe power
You that woll offre as clene and as cleer
As ye were bore lo syres thus I preche
And Ihesu cryst that is our soulys leche
So graunte you his pardon to receyue
For that is best I woll you not dysceyue
But syres o worde forgate I in my tale
I haue relykes and pardon in my male
As fayr as ony man in englonde
Whyche were me yeue by the popis honde
Yf ony of you wyll of deuocyoun
Offre and haue myn absolucyoun
Comyth forth anon and knelyth here a doun

Al newe and fresshe at euery myles ende

So assoyle you in countre as ye ryde
For auenturis whyche that maye betyde
For parauenture there may falle one or two

Loke whyche a surete it is to you alle

That may assoylle you bothe more ⁊and lasse

For he is most enuolupyd in synne
Comyth forth syr hoste ⁊and offreth ryght anone

¶ Nay nay quod he then haue I cristis curs
Let be quod he it shall not be so theche
Thou woldest make me kysse thyn old breche
And swere it were a relyk of a saynt
Though it were wᵗith thy fundement y depaynte

I wolde I had thy colyons in my honde

Let kyt hem of I woll helpe the hem to cary
They shull be shryned in an hoggys torde
This pardoner answerde not o worde
So wroth he was he wolde no worde say
¶ Now quod our hoste I woll no lenger play
Wyth the ne wyth none other angry man
¶ But ryght anon the worthy knyght began
Whan that he sawe that all the peple lough
No more of this for it is ryght ynough
Syr pardoner be mery and glad of chere
And ye syr hoste that be to me so dere
I pray you that ye kysse the pardonere
And pardoner I pray the drawe the nere
And as we dyde lete vs laugh and play
Anon they kyssed and ryden forth her way
Here endyth the pardoners tale
Here begynneth the shypmannys tale
A Marchaunt sōmtyme was at sayut denys
That riche was wherfore men helde hy wyse
A wyf he had of excellent bewte
And compenable and reuelous was she
Whyche is a thyng that causyth more dispence
Than worth is all the chere and reuerence
That men hem done at festes and at daunces
Suche salutacyons and countenaunces
Passen as doth a shadow on a walle
But wo is hym that payen must for alle
The sely husbonde algate he must paye
He muste vs bothe clothe and eke araye
All for his owne worship ful rychely
In whyche araye we daunsen Iolily
And yf that he nought paye perauenture
Or ellys lyst not suche spences endure
But thynketh it is wastyd and y lost
Then must a nother paye for our cost
Or lene vs golde and that is perlous
¶ This noble marchaunt helde a noble hous
For whyche he had so grete repeyr
For his largenes ⁊and for his wyf was feyr
That wonder was but herkenyth to my tale
Amonge all thyse gestis grete and smale
¶ Ther was a monk a fayr man ⁊and a bolde
I trowe that . xxx . wynter he was olde
That euer in one was drawyng to that place
This yonge monke that was so fayr of face
Aqueynted was wyth the good man
Syth that theyr fyrst knowlege began
That in his hous as famylyer was he
As it is possyble ony frende to be
But for as moche as this good man
And eke this monke of whyche I began
Were bothe two born in one village
The monke hym claymeth as for cosynage
And he ayen sayth not onys nay
But was as glad therof as foule of day
For to his herte it was a grete plesaunce
Thus ben they knyght wyth etern allyaunce
And eche of hem gan other for to ensure
Of brotherhede whyle that her lyf may endure
¶ Fre was dan Iohn and namely of dyspence
As in that hous and full of dilygence
To doon plesaunce and also grete costage
He not foryat to yeue the leste page
In all that hous but after his degree
He yaf the lord and also his meynee
Whan that he came som maner honest thynge
For whyche they were as glad of his comynge
As foule is fayn whan the sonne vpryseth
Nomore of this for it suffyseth
¶ But so befell this marchaunt on a day
Shope hym to make redy his aray
Towarde the towne of bruggis for to fare
To byen there a porcyoun of ware
For whyche he had to parys sent anon
A messenger and prayed hath dan Iohn
That he sholde come to saynt denys ⁊and pley
Wyth hym ⁊and his wyf a day or twey
Er he to bruggis went in all wyse
¶ This noble monk the whyche I you deuyse
Hath of his abbot as hym lyst lycence
By cause he was a man of hygh prudence
And eke an offycer out for to ryde
To se her graungis and her bernis wyde
And to saynt denys comyth him anon
¶ Who was so welcom as my lorde dan Iohn
Our dere cosyn full of curtesye
Wyth hym he brought a Iub of maluesye
And eke a nother full of fyue vernage
And volatyle as was his vsage
And thus I lete hem ete drynke and pleye
This marchaunt ⁊and this monk a day or tweye
¶ The thyrde day the marchaunt vpryseth
And on his nedys sadly hym auyseth
And vp to his courtirhous goth he
To rekene wyth hymself what may be
Of that yere how that it with hym stode
And how that he dispended had his gode
And yf encresed he had or none
His bokis and his baggis many one
He layeth beforn hym on his countyng borde
Full ryche was his tresour and his horde
For whyche full fast his countour he shet
And eke he nolde that no man sholde hym let

And thus he sat tyll it was passyd pryme
¶ Dan Iohn was rysen in the morow also
And in the gardyn walkyd to and fro
And sayd his thynges full curyously
¶ This good wyf cam walkyng pryuely
In to the gardyn there as he walkyd softe
And hym salewed as she hath doon ofte
A mayde chylde came in her companye
Whyche as she lyst she may gouerne and gye
For yet vnder the yerde was the mayde
¶ O dere cosynmyn dan Iohn she sayde
What eylleth you so rathe for to ryse
¶ Nece quod he it ought ynough suffyse
Fyue houris to slepe on a nyght
But it were for an olde pallyd wyght
As been thyse wedded men that lyen and dare
As in a fourme sytteth a wery hare
Were al for straught wᵗith houndys grete ⁊and smale
But dere nece why loke ye now so pale
I trowe certes that our good man
Hath you labouryd syth the nyght began
That you were nede to resten hastely
And wyth that worde he lough full merily
And wyth his owne thought wext all reed
¶ This fayr wyf gan shake her heed
And sayd thus ye god wote all quod she
Nay cosyn it stondyth not so wyth me
For by that god that yaf me soule and lyf
In all the reame of fraunce is ther no wyf
That lesse lust hath to that soryp laye
For I may synge alas and wel awaye
That I was born but to no wyght quod she
Dar I not telle how it stondyth wyth me
Wherfore I thynke out of this londe to wende
Or ellys of myself to make an ende
So full I am of drede and eke of care
¶ This monk began vpon this wyf to stare
And sayd alas my nece god forbede
That ye for ony sorowe or for ony drede
To fordo yourself / but tell me your greef
Perauenture I may in your myscheef
Counsell or helpe and therfore tellyth me
All your annoye / for it shall secret be
For on my porthorse here I make an othe
That neuer in my lyf for leyf ne lothe
Ne shall I of no counsell you bewreye
¶ The same quod she to you y seye
By god and by this porthose I you swere
Though men woll me all to pecys tere
Ne shall I neuer for to goo to helle
Bewreye o worde of thynge that ye me telle
Not for no cosynage / ne allyaunce
But verily for loue / and affyaunce
Thus been they swore ⁊and therupon they kyst
And eche talkyth to other what them lyst
¶ Cosyn quod she yf that I had space
As I haue none ⁊and namely in this place
Then wolde I telle a legende of my lyf
What I haue suffryd syn I was wyf
Wyth my husbonde all be he your cosyn
¶ Nay quod this monk bi god ⁊and saynt martin
He is no more cosyn vnto me
Than is the leef that hangyth on the tre
I clepe hym so by saynt denys of fraunce
To haue the more cause of acqueyntaunce
Of you whom I haue loued specyally
Aboue all other wymen sykerly
This swere I you on my professyoun
Tellyth your greyf lest he come doun
And hastyth you and goo away anon
¶ My dere loue quod she o my dan Iohn
Ful leef were me this counsell to hyde
But out it muste it may no lenger abyde
¶ My husbonde is to me the worst man
That euer was syth the worde began
But syth I am his wyf it sytteth not me
To telle no wyght of our pryuyte
Neyther in bed ne in none other place
God shylde I sholde it telle it for his grace
A wyf sholde not sayen of her husbonde
But all honour as I can vnderstonde
Saue vnto you thus moche I telle shal
As helpe me god he is not worth at al
In no degree the value of a flye
But yet me greuyth moost his nygardrye
And well ye wote that wymen naturelly
Desyren thynges syxe as well as do I
They wolde that her husbondes sholde be
Hardy and wyse ryche and therto fre
And buxom to his wyf and fressh a bedde
But by that ylke lorde that for vs bledde
For his houour myself for to araye
A sonday next I must nedys paye
An hundryd frankys or elles I am lore
Yet were I leuer to be vnbore
Then me were doo dysclaunder or vylonye
And yf my husbonde myght it spye
I nere but lost and therfore I you preye
Lene me this sōmme or ellys I muste deye
Dan Iohn I say lene me this hıı̄unndred frankis
Parde I woll not fayle you my thankis
Yf that ye lyst to do that I you praye
For at a certeyn daye I woll you paye
And don to you what plesaunce or seruyse
That I may doon ryght as ye lyste deuyse
And but I do god take on me vengaunce
As fowle as euer had genylyon of fraunce
¶ This gentyll monk ansuerd in this manere
Now truely myn owne lady dere
I haue on you quod he so grete a routhe
That I you swere and plyght my trouthe
That whan your husbond is to flaundris far
I woll delyuer you out of this care
For I woll brynge you an hundryd frankis
And wᵗith the worde he caught her bi the shankis
And her enbraced harde and kyste her softe
Goth now your waye quod he al stylle ⁊and softe
And lete vs dyne as sone as ye may
For by my kalender it is pryme of the day
Goth now and be as true as I shall be
¶ Now ellys god forbede syr quod she
And forth she goth as Ioly as a pye
And bad the cokys that they sholde hye
So that men myght dyne at none
Vp to her husbonde is this wyf goon
And knockyd at his countir boldly
¶ Who is there quod he petyr it am I
Quod she what syr how longe woll ye fast
How longe tyme woll ye rekyn and caste
Your sōmmes ⁊and your bokys and your thynges
The deuyll haue parte of al suche rekenynges
Ye haue ynough parde of goddys sonde
Come downe to daye ⁊and let your baggis stonde
Ne be ye not asshamyd that dan Iohn
Shall fastyng all this longe day gon
What lete vs goo here a masse and go dyne
¶ Ye quod this man lytyll canst thou dyuyne
The curyous besynes that we haue
For of vs chapmen all so god me saue
And by that lorde that clepyd is saynt Iue
Scarcely among twyes ten twelue shal thryue
Contynuelly lastynge vnto theyr age
We maye well make chere and good vysage
And dryue forth the worlde as it may be
And kepe our astate in preuyte
Tyll we be ded or elles that we pleye
A pylgrymage or gon out of the weye
And therfore haue I grete necessyte
Vpon this queynte worlde to auyse me
For euer more we must stonde in drede
Of hap ⁊and fortune in our chapmanhede
¶ To flaundris wol I go to morow at day
And come ayen assone as euer I may
For whyche dere wyf I the beseke
As be to euery wight buxom and meke
And for to kepe our good be curyous
And honestly gouerne well our hous
Thou hast ynough in euery maner wyse
That to a thrifty housholde may suffyse
The lackyth none araye ne none vytayll
Of syluer in thy purs shall thou not fayll
And wyth that worde his countir dore he shett
And downe he goth he wolde no lenger lett
But hastely a masse was there sayde
And spedily the tables were layde
And to dyner faste they hem sped
And rychely the chapman this monke fed
¶ And after dyner dan Iohn sobirly
This chapman toke a parte properly
And sayd hym thus cosyn it stondyth so
That well I see to bruggis woll ye go
God ⁊and saynt austyn spede you and guyde
I pray you cosyn wysely thyder ye ryde
Gouerne you also well of your dyete
Attemperly and namly in this hete
Betwyxte vs two nedyth no straunge fare
Farwell cosyn god shelde you fro care
And yf ony thynge by day or by nyght
Be in my power or in my myght
That ye me woll cōmmaunde in ony wyse
It shall be do ryght as ye woll deuyse
¶ O thynge or that ye goon yf it may be
I pray you to lene it vnto me
An hundryd frankys for a weke or tweye
For certen bestys that I must beye
To store wyth a place that is houris
God helpe me so I wolde it were youris
I shall not faylle surely of my day
Not for a thousande frankys a myle way
But lete this thynge be secret I you preye
For yet this nyght this bestes must I beye
And fare now well myn owne cosyn dere
Gramercy of your cost and of your chere
¶ This uoble marchaunt and that anon
Ansuerde ⁊and sayde o cosyn myn dan Iohn
Now sykerly this is a small request
My golde is yours whan that ye lest
And not only my golde but my chaffare
Take that ye lyste god shelde that ye spare
But o thynge ye knowe well y nough
Of chapmen that her money is her plough
We may creaunce whyle we haue a name
But goodles for to be it is a shame
Paye it ayen whan it lyth at your ese
After my myght fayne wolde I you plese
¶ Thyse hundryd frankys fet he forth anon
And pryuely he toke hem to dan Iohn
No wyght of all this londe wyst of this lone
Sauyng this marchaunt and dan Iohn alone
They drynke ⁊and speke ⁊and rome a whyle ⁊and pleye
Tyll that dan Iohn rydeth to his abbeye
¶ The morow cam ⁊and forth ryde this marchaunt
To flaıı̄undris ward his prent brouȝt hy auaunt
Tyl he cam to bruggis wel ⁊and merily
Now goth this marchaunt well and besyly
Aboute his nedis and byeth and creaunsyth
He neyther playeth at the dyce ne daunsyth
But as a marchaunt shortly to telle
He ledde his lyf ⁊and there I lete hym dwelle
¶ The sonday next þᵗat this marchaıı̄unt wasgon
To saynt denys is comyn dan Iohn
Wyth crowne ⁊and berde all fresshe ⁊and newe shaue
In all this hous ther nas solytyll a knaue
Ne no wyght ellys / but he was full fayn
That my lord dan Iohn was comyn agayn
And shortly to the poynt ryght for to gon
This fayr wyf accordyth wyth dan Iohn
That for his hıı̄undryd frankis he shold al nyȝt
Haue her in his armes bolt vp ryght
And this accorde perfourme is in dede
In myrthe all nyght a besy lyf they lede
Tyll it was day þᵗat dan Iohn yede his way
And bad the meyne farwel ⁊and haue good day
For non of hem ne no wyght in the toun
Hath of dan Iohn ony suspecyoun
And forth he rydeth home to his abbeye
Or where hym lyst no more of hym I seye
¶ This marchaıı̄unt whan þᵗat endyd was þᵉ feyre
To saynt denys he gan ageyn repeyre
And wyth his wyf he makyth feeste and chere
And tellyth her the chaffare that is so dere
That nedis must he make a cheuesaunce
For he was bounden in a recognysaunce
To paye . xx . thousande sheldys anoon
For whyche this marchaunt is to parys goon
To borowe of certeyn frendes that he had
A (certeyn of frankys ⁊and some wyth hym he lad
And whan that he was come in to the toun
For chierte and grete affeccyoun
Vnto dan Iohn he goth him fyrst to pleye
Not for to axe ne borowe of hym moneye
But for to wyte ⁊and se his welfare
And for to tellen hym of his chaffare
As frendys done whan they mete in fere
¶ Dan Iohn hym maketh feste ⁊and mery chere
And he hym tolde full specyally
How he had well sped ⁊and gracyously
Thaunkyd by god all hole his marchaundyse
Saue that he must in alle manere wyse
Maken a cheuesaunce as for thebeste
And then he sholde be in Ioye and reste
Dam Iohn answerde certes I am fayn
That ye in hele ar comen home agayn
And yf that I were ryche as I haue blys
Of . xx . thousande sheldes sholde ye not mys
For ye so kyndely this other daye
Lent me golde and as I can and may
I thanke you by god and by saynt Iame
But netheles I toke it vnto our dame
Your wyf at home the same golde ayen
Vpon your benche she wote it well certeyn
By certeyn tokens that I can you telle
Now by your leue I maye no lenger dwelle
Our abbot woll out of this towne anoon
And in his company must I goon
Grete wele our dame myn owne nece swete
And farwell dere cosyn tyll we mete
¶ This marchaunt whiche þᵗat was ful ware ⁊and wyse
Creaunsyd hath ⁊and payd eke in paryse
To certeyn lumbardis redy in her honde
The some of golde and gate of hem his bonde
And home he goth as mery as a popyngeay
For well he knewe he stode in suche araye
That nedys must he wynne in that vyage
A thousande frankys aboue al his costage
¶ His wyf full redyly mett hym atte yate
As she was wont of olde vsage algate
And all that nyghte in myrthe they be set
For he was ryche and cleerly out of det
¶ Whan it was day þᵉ marchaunt gan enbrace
Hys wyf all newe and kyste her in the face
And vp he goth and makyth it full tough
Nomore quod she by god ye haue ynough
And wantounly agayn wyth hym she playde
Tyll atte laste the marchaunt thus sayde
¶ By god quod he I am a lytyll wroth
Wyth you my wyf all though it be me loth
And wote ye why by god as I gesse
That ye haue made a manere straungenesse
Betwyxte me and my cosyn dan Iohn
Ye sholde haue warnyd me or I had gon
That he had you an hundryd frankys payde
By redy token and helde hym euyll apayde
For that I to hym spake of cheuesaunce
Me semyd so as by his countenaunce
But netheles by god our heuen kynge
I thought to axe of hym no thynge
I praye the wyf do nomore so
Telle me now or I fro the goo
Yf ony dettour hath in myn absence
Y payed the leest by thy neclygence
I myght hym axe a thynge that he hath payd
¶ This wyf was not ferde ne affrayd
But boldly she sayd and that anon
Mary I diffye that fals monk dan Iohn
I kepe not of his tokenys neuer a dele
He toke me certen golde that wote I wele
What euyll thedom on his monkys snowte
For god it wote I wende wythouten dowte
That he had yeue it me by cause of you
To doo therwith myn honour and my prow
For cosynage and eke for bele chere
That he hath had full ofte tymes here
But syth I se it stont in suche dysioynt
I woll answere you shortly to the poynt
¶ Ye haue no slacker dettonr than am I
For I woll pay you redily
Fro day to day yf so be I fayll
I am your wyf score it vpon my tayll
And ellys I shall pay as sone as euer I may
For by my trouth I haue on myn aray
And not in waste bestowed it euery dele
And for I haue bestowed it so wele
For your honour for goddys sake I saye
As be not wroth ⁊and let vs laugh ⁊and playe
Ye shall my Ioly body haue to wedde
By god I woll not pay you but a bedde
Forgeue it me myn owne spowse dere
Turnyth hether makyth better chere
¶ This marchaıı̄unt saw ther was non other remedy
And for to chyde it were but a foly
Syn that the thynge may none other be
Now wyf he sayd and I foryeue it the
And by thy lyf be nomore so large
Kepe better thy good this gyue I in charge
Thus endyth my tale and god vs sende
Talynge ynough vnto our lyues ende
Here endith the shypmannys tale
Here endith the shypmannys tale
The wordis of the hoste
WEll sayd by corpus dns sayd our hoste
Nowlonge mote thou sayll by the coste
Thou gentyll mayster gentyll maryner
God geue the monk a thousand last quad yer
A ha felowes beware of suche a Iape
The monk put in the mannys hode an ape
And in his wyues eke by saynt austyn
Drawyth no monkys nomore to your in
¶ But now passe ouer and lete vs seke aboute
Who shall telle a tale fyrst of all this route
A nother tale ⁊and wyth that worde he sayde
As curteysly as it had be a mayde
¶ My lady prioresse by yonr leue
So that I wyst I sholde you not greue
I wolde deme that ye tellen sholde
A tale nexte yf so were that ye wolde
Now woll ye vouchesauf my lady dere
¶ Gladly quod she and sayd as ye sholl here
Her endeth the wordes of the host
Here begynneth the prioresse prologue
¶ Domine dns noster quā admirabile est nomen tuıı̄un in vniuersa terra
LOrd our lord thi name is euer meruelous
In this large worlde y spred quod she
For not all only thy laude prrecyous
Perfourmyd is by men of dygnyte
But by thy mouth of chyldren thy bounte
Perfourmyd is for on the brest soukynge
Somtyme shewen they thyn heryenge
Wherfore in laude as I can and may
Of the and of the whyte lyly flour
Whyche that the bare and is mayde alway
To telle a story I woll do my labour
Not that I maye encrese her honour
For she herself is honour and the rote
Of bounte nexte her sonne and soulis bote
O moder mayde o mayde and moder fre
O busshe vnbrent brennynge in moyses syght
That raueshedist downe from the deyte
Thruh thyn hıı̄unblynes the ghost þᵗat in the alyȝt
Of whose vertue whan he thin herte lyghte
Conceyued was the faders sapyence
Helpe me to telle it in thy reuerence
Lady thy bounte thy magnyfycence
Thy vertue and thy grete humylyte
Ther may no tunge expresse in no scyence
For sumtyme lady or men praye the
Thou ghost beforn of thy benygnyte
And getyst vs the lyght of thy prayer
To gyden vs vnto thy sone so deer
My cunnynge is so weke o blysfull quene
For to declare thyn hyghe worthynesse
That I ne may the weyght sustene
But as a chylde or twelfmonth olde or lesse
That can vnnethe ony worde expresse
Ryght so fare I and therfore I you praye
Gydeth my songe as I shall you saye

Here endyth the prioresse prologue
And here begynneth her tale
THer was in asye in a grete cyte
Amonge cristen folke a Iurye
Susteyned by a lorde of that countre
For fowle vsure and lucre of vylonye
Hatefull to cryst and to his companye
And thorouh this strete men might ryde ⁊and wende
For it was fre and open at euery ende
A lytyll scole of crysten folke ther stode
Downe at ferder ende in whyche there were
Chyldren an hepe comyn of crysten blood
That lernyd in scole yere by yere
Suche manere doctryne as men vsen here
This is to saye to synge and to rede
As smale chyldren doon in her chyldehede
¶ Among thyse chydn was a wydowes sone
A lytyll clergyon seuen yere of aege
And day by day to scole was his wone
And eke also where as he sawe the ymage
Of crystis moder had he in vsage
As hym was taught to knele a downe ⁊and saye
His Aue maria as he goth by the waye
Thus hath his wydowe her lytyll sone taught
Our blessyd lady cristis moder dere
To worshyp ay and he forgate it nought
For the sely chylde wolde alway sone lere
But ay whan I remembre me on this matere
Saynt nicholas stont euer in my presence
For he so yonge to crist dyde reuerence
This lytyll chylde his lytyll boke lernynge
As he sat in the scole at his prymere
He Alma redemptoris mater herde synge
As chyldren lernyd her antiphoner
And as he durste he drewe ay nere and nere
And herknyd ay the wordes and the note
Tyll he the fyrste vers cowde all by rote
Nought wyst he what this laten was to say
For he so yonge and tender was of age
But on a day his felowe gan he pray
To expowne hym this songe in his langage
Or tell hym why this song was in vsage
This prayd he hym to construe and declare
Full oft tymes vpon his knees bare
¶ His felowe whyche that elder was than he
Ansuerde him thus this songe I haue herd say
Was made of our blessyd lady fre
Her to salewe ⁊and eke her for to praye
To be our helpe and socour whan we deye
I can no more expowne in this matere
I lerne songe I can but lytyll gramere
¶ And is this songe made in reuerence
Of cristys moder sayd this Innocent
Now certeyn I woll do my dyligence
To conne it all or crystmas is all y went
Though that I for my prymer be shent
And sholde be bete thr yes in an hour
I woll it conne our lady to honour
His felow taught hym homwarde pryuely
Fro day to day tyll he cowde it all by rote
And thenne he songe it well and boldly
Fro worde to worde acordinge to the note
Twys a day it passyd thrugh his throte
To scoleward and homwarde whan he went
On cristys moder set was all his entente
As I haue sayd thrugh out the Iurye
This lytyll chylde as he came to and fro
Full merily wolde he synge and crye
O alma redemptoris mater euer mo
The swetnesse his herte persed so
Of crystis moder that he to her praye
He can not stynt of syngynge by the waye
¶ Our fyrst foo the serpent sathanas
That hath in Iewes herte his waspis neest
Vp swall and sayde o ebraik peple allas
Is this a thynge that is to vs honest
That suche a boye shall walke as hym leest
In your dispyte and synge of suche sentence
Whyche is ayenst our lawes reuerence
¶ Fro thens forth the Iewes haue conspyred
This Innocent out of this worlde to chace
An homicide therto haue they hyred
Ryght at an aley had a preuy place
And as the chylde gan forth by to pace
This cursyd Iue hym hent and helde faste
And kytte his throte ⁊and in a pytte hym caste
I say that in a warderope they hym threwe
Where as the Iewes purge her entrayll
O cursyd folke of herodis all newe
What may your euyll entent you auayle
Murdre woll out certeyn it woll not fayle
And namly ther the honour of god shal I sprede
The blood out cryeth on your cursyd dede
O martyr sowdyd vnto vyrgynyte
Now mayst thou synge folowynge euer in oon
The whyte lambe celestyall quod he
Of whyche the grete euangelist saynt Iohn
In pathmos wrote whyche sayth þᵗat they goon
Beforn this lambe and synge a songe ay new
That neuer flesshly woman they ne knewe
¶ This pore wydow awayteth all that nyght
After her lytyll chylde and he cam nought
For whyche as sone as it was daye lyght
Wyth face pale o f drede and besy thought
She hath at scole and ellys where hym sought
Tyll fynally so fer she gan to espye
That he last seen was in the Iurye
Wyth moders pyte in her brest enclosyd
She goth as she were half out of her mynde
To euery place where she hath supposyd
By lyklyhede her lytyll chylde for to fynde
And euer on crystis moder meke and kynde
She cryed ⁊and at last thus she wrought
Amonge the cursyd Iewes she hym sought
She axeth ⁊and she freyneth pytously
Of euery Iewe that dwelled in that place
To telle yf her chylde went aught forth by
They sayd nay but Ihesu of his grace
Yaf in her thought wythin a lytyll space
That in that place after her sone she cryde
Where he was casten in a pyt besyde
¶ O grete god that parfourmest thy laude
By mouth of Innocentis lo here thy myght
This gemme of chastyte this emeraude
And eke of martyrdom the ruby bryght
There he wyth throte ycoruen lyth vpryght
He Alma redemptoris gan to synge
So lowde þᵗat all the place gan for to rynge
¶ The crysten folk that by the strete went
In cam for to wonder vpon this thynge
And hastily they for the prouost sent
Whyche fond the chylde fresshly yet bledynge
And heryeth cryste that is of heuen kynge
And eke his moder honour of mankynde
And after that the Iewes lete he bynde
¶ This chylde wyth pytous lamentacyoun
Vp taken was syngynge this songe alwey
And wyth honour and grete processyoun
They carye hym in to the nexte abbey
His moder swownynge by his beer ley
Vneth myght the peple that was there
This sorowfull rachel brynge from the bere
¶ Wyth torment ⁊and wyth shamfull deth echon
This prouost doth thise Iewes for to sterue
That of this murdre wyste and that anon
He nolde no suche cursydnes obserue
Euyll shall he haue that euyll woll deserue
Wherfore with wylde hors he dyde hem drawe
And after he hangyd hem by the lawe
¶ Vpon his beer aye lyeth this Innocent
Before the hyghe awter whyle the masse last
And after that the abbot and his couent
Hem spedde for to bery hym full fast
And whan they holy water on hym cast
Yet spak this child whan spreynt was holi water
He sange O alma redemptoris mater
This abbot whyche that was an holy man
As monkys ben or elles ought to be
This yonge chylde to coniure he began
And sayd o dere chylde I coniure the
In the vertue of the holy trynyte
Tell me what is thy cause for to syng
Syn that thy throte is kyt to my semynge
My throte is kyt . vnto myn necke boon
Sayd this chylde . and as by way of kynde
I sholde a deyed . ye longe tyme a goon
But Ihesu cryst as ye in bokis fynde
Woll that his glory last and be in mynde
And for the worshyp of his moder dere
Yet may I synge . O alma . loude and clere
This welle of mercy . crystis moder swete
I louyd always . as after my cunnynge
And whan that I my lyf . sholde forlete
To me she cam . and bad me for to synge
This antheme . verily in my deyenge
As ye han herde . ⁊and whan that I had songe
Me thought . she layd a greyn vpon my tonge
Wherfore I synge . and synge moot certeyn
In honour of that blysfull mayden free
Tyll fro my tonge . y taken is the greyn
And after that . thus sayd she to me
My lytyll chylde . now woll I fetche the
Whan that the greyn . is fro thy tonge y take
Be not agast . I woll the not forsake
¶ This holy monk this abbot . hym mene I
His tonge out caught . and toke away þᵉ greyn
And he yaf vp the ghost . full softely
And whan this abbot had . this wonder seyn
His salt terys . trykled downe as reyn
And gruf he fell . all flat vnto the grounde
And stylle he laye . as he had layn y bounde
The couent eke . laye on the pauement
Wepynge . and heryeng cristis moder dere
And after that they rose . and forth been went
And toke away . this martyr from his beere
And in a tombe . of marbyll stones cleere
Enclocen they . this lytyll body swete
There he is now . god graunt vs for to mete
¶ O yonge hugh of lyncoln . slayn also
Wyth cursyd Iewes . as it is notable
For it is . but a lytyll whyle y go
Praye eke for vs . we synfull folke vnstable
That of his mercy . god so mercyable
On vs . his grete mercy multyplye
For reuerence . of his moder marie . Amen

Here endyth the Prioresse
her tale
Here foloweth the prologue of co mynynge of the hoste to Chaucer .
WHan sayd was all this myracle euery mān
As sobre was . that wonder was to se
Tyll that our hoste . to Iapen began
And thene at erst he lokid vp on me . i . chaucer
And sayd thus . what man artou quod he ;
Thou lokist . as thou woldest fynde an hare
For euer vpon the grounde . I se the stare
Approche nere . and loke vp merily
Now ware you syres . ⁊and let this man haue place
He in the waste . is shape as well as I
This were a popet . in an arme to tenbrace
For ony woman small . and fayr of face
He semyth eluyssh by his countenaunce
For vnto no wyght . doth he dalyaunce
Say now somwhat . syn other folke . han sayd
Telle vs a tale of myrthe . and that anoon
¶ Hoste quod I . ne be not euyll apayd
For other tale . certes can I noon
But of a rym . I lernyd longe agoon
Ye þᵗat is good quod he . now shull we here
Som deynte thynge . me thynkith by his chere
Here endyth the prologe

Here begynneth Chaucers tale
tale of syre Thopas
LYsteth lordynges . in good entent
And I woll tell verrayment
Of myrthe . and of solas
All of a knyght . was fayre and gent
In bataylle . and in torneyment
His name was . syre thopas
¶ Yborn he was . in ferre countree
In flaundres . all biyonde the see
At poperynge . in the place
His fader was . a man full free
And lorde he was . of that countree
As it was goodis grace
¶ Syre thopas . wax a doughty swayn
Whyt was his face . as payndemayn
His lyppes . reed as rose
His rode is lyke . scarlet in grayn
As I you telle . in good certayn
He hadde . a semy nose
¶ His heer . his berde was lyke saffroun
That it to his girdyll raught a doun
His shone . of cordewane
Of brydges were his hosen broun
His robe was . of syklatoun
That coste . many a Iane
¶ He cowde hunte . at wylde bore
And ryde on hawkynge . for ryuere
Wyth grey goshawke on honde
Therto he was . a good archere
Of wrastlynge . was ther none his pere
Ther ony ram . sholde stonde
¶ Full many a mayde . bryght in bour
They mourned for hym paramour
Whan hem . were bet to slepe
But he was chast . and no lechour
And swete . as is the brembyll flour
That beeryth the reed hepe
¶ And so it fell . vpon a day
Forsoth . as I you telle may
Syre thopas wolde out ryde
He warth . vpon his steede bay
And in his honde . a launcegay
A longe swerde . by his syde
¶ He pricketh . thorugh a fayr forest
Therin . is many a wylde best
Ye . bothe . bucke and hare
And as he prycketh . north and eest
I tell it you . hym had almeest
Betyd . a sory care
¶ Ther spryngen herbes . grete and smale
The lycoris . and cetewale
And many a cloue gilofre
And notmygge to . putte in ale
Whether it be . moyste or stale
Or for to laye in coffre
¶ The byrdes synge . it is no nay
The sperhauk . and the popyngiay
That Ioye . it was to here
The thrustylcok . made eke his lay
The wodedouue . vpon the spray
She sange . full lowde and clere
¶ Syre thopas . fyll in loue longynge
All whan he herde . the thrustyll synge
And prycked . as he were wood
His fayr stede . in his prykynge
So swatte . that men myght hym wrynge
His sydes were all blood
¶ Syre thopas eke so . wery was
For pryckynge . on the softe gras
So fyers . was his courage
That downe he layd hym in the plas
To maken his stede . some solas
And yaf hym good forage
¶ O saynt marie . benedicite
What eyleth . this loue at me
To bynde me . so sore
Me dremyd . all this nyght pardee
An elfe quene . shall my lemman be
And slepe . vnder my gore
¶ An elf quene . Woll I haue ywys
For in this worlde . no woman is
Worthy . to be my make
in towne
¶ Alle other wymen . I forsake
And to an elf quene . I me take
By dale . and eke by downe
¶ In to his saddyll . he clamb anon
And prycketh . ouer style and stoon
An elf quene . for to spye
Tyll he so longe . hath ryden and goon
That he founde . in a preuy woon
The countree . of fayrie
For in that countre . was there noon
Neyther wyf . ne chylde
¶ Tyll that there came . a grete gyaunt
His name was . syre olifaunt
A peryllous man . of deede
He sayd chylde . by termagaunt
But yf thou prycke . out of my haunt
Anon I slee . thy steede
¶ Here is this quene . of feyrie
Wyth harpe and pype . and symphonye
Dwellynge . in this place
¶ The chylde sayde . als moot I thee
To morowe . woll I mete the
Whan I haue myn armour
¶ And yet I hope . par ma fay
That thou shalt wyth this launcegay
Abeyen it . ful sour
Thyn hauberke shall I percen yf I may
Or it be fully pryme of day
For here . shaltow been slawe
¶ Syre thopas . drewe abak full faste
This gyaunt . at hym stones caste
Out . of a fell staf slynge
¶ But fayre escapyth . syre thopas
And all was . thorugh goddis gras
And thrugh his fayre berynge
Et lysteth lordes . to my tale
Meryer than the nyghtyngale
I woll yow rowne
How syre thopas . wyth sydes smale
Pryckynge ouer hylle and dale
Is comen . agayn to towne
¶ His mery men . cōmmauuded he
To make hym . bothe game and glee
For nedys mnst he fyghte
Wyth a gyaunt . wyth hedys thre
For paramour. and Iolyte
Of one . that shone full bryghte
¶ Do come he sayd . my mynstrales
And gestours . for to telle tales
Anon . in myn armynge
Of romances . that ben royalles
Of popes . and of cardynales
And eke of loue lykynge
¶ They sette hym fyrste . swete wyne
And mede eke . in a maȝelyne
And ryall spycerye
Of gyngerbrede . that was full fyne
And lycoris . and eke comyne
Wyth sugre . that is trye
¶ He dyde nexte . his whyte lere
Of clooth a lake . fyn and clere
Abreche . and eke a sherte
¶ And next his sherte . an alketon
And ouer that . an hanbergeon
For percyng . of his herte
¶ And ouer that . a fyn hawberk
Was all y wrought . of Iewes werk
full stronge it was . of plate
And ouer that . his cote armour
As whyte . as is . a lelye flour
In whyche . he woll debate
¶ His sheelde was all . of golde so reed
And therin was . a bores heed
A charbocle . by his syde
And there he swore . on ale and breed
How that the gyaunt . shall be deed
Betyde . what betyde
¶ His Iambeux were . of quyrboily
His swerdis shethe . of yuory
His helme . of laton bryght
¶ His sadyll was . of rewell boon
His brydell . as the sonne shoon
Or as . the moon lyght
¶ His spere was . of fyn cyprees
That bodyth werre and no thynge pees
The heed . full sharpe y grounde
¶ His stede was all . dappull gray
It gooth an ambyll . in the way
Full softely . and rounde
¶ Lo lordis myn here . is a fyt
Yf ye woll ony . more of it
To telle it . wolde I fonde
NOw holde your mouth pur charitee
Bothe knyght . and lady free
And hekenyth to my spelle
¶ Of bataylle . and of chyualrye
And of ladyes . loue drurye
Anon . I woll you telle
¶ Men speken . of romances of prys
Of hornchylde . and of ypotis
Of beues . and syre guy
¶ Of syre lybeux . and playndamour
But syre thopas . he beryth the flour
Of ryall chyualrye
¶ His good stede . all he bestrood
And forth . vpon his waye he glood
As sparcle . out of the bronde
¶ Vpon his crest . he bare a tour
And therin stycked . a lelye flour
God shylde . his cors fro shonde
¶ And for he was . a knyght auntrous
He nolde slepen . in noon hous
But lyggen . in his hode
¶ His bryghte helme . was his woouger
And by hym . bayteth his distrer
Of herbes . fyne and gode
¶ Hymself . dranke water of the well
As dyde the knyght . syre percyuell
So worly . vnder wede
¶ Tyll on a day

Here stynteth the hoste Chaucer
of his tale of syre Thopas . ⁊and byd-
dyth hym telle a nother tale .
NO more of this . for goddys dygnyte
Quod our hoste . for thou makest me
So wery . of thy very lewdenesse
That also wysly . god my soule blesse
Myn eres aken . of thy drafty speche
Now suche a ryme . the deuyll I beteche
This may well . be ryme dogerell quod he
¶ Why so quod I . why woltow lette me
More of my tale . than a nother man
Syn that it is . the best ryme that I can
¶ By god quod he . for playuly. at o worde
Thy drasty rymynge . is not worth a torde
Thou doost nought ellys . but despendyst tyme
Syre at o worde. thou shalt no lenger ryme
Lat se whether thou canst . tellen ought in geste
Or telle in prose . somwhat at the lest
In whiche ther be . som myrthe or doctryne
¶ Gladly quod I . by goddys swete pyne
I woll you telle . a lytyll thynge in prose
That ought lyke you . as I suppose
Or elles certes . ye be to daungerous
It is a morall tale vertuous
All be it tolde somtyme . in sondry wyse
Of sondry folke . as I shall you deuyse
¶ And thus . ye wote . that euery euangelist
That tellyth vs . the peyne of Ihesu crist
Ne sayth not all thynge . as his felowe dooth
But netheles . her sentence is all sooth
And alle accorden . as in her sentence
All be there . in her tellynge dyfference
For some of hem sayn more . ⁊and some sayn lesse
Whan they . his pytous passyon expresse
I mene . of mark . mathew . luke . and Iohn
But doutelees . her sentence is all oon
¶ Therfore . lordynges alle . I you beseche
Yf that ye thynke . I varye . as in my speche
As thus . though that I telle . somwhat more
Of yrouerbes . than ye han herde before
Comprehendyd . in this lytyll tretys here
To enforce wyth . theffect of my matere
And though I not . the same wordes saye
As ye han herde . yet to you all I praye
Blameth me not . for as in my sentence
Shall ye . nowhere fynde dyfference
Fro the sentence . of this tretys lyte
After the whiche . this merye tale I wryte
And therfore herkenyth . what that I shall say
And lat me tellen . all my tale I pray

Here endyth the disputacyon by
twene the Hoste and Chaucer for
tellynge of his tale in ryme of syre ⁊andlb Thopas . And after foloweth his ⁊andlb tale of Melibeus in prose .

of the monkis tale
WHan ended was the tale of Melibee
And of Prudence ⁊and of her benygnytee
Our hoost sayd as I am faythfull man
And by the precyous corps madrian
I had leuer than a barell of ale
That gode leyf my wyf had herde this tale
For she no thynge is of suche pacyence
As was this melibeus wyf prudence
By goddys bonys whan I bete my knaues
She bryngeth me the grete clubbed stauys
And cryeth slee the dogges euerychon
And breke both bak and euery boon
And yf that ony neyghbour of myn
Wyll not in chyrche to my wyf enclyn
Or be so hardy to her to trespas
Whan she comyth home she rāmpyth in my face
And cryeth fals cowarde wreke thy wyf
By corpus dominus I woll haue thy knyf
And thou shalt haue my dystaf ⁊and goo spynne
Fro day tyll nyghte she woll thus begynne
¶ Alas she sayth that euer she was shape
To wedde a mylksop a cowarde ape
That wyll be ouerlad wyth euery wyght
Thou darst not stonde by thy wyues ryght
This is my lyf / but yf that I wolde fyghte
And out at dore anone I moot me dyght
And ellys I am lost but yf that I
Be lyke a wylde lyon fole hardy
I wote well she woll do me slee som day
Som neyghbour and thenne goo my way
For I am perlous wyth knyf in honde
All be it that I dare not her wythstonde
For she is byg in armys by my fayth
That shal he fynde that her mysdoth or sayth
But lete vs passe awaye from this matere
¶ My lord he sayd he sayd syr monke be mery of cher
For ye shall telle a tale truly
Lo rouchester stondyst here fast by
Ryde forth myn owne lord breke not our gam
But by my trouth I knowe not your name
Whether shall I call you my lorde dan Iohan
Oe dan thomas dan robert or dan albon
Or of what hous be ye by your fader kyn
I vowe to god thou hast a full fayr chyn
It is a gentyll pasture there thou goost
Thou art not lyke a penaunte or a ghost
Vpon my fayth thou art some offycere
Som worthy sexten or som celerer
For by my fader sonle as to my dome
Thou art a mayster whan thou art at hom
No poore cloysterer ne no poore nouice
But a gouernour wyle and wyse
And therwyth of brawne and of bonys
A well farynge persone for the nonys
I praye to god yeue hym confusyon
That fyrst the brought in to religyon
Thou woldest be a tredefoul a ryght
Haddest thou as grete leue as thou hast myght
To perfourme all thy luste in engendrure
Thou haddist begoten many a creature
Alas why werest thou so wyde a cope
God geue me sorowe and I were pope
Not only thou but euery myghty man
Though he were shore highe vpon his pan
Shold haue a wyf for all this worlde is lorn
Religyon hath take vp all the corn
Of tredynge and borell men ben shrympes
Of feble trees there comyth wretchyd ympes
This makyth that our heyres be so sklender
And feble that they maye not well engender
This makyth that our wyues woll assaye
Religyous folke for they maye better paye
Of venus payementis than mowe we
God wote no lussheburghs paye ye
But be not wrothe my lorde though I play
Full ofte in game a soth haue I herde saye
¶ This worthy monke toke alle in pacyence
And sayd I woll do my dilygence
As fer as sowneth in to honeste
To telle you a tale or two or thre
And yf ye lyst to herken hytherwarde
I woll you sayen of the lyf of saynt edWarde
Or ellys tragedyes fyrst I woll telle
Of whyche I haue an hundryd in my celle
¶ Tragedye is for to telle a certayn storye
As olde bokys make memorye
Of them that stode in grete prosperyte
And is falle out of hye degree
In to mysery and endyth wretchydly
And they ben vercyfied comynly
Of . vi . feet whyche men calle exametron
In prose eke ben endyted many on
And in metre many a sondry wyse
Lo this ought ynough to suffyse
¶ Now herkenyth yf yow lyst for to here
But fyrst I beseche you in this matere
Though I by order telle not thyse thynges
Be it of popis emperours or kynges
And after her aeges as men wryten fynde
But telle hem som before ⁊and some behynde
As it comyth to my remembraunce
Haue me excusyd of myn Ignoraunce
Here endeth the monkys prologe
Here begynneth the monkis tale
I wyll bewayle in manere of tragedye
The harme of them þᵗat stond in hy degre
And fylle so that there was no remedye
To brynge hem out of her aduersyte
For certayn whan þᵗat fortune lyst to fle
Ther may no man of her the cours wᵗithholde
Lete no man truste on blynde prosperyte
Beth ware by this ensample yonge ⁊and olde
¶ At lucifer though he an angell were
And not a man at hym I woll begynne
For though fortune may not aungell dere
From hye degre yet fyll he for hys synne
Doun in to helle where he is yet ynne
O lucifer bryghtest af auugellis alle
Now art thou sathanas that mayst not twyne
Out of myserye whyche thou art falle
¶ Lo adam in the felde of damascene
Wyth goddis owne fyngre wrought was
And not begoten of mannys sperme vnclene
And welte all paradys sauynge one tree
Had neuer worldly man so hye degree
As adam tyll he for mysgouernaunce
Was dryuen out of his hyghe prosperyte
To labour ⁊and to helle and to myschaunce
¶ Lo sampson whyche that was anunciat
By the aungell longe or his natiuite
And was to god almyghty consecrat
And stode in nobles whyle he myght se
Was neuer suche a nother as was he
To speke of strengthe and therto hardynes
But to his wyues tolde he his secre
Thruh whyche he slongh hy for wretchydnes
Sampson this noble ⁊and myghty champyon
Wythout wepen saue his hondes tweye
He slough and all to rent the lyoun
Towarde his weddynge walkynge by þᵉ weye
His fals wyf cowde hym so pleyse ⁊and preye
Tyll she his counsell knewe ⁊and she vntrewe
Vnto his foos his counsell gan bewreye
And hym forsoke and toke a nother newe
An hundryd foxis toke sampson for yre
And all her tayles he togyder bonde
And sette the foxis taylles all on fyre
For he in euery taylle hath put a bronde
And they brent alle the cornes in that londe
And her olyues and her vynes eke
A thousand men eke he slough wyth his hond
And had no wepen but an asse cheke
Whan they were slayn so thrystid hym that he
Was well nye lorn for whyche he gan to preye
That god wolde of his payne haue som pyte
And sende hym drynke or ellis must he dye
And of this asse cheke that was so drye
Out of a wange toth sprange anon a welle
Of whyche he dranke ynough shortly to sey
Thus halpe hym god as Iudicum can telle
By very force at gasa on a nyght
Maugre the philistenys of that cyte
The gates of the towne he hath vp plyght
And on his back y caryed hem hath he
Hyghe on an hylle wher as men myght hem se
O noble ⁊and myghty sampson leyf ⁊and dere
Had thou not tolde to wymen thy secree
In all this worlde ne had be thy pere
This sampmson neyther sydre dranke ne wyn
Ne on his hed cam rasour none ne shere
By precept of the messager dyuyne
For all his strengthes in his heeres were
And fully twenty yere by yere
Of Israel he had the gouernaunce
But after sone shall he wepe many a teere
For wymen shall brynge hym to myschaunce
Vnto his lemman dalida he tolde
That in his heeris all his strengthe lay
And falsly to his foes hym she solde
And slepynge in his barm vpon a day
They made to clyppe or shere his heere away
And made his fomen all his crafte aspyen
And whan that they hym fonde in suche aray
They bonde hym faste ⁊and put out his eyen
But or his heeris were clypped or shaue
There was no bonde that myght hym bynde
But now is he put in pryson in a caue
Where as they made hym at the querne grynd
O noble sampson strongest of mankynde
O whylom Iuge in glory and in ryches
Now mayst þᵘ wepe wyth thyn eyen blynde
Sith þᵘ art from wele falle in to wretchydnes
¶ The ende of this caytif was as I shall saye
His fomen made a feste vpon a daye
And made hym as theyr fole before hem playe
And this was in a temple of grete araye
But at laste he made a fowle fray
For he two postis shoke ⁊and made hem falle

And slough hymself ⁊and eke his fomee
This is to saye the prynces euerychon
And eke thre thousand bodyes were there slayn
Wyth fallynge of the grete temple of stone
Of sampson woll I no more sayn
Beth ware of this ensample olde ⁊and playn
That no man telle his counsell to her wyues
Of suche thyng as they wold haue secret fayn
Yf that it towche her lymes or her lyues
OF hercules the souereyn conquerour
Syngyn his werkes lande ⁊and hye renoun
For in his tyme of strengthe he bare the flour
He slough ⁊and raft the skyn of the lyoun
And of centaurus layd the bost a doun
He arpies slewe the cruell byrdes felle

He drewe out cerberus the hounde of helle
He slewe thecruell tyraunt busurus
And made his hors to frete hym flesshe ⁊and boon

And euery reame went he for to se

¶ A lemman had this noble champyon

¶ Lordynges here by ensample mow ye take

CEnobia of palimerie quene

So worthy was in armys ⁊and so kene

And ye shall vnderstonde how that he

And also sone as she myght aspye
That she was not with chylde wyth that dede
Then wolde she suffre hym do his fantasye
Eft sonys ⁊and not but onys out of drede
And yf she were wyth chylde at that cast
Nomore sholde he playe that game
Tyll fully fourty dayes were past
Thenne wolde she onys suffre hym the same
All were thys onedac wylde or tame
He gate nomore of her for thus she sayd
It was to wyues lechery and shame
In other caas yf men wyth hem playd
¶ Two sonys by this onedac had she
The whyche she kept in vertue and lettrure
But now vnto our tale torne we
I saye that so worshypfull a creature
And wyse therwyth ⁊and large wyth mesure
So penyble in werre and curteys eke
Ne more labour myght in werre endure
Was non thouh all this worlde men wold seke
Her ryche araye ue myght not be tolde
As well in vessell as in her clothynge
She was all clad in perrey and in golde
And eke she lefte not for none huntynge
To haue of sondry tonges folke knowynge
Whan that she leyser had ⁊and for to entende
To lerne bokis was all her lykynge
How she in vertue her lyf myght dyspende
And shortly of this story for to trete
She doughty was her husbonde as she
That they conqueryd many regnes grete
In the orient wyth many a fayr cyte
Appertenaunt vnto the maieste
Of rome ⁊and wyth strengthe helde them fast
Ne neuer myght her foo men do her fle
All the whyles that onedacs dayes last
¶ Her bataylles who so lyst hem for to rede
Agayn sapor the kynge and other mo
And how all this proces fyll in dede
Why she conquerid ⁊and what tytle had she therto
And after of her myscheyf ⁊and of her woo
How that she was bysegyd and y take
Let hym to my mayster petrak goo
That wryteth yuough of this I vndertake
¶ Whan onedac was ded she myghtyly
The remys helde and with her owne honde
Agaynst her foes she fought truly
That ther was no prynce ne kyng in al þᵗat lond
But were glad yftheyl that grace fonde
That she ne sholde vpon his londe werreye
Wyth her they made alyaunce by bonde
To be in peas ⁊and lete hem ryde ⁊and playe
The emperour of more claudius
Ne hym beforn the romayn galyene
Ne durste neuer be so corageous
Ne non ermyn ne non egypcyen
Ne surryen ne none arabyen
Wythin the felde that durste wyth her fyght
Leest that she wolde them wyth her hondes sleen
Or wyth her meyne put them to flyght
In kyngys habyte went her sones two
As heyres of her reames alle
And hermanno and titamallo
Her names were as percyens them calle
But ay fortune hath in her hony galle
This myghty quene may no whyle endure
Fortune out of regne made her to falle
To wretchydnesse and to mysauenture
¶ Aurilian whan that the gouernaunce
Of rome came in his hondys tweye
He shope vpon this quene to do vengaunce
And wyth his legyons he toke his waye
Towarde senobie and shortly for to saye
He made her flee and at laste her hent
And feteryd her and eke her chyldren twaye
And wan the londe and home to rome he went
¶ Amonge other thynges that he wan
Her chare that of golde was wrought and perre
This grete romayn this aurilian
Hath wyth hym ladde that for men sholde see
Beforn his tryumphe walkyd she
Wyth golden cheynes on her neeke hangynge
Crowned she was as after her degree
And full of perre charged her clothynge
¶ Allas fortune she that whylom was
Dredefull to kyngis and to emperouris
Now gawryth all the peple on her alas
And she that helmyd was in starke stouris
And wan by force townes stronge and touris
Shall on her hed now were autremyte
And she that bare the septre full of flouris
Shall bere a dystaf her cost for to quyte
All though that nero were as vycyous
As ony fende that lyeth full lowe a doun
Yet he as tellyth vs suetonius
All this worlde had in subieccyon
Bothe est and west and septemtrion
Of rubyes saphires and of perlys whyte
Were all his clothes browdid vp and doun
For he in gemmys gretly gan delyte
He rome brent for his dilycacye
The senatours he slewe vpon a daye
To here how that wymmen wolde wepe and crye
And slough his brother and by his syster laye
His moder made he in a pytous araye
For he her wombe lete slytte to beholde
Where he conceyued was so weleawaye
That he so lytyll of his moder tolde
¶ In youth a mayster had this emperour
To teche hym lettrure and curteysye
For of moralyte he was the flour
As in his tyme bnt yf his bokys lye
And whyles his mayster had of hym maystry
He made hym so cunnynge and so souple
That longe tyme it was or tyrannye
Or ony vyce durst in hym vncouple
¶ Seneka his mayster was of whyche I dyuyse
By cause nero had of hym suche drede
For he for his vyces wolde hym chastyse
Dyscretly as by worde and not by dede
Syre he wolde saye an emperour must nede
Be vertuous and hate tyrannye
For whyche he made hym in a bath to blede
On bothe his armys tyll he must dye
¶ This nero had eke of a custumaunce
In youth ayenst his mayster to ryse
Whyche afterwarde hym thought a grete greuaunce
By cause he ofte wolde hym chastyse
Therfore he made hym deye in this wyse
To chese in a bath to deye in this manere
Rather than to haue a nother tormentyse
And thus hath nero slayn his mayster dere
Now fell it so that fortune lyst no lenger
The hyghe pryde of nero to cherysshe
For though he were strong yet was she stronger
She thought thus by god I am to nyce
To sette a man þᵗat is fnlfylled of vyce
In hye degree ⁊and an emperour hym calle
By god out of his sete I woll hym tryce
Whan he leest wenyth sonest shall he falle
¶ The peple rose vpon hym on a nyght
For his defawte ⁊and whan he it aspyed
Out of his dores anon he hath him dyght
Alone and there he wende haue be alyed
He knockyd fast ⁊and ay the more he cryed
The faster shytte they the dorys alle
Tho wyst he well he had hymself begyled
And went his way no lenger durst he calle
The peple cryed ⁊and rombelyd vp ⁊and doun
That wyth his erys he herd how þᵗat they sayde
Where is this fals tyraunt this neron
For fere ful nere out of his wytte he breyde
And to his goddis pyteusly he prayde
For socour but it myght not betyde
For drede of this hym thought þᵗat he deyde
And ran in to a gardyn hym to hyde
And in this gardynfonde he churlys tweye
And syttynge by a fyre grete ⁊and reed
And to the churles two he gan to preye
To slee hym and to gyrde of his heed
That to his body whan he were deed
Were no despyte done for his dyffame
Hymself he slough he cowde no better rede
Of whyche fortune lough ⁊and had game
WAs neuer capteyn vnder a kyng
That regnes mo put in subieccyon
Nestrenger was in felde of all thynge
As in his tyme ne gretter of renoun
Ne more pompous in hyghe presumpcyon
Then olopherne whyche fortune ay kyste
So lycorously lad hym vp and doun
Tyll that he ded was or that he wyst
Not only that this worlde had of hym awe
For lesynge of ryches and lyberte
But he made euery man renye his lawe
Nabugodonosor was lorde sayd he
None other god sholde honouryd be
Ayenst his heest there dare no wyght trespas
Saue in bethulia a stronge cyte
Where eliachim was preest of that place
But take kepe of the deth of olophern
Amyd his hoost he dronke laye all nyght
Wythin his tent large as is a bern
And yet for all his pompe ⁊and all his myght
Iudyth a woman as he laye vpryght
Slepynge his heed of smote ⁊and fro his tente
Full pryuely she stale from euery wyght
And wyth his hed vnto her towne she wente
What nedyth it of kynge antiocus
To tell his hygh ⁊and ryall mageste
His hyghe pryde his werke venemus
For suche a nother man nas neuer as he
Redyth what that he was in machabe
And redyth the proude werkys that he sayd
And why he fyll from his prosperite
And in an hylle how wretchidly he deyde
Fortune hym had enhaunsyd so in pryde
That verily he wende he myght atteyne
Vnto the sterrys vpon euery syde
And in a balaunce to weye eche mounteyne
And all the flodys of the se restreyne
And goddys peple had he moost in hate
Hem wolde he slee in torment and in peyn
Wenynge þᵗat god ne myght his pryde abate
And for þᵗat nychamore and Thymothe
Whyche Iewes were vencusyd myghtly
Vnto the Iewes suche an hate had he
That he had greythid his chare full hastily
And swore ⁊and sayd full dispytously
Vnto Iherusalem he wolde eftsone
To wreke his yre on it full cruelly
But of his purpoos was he let full sone
God for his manace hym sore smote
Wyth Inuysible wounde ay Incurable
That in his guttes carf so and bote
That his peynes were Importaale
And certenly the wretche was resonable
For many a mannys guttys dyde he peyne
But from his purpoos cursyd and dampnable
For all his smert he nolde hym restreyne
But bad anon pareylle his hoost
And sodenly or he thenne was waar
God dauntid all his pryde ⁊and all his boost
For he so sorefell out of his chare
That all his lymes ⁊and his skyn to tare
So that he ne myght goo ne ryde
But in a chayr men about hym bare
All forbrusyd both bak and syde
The wreche of god hym smote so cruelly
That in his body wycked wormes crept
And therwyth all he stanke so horribly
That none of all his meyny that hym kept
Whether that he woke or ellys slept
Ne myght not of hym the stynke endure
And in this myscheyf he waylled ⁊and eke wept
And knewe god lorde of euery creature
To all his hoost and to hymself also
Full lothsom was the stynke of his careyn
No man myght hym bere to ne fro
And in his stynke ⁊and in his horryble payn
He sterf full wretchydly on a mountayn
Thus hath this robber ⁊and this homicide
That many a man made to wepe ⁊and playn
Suche guerdon as belongyth vnto pryde
THe story of alisaundre is so comune
That euery wight that hath discrecōion
Hath herde somwhat or all of his fortune
This wyde worlde as in conclusyon
He wan by strengthe and his renoun
They were glad for peas vnto hym sende
The pryde of man ⁊and boste layd a doun
Where so he came in to the worldis ende
Comparyson myght yet neuer be maked
Betwyx hym and a nother conquerour
For al this worlde for drede of hy hath quaked
He was of knyghthod ⁊and of fredom flour
Fortune hym made the heyre of hygh honour
Saue wyn ⁊and wymen no thyng might aswage
His hyghe entent in armys and labour
So was he full of louynge corage
¶ What pryde were it to hy though I you told
Of darius ⁊and of an hundryd thousande mo
Of prynces erlys and kyngis bolde
Whyche he conqueryd and brought to wo
I say as fer as a man may ryde or go
The world was his what sholde I more deuise
For though I wrote ⁊and tolde you euer mo
Of his knyghthode it myght not suffyse
¶ xij . yere he regned as I rede in machabe
Philippis sone of macedone he was
That fyrst was kynge of grece that countre
O worthy gentyll alisaunder alas
That euer sholde the falle suche a cas
Empoysonyd of thy folke thou were
Thy syce fortune hath torned in to an ace
And yet for the ne wept she neuer a tere
Who shall yeue men terys to compleyne
Of deth of gentylnes and of fraunchyse
That all the worlde weldyd in his demeyn
And yet hym thought it myght not suffyse
So full was his corage of hyghe empryse
Alas who shall me helpe to endyte
Fals fortune ⁊and poyson to dispyse
The whyche of all this wo I wyte
BY wysdom manhod and hyghe labour
From humble bedde to ryall mageste
Vp roos he Iulius the conquerour
That all the occident by londe and see
By strengthe of honde or ellys by trete
And vnto rome made hem tributary
And syth of rome emperour was he
Tyll that fortune wext his aduersary
O myghty cesar that in thessaly
Ayenst Pompeius fader thyn in lawe
That of the oryent haddest the chyualry
As fer as that the day begynnyth to dawe
Them thrugh knyghthode hast take ⁊and slawe
Saue fewe folke that wyth pompeius fledde
Thrugh whyche þᵘ puttest all þᵉ orient in awe
Thanke fortune that so well the spedde
¶ But now a lytyll wyle I woll bewayll
This pompeius this noble gouernour
Of rome whyche that fledde at this batayll
I saye one of his men a fals traytour
His hed ofsmote to wynne hym fauour
Of Iulius and to hym the heed broughte
Alas pompeie of the orient conquerour
That fortuue vnto suche a fyne the broughte
¶ To rome agayn repeyreth Iulius
Wyth his triumphe laureat full hye
But on a tyme brutus cassius
That euer had of hye estate enuye
Full pryuely had made conspyrecye
Ayenst this Iulius in subtyll wyse
And cast the place in whyche he sholde deye
Wyth bodkyns as I shall you deuyse
¶ This Iulius vnto the capitoly went
Vp an a daye as he was wont to goon
And in the capitoly anon hym hent
This fals brutus and his other foon
And stickyd hym wyth bodkyns anon
Wyth many a wounde ⁊and thus they lete hy lye
But neuer gruntyd he at no stroke but oon
Or ellys at two but yf his story lye
So manly was this Iulius of herte
And so well loued estatly honeste
That though his dedly woundis so sore smert
His mantell ouer his hippes cast he
For no man sholde se his preuyte
And as he laye in deyenge on a traunce
And wyst verily that deye he sholde
Of honeste yet had he remembrauuce
¶ Lucan to the this story I recōmmende
And to sueton and to valeri also
That of this story wryten worde and ende
How that thyse conquerours two
Fortune was fyrste a frende ⁊and sythen a foo
No man trust vp on her fauour longe
But haue her in a wayte for euer moo
Wytnes on all the conquerours stronge
THe ryche cresus whylom kynge of lyde
Of whyche cresus cirus sore hym drad
Yet was he caughtamydde all his pryde
And to brenne men to the fyre hym lad
But suche a reyn doun fro þᵉ firmament shad
That queynt the fyre and made hym to scape
But to beware yet no grace he had
Tyll fortune on the galowes made hym gape
Whan he escapid was he cowde not stynt
For to begyn a newe araye agayn
He wende well for that fortune hym sent
Suche hap that he escapyd thrugh the rayn
That of his foes he myght not be slayn
And eke a sweuen vpon a nyght he mette
Of whyche he was so prowde ⁊and eke so fayn
That in vengaunce he all his herte sette
¶ Vpon a tree he was as hym thought
There Iubiter hym wyssh both back ⁊and syde
And phebus eke a fayr to well hym brought
To drye hym wyth ⁊and therwyth wext his pride
And to his donghter that stode hym besyde
Whyche þᵗat he knewe in hye sentence habounde
He bad her telle what it signyfied
And she his dreme ryght thus expowned
¶ The tree quod she the galous is to mene
And Iupiter betokenyth snowe and rayn
And phebus wyth his to well so clene
Betokenyth the sonne bemys soth to sayn
Thou shalt hangid be fader certayn
Rayn shall the wasshe ⁊and sonne shall the drye
Thus she warnyd hym full plat ⁊and full playn
His doughter that callyd was phanye
And hangid was cresus the prowde kynge
His ryall trone myght hym not auaylle
Tragedies none other maner thynges
Ne can in syngyng crye ne bewaylle
But for that fortune alday woll assaylle
Wyth vnwar stroke the regnes that ben proude
For whan men trusteth her then wol she fayll
And couere her bryght face wyth a clowde
O Noble o worthy petro glorye of spayn
Whom fortune helde so hyghe in mageste
Well ought men thy pytous deth complayne
Out of thy londe thy brother made the fle
And after at a syge by subtylte
Thou were betrayed and lad vnto his tente
Where as he wyth his owne honde slow the
Succedynge in thy regne ⁊and in thy rente
¶ The felde of snow wᵗith thegle of blake therin
Caught with the lymrod colouryd al wᵗith glede
He brewe this cursydnesse ⁊and all this synne
The wyckyd neest was werker of this nede
Nought charles olyuer that toke aye hede
Of trouth ⁊and honour but of armorik
Genilon oliuer corrupt for mede
Brought this worthy kynge in suche a brike
¶ O worthy petro kynge of cypre also
That alisandre wan by hyghe maystrye
Full many a hethen wroughtest þᵘ full wo
Of whyche thyn owne lyges hadde enuye
And for no thyng but for thy chyualrye
They in thy bed han slayn the by the morowe
Thus can fortune her whele gouerue ⁊and gye
And out of Ioye brynge man to sorowe
¶ Of melan grete barnabo vicounte
God of delyte ⁊and scourge of lumbardye
Why sholde I not thyn Infortune accounte
Syn in astate thou clomben were so hye
Thy brother sone that was thy dowble alye
For he thy neuewe was ⁊and sone in lawe
Wythin his pryson made the to dye
But whi ne how noot I not þᵗat thou wer slawe
¶ Of the erle hugelyn of pyȝe the langour
Ther may no tonge telle for pyte
But lytyll out of pyȝe stont a tour
In whyche tour in pryson put was he
And wyth hym ben his lytyll chyldren thre
The eldest scarsly fyue yere was of age
Alas fortune it was grete cruelte
Suche byrdes for to put in suche a cage
Dampned was he to deye in that pryson
For roger whyche bysshop was of pyȝe
Had on hym made a fals suggestion
Thrugh the peple gan vpon hym ryse
And put hym in pryson in suche a wyse
As ye haue herde and mete ⁊and drynke he had
So smal that vnethe it may suffyse
And therwyth all it was full poore and bad
And on a day befell that in that hour
Whan that his mete wont was to be brought
The geylour shytte the dores of the tour
He herde it well but he spake ryght nought
And in his herte anone there fyll a thought
That they for hungre wolde doo hym dyen
Alas quod he alas that I was wroughte
Therwyth the terys fylle fro his eyen
¶ His yonge sone þᵗat thre yere was of age
Vnto hym sayd fader fader why do ye wepe
Whan woll the geylour brynge our potage
Is there no morsell brede that ye do kepe
I am so hungry that I maye not slepe
Now wolde god that I myght slepe euer
Thenne shold not hungre in my wombe crepe
Ther nys no thyng but brede þᵗat me were leuere
¶ Thus day by day this chylde began to crye
Tyll in his faders arme adowne it laye
And sayd fare well fader I must dye
And kyste his fader and deyed the same day
And whan the wofull fader ded it say
For wo his armys two he gan to byte
And sayd alas fortune and welawaye
Thy false whele my wo all may it wyte
His chyldren wende that it for hungre was
That he his armys gnewe and not for wo
div.fw: The prologe of the nonnes prest
div.l: And sayd fader do not so alas
But rather ete the flesshe vpon vs two
Our flessh thou yaue vs take our flessh vs fro
And ete ynough ryght thus they to hym sayde
And after that wythin a day or two
They layed hem in his lappe adowne ⁊and deyde
Hymself dispeyred eke for hungre starf
Thus ended is this myghty erle of pyȝe
From hyghe astate fortune awaye fro hy carf
Of this tragedie it ought ynough suffyse
Who so woll here it in a longer wyse
Redyth the grete poete of ytaille
That hyght dant for he can it all deuyse
Fro poynt to poynt not o worde woll he faylle
HOo qd þᵉ knyght gode syr nomor of this
That ye haue sayd is ryȝt ynouh ywys
And moche more for lytyll heuynesse
Is ryght ynough to moche folke I gesse
Your tales doon vs no dysporte ne game
Therfor syr monk o dan pyers by your name
I praye you hertly telle vs somwhat elles
For sykerly nere clynkynge of your belles
That on your brydyll hange on euery syde
By heuen kynge that for vs al dyed
I sholde er this han fall downe for slepe
All though the slough had neuer be so depe
Then had your tale al be tolde in veyn
For certaynly as that thyse clerkes seyn
Where as a man maye haue none audyence
Nought helpyth it to telle his sentence
And well I wote the substaunce is in me
Yf ony thynge shall well reportyd be
Syr saye somwhat of huntyng I you preye
Nay quod this monke I haue no lust to playe
Now lat a nother telle as I haue tolde
Then spak our host wyth rude speche ⁊and bold
And sayd vnto the nonnys preest anon
Com nere thou preest come nere thou syr Iohn
Tell vs suche thyng as may our hertes glade
Be blythe though thou ryde vpon a Iade
What though thy hors be both foul and lene
Yf he woll serue the recke not a bene
Loke that thyn herte be mery euer mo
¶ Yes syr quod he yes host so mote I go
But I be mery ywys I woll be blamyd
And ryght anone his tale he hath atamyd
And thus he sayd vnto vs euerychon
This swete preest this goodly man syr Iohn

Her endyth the prologe of the
nonnys preest

body.fw: The tale of the nonnys prest

div.l: Here begynneht the nonnys preest tale
A Poore wydow som dele y stept in age
Was somtyme dwellyng in a pore cotage
Besyde a groue stondyng in a dale
This wydow of whyche I telle you my tale
Syn that day þᵗat she was last a wyf
In pacyence ledde a full symple lyf
For lytyll was her catell ⁊and her rent
By husbondry of suche as god her sent
She fonde herself ⁊and eke her doughters two
Thre large sowys had she and nomo
Thre kyne ⁊and eke a shepe that hyght malle
Well soty was her bour ⁊and eke her halle
In whyche she ete many a slender meel
Of poynaunt sauce ne knewe she neuer a deel
Ne deynte morcell passid thrugh her throte
Her dyet was accordaunt to her cote
Repleccyon ne made her neuer syke
A temperat dyet was her phisyke
And excercyse ⁊and hertis suffysaunce
The gowte let her no thynge for to daunce
Ne apoplexie shent not her heed
No wyne ne darnke she whyte ne reed
Her borde was most serued wyth whyt ⁊and blak
Mylk ⁊and broun bred in whiche she fonde no lak
Seynde bakon ⁊and somtyme an eye or tweye
For she was as it were a manere deye
¶ A yerde she had enclosyd all abowte
Wyth styckes and drye dyched wythout
In whyche she had a cok hyght chauntecleer
In all the londe of crowynge nas his peer
His voys was merier than the mery orgon
On masse dayes that in the chyrches goon
Well sykerer was his crowynge in his loge
Than is a cloke or in ony abbey an orloge
By nature he crewe eche assencōion
Of the equinoccion in the toun
For whan degrees . xv . were ascendid
Then crewe he that it myght not be amendyd
His combe was redder than the fyn corall
And batellyd as it had be a castell wall
His byll was blak as ony gete it shoon
Lyke assure were his legges ⁊and his toon
His naylles whytter than the lely flour
And lyke the burnyd golde was his colour
¶ This gentyll cock had in his gouernaunce
Seuen hennys to do all his plesaunce
Whyche were his systers ⁊and his paramours
And wonder lyke to hym as of colours
Of whyche the fayrist hewyd in the throte
Was callyd fayr damoysell pertelote
He fetheryd her an hundryd tymes a daye
And she hym plesyth all that euer she maye
Curteys she was discrete and debonayr
And compenable and bare herself so fayr
