And whan the foxe sawe þᵗat he was gon
¶ Alas quod he o chauntecleer alas
I haue quod he do to you trespas
In as moche as I made you aferde
Whan I you hente ⁊and broughte out of your yerde
But syr I dyd it not in no wyckid entent
Come downe ⁊and I shall tell you what I ment
I shall you saye soth so god helpe me so
¶ Nay then qd he I shrewe vs both two
And fyrst I shrewe myself both blood ⁊and bonys
Yf you begyle me ofter than onys
Thou shalt nomore wyth thy flaterye
Do me synge wyth a wynkynge eye
For he that wynkith whan he sholde see
All wylfully god lete hym neuer thee
¶ Nay qd the fox but god yeue hym myschaıı̄unce
That is so Indiscrete of gouernaunce
That Iangelyth whan þᵗat he sholde haue pees
¶ Lo suche it is for to be retchelees
And neclygent ⁊and truste on flaterie
But ye that holde this tale a lye
As of a foxe and a cok ⁊and an hen
Takyth the moralyte good men
For saynt poul sayth all the wryten is
To our doctryne it is wryten ywys
Takyth the fruyt ⁊and lete the chaf be stylle
Now good god yf that it be thy wylle
As sayth my lorde so make vs all good men
And brynge vs to thy hyghe blysse amen

l.hi: Here endyth the tale of the nonnys preest .

div.l:
Here folowyth the prolo
ge of the maunciple .
SYr nonnys preest oure hoste sayd anon
Y blessyd be thy breche ⁊and euery stoon
This was a mery tale of chauntecleer
But by my trouth yf thou were seculer
Thou woldest be a tredefoul a ryght
For yf þᵘ haue corage ad thou hast myght
The were nede of hennys as I wene
Ye more than seuen tymes seuentene
See whyche brawnes hath this gentyll preest
So grete a necke ⁊and suche a large breest
He lokyth as a sperhawke wyth his eyen
Hym nedyth not his colours for to dyen
Wyth brasyll ne wyth grayu of portyngale
But syr fayr falle you for yourtale
And after that he wyth full mery chere
Sayd to a nother as ye shall here
Wote ye not where stondyth a lytyll towne
Whyche that is a called bob vp ⁊and downe
Vnder the blee in caunterbery waye
There gan our hoste to Iape and to pley
And sayd syres what dun is in the myre
Is there no man for prayer ne for hyre
That woll awake our felowe behynde
A theyf myght hym ful lyghtly robbe ⁊and bynde
Se how he nappyth se for cockys bonys
How he woll falle from his hors attonys
Is that a coke of london wyth myschaunce
Do hym comfort he knowyth his penaunce
For he shall telle a tale by my fey
All though it be not worth a botell of hey
Awake thou coke quod he god yeue the sorowe
What eylleth the to slepe by the morowe
Hast þᵘ had fleyn all nyght or art thou dronke
Or hast þᵘ all nyght wyth som queyn y swonke
So that thou mayst not holde vp thy hed
¶ This coke þᵗat was full pale ⁊and no thynge red
Sayd our hoste so god my soule blesse
There is falle on me grete heuynesse
Not I nat why me were leue to slepe
Than the beste galon of wyne in chepe
¶ Well quod the manciple yf it may do ese
To the syr coke and to no wyght displese
Whyche that here ryde in this companye
And that our hoste wyll of his curtesye
I woll as now excuse the of thy tale
For in good fayth thy vysage is full pale
Thyn eyen dase sothely as me thynketh
And well I wote thy breth full sore stynkith
That sheweth well þᵘ art not well dysposyd
Of me certayn thou shalt not be glosyd
Se how he galpyth lo this dronken wyght
As though he wolde vs swolow anon ryght
Holde cloos thy mouth by thy fader kyn
The deuyll of helle sette his fote therin
Thy cursyd breth wyll enfect vs all
Fy stynkyng swyn / fy fowle myght the befall
Takyth hede syres of this lusty man
Now swete syr woll ye Iust atte van
Therto me thynketh ye be well shape
I trowe that ye haue dronken wyn ape
And that is whan men playe at strawe
¶ And with his speche þᵉ coke wexid al wrawe
And on the maıı̄unciple he gan to nodde faste
For lacke of speche adowne the hors hy caste
Where as he lay tyll that men hym vp toke
This was a fayr cheuesaunce of a coke
Alas þᵗat he ne had holde hym by his ladyll
And er that he ayen were in the sadyll
Ther was a grete shouynge both to ⁊and fro
To lyft hym vp and moche care ⁊and wo
So vnweldy was this sely pallyd ghost
And to the maunciple then spake our hoost
¶ By cause that drynke hath domynacyon
Vpon this man by my sauacyon
I trowe lewdely woll he telle his tale
For were it wyne or olde moysti ale
That he hath dronke he spekith so in his nose
And fnesyth fast and eke hath the pose
He also hath to do more than ynough
To kepe hym on his capyll out of the slough
And yf he fall from his capyll eft sone
Then shull we all haue ynough to done
In lyftyng vp his dronken corps
Tell on thy tale of hym make I no fors
¶ But yet maunciple in fayth þᵘ art to nyce
Thus openly to repreue hym of his vyce
A nother day he woll parauenture
Recleyme the and brynge the to lure
I mene he speke woll of smale thynges
And for to pynche at thy rekenynges
That were not honest yf it cam to the preyf
¶ No quod the maıı̄unciple þᵗat were a grete myscheyf
So myght he brynge me in to the snare
Yet had I leuer paye for the mare
Which he rydeth on than he sholde wᵗith me stryue
I woll not wrath hym so mote I thryue
That I spake I sayd it but in bourde
And wote ye what I haue here in my gourde
A draught of wyne ye of a rype grape
And ryght anon ye shull se a good Iape
This coke shall drynke therof yf I maye
Vp payne of my lyf he woll not say nay
And certenly to telle as it was
Of this vessell the coke dranke fast alas
What nedyth it he dranke ynough beforn
And whan he had poupyd in his horn
To the maunciple he toke the gourde agayn
And of the drynke the coke was ful fayn
And thankyd hym in suche wyse as he cowde
¶ Then gan our host to laugh wonder lowde
And sayd I se well it is necessary
Where þᵗat we gon good drynke wyth vs to cary
For that woll torne rancour and disese
To acorde ⁊and loue and many a worde to pese
¶ O bacus I blessyd be thy holy uame
That so canst torne ernest in to game
Worshyp and thanke be to thy deyte
Of that matere ye gete nomore of me
Tell on thy tale þᵘ maunciple I the preye
Well syr quod he herkenyth What I sey
Here endyth the maunciples prologe
And here begynneth the maunciples tale
WHan phebus dwellyd here in erthe adoun
As olde bokys make mencyon
He was the moost lusty bacheler
Of all the worlde and eke the best archer
He slough pheton the serpent as he lay
Slepynge ayenst the sonne vpon a day
And many a nother noble worthy dede
He wyth his bowe wrought as men mowe rede
Playe he cowde on euery mynstralcye
And synge that it was a melodye
To here of his clere voys the soun
Certes the kynge of thebes amphion
That wyth his songe wallyd the cyte
Cowde neuer synge half so well as he
Therto he was the semelyst man
That is or was syth the worlde began
What nedyth it his feture to discryue
For in this world nas ther non so fayr a lyue
He was therwyth fulfylled of gentylnesse
Of honour and of perfyght worthynesse
This phebus that was flour of bachelerye
As well in fredom as in chyualrye
For his disport in sygne eke of vyctorye
Of pheton so as tellyth vs the story
Was wont to bere in his honde a bowe
Now had this phebus in his hous a crowe
Wythin a cage y frostryd many a day
And taught it speche as men teche a Iaye
Whyt was this crow as is a snow whyt swan
And countrefetid the speche of euery man
He cowde whan he sholde telle a tale
There was in al this world non nyghtyngale
Ne cowde be an hundred thousande deell
Synge so wonderly mery and well
Now had this phebus in his hous a wyf
Whyche that he louyd more than his lyf
And nyght ⁊and day dyd euer his dilygence
Her for to plese and do her reuerence
Saue only yf the soth yf I shall sayn
Ielous he was ⁊and wolde haue kept her fayn
For hym were loth Iapyd for to be
And so is euery wyght in suche degre
But all for nought for it auaylled nought
A good wyf þᵗat is clene of werke and thought
Sholde not be kept in non awayte certeyn
And truely the labour is in veyn
To kepe a shrewe for it woll not be
This holde I for a very nycete
To spylle labour for to kepe wyuys
Thus wryten olde clerkis in her lyues
But now to purpos as I fyrst began
This worthy phebus doth all that he can
To plese her wenynge thrugh suche plesaıı̄unce
And for his manhode ⁊and for his gouernaunce
That no man sholde put hym from her grace
But god it wote there may no man enbrace
As to distreyne a thynge whyche þᵗat nature
Hath naturelly set in a creature
Take ony byrde ⁊and put hym in a cage
And do all thyn entent ⁊and thy corage
To fostre it tenderly wyth mete ⁊and drynke
Of all deyntees that thou canst bethynke
And kepe it also clenly as thou may
All though his cage of golde be neuer so gay
Yet hath this byrde by twenty thousand folde
Leuer in a forest that is wyde and colde
Go ete wormys and suche wretchydnesse
For euer this byrde wyll do his besynesse
To escape out of his cage when he may
His lyberte the byrde desyreth ay
Let take a cat ⁊and fostre her wyth mylke
And tender flessh ⁊and make her couche of sylke
And let her se a mous go by the walle
Anon she weyueth flessh ⁊and couche and alle
And euery deynte that is in that hous
Suche appetyte hath she to ete the mous
Lo here hath lust his domynacyon
And appetyt flemyth dyscrecyon
A she wulf hath also a vylens kynde
The lewdest wulf þᵗat she maye fynde
Or leest of reputacyon that woll she take
In tyme whan her lust to haue a make
All thyse ensamples speke I by thyse men
That ben vntreue ⁊and no thynge by wymen
For men haue euer a lycorous appetyt
On lower thynge to perfourme her delyt
Than on her wyues be they neuer so fayr
Ne neuer so true ne so debonayr
Flessh is so newfangyll wyth myschaunce
That we ne conne in no thynge haue plesaıı̄unce
That sownyth vnto vertu ony whyle
¶ Thus phebus whyche thought no gyle
Disceyued was for all his Iolyte
For vnder hym a nother had she
A man of lytyll reputacyon
Not worth to phebus in comparyson
The more harme is it happeth oft so
Of whyche there comyth muche harme ⁊and wo
And so befell whan phebus was absent
His wyf anon hath for her lemman sent
Her lemman certes þᵗat is a knauyssh speche
Foryeue it me ⁊and that I you beseche
¶ The wyse plato sayth as ye mow rede
The worde must nede acorde wyth the dede
Yf men sholde telle properly a thynge
The worde must cosyn be to the werkynge
I am a boystous man ryght thus saye I
There is but lytyll dyfference trewely
Betwyx a wyf that is of hye degre
Yf of her body dyshonest she be
And a pore wenche other than this
Yf it so be they werke both amys
But þᵗat the gentyll is in state aboue
She shall be callyd his lady ⁊and his loue
And for that other is a poore woman
She shall be callyd his wenche or his lemman
And god it wote myn owne dere brother
Men laye as lowe that one as that other
Ryght so betwyx a titelees tyraunt
And an outlawe or a theyf erraunt
The same I saye there is no dyfference
To alisaunder was tolde this sentence
That for the tyraunt is of gretter myght
By force of meyne to slee downe right
And brenne hous ⁊and home ⁊and make all pleyn
Lo therfore is he callyd a capteyn
And for the outlawe hath but small meyne
And may not do so grete an harme as he
Ne brynge a countree to so grete myscheyf
Men calle hym an outlawe or a theyf
¶ But for I am a man not texuell
I woll not telle of textis neuer a deell
I woll go to my tale as I began
¶ Whan phebus wyf had sent for her lēmman
Anon they wroughte all ther lust volage
This whyte crowe that hynge ay in the cage
Beheld ther werke ⁊and sayd neuer a worde
¶ And whan hom was com phebus the lorde
This crowe songe cuckow cuckow cuckow
¶ What byrde quod phebus what syngest thow
Ne were thou not wont so meryly to synge
That to my herte it was a reioysynge
To here this voys alas what songe is this
¶ By god quod he I synge not amys
Phebus quod he for all thy worthynes
For all thy bewte and thy gentylnes
For all thy songe ⁊and thy mynstralsye
For all thy waytyng blerid is thyn eye
Wyth one of lytyll reputacyon
Not worth to the in comparyson
The mountaunce of a gnat so mote I thryue
For on thy bed thy wyf I sawe hym swyue
What woll ye more þᵉ crowe anon hym tolde
By sad tokenys ⁊and by wordes bolde
How that his wyf had don her lechery
Hym to grete shame ⁊and to grete vylonye
And tolde hy efte he sawe it wyth his eyen
¶ This pheb̉e gan away warde for to pryen
Hym thought his wofull herte brast a two
His bowe he bent ⁊and set therin a flo
And in his yre he hath his wyf slayn
This is the effect there is nomore to sayn
For sorowe wherof he brake his mynstralsye
Bothe harpe ⁊and lute geterue ⁊and sawtrye
And eke he brake his arowes ⁊and his bowe
And after þᵗat thus spake he to the crowe
¶ Traytour quod he wᵗith tonge of scorpyon
Thu hast me brought to my confusyon
Alas that I was wrought why nere I deed
O dere wyf o gemme o lustyheed
That were to me so sad ⁊and eke so trewe
Now lyest thou ded wyth face pale of hewe
Full gyltlees that durst I swere I wys
O rakyll honde to do so fowle amys
O trowbyld wyt o yre retcheles
That vnauysed synnest gyltles
O wantrust full of fals suspecyon
Where was thy wyt and thy dyscrecyon
O euery man beware of rekylnes
Nt trowe no thynge wythout stronge wytnes
Smyte not to sone or thou wyt why
And be auysed well and sykerly
Or ye do ony execusyon
Vpon your yre for suspecyon
Alas a thousande folke haue rekyll yre
Fully fordoon ⁊and brought hem in the myre
Alas for sorowe I woll myself slee
And to the crowe a fals theyf sayd he
I woll quyte anon thy fals tale
Thou songe whylom lyke a nyghtyngale
Now shalt thou fals theyf thy songe forgoon
Eke thy whyte fetherys euerychon
Ne neuer in all thy lyf shalt thou speke
Thus shull men on a traytour be a wrecke
Thou ⁊and thyn ofspryng euer shall be blake
Ne neuer swete noyse shall ye make
But euer crye ayenst tempest and reyn
In token that thrugh the my wyf is slayn
And to the crowe he stert and that anon
And pullyd of his whyte fetheris euerychon
And made hym blak ⁊and refte hym all his songe
And eke his speche ⁊and out at dore hym slonge
Vnto the deuyll whyche I hym betake
And for this caas ben all crowes blake
¶ Lordynges by this ensāmple I woll you pray
Beware and take kepe what I saye
Ne tellyth neuer no man in your lyf
How þᵗat a nother man hath dyght his wyf
He woll you hate mortally certeyn
Dan salomon as wyse clerkys sayn
Techeth a man to kepe his tonge well
But as I sayd I am not textuell
But netheles thus taught me my dame
My sonne thynke on þᵉ crowe a goddys name
My sone kepe wel thy tonge ⁊and kepe thy frende
A wyckyd tonge is worse than a fende
My sone from a fende men may hem blesse
My sone god of his endles goodnesse
wallyd a tonge wyth teeth ⁊and lyppes eke
For man sholde hym auyse what he speke
My sone full oft for to moche speche
Hath many a man be spylt as clerkys teche
But for lytyll speche spoken auysedly
Is no man shent to speke generally
My sone thy tongue sholdest thou restreyne
At all tyme but whan þᵘ dost thy peyne
To speke of god in houour and prayere
The fyrst vertue sone yf thou wolt lere
Is to restreyne and kepe wel thy tonge
Thus lerne chyldren whan they be yonge
My sone of moche spekynge vnauysed
There lasse spekyng had ynough suffysed
Comyth moche harme thus was metaught
In moche speche synne wantyth naught
Wost thou wherfore a rakyll tonge seruyth
Ryght as a swerde forkyttyth and forkeruyth
An arme or two my dere sone ryght so
A tonge kytteth frendshyp all a two
A Iangeler is to god abhomynable
Rede salomon so wyse and honourable
Rede dauid ⁊and his psalmes rede senek
My sone speke not ne wᵗith thy heed thou beke
Dyssymyll as thou were deef yf þᵗat thou here
The Iangelour spekyth of perlous matere
¶ The flemynge sayth lerne yf þᵗat thou lest
That lytyll Iangelyng causyth moche rest
My sone yf thou no wyckyd worde hast sayd
The dare not drede for to be wrayd
But he þᵗat hath myssayd I dare well sayn
He may by no way clepe his worde agayn
Thynge þᵗat is sayd / is sayd ⁊and forth it goth
Though hym repent or him be neuer so loth
He is thrall to hym to whom he hath sayd
A tale for whyche he is now euyll apayd
My sone beware ⁊and be non auctor newe
Of tidynges whether they be fals or trewe
Where so thou come amonge hye or lowe
Kepe well thy tonge ⁊and thynke on the crowe
Here endyth the maunciples tale .

And folowyth the personys pro-
louge .
BY þᵗat the maunciple had his tale endyd
The sonne fro þᵉ south syde is descended
So lowe that it was not to my syght
Degrees of fyue ⁊and twenti on heyght
Ten at clocke it was so as I gesse
For enleuen fote a lytyll more or lesse
My shadow was at that tyme as there
Of suche fete as my lengthe partyd were
In . vi . feet equally of proporcyon
Therwyth the monys exaltacyon
I mene libra alwaye gan ascende
As we were entrynge at the thorpis ende
For whyche our hoste as he was wont to gye
Ayin this caas this Ioly companye
Sayd in this wyse lordynges euerychon
Now lackyth vs tale nomore than on
Fulfylled is my sentence and my decre
Who woll now telle a tale let see
Almost fulfylled is myn ordynaunce
I pray to god so yeue hy ryght good chaunce
That tellyth this tale to vs lustily
Syr preest quod he art thou a vycary
Or art thou a parson say soth by thy fey
Be what þᵘ be breke thou not our pley
For euery man saue thou hath tolde his tale
Vnbokyll ⁊and shewe vs what is in thy male
For truely me thynkyth by thy chere
Thou sholdest knyt vp well a grete matere
Telle vs a fable anon for cockys bonys
¶ This parson hym answerde all attonys
Thou getyst fable non tolde for me
For poul that wryteth to thimothe
Repreueth them that wayuen sothfastnesse
And teche fables and suche wretchydnesse
Why sholde I sowe draf out of my fyst
Whan I maye sowe whete yf that me lyst
For whyche I saye yf that ye lyst to here
Moralyte and of vertuous matere
And thenne yf ye woll yeue me audyence
I wolde full fayn at cristis reuerence
Done you plesaunce lefull as I can
But trustyth well I am a sotheryn man
I can not geste rum ram ruf by letter
And god wote rym holde I but lytyll b ette
And therfore yf ye lust I woll not glose
I wol l you telle a lytyll tale in prose
To knyt vp all this feest ⁊and make an ende
And Ihesu for his grace wyt me sende
To shewe the waye in this vyage
Of thylke perfyght gloryous pilgrimage
That hyght Iherusalem celestiall
And yf ye vouchesauf anon I shall
Begynne vpon my tale for whyche I preye
Tell your aduys I can no better seye
But netheles this medytacyon
I put it ay vnder correccyon
Of clerkys for I am not textuell
I take but the sentence trusteth well
Therfore I make protestacyon
That I woll stonde to coreccyon
¶ Vpon this worde we haue assentyd sone
For as it semyd it was for to done
To ende in some vertuous sentence
And for to yeue hym space and audyence
And bad our hoost he sholde to hym saye
That all we to telle his tale hym praye
¶ Our hoost had the wordes for vs alle
Syr prest quod he now fayr moot you befalle
Sayth what ye lyste and we shall gladly here
And wyth þᵗat worde he sayd in this manere
Tellyth quod he your medytacyon
But hastyth you the sonne woll a doun
Beth fructuous and that in lytyll space
And to do well god sende you his grace

div.ab: Here begynneth the parsons tale

Ier . vj . State super vias
⁊and videte ⁊and interogate de semi-
tis antiquis . que sit via bona
et ambulate in ea . et inuenie-
tis refrigeriıı̄un animabus vestris .

OVr swete lord god of heuene . that
no man woll peryssh / but woll þᵗat
we torne all to the knowlege of hym . ⁊and
to the blysfull lyfe that is perdurable /

amonestith vs by the prophete Ieremye
þᵗat sayth in this wyse

Standyth vpon
the wayes ⁊and seeth . and axeth of olde pa-
thes / that is to saye / of olde sentences
whyche is the god waye .

⁊and walkyth in
that waye / ⁊and ye shall fynde refresshyng
for your soules /⁊and c

¶ Many ben þᵉ way-
es espyrytueles that lede folk to our lor-
de Iesu crist . ⁊and to the regne of glory .

Of
whyche wayes ther is a full noble way
⁊and a full couenable / whyche maye not
faylle to man ne to womman that thurȝ
synne hath mysgoon fro the ryght way
of Ierusalem celestiall /

And this waye
is clallid Penitence . of whiche man shol-
de gladly herke ⁊and enquyre wyth all his
herte .

to wyte what is Penitence . ⁊and whi
it is callyd Penitence / And how many
maneres ben of accyons / or werkynges
of penitence .

And how many specis the-
re ben of penitence . and whyche thynges
apperteyne ⁊and behoue to penitence . And
whyche thynges distourbe penitence . +

Saynt Ambrose sayth . þᵗat penitence is
the pleynynge of man . for the gylt that
he hath don . ⁊and nomore to do ony thyge
for whyche hym ouȝt to playne .

¶ And
som doctour sayth . Penitence is þᵉ way-
The personys tale
mentynge of man that sorowyth for his
synne . and peyneth hymself for he hath
mysdone .

¶ Penttence wyth certen cyr-
cıı̄unstaıı̄unces is veri repentaunce of a man
that holt hymself in sorow ⁊and other pey-
ne for his gyltes :

⁊and for he shall be very
penitent . he shall fyrst bewayle synnes
that he hath don . and stedfastly purpo-
se in his hert to haue shryfte of mouth
⁊and to do satisfaccōion .

and neuer to do thy-
ge for whyche him ought more to beway-
le or to compleyne . ⁊and contynew in good
werkys / or elles his repentance maye
not auaylle . +

For as saynt Isyder sa-
